Pataca: P a t a c a "n. The Spanish dollar; -- called also patacoon.

Patache: P a t a c h e "n. A tender to a fleet  formerly used for conveying men orders or treasure.

Patacoon: P a t a c o o n "n. See Pataca.

Patagia: P a t a g i a "pl. "of Patagium

Patagium: P a t a g i u m "n. In bats  an expansion of the integument uniting the fore limb with the body and extending between the elongated fingers to form the wing; in birds the similar fold of integument uniting the fore limb with the body.

Patagium: P a t a g i u m "n. One of a pair of small vesicular organs situated at the bases of the anterior wings of lepidopterous insects. See Illust. of Butterfly.

Patagonian: P a t a g o n i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Patagonia.

Patagonian: P a t a g o n i a n "n. A native of Patagonia.

Patamar: P a t a m a r "n. A vessel resembling a grab  used in the coasting trade of Bombay and Ceylon.

Patas: P a t a s "n. A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); the red monkey.

Patavinity: P a t a v i n i t y "n. The use of local or provincial words  as in the peculiar style or diction of Livy the Roman historian; -- so called from Patavium now Padua the place of Livy's nativity.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A piece of cloth  or other suitable material sewed or otherwise fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it esp. upon an old garment to cover a hole.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A small piece of anything used to repair a breach; as  a patch on a kettle a roof etc.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A small piece of black silk stuck on the face  or neck to hide a defect or to heighten beauty.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A piece of greased cloth or leather used as wrapping for a rifle ball  to make it fit the bore.

Patch: P a t c h "n. Fig.: Anything regarded as a patch; a small piece of ground; a tract; a plot; as  scattered patches of trees or growing corn.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A block on the muzzle of a gun  to do away with the effect of dispart in sighting.

Patch: P a t c h "n. A paltry fellow; a rogue; a ninny; a fool.

Patch: P a t c h "v. t. To mend by sewing on a piece or pieces of cloth  leather or the like; as to patch a coat.

Patch: P a t c h "v. t. To mend with pieces; to repair with pieces festened on; to repair clumsily; as  to patch the roof of a house.

Patch: P a t c h "v. t. To adorn  as the face with a patch or patches.

Patch: P a t c h "v. t. To make of pieces or patches; to repair as with patches; to arrange in a hasty or clumsy manner; -- generally with up; as  to patch up a truce.

Patched: P a t c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Patch

Patcher: P a t c h e r "n. One who patches or botches.

Patchery: P a t c h e r y "n. Botchery; covering of defects; bungling; hypocrisy.

Patching: P a t c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Patch

Patchingly: P a t c h i n g l y "adv. Knavishy; deceitfully.

Patchouli: P a t c h o u l i "n. Alt. of Patchouly

Patchouly: P a t c h o u l y "n. A mintlike plant (Pogostemon Patchouli) of the East Indies  yielding an essential oil from which a highly valued perfume is made.

Patchouly: P a t c h o u l y "n. The perfume made from this plant.

Patchwork: P a t c h w o r k "n. Work composed of pieces sewed together  esp. pieces of various colors and figures; hence anything put together of incongruous or ill-adapted parts; something irregularly clumsily composed; a thing putched up.

Patchy: P a t c h y "a. Full of  or covered with patches; abounding in patches.

Pate: P a t e "a. See Patte.

Pate: P a t e "n. A pie. See Patty.

Pate: P a t e "n. A kind of platform with a parapet  usually of an oval form and generally erected in marshy grounds to cover a gate of a fortified place.

Pate: P a t e "n. The head of a person; the top  or crown of the head.

Pate: P a t e "n. The skin of a calf's head.

Pated: P a t e d "a. Having a pate; -- used only in composition; as  long-pated; shallow-pated.

Patee: P a t e e "n. See Pattee.

Patefaction: P a t e f a c t i o n "n. The act of opening  disclosing or manifesting; open declaration.

Patela: P a t e l a "n. A large flat-bottomed trading boat peculiar to the river Ganges; -- called also puteli.

Patella: P a t e l l a "n. A small dish  pan or vase.

Patella: P a t e l l a "n. The kneepan; the cap of the knee.

Patella: P a t e l l a "n. A genus of marine gastropods  including many species of limpets. The shell has the form of a flattened cone. The common European limpet (Patella vulgata) is largely used for food.

Patella: P a t e l l a "n. A kind of apothecium in lichens  which is orbicular flat and sessile and has a special rim not a part of the thallus.

Patellae: P a t e l l a e "pl. "of Patella

Patellar: P a t e l l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the patella  or kneepan.

Patelliform: P a t e l l i f o r m "a. Having the form of a patella.

Patelliform: P a t e l l i f o r m "a. Resembling a limpet of the genus Patella.

Patellula: P a t e l l u l a "n. A cuplike sucker on the feet of certain insects.

Patellulae: P a t e l l u l a e "pl. "of Patellula

Paten: P a t e n "n. A plate.

Paten: P a t e n "n. The place on which the consecrated bread is placed in the Eucharist  or on which the host is placed during the Mass. It is usually small and formed as to fit the chalice or cup as a cover.

Patena: P a t e n a "n. A paten.

Patena: P a t e n a "n. A grassy expanse in the hill region of Ceylon.

Patency: P a t e n c y "n. The condition of being open  enlarged or spread.

Patency: P a t e n c y "n. The state of being patent or evident.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. Open; expanded; evident; apparent; unconcealed; manifest; public; conspicuous.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. Open to public perusal; -- said of a document conferring some right or privilege; as  letters patent. See Letters patent under 3d Letter.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. Appropriated or protected by letters patent; secured by official authority to the exclusive possession  control and disposal of some person or party; patented; as a patent right; patent medicines.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. Spreading; forming a nearly right angle with the steam or branch; as  a patent leaf.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. A letter patent  or letters patent; an official document issued by a sovereign power conferring a right or privilege on some person or party.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. A writing securing to an invention.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. A document making a grant and conveyance of public lands.

Patent: P a t e n t "a. The right or privilege conferred by such a document; hence  figuratively a right privilege or license of the nature of a patent.

Patent: P a t e n t "v. t. To grant by patent; to make the subject of a patent; to secure or protect by patent; as  to patent an invention; to patent public lands.

Patent-hammered: P a t e n t - h a m m e r e d "a. Having a surface dressed by cutting with a hammer the head of which consists of broad thin chisels clamped together.

Patentable: P a t e n t a b l e "a. Suitable to be patented; capable of being patented.

Patented: P a t e n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Patent

Patentee: P a t e n t e e "n. One to whom a grant is made  or a privilege secured by patent.

Patenting: P a t e n t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Patent

Patently: P a t e n t l y "adv. Openly; evidently.

Patera: P a t e r a "n. A saucerlike vessel of earthenware or metal  used by the Greeks and Romans in libations and sacrificies.

Patera: P a t e r a "n. A circular ornament  resembling a dish often worked in relief on friezes and the like.

Paterae: P a t e r a e "pl. "of Patera

Paterero: P a t e r e r o "n. See Pederero.

Pateresfamilias: P a t e r e s f a m i l i a s "pl. "of Paterfamilias

Paterfamilias: P a t e r f a m i l i a s "n. The head of a family; in a large sense  the proprietor of an estate; one who is his own master.

Paternal: P a t e r n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a father; fatherly; showing the disposition of a father; guiding or instructing as a father; as  paternal care.

Paternal: P a t e r n a l "a. Received or derived from a father; hereditary; as  a paternal estate.

Paternalism: P a t e r n a l i s m "n. The theory or practice of paternal government. See Paternal government  under Paternal.

Paternally: P a t e r n a l l y "adv. In a paternal manner.

Paternity: P a t e r n i t y "n. The relation of a father to his child; fathership; fatherhood; family headship; as  the divine paternity.

Paternity: P a t e r n i t y "n. Derivation or descent from a father; male parentage; as  the paternity of a child.

Paternity: P a t e r n i t y "n. Origin; authorship.

Paternoster: P a t e r n o s t e r "n. The Lord's prayer  so called from the first two words of the Latin version.

Paternoster: P a t e r n o s t e r "n. A beadlike ornament in moldings.

Paternoster: P a t e r n o s t e r "n. A line with a row of hooks and bead/shaped sinkers.

Path: P a t h "n. A trodden way; a footway.

Path: P a t h "n. A way  course or track in which anything moves or has moved; route; passage; an established way; as the path of a meteor of a caravan of a storm of a pestilence. Also used figuratively of a course of life or action.

Path: P a t h "v. t. To make a path in  or on (something) or for (some one).

Path: P a t h "v. i. To walk or go.

Pathed: P a t h e d "imp. & p. p. of Path

Pathematic: P a t h e m a t i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating emotion or suffering.

Pathetic: P a t h e t i c "a. Expressing or showing anger; passionate.

Pathetic: P a t h e t i c "a. Affecting or moving the tender emotions  esp. pity or grief; full of pathos; as a pathetic song or story.

Pathetical: P a t h e t i c a l "a. Pathetic.

Pathetism: P a t h e t i s m "n. See Mesmerism.

Pathfinder: P a t h f i n d e r "n. One who discovers a way or path; one who explores untraversed regions.

Pathic: P a t h i c "n. A male who submits to the crime against nature; a catamite.

Pathic: P a t h i c "a. Passive; suffering.

Pathing: P a t h i n g "pr.p. & vb. n. of Path

Pathless: P a t h l e s s "a. Having no beaten path or way; untrodden; impenetrable; as  pathless woods.

Pathmaker: P a t h m a k e r "n. One who  or that which makes a way or path.

Pathogene: P a t h o g e n e "n. One of a class of virulent microorganisms or bacteria found in the tissues and fluids in infectious diseases  and supposed to be the cause of the disease; a pathogenic organism; a pathogenic bacterium; -- opposed to zymogene.

Pathogenesis: P a t h o g e n e s i s "n. Pathogeny.

Pathogenetic: P a t h o g e n e t i c "a. Pathogenic.

Pathogenic: P a t h o g e n i c "a. Of or pertaining to pathogeny; producting disease; as  a pathogenic organism; a pathogenic bacterium.

Pathogeny: P a t h o g e n y "n. The generation  and method of development of disease; as the pathogeny of yellow fever is unsettled.

Pathogeny: P a t h o g e n y "n. That branch of pathology which treats of the generation and development of disease.

Pathognomonic: P a t h o g n o m o n i c "a. Specially or decisively characteristic of a disease; indicating with certainty a disease; as  a pathognomonic symptom.

Pathognomy: P a t h o g n o m y "n. Expression of the passions; the science of the signs by which human passions are indicated.

Pathologic: P a t h o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Pathological

Pathological: P a t h o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to pathology.

Pathologies: P a t h o l o g i e s "pl. "of Pathology

Pathologist: P a t h o l o g i s t "n. One skilled in pathology; an investigator in pathology; as  the pathologist of a hospital whose duty it is to determine the causes of the diseases.

Pathology: P a t h o l o g y "n. The science which treats of diseases  their nature causes progress symptoms etc.

Pathopoela: P a t h o p o e l a "n. A speech  or figure of speech designed to move the passion.

Pathos: P a t h o s "n. That quality or property of anything which touches the feelings or excites emotions and passions  esp. that which awakens tender emotions such as pity sorrow and the like; contagious warmth of feeling action or expression; pathetic quality; as the pathos of a picture of a poem or of a cry.

Paths: P a t h s "pl. "of Path

Pathway: P a t h w a y "n. A footpath; a beaten track; any path or course. Also used figuratively.

Patible: P a t i b l e "a. Sufferable; tolerable; endurable.

Patibulary: P a t i b u l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to the gallows  or to execution.

Patibulated: P a t i b u l a t e d "a. Hanged on a gallows.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. The state or quality of being patient; the power of suffering with fortitude; uncomplaining endurance of evils or wrongs  as toil pain poverty insult oppression calamity etc.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. The act or power of calmly or contentedly waiting for something due or hoped for; forbearance.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. Constancy in labor or application; perseverance.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. Sufferance; permission.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. A kind of dock (Rumex Patientia)  less common in America than in Europe; monk's rhubarb.

Patience: P a t i e n c e "n. Solitaire.

Patient: P a t i e n t "a. Having the quality of enduring; physically able to suffer or bear.

Patient: P a t i e n t "a. Undergoing pains  trails or the like without murmuring or fretfulness; bearing up with equanimity against trouble; long-suffering.

Patient: P a t i e n t "a. Constant in pursuit or exertion; persevering; calmly diligent; as  patient endeavor.

Patient: P a t i e n t "a. Expectant with calmness  or without discontent; not hasty; not overeager; composed.

Patient: P a t i e n t "a. Forbearing; long-suffering.

Patient: P a t i e n t "n. ONe who  or that which is passively affected; a passive recipient.

Patient: P a t i e n t "n. A person under medical or surgical treatment; -- correlative to physician or nurse.

Patient: P a t i e n t "v. t. To compose  to calm.

Patiently: P a t i e n t l y "adv. In a patient manner.

Patin: P a t i n "n. Alt. of Patine

Patina: P a t i n a "n. A dish or plate of metal or earthenware; a patella.

Patina: P a t i n a "n. The color or incrustation which age gives to works of art; especially  the green rust which covers ancient bronzes coins and medals.

Patine: P a t i n e "n. A plate. See Paten.

Patio: P a t i o "n. A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted  or where ore salt mercury etc. are trampled by horses to effect intermixture and amalgamation.

Patly: P a t l y "adv. Fitly; seasonably.

Patness: P a t n e s s "n. Fitness or appropriateness; striking suitableness; convenience.

Patois: P a t o i s "n. A dialect peculiar to the illiterate classes; a provincial form of speech.

Patonce: P a t o n c e "a. Having the arms growing broader and floriated toward the end; -- said of a cross. See Illust. 9 of Cross.

Patrial: P a t r i a l "a. Derived from the name of a country  and designating an inhabitant of the country; gentile; -- said of a noun.

Patrial: P a t r i a l "n. A patrial noun. Thus Romanus  a Roman and Troas a woman of Troy are patrial nouns or patrials.

Patriarch: P a t r i a r c h "n. The father and ruler of a family; one who governs his family or descendants by paternal right; -- usually applied to heads of families in ancient history  especially in Biblical and Jewish history to those who lived before the time of Moses.

Patriarch: P a t r i a r c h "n. A dignitary superior to the order of archbishops; as  the patriarch of Constantinople of Alexandria or of Antioch.

Patriarch: P a t r i a r c h "n. A venerable old man; an elder. Also used figuratively.

Patriarchal: P a t r i a r c h a l "a. Of or pertaining to a patriarch or to patriarchs; possessed by  or subject to patriarchs; as patriarchal authority or jurisdiction; a patriarchal see; a patriarchal church.

Patriarchal: P a t r i a r c h a l "a. Characteristic of a patriarch; venerable.

Patriarchal: P a t r i a r c h a l "a. Having an organization of society and government in which the head of the family exercises authority over all its generations.

Patriarchate: P a t r i a r c h a t e "n. The office  dignity or jurisdiction of a patriarch.

Patriarchate: P a t r i a r c h a t e "n. The residence of an ecclesiastic patriarch.

Patriarchate: P a t r i a r c h a t e "n. A patriarchal form of government or society. See Patriarchal  a. 3.

Patriarchdom: P a t r i a r c h d o m "n. The office or jurisdiction of a patriarch; patriarchate.

Patriarchic: P a t r i a r c h i c "a. Patriarchal.

Patriarchism: P a t r i a r c h i s m "n. Government by a patriarch  or the head of a family.

Patriarchship: P a t r i a r c h s h i p "n. A patriarchate.

Patriarchy: P a t r i a r c h y "n. The jurisdiction of a patriarch; patriarchship.

Patriarchy: P a t r i a r c h y "n. Government by a patriarch; patriarchism.

Patrician: P a t r i c i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the Roman patres (fathers) or senators  or patricians.

Patrician: P a t r i c i a n "a. Of  pertaining to or appropriate to a person of high birth; noble; not plebeian.

Patrician: P a t r i c i a n "n. Originally  a member of any of the families constituting the populus Romanus or body of Roman citizens before the development of the plebeian order; later one who by right of birth or by special privilege conferred belonged to the nobility.

Patrician: P a t r i c i a n "n. A person of high birth; a nobleman.

Patrician: P a t r i c i a n "n. One familiar with the works of the Christian Fathers; one versed in patristic lore.

Patricianism: P a t r i c i a n i s m "n. The rank or character of patricians.

Patriciate: P a t r i c i a t e "n. The patrician class; the aristocracy; also  the office of patriarch.

Patricidal: P a t r i c i d a l "a. Of or pertaining to patricide; parricidal.

Patricide: P a t r i c i d e "n. The murderer of his father.

Patricide: P a t r i c i d e "n. The crime of one who murders his father. Same as Parricide.

Patrimonial: P a t r i m o n i a l "a. Of or pertaining to a patrimony; inherited from ancestors; as  a patrimonial estate.

Patrimonially: P a t r i m o n i a l l y "adv. By inheritance.

Patrimonies: P a t r i m o n i e s "pl. "of Patrimony

Patrimony: P a t r i m o n y "n. A right or estate inherited from one's father; or  in a larger sense from any ancestor.

Patrimony: P a t r i m o n y "n. Formerly  a church estate or endowment.

Patriot: P a t r i o t "n. One who loves his country  and zealously supports its authority and interests.

Patriot: P a t r i o t "a. Becoming to a patriot; patriotic.

Patriotic: P a t r i o t i c "a. Inspired by patriotism; actuated by love of one's country; zealously and unselfishly devoted to the service of one's country; as  a patriotic statesman vigilance.

Patriotical: P a t r i o t i c a l "a. Patriotic; that pertains to a patriot.

Patriotism: P a t r i o t i s m "n. Love of country; devotion to the welfare of one's country; the virtues and actions of a patriot; the passion which inspires one to serve one's country.

Patripassian: P a t r i p a s s i a n "n. One of a body of believers in the early church who denied the independent preexistent personality of Christ  and who accordingly held that the Father suffered in the Son; a monarchian.

Patrist: P a t r i s t "n. One versed in patristics.

Patristic: P a t r i s t i c "a. Alt. of Patristical

Patristical: P a t r i s t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the Fathers of the Christian church.

Patristics: P a t r i s t i c s "n. That departnent of historical theology which treats of the lives and doctrines of the Fathers of the church.

Patrizate: P a t r i z a t e "v. i. To imitate one's father.

Patrocinate: P a t r o c i n a t e "v. t. To support; to patronize.

Patrocination: P a t r o c i n a t i o n "n. The act of patrocinating or patronizing.

Patrociny: P a t r o c i n y "n. See Patrocination.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. i. To go the rounds along a chain of sentinels; to traverse a police district or beat.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. t To go the rounds of  as a sentry guard or policeman; as to patrol a frontier; to patrol a beat.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. i. A going of the rounds along the chain of sentinels and between the posts  by a guard usually consisting of three or four men to insure greater security from attacks on the outposts.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. i. A movement  by a small body of troops beyond the line of outposts to explore the country and gain intelligence of the enemy's whereabouts.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. i. The guard or men who go the rounds for observation; a detachment whose duty it is to patrol.

Patrol: P a t r o l "v. i. Any perambulation of a particular line or district to guard it; also  the men thus guarding; as a customs patrol; a fire patrol.

Patrole: P a t r o l e "n. & v. See Patrol  n. & v.

Patrolled: P a t r o l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Patrol

Patrolling: P a t r o l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Patrol

Patrolmen: P a t r o l m e n "pl. "of Patrolman

Patron: P a t r o n "n. One who protects  supports or countenances; a defender.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. A master who had freed his slave  but still retained some paternal rights over him.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. A man of distinction under whose protection another person placed himself.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. An advocate or pleader.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. One who encourages or helps a person  a cause or a work; a furtherer; a promoter; as a patron of art.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. One who has gift and disposition of a benefice.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. A guardian saint. -- called also patron saint.

Patron: P a t r o n "n. See Padrone  2.

Patron: P a t r o n "v. t. To be a patron of; to patronize; to favor.

Patron: P a t r o n "a. Doing the duty of a patron; giving aid or protection; tutelary.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "n. Special countenance or support; favor  encouragement or aid afforded to a person or a work; as the patronage of letters; patronage given to an author.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "n. Business custom.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "n. Guardianship  as of a saint; tutelary care.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "n. The right of nomination to political office; also  the offices contracts honors etc. which a public officer may bestow by favor.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "n. The right of presentation to church or ecclesiastical benefice; advowson.

Patronage: P a t r o n a g e "v. t. To act as a patron of; to maintain; to defend.

Patronal: P a t r o n a l "a. Patron; protecting; favoring.

Patronate: P a t r o n a t e "n. The right or duty of a patron; patronage.

Patroness: P a t r o n e s s "n. A female patron or helper.

Patronization: P a t r o n i z a t i o n "n. The act of patronizing; patronage; support.

Patronize: P a t r o n i z e "v. t. To act as patron toward; to support; to countenance; to favor; to aid.

Patronize: P a t r o n i z e "v. t. To trade with customarily; to frequent as a customer.

Patronize: P a t r o n i z e "v. t. To assume the air of a patron  or of a superior and protector toward; -- used in an unfavorable sense; as to patronize one's equals.

Patronized: P a t r o n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Patronize

Patronizer: P a t r o n i z e r "n. One who patronizes.

Patronizing: P a t r o n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Patronize

Patronizing: P a t r o n i z i n g "a. Showing condescending favor; assuming the manner of airs of a superior toward another.

Patronless: P a t r o n l e s s "a. Destitute of a patron.

Patronomayology: P a t r o n o m a y o l o g y "n. That branch of knowledge which deals with personal names and their origin; the study of patronymics.

Patronymic: P a t r o n y m i c "a. Derived from ancestors; as  a patronymic denomination.

Patronymic: P a t r o n y m i c "n. A modification of the father's name borne by the son; a name derived from that of a parent or ancestor; as  Pelides the son of Peleus; Johnson the son of John; Macdonald the son of Donald; Paulowitz the son of Paul; also the surname of a family; the family name.

Patronymical: P a t r o n y m i c a l "a. Same as Patronymic.

Patroon: P a t r o o n "n. One of the proprietors of certain tracts of land with manorial privileges and right of entail  under the old Dutch governments of New York and New Jersey.

Patroonship: P a t r o o n s h i p "n. The office of a patroon.

Patte: P a t t e "a. Alt. of Pattee

Patted: P a t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Pat

Pattee: P a t t e e "a. Narrow at the inner  and very broad at the other end or having its arms of that shape; -- said of a cross. See Illust. (8) of Cross.

Pattemar: P a t t e m a r "n. See Patamar.

Patten: P a t t e n "n. A clog or sole of wood  usually supported by an iron ring worn to raise the feet from the wet or the mud.

Patten: P a t t e n "n. A stilt.

Pattened: P a t t e n e d "a. Wearing pattens.

Patter: P a t t e r "v. i. To strike with a quick succession of slight  sharp sounds; as pattering rain or hail; pattering feet.

Patter: P a t t e r "v. i. To mutter; to mumble; as  to patter with the lips.

Patter: P a t t e r "v. i. To talk glibly; to chatter; to harangue.

Patter: P a t t e r "v. t. To spatter; to sprinkle.

Patter: P a t t e r "v. i. To mutter; as prayers.

Patter: P a t t e r "n. A quick succession of slight sounds; as  the patter of rain; the patter of little feet.

Patter: P a t t e r "n. Glib and rapid speech; a voluble harangue.

Patter: P a t t e r "n. The cant of a class; patois; as  thieves's patter; gypsies' patter.

Pattered: P a t t e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Patter

Patterer: P a t t e r e r "n. One who patters  or talks glibly; specifically a street peddler.

Pattering: P a t t e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Patter

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. Anything proposed for imitation; an archetype; an exemplar; that which is to be  or is worthy to be copied or imitated; as a pattern of a machine.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. A part showing the figure or quality of the whole; a specimen; a sample; an example; an instance.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. Stuff sufficient for a garment; as  a dress pattern.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. Figure or style of decoration; design; as  wall paper of a beautiful pattern.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. Something made after a model; a copy.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. Anything cut or formed to serve as a guide to cutting or forming objects; as  a dressmaker's pattern.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "n. A full-sized model around which a mold of sand is made  to receive the melted metal. It is usually made of wood and in several parts so as to be removed from the mold without injuring it.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "v. t. To make or design (anything) by  from or after something that serves as a pattern; to copy; to model; to imitate.

Pattern: P a t t e r n "v. t. To serve as an example for; also  to parallel.

Patterned: P a t t e r n e d "imp. & p. p. of Pattern

Patterning: P a t t e r n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pattern

Patty: P a t t y "n. A little pie.

Pattypan: P a t t y p a n "n. A pan for baking patties.

Pattypan: P a t t y p a n "n. A patty.

Patulous: P a t u l o u s "a. Open; expanded; slightly spreading; having the parts loose or dispersed; as  a patulous calyx; a patulous cluster of flowers.

Pau: P a u "n. See Pah.

Pauciloquent: P a u c i l o q u e n t "a. Uttering few words; brief in speech.

Pauciloquy: P a u c i l o q u y "n. Brevity in speech.

Paucispiral: P a u c i s p i r a l "a. Having few spirals  or whorls; as a paucispiral operculum or shell.

Paucity: P a u c i t y "n. Fewness; smallness of number; scarcity.

Paucity: P a u c i t y "n. Smallnes of quantity; exiguity; insufficiency; as  paucity of blood.

Paugie: P a u g i e "n. Alt. of Paugy

Paugies: P a u g i e s "pl. "of Paugy

Paugy: P a u g y "n. The scup. See Porgy  and Scup.

Pauhaugen: P a u h a u g e n "n. The menhaden; -- called also poghaden.

Paul: P a u l "n. See Pawl.

Paul: P a u l "n. An Italian silver coin. See Paolo.

Pauldron: P a u l d r o n "n. A piece of armor covering the shoulder at the junction of the body piece and arm piece.

Paulian: P a u l i a n "n. Alt. of Paulianist

Paulianist: P a u l i a n i s t "n. A follower of Paul of Samosata  a bishop of Antioch in the third century who was deposed for denying the divinity of Christ.

Paulician: P a u l i c i a n "n. One of a sect of Christian dualists originating in Armenia in the seventh century. They rejected the Old Testament and the part of the New.

Paulin: P a u l i n "n. See Tarpaulin.

Pauline: P a u l i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the apostle Paul  or his writings; resembling or conforming to the writings of Paul; as the Pauline epistles; Pauline doctrine.

Paulist: P a u l i s t "n. A member of The Institute of the Missionary Priests of St. Paul the Apostle  founded in 1858 by the Rev. I. T. Hecker of New York. The majority of the members were formerly Protestants.

Paulownia: P a u l o w n i a "n. A genus of trees of the order Scrophulariaceae  consisting of one species Paulownia imperialis.

Paum: P a u m "v. t. & i. To palm off by fraud; to cheat at cards.

Paunce: P a u n c e "n. The pansy.

Paunch: P a u n c h "n. The belly and its contents; the abdomen; also  the first stomach or rumen of ruminants. See Rumen.

Paunch: P a u n c h "n. A paunch mat; -- called also panch.

Paunch: P a u n c h "n. The thickened rim of a bell  struck by the clapper.

Paunch: P a u n c h "v. t. To pierce or rip the belly of; to eviscerate; to disembowel.

Paunch: P a u n c h "v. t. To stuff with food.

Paunched: P a u n c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Paunch

Paunching: P a u n c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Paunch

Paunchy: P a u n c h y "a. Pot-bellied.

Paune: P a u n e "n. A kind of bread. See Pone.

Pauper: P a u p e r "n. A poor person; especially  one development on private or public charity. Also used adjectively; as pouper immigrants pouper labor.

Pauperism: P a u p e r i s m "n. The state of being a pauper; the state of indigent persons requiring support from the community.

Pauperization: P a u p e r i z a t i o n "n. The act or process of reducing to pauperism.

Pauperize: P a u p e r i z e "v. t. To reduce to pauperism; as  to pauperize the peasantry.

Pauperized: P a u p e r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Pauperize

Pauperizing: P a u p e r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pauperize

Pauropoda: P a u r o p o d a "n. pl. An order of small myriapods having only nine pairs of legs and destitute of tracheae.

Pause: P a u s e "n. A temporary stop or rest; an intermission of action; interruption; suspension; cessation.

Pause: P a u s e "n. Temporary inaction or waiting; hesitation; suspence; doubt.

Pause: P a u s e "n. In speaking or reading aloud  a brief arrest or suspension of voice to indicate the limits and relations of sentences and their parts.

Pause: P a u s e "n. In writing and printing  a mark indicating the place and nature of an arrest of voice in reading; a punctuation point; as teach the pupil to mind the pauses.

Pause: P a u s e "n. A break or paragraph in writing.

Pause: P a u s e "n. A hold. See 4th Hold  7.

Pause: P a u s e "n. To make a short stop; to cease for a time; to intermit speaking or acting; to stop; to wait; to rest.

Pause: P a u s e "n. To be intermitted; to cease; as  the music pauses.

Pause: P a u s e "n. To hesitate; to hold back; to delay.

Pause: P a u s e "n. To stop in order to consider; hence  to consider; to reflect.

Pause: P a u s e "v. t. To cause to stop or rest; -- used reflexively.

Paused: P a u s e d "imp. & p. p. of Pause

Pauser: P a u s e r "n. One who pauses.

Pausing: P a u s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pause

Pausingly: P a u s i n g l y "adv. With pauses; haltingly.

Pauxi: P a u x i "n. A curassow (Ourax pauxi)  which in South America is often domesticated.

Pavage: P a v a g e "n. See Pavage.

Pavan: P a v a n "n. A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock.

Pave: P a v e "n. The pavement.

Pave: P a v e "v. t. To lay or cover with stone  brick or other material so as to make a firm level or convenient surface for horses carriages or persons on foot to travel on; to floor with brick stone or other solid material; as to pave a street; to pave a court.

Pave: P a v e "v. t. Fig.: To make smooth  easy and safe; to prepare as a path or way; as to pave the way to promotion; to pave the way for an enterprise.

Paved: P a v e d "imp. & p. p. of Pave

Pavement: P a v e m e n t "n. That with which anythingis paved; a floor or covering of solid material  laid so as to make a hard and convenient surface for travel; a paved road or sidewalk; a decorative interior floor of tiles or colored bricks.

Pavement: P a v e m e n t "v. t. To furnish with a pavement; to pave.

Paven: P a v e n "n. See Pavan.

Paver: P a v e r "n. One who paves; one who lays a pavement.

Pavesade: P a v e s a d e "n. A canvas screen  formerly sometimes extended along the side of a vessel in a naval engagement to conceal from the enemy the operations on board.

Pavese: P a v e s e "n. Alt. of Pavesse

Pavesse: P a v e s s e "n. Pavise.

Paviage: P a v i a g e "n. A contribution or a tax for paving streets or highways.

Pavian: P a v i a n "n. See Pavan.

Pavid: P a v i d "a. Timid; fearful.

Pavidity: P a v i d i t y "n. Timidity.

Pavier: P a v i e r "n. A paver.

Paviin: P a v i i n "n. A glucoside found in species of the genus Pavia of the Horse-chestnut family.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. A temporary movable habitation; a large tent; a marquee; esp.  a tent raised on posts.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. A single body or mass of building  contained within simple walls and a single roof whether insulated as in the park or garden of a larger edifice or united with other parts and forming an angle or central feature of a large pile.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. A flag  colors ensign or banner.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. Same as Tent (Her.)

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. That part of a brilliant which lies between the girdle and collet. See Illust. of Brilliant.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. The auricle of the ear; also  the fimbriated extremity of the Fallopian tube.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "n. A covering; a canopy; figuratively  the sky.

Pavilion: P a v i l i o n "v. t. To furnish or cover with  or shelter in a tent or tents.

Pavilioned: P a v i l i o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Pavilion

Pavilioning: P a v i l i o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pavilion

Pavin: P a v i n "n. See Pavan.

Paving: P a v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pave

Paving: P a v i n g "n. The act or process of laying a pavement  or covering some place with a pavement.

Paving: P a v i n g "n. A pavement.

Pavior: P a v i o r "n. One who paves; a paver.

Pavior: P a v i o r "n. A rammer for driving paving stones.

Pavior: P a v i o r "n. A brick or slab used for paving.

Pavise: P a v i s e "n. A large shield covering the whole body  carried by a pavisor who sometimes screened also an archer with it.

Pavisor: P a v i s o r "n. A soldier who carried a pavise.

Pavo: P a v o "n. A genus of birds  including the peacocks.

Pavo: P a v o "n. The Peacock  a constellation of the southern hemisphere.

Pavon: P a v o n "n. A small triangular flag  esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon.

Pavone: P a v o n e "n. A peacock.

Pavonian: P a v o n i a n "a. Of or pertaining to a peacock.

Pavonine: P a v o n i n e "a. Like  or pertaining to the genus Pavo.

Pavonine: P a v o n i n e "a. Characteristic of a peacock; resembling the tail of a peacock  as in colors; iridescent.

Paw: P a w "n. The foot of a quadruped having claws  as the lion dog cat etc.

Paw: P a w "n. The hand.

Paw: P a w "v. i. To draw the forefoot along the ground; to beat or scrape with the forefoot.

Paw: P a w "v. t. To pass the paw over; to stroke or handle with the paws; hence  to handle fondly or rudely.

Paw: P a w "v. t. To scrape or beat with the forefoot.

Pawed: P a w e d "imp. & p. p. of Paw

Pawing: P a w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Paw

Pawk: P a w k "n. A small lobster.

Pawky: P a w k y "a. Arch; cunning; sly.

Pawl: P a w l "n. A pivoted tongue  or sliding bolt on one part of a machine adapted to fall into notches or interdental spaces on another part as a ratchet wheel in such a manner as to permit motion in one direction and prevent it in the reverse as in a windlass; a catch click or detent. See Illust. of Ratchet Wheel.

Pawl: P a w l "v. t. To stop with a pawl; to drop the pawls off.

Pawn: P a w n "n. See Pan  the masticatory.

Pawn: P a w n "n. A man or piece of the lowest rank.

Pawn: P a w n "n. Anything delivered or deposited as security  as for the payment of money borrowed or of a debt; a pledge. See Pledge n. 1.

Pawn: P a w n "n. State of being pledged; a pledge for the fulfillment of a promise.

Pawn: P a w n "n. A stake hazarded in a wager.

Pawn: P a w n "v. t. To give or deposit in pledge  or as security for the payment of money borrowed; to put in pawn; to pledge; as to pawn one's watch.

Pawn: P a w n "v. t. To pledge for the fulfillment of a promise; to stake; to risk; to wager; to hazard.

Pawnable: P a w n a b l e "a. Capable of being pawned.

Pawnbroker: P a w n b r o k e r "n. One who makes a business of lending money on the security of personal property pledged or deposited in his keeping.

Pawnbroking: P a w n b r o k i n g "n. The business of a pawnbroker.

Pawned: P a w n e d "imp. & p. p. of Pawn

Pawnee: P a w n e e "n. One or two whom a pledge is delivered as security; one who takes anything in pawn.

Pawnees: P a w n e e s "n. pl. A tribe of Indians (called also Loups) who formerly occupied the region of the Platte river  but now live mostly in the Indian Territory. The term is often used in a wider sense to include also the related tribes of Rickarees and Wichitas. Called also Pani.

Pawner: P a w n e r "n. Alt. of Pawnor

Pawning: P a w n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pawn

Pawnor: P a w n o r "n. One who pawns or pledges anything as security for the payment of borrowed money or of a debt.

Pawpaw: P a w p a w "n. See Papaw.

Pax: P a x "n. The kiss of peace; also  the embrace in the sanctuary now substituted for it at High Mass in Roman Catholic churches.

Pax: P a x "n. A tablet or board  on which is a representation of Christ of the Virgin Mary or of some saint and which in the Mass was kissed by the priest and then by the people in mediaeval times; an osculatory. It is still used in communities confraternities etc.

Paxilli: P a x i l l i "pl. "of Paxillus

Paxillose: P a x i l l o s e "a. Resembling a little stake.

Paxillus: P a x i l l u s "n. One of a peculiar kind of spines covering the surface of certain starfishes. They are pillarlike  with a flattened summit which is covered with minute spinules or granules. See Illustration in Appendix.

Paxwax: P a x w a x "n. The strong ligament of the back of the neck in quadrupeds. It connects the back of the skull with dorsal spines of the cervical vertebrae  and helps to support the head. Called also paxywaxy and packwax.

Paxywaxy: P a x y w a x y "n. See Paxwax.

Pay: P a y "v. t. To cover  as bottom of a vessel a seam a spar etc. with tar or pitch or waterproof composition of tallow resin etc.; to smear.

Pay: P a y "v. t. To satisfy  or content; specifically to satisfy (another person) for service rendered property delivered etc.; to discharge one's obligation to; to make due return to; to compensate; to remunerate; to recompense; to requite; as to pay workmen or servants.

Pay: P a y "v. t. Hence  figuratively: To compensate justly; to requite according to merit; to reward; to punish; to retort or retaliate upon.

Pay: P a y "v. t. To discharge  as a debt demand or obligation by giving or doing what is due or required; to deliver the amount or value of to the person to whom it is owing; to discharge a debt by delivering (money owed).

Pay: P a y "v. t. To discharge or fulfill  as a duy; to perform or render duty as that which has been promised.

Pay: P a y "v. t. To give or offer  without an implied obligation; as to pay attention; to pay a visit.

Pay: P a y "v. i. To give a recompense; to make payment  requital or satisfaction; to discharge a debt.

Pay: P a y "v. i. Hence  to make or secure suitable return for expense or trouble; to be remunerative or profitable; to be worth the effort or pains required; as it will pay to ride; it will pay to wait; politeness always pays.

Pay: P a y "n. Satisfaction; content.

Pay: P a y "n. An equivalent or return for money due  goods purchased or services performed; salary or wages for work or service; compensation; recompense; payment; hire; as the pay of a clerk; the pay of a soldier.

Payable: P a y a b l e "a. That may  can or should be paid; suitable to be paid; justly due.

Payable: P a y a b l e "a. That may be discharged or settled by delivery of value.

Payable: P a y a b l e "a. Matured; now due.

Payee: P a y e e "n. The person to whom money is to be  or has been paid; the person named in a bill or note to whom or to whose order the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange under Bill.

Payen: P a y e n "n. & a. Pagan.

Payer: P a y e r "n. One who pays; specifically  the person by whom a bill or note has been or should be paid.

Paying: P a y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pay

Paymaster: P a y m a s t e r "n. One who pays; one who compensates  rewards or requites; specifically an officer or agent of a government a corporation or an employer whose duty it is to pay salaries wages etc. and keep account of the same.

Payment: P a y m e n t "n. The act of paying  or giving compensation; the discharge of a debt or an obligation.

Payment: P a y m e n t "n. That which is paid; the thing given in discharge of a debt  or an obligation or in fulfillment of a promise; reward; recompense; requital; return.

Payment: P a y m e n t "n. Punishment; chastisement.

Payn: P a y n "n. Bread. Having

Payndemain: P a y n d e m a i n "n. The finest and whitest bread made in the Middle Ages; -- called also paynemain  payman.

Paynim: P a y n i m "n. & a. See Painim.

Paynize: P a y n i z e "v. t. To treat or preserve  as wood by a process resembling kyanizing.

Payor: P a y o r "n. See Payer.

Payse: P a y s e "v. t. To poise.

Paytine: P a y t i n e "n. An alkaloid obtained from a white bark resembling that of the cinchona  first brought from Payta in Peru.

Pea: P e a "n. The sliding weight on a steelyard.

Pea: P e a "n. See Peak  n. 3.

Pea: P e a "n. A plant  and its fruit of the genus Pisum of many varieties much cultivated for food. It has a papilionaceous flower and the pericarp is a legume popularly called a pod.

Pea: P e a "n. A name given  especially in the Southern States to the seed of several leguminous plants (species of Dolichos Cicer Abrus etc.) esp. those having a scar (hilum) of a different color from the rest of the seed.

Pea-jacket: P e a - j a c k e t "n. A thick loose woolen jacket  or coat much worn by sailors in cold weather.

Peabird: P e a b i r d "n. The wryneck; -- so called from its note.

Peabody bird: P e a b o d y   b i r d " An American sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis) having a conspicuous white throat. The name is imitative of its note. Called also White-throated sparrow.

Peace: P e a c e "v. A state of quiet or tranquillity; freedom from disturbance or agitation; calm; repose

Peace: P e a c e "v. Exemption from  or cessation of war with public enemies.

Peace: P e a c e "v. Public quiet  order and contentment in obedience to law.

Peace: P e a c e "v. Exemption from  or subjection of agitating passions; tranquillity of mind or conscience.

Peace: P e a c e "v. Reconciliation; agreement after variance; harmony; concord.

Peace: P e a c e "v. t. & i. To make or become quiet; to be silent; to stop.

Peaceable: P e a c e a b l e "a. Begin in or at peace; tranquil; quiet; free from  or not disposed to war disorder or excitement; not quarrelsome.

Peacebreaker: P e a c e b r e a k e r "n. One who disturbs the public peace.

Peaceful: P e a c e f u l "a. Possessing or enjoying peace; not disturbed by war  tumult agitation anxiety or commotion; quiet; tranquil; as a peaceful time; a peaceful country; a peaceful end.

Peaceful: P e a c e f u l "a. Not disposed or tending to war  tumult or agitation; pacific; mild; calm; peaceable; as peaceful words.

Peaceless: P e a c e l e s s "a. Without peace; disturbed.

Peacemaker: P e a c e m a k e r "n. One who makes peace by reconciling parties that are at variance.

Peach: P e a c h "v. t. To accuse of crime; to inform against.

Peach: P e a c h "v. i. To turn informer; to betray one's accomplice.

Peach: P e a c h "n. A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit  containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or stone; also the tree which bears it (Prunus / Amygdalus Persica). In the wild stock the fruit is hard and inedible.

Peach-colored: P e a c h - c o l o r e d "a. Of the color of a peach blossom.

Peacher: P e a c h e r "n. One who peaches.

Peachick: P e a c h i c k "n. The chicken of the peacock.

Peachy: P e a c h y "a. Resembling a peach or peaches.

Peacock: P e a c o c k "n. The male of any pheasant of the genus Pavo  of which at least two species are known native of Southern Asia and the East Indies.

Peacock: P e a c o c k "n. In common usage  the species in general or collectively; a peafowl.

Peafowl: P e a f o w l "n. The peacock or peahen; any species of Pavo.

Peage: P e a g e "n. See Paage.

Peagrit: P e a g r i t "n. A coarse pisolitic limestone. See Pisolite.

Peahen: P e a h e n "n. The hen or female peafowl.

Peak: P e a k "n. A point; the sharp end or top of anything that terminates in a point; as  the peak or front of a cap.

Peak: P e a k "n. The top  or one of the tops of a hill mountain or range ending in a point; often the whole hill or mountain esp. when isolated; as the Peak of Teneriffe.

Peak: P e a k "n. The upper aftermost corner of a fore-and-aft sail; -- used in many combinations; as  peak-halyards peak-brails etc.

Peak: P e a k "n. The narrow part of a vessel's bow  or the hold within it.

Peak: P e a k "n. The extremity of an anchor fluke; the bill.

Peak: P e a k "v. i. To rise or extend into a peak or point; to form  or appear as a peak.

Peak: P e a k "v. i. To acquire sharpness of figure or features; hence  to look thin or sicky.

Peak: P e a k "v. i. To pry; to peep slyly.

Peak: P e a k "v. t. To raise to a position perpendicular  or more nearly so; as to peak oars to hold them upright; to peak a gaff or yard to set it nearer the perpendicular.

Peaked: P e a k e d "imp. & p. p. of Peak

Peaked: P e a k e d "a. Pointed; ending in a point; as  a peaked roof.

Peaked: P e a k e d "a. Sickly; not robust.

Peaking: P e a k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peak

Peaking: P e a k i n g "a. Mean; sneaking.

Peaking: P e a k i n g "a. Pining; sickly; peakish.

Peakish: P e a k i s h "a. Of or relating to a peak; or to peaks; belonging to a mountainous region.

Peakish: P e a k i s h "a. Having peaks; peaked.

Peakish: P e a k i s h "a. Having features thin or sharp  as from sickness; hence sickly.

Peaky: P e a k y "a. Having a peak or peaks.

Peaky: P e a k y "a. Sickly; peaked.

Peal: P e a l "n. A small salmon; a grilse; a sewin.

Peal: P e a l "v. i. To appeal.

Peal: P e a l "n. A loud sound  or a succession of loud sounds as of bells thunder cannon shouts of a multitude etc.

Peal: P e a l "n. A set of bells tuned to each other according to the diatonic scale; also  the changes rung on a set of bells.

Peal: P e a l "v. i. To utter or give out loud sounds.

Peal: P e a l "v. i. To resound; to echo.

Peal: P e a l "v. t. To assail with noise or loud sounds.

Pealed: P e a l e d "imp. & p. p. of Peal
