Pean: P e a n "n. One of the furs  the ground being sable and the spots or tufts or.

Pean: P e a n "n. A song of praise and triumph. See Paean.

Peanism: P e a n i s m "n. The song or shout of praise  of battle or of triumph.

Peanut: P e a n u t "n. The fruit of a trailing leguminous plant (Arachis hypogaea); also  the plant itself which is widely cultivated for its fruit.

Pear: P e a r "n. The fleshy pome  or fruit of a rosaceous tree (Pyrus communis) cultivated in many varieties in temperate climates; also the tree which bears this fruit. See Pear family below.

Pear-shaped: P e a r - s h a p e d "a. Of the form of a pear.

Pearch: P e a r c h "n. See Perch.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A fringe or border.

Pearl: P e a r l "v. t. "To fringe; to border.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A shelly concretion  usually rounded and having a brilliant luster with varying tints found in the mantle or between the mantle and shell of certain bivalve mollusks especially in the pearl oysters and river mussels and sometimes in certain univalves. It is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some irritating foreign particle. Its substance is the same as nacre or mother-of-pearl. Pearls which are round or nearly round and of fine luster

Pearl: P e a r l "n. Hence  figuratively something resembling a pearl; something very precious.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. Nacre  or mother-of-pearl.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A fish allied to the turbot; the brill.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A light-colored tern.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. One of the circle of tubercles which form the bur on a deer's antler.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A whitish speck or film on the eye.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A capsule of gelatin or similar substance containing some liquid for medicinal application  as ether.

Pearl: P e a r l "n. A size of type  between agate and diamond.

Pearl: P e a r l "a. Of or pertaining to pearl or pearls; made of pearls  or of mother-of-pearl.

Pearl: P e a r l "v. t. To set or adorn with pearls  or with mother-of-pearl. Used also figuratively.

Pearl: P e a r l "v. t. To cause to resemble pearls; to make into small round grains; as  to pearl barley.

Pearl: P e a r l "v. i. To resemble pearl or pearls.

Pearl: P e a r l "v. i. To give or hunt for pearls; as  to go pearling.

Pearl-eyed: P e a r l - e y e d "a. Having a pearly speck in the eye; afflicted with the cataract.

Pearlaceous: P e a r l a c e o u s "a. Resembling pearl or mother-of-pearl; pearly in quality or appearance.

Pearlash: P e a r l a s h "n. A white amorphous or granular substance which consists principally of potassium carbonate  and has a strong alkaline reaction. It is obtained by lixiviating wood ashes and evaporating the lye and has been an important source of potassium compounds. It is used in making soap glass etc.

Pearlfish: P e a r l f i s h "n. Any fish whose scales yield a pearl-like pigment used in manufacturing artificial pearls  as the bleak and whitebait.

Pearlings: P e a r l i n g s "n. pl. A kind of lace of silk or thread.

Pearlins: P e a r l i n s "n. pl. Alt. of Pearlings

Pearlite: P e a r l i t e "n. Alt. of Pearlstone

Pearlstone: P e a r l s t o n e "n. A glassy volcanic rock of a grayish color and pearly luster  often having a spherulitic concretionary structure due to the curved cracks produced by contraction in cooling. See Illust. under Perlitic.

Pearlwort: P e a r l w o r t "n. A name given to several species of Sagina  low and inconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family.

Pearly: P e a r l y "a. Containing pearls; abounding with  or yielding pearls; as pearly shells.

Pearly: P e a r l y "a. Resembling pearl or pearls; clear; pure; transparent; iridescent; as  the pearly dew or flood.

Pearmain: P e a r m a i n "n. The name of several kinds of apples; as  the blue pearmain winter pearmain and red pearmain.

Peart: P e a r t "a. Active; lively; brisk; smart; -- often applied to convalescents; as  she is quite peart to-day.

Peas: P e a s "pl. "of Pea

Peasant: P e a s a n t "n. A countryman; a rustic; especially  one of the lowest class of tillers of the soil in European countries.

Peasant: P e a s a n t "a. Rustic  rural.

Peasantlike: P e a s a n t l i k e "a. Rude; clownish; illiterate.

Peasantly: P e a s a n t l y "a. Peasantlike.

Peasantry: P e a s a n t r y "n. Peasants  collectively; the body of rustics.

Peasantry: P e a s a n t r y "n. Rusticity; coarseness.

Peascod: P e a s c o d "n. The legume or pericarp  or the pod of the pea.

Pease: P e a s e "pl. "of Pea

Pease: P e a s e "n. A pea.

Pease: P e a s e "n. A plural form of Pea. See the Note under Pea.

Peasen: P e a s e n "pl. "of Pease

Peases: P e a s e s "pl. "of Pease

Peastone: P e a s t o n e "n. Pisolite.

Peasweep: P e a s w e e p "n. The pewit  or lapwing.

Peasweep: P e a s w e e p "n. The greenfinch.

Peat: P e a t "n. A small person; a pet; -- sometimes used contemptuously.

Peat: P e a t "n. A substance of vegetable origin  consisting of roots and fibers moss etc. in various stages of decomposition and found as a kind of turf or bog usually in low situations where it is always more or less saturated with water. It is often dried and used for fuel.

Peaty: P e a t y "a. Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat.

Peba: P e b a "n. An armadillo (Tatusia novemcincta) which is found from Texas to Paraguay; -- called also tatouhou.

Pebble: P e b b l e "n. A small roundish stone or bowlder; especially  a stone worn and rounded by the action of water; a pebblestone.

Pebble: P e b b l e "n. Transparent and colorless rock crystal; as  Brazilian pebble; -- so called by opticians.

Pebble: P e b b l e "v. t. To grain (leather) so as to produce a surface covered with small rounded prominences.

Pebbled: P e b b l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pebble

Pebbled: P e b b l e d "a. Abounding in pebbles.

Pebblestone: P e b b l e s t o n e " A pebble; also  pebbles collectively.

Pebbling: P e b b l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pebble

Pebbly: P e b b l y "a. Full of pebbles; pebbled.

Pebrine: P e b r i n e "n. An epidemic disease of the silkworm  characterized by the presence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood.

Pecan: P e c a n "n. A species of hickory (Carya olivaeformis)  growing in North America chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also its fruit a smooth oblong nut an inch or an inch and a half long with a thin shell and well-flavored meat.

Pecary: P e c a r y "n. See Peccary.

Peccability: P e c c a b i l i t y "n. The state or quality of being peccable; lability to sin.

Peccable: P e c c a b l e "a. Liable to sin; subject to transgress the divine law.

Peccadillo: P e c c a d i l l o "n. A slight trespass or offense; a petty crime or fault.

Peccadillos: P e c c a d i l l o s "pl. "of Peccadillo

Peccancy: P e c c a n c y "n. The quality or state of being peccant.

Peccancy: P e c c a n c y "n. A sin; an offense.

Peccant: P e c c a n t "a. Sinning; guilty of transgression; criminal; as  peccant angels.

Peccant: P e c c a n t "a. Morbid; corrupt; as  peccant humors.

Peccant: P e c c a n t "a. Wrong; defective; faulty.

Peccant: P e c c a n t "n. An offender.

Peccantly: P e c c a n t l y "adv. In a peccant manner.

Peccaries: P e c c a r i e s "pl. "of Peccary

Peccary: P e c c a r y "n. A pachyderm of the genus Dicotyles.

Peccavi: P e c c a v i " I have sinned; -- used colloquially to express confession or acknowledgment of an offense.

Pecco: P e c c o "n. See Pekoe.

Peck: P e c k "n. The fourth part of a bushel; a dry measure of eight quarts; as  a peck of wheat.

Peck: P e c k "n. A great deal; a large or excessive quantity.

Peck: P e c k "v. To strike with the beak; to thrust the beak into; as  a bird pecks a tree.

Peck: P e c k "v. Hence: To strike  pick thrust against or dig into with a pointed instrument; especially to strike pick etc. with repeated quick movements.

Peck: P e c k "v. To seize and pick up with the beak  or as with the beak; to bite; to eat; -- often with up.

Peck: P e c k "v. To make  by striking with the beak or a pointed instrument; as to peck a hole in a tree.

Peck: P e c k "v. i. To make strokes with the beak  or with a pointed instrument.

Peck: P e c k "v. i. To pick up food with the beak; hence  to eat.

Peck: P e c k "n. A quick  sharp stroke as with the beak of a bird or a pointed instrument.

Pecked: P e c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Peck

Pecker: P e c k e r "n. One who  or that which pecks; specif. a bird that pecks holes in trees; a woodpecker.

Pecker: P e c k e r "n. An instrument for pecking; a pick.

Pecking: P e c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peck

Peckish: P e c k i s h "a. Inclined to eat; hungry.

Peckled: P e c k l e d "a. Speckled; spotted.

Pecopteris: P e c o p t e r i s "n. An extensive genus of fossil ferns; -- so named from the regular comblike arrangement of the leaflets.

Pecora: P e c o r a "n. pl. An extensive division of ruminants  including the antelopes deer and cattle.

Pectate: P e c t a t e "n. A salt of pectic acid.

Pecten: P e c t e n "n. A vascular pigmented membrane projecting into the vitreous humor within the globe of the eye in birds  and in many reptiles and fishes; -- also called marsupium.

Pecten: P e c t e n "n. The pubic bone.

Pecten: P e c t e n "n. Any species of bivalve mollusks of the genus Pecten  and numerous allied genera (family Pectinidae); a scallop. See Scallop.

Pecten: P e c t e n "n. The comb of a scorpion. See Comb  4 (b).

Pectic: P e c t i c "a. Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically  designating an acid obtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphous substance tough and horny when dry but gelatinous when moist.

Pectin: P e c t i n "n. One of a series of carbohydrates  commonly called vegetable jelly found very widely distributed in the vegetable kingdom especially in ripe fleshy fruits as apples cranberries etc. It is extracted as variously colored translucent substances which are soluble in hot water but become viscous on cooling.

Pectinal: P e c t i n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a comb; resembling a comb.

Pectinal: P e c t i n a l "n. A fish whose bone/ resemble comb teeth.

Pectinate: P e c t i n a t e "a. Alt. of Pectinated

Pectinated: P e c t i n a t e d "a. Resembling the teeth of a comb.

Pectinated: P e c t i n a t e d "a. Having very narrow  close divisions in arrangement and regularity resembling those of a comb; comblike; as a pectinate leaf; pectinated muscles. See Illust. (e) of Antennae.

Pectinated: P e c t i n a t e d "a. Interlaced  like two combs.

Pectinately: P e c t i n a t e l y "adv. In a pectinate manner.

Pectination: P e c t i n a t i o n "n. The state of being pectinated; that which is pectinated.

Pectination: P e c t i n a t i o n "n. The act of combing; the combing of the head.

Pectination: P e c t i n a t i o n "n. Comblike toothing.

Pectineal: P e c t i n e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the pecten.

Pectineal: P e c t i n e a l "a. Relating to  or connected with the pubic bone.

Pectinibranch: P e c t i n i b r a n c h "n. One of the Pectinibranchiata. Also used adjectively.

Pectinibranchiata: P e c t i n i b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. A division of Gastropoda  including those that have a comblike gill upon the neck.

Pectinibranchiate: P e c t i n i b r a n c h i a t e "a. Having pectinated gills.

Pectiniform: P e c t i n i f o r m "a. Comblike in form.

Pectize: P e c t i z e "v. i. To congeal; to change into a gelatinous mass.

Pectolite: P e c t o l i t e "n. A whitish mineral occurring in radiated or fibrous crystalline masses. It is a hydrous silicate of lime and soda.

Pectora: P e c t o r a "pl. "of Pectus

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "a. Of or pertaining to the breast  or chest; as the pectoral muscles.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "a. Relating to  or good for diseases of the chest or lungs; as a pectoral remedy.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "a. Having the breast conspicuously colored; as  the pectoral sandpiper.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "n. A covering or protecting for the breast.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "n. A breastplate  esp. that worn by the Jewish high person.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "n. A clasp or a cross worn on the breast.

Pectoral: P e c t o r a l "n. A medicine for diseases of the chest organs  especially the lungs.

Pectorally: P e c t o r a l l y "adv. As connected with the breast.

Pectoriloquial: P e c t o r i l o q u i a l "a. Pertaining to  or of the nature of pectoriloquy.

Pectoriloquism: P e c t o r i l o q u i s m "n. Pectoriloquy.

Pectoriloquous: P e c t o r i l o q u o u s "a. Pectoriloquial.

Pectoriloquy: P e c t o r i l o q u y "n. The distinct articulation of the sounds of a patient's voice  heard on applying the ear to the chest in auscultation. It usually indicates some morbid change in the lungs or pleural cavity.

Pectose: P e c t o s e "n. An amorphous carbohydrate found in the vegetable kingdom  esp. in unripe fruits. It is associated with cellulose and is converted into substances of the pectin group.

Pectosic: P e c t o s i c "a. Of  pertaining to resembling or derived from pectose; specifically designating an acid supposed to constitute largely ordinary pectin or vegetable jelly.

Pectostraca: P e c t o s t r a c a "n. pl. A degenerate order of Crustacea  including the Rhizocephala and Cirripedia.

Pectous: P e c t o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or consisting of pectose.

Pectus: P e c t u s "n. The breast of a bird.

Pecul: P e c u l "n. See Picul.

Pecularized: P e c u l a r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Peculiarize

Pecularizing: P e c u l a r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peculiarize

Peculate: P e c u l a t e "v. i. To appropriate to one's own use the property of the public; to steal public moneys intrusted to one's care; to embezzle.

Peculated: P e c u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Peculate

Peculating: P e c u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peculate

Peculation: P e c u l a t i o n "n. The act or practice of peculating  or of defrauding the public by appropriating to one's own use the money or goods intrusted to one's care for management or disbursement; embezzlement.

Peculator: P e c u l a t o r "n. One who peculates.

Peculiar: P e c u l i a r "a. One's own; belonging solely or especially to an individual; not possessed by others; of private  personal or characteristic possession and use; not owned in common or in participation.

Peculiar: P e c u l i a r "a. Particular; individual; special; appropriate.

Peculiar: P e c u l i a r "a. Unusual; singular; rare; strange; as  the sky had a peculiarappearance.

Peculiar: P e c u l i a r "n. That which is peculiar; a sole or exclusive property; a prerogative; a characteristic.

Peculiar: P e c u l i a r "n. A particular parish or church which is exempt from the jurisdiction of the ordinary.

Peculiarities: P e c u l i a r i t i e s "pl. "of Peculiarity

Peculiarity: P e c u l i a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being peculiar; individuality; singularity.

Peculiarity: P e c u l i a r i t y "n. That which is peculiar; a special and distinctive characteristic or habit; particularity.

Peculiarity: P e c u l i a r i t y "n. Exclusive possession or right.

Peculiarize: P e c u l i a r i z e "v. t. To make peculiar; to set appart or assign  as an exclusive possession.

Peculiarly: P e c u l i a r l y "adv. In a peculiar manner; particulary; in a rare and striking degree; unusually.

Peculiarness: P e c u l i a r n e s s "n. The quality or state of being peculiar; peculiarity.

Peculium: P e c u l i u m "n. The saving of a son or a slave with the father's or master's consent; a little property or stock of one's own; any exclusive personal or separate property.

Peculium: P e c u l i u m "n. A special fund for private and personal uses.

Pecunial: P e c u n i a l "a. Pecuniary.

Pecuniarily: P e c u n i a r i l y "adv. In a pecuniary manner; as regards money.

Pecuniary: P e c u n i a r y "a. Relating to money; monetary; as  a pecuniary penalty; a pecuniary reward.

Pecunious: P e c u n i o u s "a. Abounding in money; wealthy; rich.

Ped: P e d "n. A basket; a hammer; a pannier.

Pedage: P e d a g e "n. A toll or tax paid by passengers  entitling them to safe-conduct and protection.

Pedagog: P e d a g o g "n. Pedagogue.

Pedagogic: P e d a g o g i c "a. See Pedagogics.

Pedagogic: P e d a g o g i c "a. Alt. of Pedagogical

Pedagogical: P e d a g o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pedagogue; suited to  or characteristic of a pedagogue.

Pedagogics: P e d a g o g i c s "n. The science or art of teaching; the principles and rules of teaching; pedagogy.

Pedagogism: P e d a g o g i s m "n. The system  occupation character or manner of pedagogues.

Pedagogue: P e d a g o g u e "n. A slave who led his master's children to school  and had the charge of them generally.

Pedagogue: P e d a g o g u e "n. A teacher of children; one whose occupation is to teach the young; a schoolmaster.

Pedagogue: P e d a g o g u e "n. One who by teaching has become formal  positive or pedantic in his ways; one who has the manner of a schoolmaster; a pedant.

Pedagogue: P e d a g o g u e "v. t. To play the pedagogue toward.

Pedagogy: P e d a g o g y "n. Pedagogics; pedagogism.

Pedal: P e d a l "a. Of or pertaining to the foot  or to feet literally or figuratively; specifically (Zool.) pertaining to the foot of a mollusk; as the pedal ganglion.

Pedal: P e d a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pedal; having pedals.

Pedal: P e d a l "a. A lever or key acted on by the foot  as in the pianoforte to raise the dampers or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a treadle as in a lathe or a bicycle.

Pedal: P e d a l "a. A pedal curve or surface.

Pedalian: P e d a l i a n "a. Relating to the foot  or to a metrical foot; pedal.

Pedality: P e d a l i t y "n. The act of measuring by paces.

Pedaneous: P e d a n e o u s "a. Going on foot; pedestrian.

Pedant: P e d a n t "n. A schoolmaster; a pedagogue.

Pedant: P e d a n t "n. One who puts on an air of learning; one who makes a vain display of learning; a pretender to superior knowledge.

Pedantic: P e d a n t i c "a. Alt. of Pedantical

Pedantical: P e d a n t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pedant; characteristic of  or resembling a pedant; ostentatious of learning; as a pedantic writer; a pedantic description; a pedantical affectation.

Pedantically: P e d a n t i c a l l y "adv. In a pedantic manner.

Pedanticly: P e d a n t i c l y "adv. Pedantically.

Pedantism: P e d a n t i s m "n. The office  disposition or act of a pedant; pedantry.

Pedantize: P e d a n t i z e "v. i. To play the pedant; to use pedantic expressions.

Pedantocracy: P e d a n t o c r a c y "n. The sway of pedants.

Pedantry: P e d a n t r y "n. The act  character or manners of a pedant; vain ostentation of learning.

Pedanty: P e d a n t y "n. An assembly or clique of pedants.

Pedarian: P e d a r i a n "n. One of a class eligible to the office of senator  but not yet chosen who could sit and speak in the senate but could not vote; -- so called because he might indicate his opinion by walking over to the side of the party he favored when a vote was taken.

Pedaries: P e d a r i e s "pl. "of Pedary

Pedary: P e d a r y "n. A sandal.

Pedata: P e d a t a "n. pl. An order of holothurians  including those that have ambulacral suckers or feet and an internal gill.

Pedate: P e d a t e "a. Palmate  with the lateral lobes cleft into two or more segments; -- said of a leaf.

Pedatifid: P e d a t i f i d "a. Cleft in a pedate manner  but having the lobes distinctly connected at the base; -- said of a leaf.

Peddle: P e d d l e "v. i. To travel about with wares for sale; to go from place to place  or from house to house for the purpose of retailing goods; as to peddle without a license.

Peddle: P e d d l e "v. i. To do a small business; to be busy about trifles; to piddle.

Peddle: P e d d l e "v. t. To sell from place to place; to retail by carrying around from customer to customer; to hawk; hence  to retail in very small quantities; as to peddle vegetables or tinware.

Peddled: P e d d l e d "imp. & p. p. of Peddle

Peddler: P e d d l e r "n. One who peddles; a traveling trader; one who travels about  retailing small wares; a hawker.

Peddlery: P e d d l e r y "n. The trade  or the goods of a peddler; hawking; small retail business like that of a peddler.

Peddlery: P e d d l e r y "n. Trifling; trickery.

Peddling: P e d d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peddle

Peddling: P e d d l i n g "a. Hawking; acting as a peddler.

Peddling: P e d d l i n g "a. Petty; insignificant.

Pederast: P e d e r a s t "n. One guilty of pederasty; a sodomite.

Pederastic: P e d e r a s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to pederasty.

Pederasty: P e d e r a s t y "n. The crime against nature; sodomy.

Pederero: P e d e r e r o "n. A term formerly applied to a short piece of chambered ordnance.

Pedes: P e d e s "pl. "of Pes

Pedesis: P e d e s i s "n. Same as Brownian movement  under Brownian.

Pedestal: P e d e s t a l "n. The base or foot of a column  statue vase lamp or the like; the part on which an upright work stands. It consists of three parts the base the die or dado and the cornice or surbase molding. See Illust. of Column.

Pedestal: P e d e s t a l "n. A casting secured to the frame of a truck and forming a jaw for holding a journal box.

Pedestal: P e d e s t a l "n. A pillow block; a low housing.

Pedestal: P e d e s t a l "n. An iron socket  or support for the foot of a brace at the end of a truss where it rests on a pier.

Pedestaled: P e d e s t a l e d "a. Placed on  or supported by a pedestal; figuratively exalted.

Pedestrial: P e d e s t r i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the feet; employing the foot or feet.

Pedestrially: P e d e s t r i a l l y "adv. In a pedestrial manner.

Pedestrian: P e d e s t r i a n "a. Going on foot; performed on foot; as  a pedestrian journey.

Pedestrian: P e d e s t r i a n "n. A walker; one who journeys on foot; a foot traveler; specif.  a professional walker or runner.

Pedestrianism: P e d e s t r i a n i s m "n. The act  art or practice of a pedestrian; walking or running; traveling or racing on foot.

Pedestrianize: P e d e s t r i a n i z e "v. i. To practice walking; to travel on foot.

Pedestrianized: P e d e s t r i a n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Pedestrianize

Pedestrianizing: P e d e s t r i a n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pedestrianize

Pedestrious: P e d e s t r i o u s "a. Going on foot; not winged.

Pedetentous: P e d e t e n t o u s "a. Proceeding step by step; advancing cautiously.

Pedi-: P e d i - " Alt. of Pedo-

Pedial: P e d i a l "a. Pertaining to the foot  or to any organ called a foot; pedal.

Pedicel: P e d i c e l "n. A stalk which supports one flower or fruit  whether solitary or one of many ultimate divisions of a common peduncle. See Peduncle and Illust. of Flower.

Pedicel: P e d i c e l "n. A slender support of any special organ  as that of a capsule in mosses an air vesicle in algae or a sporangium in ferns.

Pedicel: P e d i c e l "n. A slender stem by which certain of the lower animals or their eggs are attached. See Illust. of Aphis lion.

Pedicel: P e d i c e l "n. The ventral part of each side of the neural arch connecting with the centrum of a vertebra.

Pedicel: P e d i c e l "n. An outgrowth of the frontal bones  which supports the antlers or horns in deer and allied animals.

Pediceled: P e d i c e l e d "a. Pedicellate.

Pedicellaria: P e d i c e l l a r i a "n. A peculiar forcepslike organ which occurs in large numbers upon starfishes and echini. Those of starfishes have two movable jaws  or blades and are usually nearly or quite sessile; those of echini usually have three jaws and a pedicel. See Illustration in Appendix.

Pedicellariae: P e d i c e l l a r i a e "pl. "of Pedicellaria

Pedicellate: P e d i c e l l a t e "a. Having a pedicel; supported by a pedicel.

Pedicellina: P e d i c e l l i n a "n. A genus of Bryozoa  of the order Entoprocta having a bell-shaped body supported on a slender pedicel. See Illust. under Entoprocta.

Pedicle: P e d i c l e "n. Same as Pedicel.

Pedicular: P e d i c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to lice; having the lousy distemper (phthiriasis); lousy.

Pediculate: P e d i c u l a t e "a. Of or pertaining to the Pediculati.

Pediculati: P e d i c u l a t i "n. pl. An order of fishes including the anglers. See Illust. of Angler and Batfish.

Pediculation: P e d i c u l a t i o n "n. Phthiriasis.

Pedicule: P e d i c u l e "n. A pedicel.

Pediculi: P e d i c u l i "pl. "of Pediculus

Pediculina: P e d i c u l i n a "n. pl. A division of parasitic hemipterous insects  including the true lice. See Illust. in Appendix.

Pediculous: P e d i c u l o u s "a. Pedicular.

Pediculus: P e d i c u l u s "n. A genus of wingless parasitic Hemiptera  including the common lice of man. See Louse.

Pediform: P e d i f o r m "a. Shaped like a foot.

Pedigerous: P e d i g e r o u s "a. Bearing or having feet or legs.

Pedigree: P e d i g r e e "n. A line of ancestors; descent; lineage; genealogy; a register or record of a line of ancestors.

Pedigree: P e d i g r e e "n. A record of the lineage or strain of an animal  as of a horse.

Pediluvy: P e d i l u v y "n. The bathing of the feet  a bath for the feet.

Pedimana: P e d i m a n a "n. pl. A division of marsupials  including the opossums.

Pedimane: P e d i m a n e "n. A pedimanous marsupial; an opossum.

Pedimanous: P e d i m a n o u s "a. Having feet resembling hands  or with the first toe opposable as the opossums and monkeys.

Pediment: P e d i m e n t "n. Originally  in classical architecture the triangular space forming the gable of a simple roof; hence a similar form used as a decoration over porticoes doors windows etc.; also a rounded or broken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple.

Pedimental: P e d i m e n t a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pediment.

Pedipalp: P e d i p a l p "n. One of the Pedipalpi.

Pedipalpi: P e d i p a l p i "n pl. A division of Arachnida  including the whip scorpions (Thelyphonus) and allied forms. Sometimes used in a wider sense to include also the true scorpions.

Pedipalpi: P e d i p a l p i "pl. "of Pedipalpus

Pedipalpous: P e d i p a l p o u s "a. Pertaining to  or resembling the pedipalps.

Pedipalpus: P e d i p a l p u s "n. One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids. In some they are leglike  but in others as the scorpion they terminate in a claw.

Pedireme: P e d i r e m e "n. A crustacean  some of whose feet serve as oars.

Pedlar: P e d l a r "n. Alt. of Pedler

Pedler: P e d l e r "n. See Peddler.

Pedo-: P e d o - " Combining forms from L. pes  pedis foot as pedipalp pedireme pedometer.

Pedobaptism: P e d o b a p t i s m "n. The baptism of infants or of small children.

Pedobaptist: P e d o b a p t i s t "n. One who advocates or practices infant baptism.

Pedomancy: P e d o m a n c y "n. Divination by examining the soles of the feet.

Pedometer: P e d o m e t e r "n. An instrument for including the number of steps in walking  and so ascertaining the distance passed over. It is usually in the form of a watch; an oscillating weight by the motion of the body causes the index to advance a certain distance at each step.

Pedometric: P e d o m e t r i c "a. Alt. of Pedometrical

Pedometrical: P e d o m e t r i c a l "a. Pertaining to  or measured by a pedometer.

Pedomotive: P e d o m o t i v e "a. Moved or worked by the action of the foot or feet on a pedal or treadle.

Pedotrophy: P e d o t r o p h y "n. The art of nourishing children properly.

Pedregal: P e d r e g a l "n. A lava field.

Peduncle: P e d u n c l e "n. The stem or stalk that supports the flower or fruit of a plant  or a cluster of flowers or fruits.

Peduncle: P e d u n c l e "n. A sort of stem by which certain shells and barnacles are attached to other objects. See Illust. of Barnacle.

Peduncle: P e d u n c l e "n. A band of nervous or fibrous matter connecting different parts of the brain; as  the peduncles of the cerebellum; the peduncles of the pineal gland.

Peduncled: P e d u n c l e d "a. Having a peduncle; supported on a peduncle; pedunculate.

Peduncular: P e d u n c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to a peduncle; growing from a peduncle; as  a peduncular tendril.

Pedunculata: P e d u n c u l a t a "n. pl. A division of Cirripedia  including the stalked or goose barnacles.

Pedunculate: P e d u n c u l a t e "a. Alt. of Pedunculated

Pedunculated: P e d u n c u l a t e d "a. Having a peduncle; growing on a peduncle; as  a pedunculate flower; a pedunculate eye as in a lobster.

Pee: P e e "n. See 1st Pea.

Pee: P e e "n. Bill of an anchor. See Peak  3 (c).

Peece: P e e c e "n. & v. See Piece.

Peechi: P e e c h i "n. The dauw.

Peek: P e e k "v. i. To look slyly  or with the eyes half closed or through a crevice; to peep.

Peekaboo: P e e k a b o o "n. A child's game; bopeep.

Peel: P e e l "n. A small tower  fort or castle; a keep.

Peel: P e e l "n. A spadelike implement  variously used as for removing loaves of bread from a baker's oven; also a T-shaped implement used by printers and bookbinders for hanging wet sheets of paper on lines or poles to dry. Also the blade of an oar.

Peel: P e e l "v. t. To plunder; to pillage; to rob.

Peel: P e e l "v. t. To strip off the skin  bark or rind of; to strip by drawing or tearing off the skin bark husks etc.; to flay; to decorticate; as to peel an orange.

Peel: P e e l "v. t. To strip or tear off; to remove by stripping  as the skin of an animal the bark of a tree etc.

Peel: P e e l "v. i. To lose the skin  bark or rind; to come off as the skin bark or rind does; -- often used with an adverb; as the bark peels easily or readily.

Peel: P e e l "n. The skin or rind; as  the peel of an orange.

Peele: P e e l e "n. A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola). The hair is woolly  and ash-gray on the back and sides. The horns are black long slender straight nearly smooth and very sharp. Called also rheeboc and rehboc.

Peeled: P e e l e d "imp. & p. p. of Peel

Peeler: P e e l e r "n. One who peels or strips.

Peeler: P e e l e r "n. A pillager.

Peeler: P e e l e r "n. A nickname for a policeman; -- so called from Sir Robert Peel.

Peelhouse: P e e l h o u s e "n. See 1st Peel.

Peeling: P e e l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peel

Peen: P e e n "n. A round-edged  or hemispherical end to the head of a hammer or sledge used to stretch or bend metal by indentation.

Peen: P e e n "n. The sharp-edged end of the head of a mason's hammer.

Peen: P e e n "v. t. To draw  bend or straighten as metal by blows with the peen of a hammer or sledge.

Peenge: P e e n g e "v. i. To complain.

Peep: P e e p "v. i. To cry  as a chicken hatching or newly hatched; to chirp; to cheep.

Peep: P e e p "v. i. To begin to appear; to look forth from concealment; to make the first appearance.

Peep: P e e p "v. i. To look cautiously or slyly; to peer  as through a crevice; to pry.

Peep: P e e p "n. The cry of a young chicken; a chirp.

Peep: P e e p "n. First outlook or appearance.

Peep: P e e p "n. A sly look; a look as through a crevice  or from a place of concealment.

Peep: P e e p "n. Any small sandpiper  as the least sandpiper (Trigna minutilla).

Peep: P e e p "n. The European meadow pipit (Anthus pratensis).

Peeped: P e e p e d "imp. & p. p. of Peep

Peeper: P e e p e r "n. A chicken just breaking the shell; a young bird.

Peeper: P e e p e r "n. One who peeps; a prying person; a spy.

Peeper: P e e p e r "n. The eye; as  to close the peepers.

Peephole: P e e p h o l e "n. A hole  or crevice through which one may peep without being discovered.

Peeping: P e e p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peep

Peeping hole: P e e p i n g   h o l e " See Peephole.

Peepul tree: P e e p u l   t r e e " A sacred tree (Ficus religiosa) of the Buddhists  a kind of fig tree which attains great size and venerable age. See Bo tree.

Peer: P e e r "v. i. To come in sight; to appear.

Peer: P e e r "v. i. To look narrowly or curiously or intently; to peep; as  the peering day.

Peer: P e e r "n. One of the same rank  quality endowments character etc.; an equal; a match; a mate.

Peer: P e e r "n. A comrade; a companion; a fellow; an associate.

Peer: P e e r "n. A nobleman; a member of one of the five degrees of the British nobility  namely duke marquis earl viscount baron; as a peer of the realm.

Peer: P e e r "v. t. To make equal in rank.

Peer: P e e r "v. t. To be  or to assume to be equal.

Peerage: P e e r a g e "n. The rank or dignity of a peer.

Peerage: P e e r a g e "n. The body of peers; the nobility  collectively.

Peerdom: P e e r d o m "n. Peerage; also  a lordship.

Peered: P e e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Peer

Peeress: P e e r e s s "n. The wife of a peer; a woman ennobled in her own right  or by right of marriage.

Peerie: P e e r i e "a. Alt. of Peery

Peering: P e e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peer

Peerless: P e e r l e s s "a. Having no peer or equal; matchless; superlative.

Peert: P e e r t "a. Same as Peart.

Peerweet: P e e r w e e t "n. Same as Pewit (a & b).

Peery: P e e r y "a. Inquisitive; suspicious; sharp.

Peevish: P e e v i s h "a. Habitually fretful; easily vexed or fretted; hard to please; apt to complain; querulous; petulant.

Peevish: P e e v i s h "a. Expressing fretfulness and discontent  or unjustifiable dissatisfaction; as a peevish answer.

Peevish: P e e v i s h "a. Silly; childish; trifling.

Peevishly: P e e v i s h l y "adv. In a peevish manner.

Peevishness: P e e v i s h n e s s "n. The quality of being peevish; disposition to murmur; sourness of temper.

Peevit: P e e v i t "n. Alt. of Peewit

Peewit: P e e w i t "n. See Pewit.

Peg: P e g "n. A small  pointed piece of wood used in fastening boards together in attaching the soles of boots or shoes etc.; as a shoe peg.

Peg: P e g "n. A wooden pin  or nail on which to hang things as coats etc. Hence colloquially and figuratively: A support; a reason; a pretext; as a peg to hang a claim upon.

Peg: P e g "n. One of the pins of a musical instrument  on which the strings are strained.

Peg: P e g "n. One of the pins used for marking points on a cribbage board.

Peg: P e g "n. A step; a degree; esp. in the slang phrase To take one down peg.

Peg: P e g "v. t. To put pegs into; to fasten the parts of with pegs; as  to peg shoes; to confine with pegs; to restrict or limit closely.

Peg: P e g "v. t. To score with a peg  as points in the game; as she pegged twelwe points.

Peg: P e g "v. i. To work diligently  as one who pegs shoes; -- usually with on at or away; as to peg away at a task.

Pegador: P e g a d o r "n. A species of remora (Echeneis naucrates). See Remora.

Pegasean: P e g a s e a n "a. Of or pertaining to Pegasus  or figuratively to poetry.

Pegasoid: P e g a s o i d "a. Like or pertaining to Pegasus.

Pegasus: P e g a s u s "n. A winged horse fabled to have sprung from the body of Medusa when she was slain. He is noted for causing  with a blow of his hoof Hippocrene the inspiring fountain of the Muses to spring from Mount Helicon. On this account he is in modern times associated with the Muses and with ideas of poetic inspiration.

Pegasus: P e g a s u s "n. A northen constellation near the vernal equinoctial point. Its three brightest stars  with the brightest star of Andromeda form the square of Pegasus.

Pegasus: P e g a s u s "n. A genus of small fishes  having large pectoral fins and the body covered with hard bony plates. Several species are known from the East Indies and China.

Pegged: P e g g e d "imp. & p. p. of Peg

Pegger: P e g g e r "n. One who fastens with pegs.

Pegging: P e g g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peg

Pegging: P e g g i n g "n. The act or process of fastening with pegs.

Pegm: P e g m "n. A sort of moving machine employed in the old pageants.

Pegmatite: P e g m a t i t e "n. Graphic granite. See under Granite.

Pegmatite: P e g m a t i t e "n. More generally  a coarse granite occurring as vein material in other rocks.

Pegmatitic: P e g m a t i t i c "a. Of  pertaining to or resembling pegmatite; as the pegmatic structure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite.

Pegomancy: P e g o m a n c y "n. Divination by fountains.

Pegroots: P e g r o o t s "n. Same as Setterwort.

Pegtatoid: P e g t a t o i d "a. Resembling pegmatite; pegmatic.

Pehlevi: P e h l e v i "n. An ancient Persian dialect in which words were partly represented by their Semitic equivalents. It was in use from the 3d century (and perhaps earlier) to the middle of the 7th century  and later in religious writings.

Pein: P e i n "n. See Peen.

Peirameter: P e i r a m e t e r "n. A dynamometer for measuring the force required to draw wheel carriages on roads of different constructions.

Peirastic: P e i r a s t i c "a. Fitted for trail or test; experimental; tentative; treating of attempts.

Peise: P e i s e "n. A weight; a poise.

Peise: P e i s e "v. t. To poise or weight.

Peitrel: P e i t r e l "n. See Peytrel.

Pejorative: P e j o r a t i v e "a. Implying or imputing evil; depreciatory; disparaging; unfavorable.

Pekan: P e k a n "n. See Fisher  2.

Pekoe: P e k o e "n. A kind of black tea.

Pela: P e l a "n. See Wax insect  under Wax.

Pelage: P e l a g e "n. The covering  or coat of a mammal whether of wool fur or hair.

Pelagian: P e l a g i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the sea; marine; pelagic; as  pelagian shells.

Pelagian: P e l a g i a n "n. A follower of Pelagius  a British monk born in the later part of the 4th century who denied the doctrines of hereditary sin of the connection between sin and death and of conversion through grace.

Pelagian: P e l a g i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Pelagius  or to his doctrines.

Pelagianism: P e l a g i a n i s m "n. The doctrines of Pelagius.

Pelagic: P e l a g i c "a. Of or pertaining to the ocean; -- applied especially to animals that live at the surface of the ocean  away from the coast.

Pelargonic: P e l a r g o n i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating an organic acid (called also nonoic acid) found in the leaves of the geranium (Pelargonium) and allied plants.

Pelargonium: P e l a r g o n i u m "n. A large genus of plants of the order Geraniaceae  differing from Geranium in having a spurred calyx and an irregular corolla.

Pelasgian: P e l a s g i a n "a. Alt. of Pelasgic

Pelasgic: P e l a s g i c "a. Of or pertaining to the Pelasgians  an ancient people of Greece of roving habits.

Pelasgic: P e l a s g i c "a. Wandering.

Pelecan: P e l e c a n "n. See Pelican.

Pelecaniformes: P e l e c a n i f o r m e s "n. pl. Those birds that are related to the pelican; the Totipalmi.

Pelecoid: P e l e c o i d "n. A figure  somewhat hatched-shaped bounded by a semicircle and two inverted quadrants and equal in area to the square ABCD inclosed by the chords of the four quadrants.

Pelecypoda: P e l e c y p o d a "n. pl. Same as Lamellibranchia.

Pelegrine: P e l e g r i n e "a. See Peregrine.

Pelerine: P e l e r i n e "n. A woman's cape; especially  a fur cape that is longer in front than behind.

Pelf: P e l f "n. Money; riches; lucre; gain; -- generally conveying the idea of something ill-gotten or worthless. It has no plural.

Pelfish: P e l f i s h "a. Of or pertaining to pelf.

Pelfray: P e l f r a y "n. Alt. of Pelfry

Pelfry: P e l f r y "n. Pelf; also  figuratively rubbish; trash.

Pelican: P e l i c a n "n. Any large webfooted bird of the genus Pelecanus  of which about a dozen species are known. They have an enormous bill to the lower edge of which is attached a pouch in which captured fishes are temporarily stored.

Pelican: P e l i c a n "n. A retort or still having a curved tube or tubes leading back from the head to the body for continuous condensation and redistillation.

Pelick: P e l i c k "n. The American coot (Fulica).

Pelicoid: P e l i c o i d "n. See Pelecoid.

Pelicosauria: P e l i c o s a u r i a "n. pl. A suborder of Theromorpha  including terrestrial reptiles from the Permian formation.

Peliom: P e l i o m "n. A variety of iolite  of a smoky blue color; pelioma.

Pelioma: P e l i o m a "n. A livid ecchymosis.

Pelioma: P e l i o m a "n. See Peliom.

Pelisse: P e l i s s e "n. An outer garment for men or women  originally of fur or lined with fur; a lady's outer garment made of silk or other fabric.

Pell: P e l l "v. t. To pelt; to knock about.

Pell: P e l l "n. A skin or hide; a pelt.

Pell: P e l l "n. A roll of parchment; a parchment record.

Pell-mell: P e l l - m e l l "n. See Pall-mall.

Pellack: P e l l a c k "n. A porpoise.

Pellage: P e l l a g e "n. A customs duty on skins of leather.

Pellagra: P e l l a g r a "n. An erythematous affection of the skin  with severe constitutional and nervous symptoms endemic in Northern Italy.

Pellagrin: P e l l a g r i n "n. One who is afficted with pellagra.

Pellet: P e l l e t "n. A little ball; as  a pellet of wax / paper.

Pellet: P e l l e t "n. A bullet; a ball for firearms.

Pellet: P e l l e t "v./. To form into small balls.

Pelleted: P e l l e t e d "a. Made of  or like pellets; furnished with pellets.

Pellibranchiata: P e l l i b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. A division of Nudibranchiata  in which the mantle itself serves as a gill.

Pellicle: P e l l i c l e "n. A thin skin or film.

Pellicle: P e l l i c l e "n. A thin film formed on the surface of an evaporating solution.

Pellicular: P e l l i c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to a pellicle.

Pellile: P e l l i l e "n. The redshank; -- so called from its note.

Pellitory: P e l l i t o r y "n. The common name of the several species of the genus Parietaria  low harmless weeds of the Nettle family; -- also called wall pellitory and lichwort.

Pellitory: P e l l i t o r y "n. A composite plant (Anacyclus Pyrethrum) of the Mediterranean region  having finely divided leaves and whitish flowers. The root is the officinal pellitory and is used as an irritant and sialogogue. Called also bertram and pellitory of Spain.

Pellitory: P e l l i t o r y "n. The feverfew (Chrysanthemum Parthenium); -- so called because it resembles the above.

Pellmell: P e l l m e l l "adv. In utter confusion; with confused violence.

Pellucid: P e l l u c i d "a. Transparent; clear; limpid; translucent; not opaque.

Pellucidity: P e l l u c i d i t y "n. Alt. of Pellucidness

Pellucidly: P e l l u c i d l y "adv. In a pellucid manner.

Pellucidness: P e l l u c i d n e s s "n. The quality or state of being pellucid; transparency; translucency; clearness; as  the pellucidity of the air.

Pelma: P e l m a "n. The under surface of the foot.

Pelmata: P e l m a t a "pl. "of Pelma

Pelopium: P e l o p i u m "n. A supposed new metal found in columbite  afterwards shown to be identical with columbium or niobium.

Peloponnesian: P e l o p o n n e s i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the Peloponnesus  or southern peninsula of Greece.

Peloponnesian: P e l o p o n n e s i a n "n. A native or an inhabitant of the Peloponnesus.

Peloria: P e l o r i a "n. Abnormal regularity; the state of certain flowers  which being naturally irregular have become regular through a symmetrical repetition of the special irregularity.

Peloric: P e l o r i c "a. Abnormally regular or symmetrical.

Pelotage: P e l o t a g e "n. Packs or bales of Spanish wool.

Pelt: P e l t "n. The skin of a beast with the hair on; a raw or undressed hide; a skin preserved with the hairy or woolly covering on it. See 4th Fell.

Pelt: P e l t "n. The human skin.

Pelt: P e l t "n. The body of any quarry killed by the hawk.

Peludo: P e l u d o "n. The South American hairy armadillo (Dasypus villosus).

Pelusiac: P e l u s i a c "a. Of or pertaining to Pelusium  an ancient city of Egypt; as the Pelusiac (or former eastern) outlet of the Nile.

Pelvic: P e l v i c "a. Of  pertaining to or in the region of the pelvis; as pelvic cellulitis.

Pelvimeter: P e l v i m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the dimensions of the pelvis.

Pelvis: P e l v i s "n. The pelvic arch  or the pelvic arch together with the sacrum. See Pelvic arch under Pelvic and Sacrum.

Pelvis: P e l v i s "n. The calyx of a crinoid.

Pemmican: P e m m i c a n "n. Among the North American Indians  meat cut in thin slices divested of fat and dried in the sun.

Pemmican: P e m m i c a n "n. Meat  without the fat cut in thin slices dried in the sun pounded then mixed with melted fat and sometimes dried fruit and compressed into cakes or in bags. It contains much nutriment in small compass and is of great use in long voyages of exploration.

Pemphigus: P e m p h i g u s "n. A somewhat rare skin disease  characterized by the development of blebs upon different part of the body.

Pen: P e n "n. A feather.

Pen: P e n "n. A wing.

Pen: P e n "n. An instrument used for writing with ink  formerly made of a reed or of the quill of a goose or other bird but now also of other materials as of steel gold etc. Also originally a stylus or other instrument for scratching or graving.

Pen: P e n "n. Fig.: A writer  or his style; as he has a sharp pen.

Pen: P e n "n. The internal shell of a squid.

Pen: P e n "n. A female swan.

Pen: P e n "v. t. To write; to compose and commit to paper; to indite; to compose; as  to pen a sonnet.

Pen: P e n "n. & v. To shut up  as in a pen or cage; to confine in a small inclosure or narrow space; to coop up or shut in; to inclose.

Pen: P e n "n. A small inclosure; as  a pen for sheep or for pigs.

Penal: P e n a l "a. Of or pertaining to punishment  to penalties or to crimes and offenses; pertaining to criminal jurisprudence

Penal: P e n a l "a. Enacting or threatening punishment; as  a penal statue; the penal code.

Penal: P e n a l "a. Incurring punishment; subject to a penalty; as  a penalact of offense.

Penal: P e n a l "a. Inflicted as punishment; used as a means of punishment; as  a penal colony or settlement.

Penality: P e n a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being penal; lability to punishment.

Penalize: P e n a l i z e "v. t. To make penal.

Penalize: P e n a l i z e "v. t. To put a penalty on. See Penalty  3.

Penally: P e n a l l y "adv. In a penal manner.

Penalties: P e n a l t i e s "pl. "of Penalty

Penalty: P e n a l t y "n. Penal retribution; punishment for crime or offense; the suffering in person or property which is annexed by law or judicial decision to the commission of a crime  offense or trespass.

Penalty: P e n a l t y "n. The suffering  or the sum to be forfeited to which a person subjects himself by covenant or agreement in case of nonfulfillment of stipulations; forfeiture; fine.

Penalty: P e n a l t y "n. A handicap.

Penance: P e n a n c e "n. Repentance.

Penance: P e n a n c e "n. Pain; sorrow; suffering.

Penance: P e n a n c e "n. A means of repairing a sin committed  and obtaining pardon for it consisting partly in the performance of expiatory rites partly in voluntary submission to a punishment corresponding to the transgression. Penance is the fourth of seven sacraments in the Roman Catholic Church.

Penance: P e n a n c e "v. t. To impose penance; to punish.

Penanced: P e n a n c e d "imp. & p. p. of Penance

Penanceless: P e n a n c e l e s s "a. Free from penance.

Penang nut: P e n a n g   n u t " The betel nut.

Penannular: P e n a n n u l a r "a. Nearly annular; having nearly the form of a ring.

Penary: P e n a r y "a. Penal.

Penates: P e n a t e s "n. pl. The household gods of the ancient Romans. They presided over the home and the family hearth. See Lar.

Penaunt: P e n a u n t "n. A penitent.

Pence: P e n c e "n. pl. of Penny. See Penny.

Pence: P e n c e "pl. "of Penny

Pencel: P e n c e l "n. A small  narrow flag or streamer borne at the top of a lance; -- called also pennoncel.

Penchant: P e n c h a n t "n. Inclination; decided taste; bias; as  a penchant for art.

Penchute: P e n c h u t e "n. See Penstock.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. A small  fine brush of hair or bristles used by painters for laying on colors.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. A slender cylinder or strip of black lead  colored chalk slate etc. or such a cylinder or strip inserted in a small wooden rod intended to be pointed or in a case which forms a handle -- used for drawing or writing. See Graphite.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. Hence  figuratively an artist's ability or peculiar manner; also in general the act or occupation of the artist descriptive writer etc.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. An aggregate or collection of rays of light  especially when diverging from or converging to a point.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. A number of lines that intersect in one point  the point of intersection being called the pencil point.

Pencil: P e n c i l "n. A small medicated bougie.

Pencil: P e n c i l "v. t. To write or mark with a pencil; to paint or to draw.

Penciled: P e n c i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pencil

Penciled: P e n c i l e d "a. Painted  drawn sketched or marked with a pencil.

Penciled: P e n c i l e d "a. Radiated; having pencils of rays.

Penciled: P e n c i l e d "a. Marked with parallel or radiating lines.

Penciling: P e n c i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pencil

Penciling: P e n c i l i n g "n. The work of the pencil or bruch; as  delicate penciling in a picture.

Penciling: P e n c i l i n g "n. Lines of white or black paint drawn along a mortar joint in a brick wall.

Pencillate: P e n c i l l a t e "a. Alt. of Pencillated

Pencillated: P e n c i l l a t e d "a. Shaped like a pencil; penicillate.

Pencilled: P e n c i l l e d " of Pencil

Pencilling: P e n c i l l i n g " of Pencil

Pencraft: P e n c r a f t "n. Penmanship; skill in writing; chirography.

Pencraft: P e n c r a f t "n. The art of composing or writing; authorship.

Pend: P e n d "n. Oil cake; penock.

Pend: P e n d "v. i. To hang; to depend.

Pend: P e n d "v. i. To be undecided  or in process of adjustment.

Pend: P e n d "v. t. To pen; to confine.

Pendant: P e n d a n t "n. Something which hangs or depends; something suspended; a hanging appendage  especially one of an ornamental character; as to a chandelier or an eardrop; also an appendix or addition as to a book.

Pendant: P e n d a n t "n. A hanging ornament on roofs  ceilings etc. much used in the later styles of Gothic architecture where it is of stone and an important part of the construction. There are imitations in plaster and wood which are mere decorative features.

Pendant: P e n d a n t "n. One of a pair; a counterpart; as  one vase is the pendant to the other vase.

Pendant: P e n d a n t "n. A pendulum.

Pendant: P e n d a n t "n. The stem and ring of a watch  by which it is suspended.

Pended: P e n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Pend

Pendence: P e n d e n c e "n. Slope; inclination.

Pendency: P e n d e n c y "n. The quality or state of being pendent or suspended.

Pendency: P e n d e n c y "n. The quality or state of being undecided  or in continuance; suspense; as the pendency of a suit.

Pendent: P e n d e n t "a. Supported from above; suspended; depending; pendulous; hanging; as  a pendent leaf.

Pendent: P e n d e n t "a. Jutting over; projecting; overhanging.

Pendentive: P e n d e n t i v e "n. The portion of a vault by means of which the square space in the middle of a building is brought to an octagon or circle to receive a cupola.

Pendentive: P e n d e n t i v e "n. The part of a groined vault which is supported by  and springs from one pier or corbel.

Pendently: P e n d e n t l y "adv. In a pendent manner.

Pendice: P e n d i c e "n. A sloping roof; a lean-to; a penthouse.

Pendicle: P e n d i c l e "n. An appendage; something dependent on another; an appurtenance; a pendant.

Pendicler: P e n d i c l e r "n. An inferior tenant; one who rents a pendicle or croft.

Pending: P e n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pend

Pending: P e n d i n g "a. Not yet decided; in continuance; in suspense; as  a pending suit.

Pending: P e n d i n g "prep. During; as  pending the trail.

Pendragon: P e n d r a g o n "n. A chief leader or a king; a head; a dictator; -- a title assumed by the ancient British chiefs when called to lead other chiefs.

Pendular: P e n d u l a r "a. Pendulous.

Pendulate: P e n d u l a t e "v. i. To swing as a pendulum.

Pendule: P e n d u l e "n. A pendulum.

Penduline: P e n d u l i n e "n. A European titmouse (Parus  / Aegithalus pendulinus). It is noted for its elegant pendulous purselike nest made of the down of willow trees and lined with feathers.

Pendulosity: P e n d u l o s i t y "n. The state or quality of being pendulous.

Pendulous: P e n d u l o u s "a. Depending; pendent loosely; hanging; swinging.

Pendulous: P e n d u l o u s "a. Wavering; unstable; doubtful.

Pendulous: P e n d u l o u s "a. Inclined or hanging downwards  as a flower on a recurved stalk or an ovule which hangs from the upper part of the ovary.

Pendulously: P e n d u l o u s l y "adv. In a pendulous manner.

Pendulousness: P e n d u l o u s n e s s "n. The quality or state of being pendulous; the state of hanging loosely; pendulosity.

Pendulum: P e n d u l u m "n. A body so suspended from a fixed point as to swing freely to and fro by the alternate action of gravity and momentum. It is used to regulate the movements of clockwork and other machinery.

Pendulums: P e n d u l u m s "pl. "of Pendulum

Penelope: P e n e l o p e "n. A genus of curassows  including the guans.

Penetrability: P e n e t r a b i l i t y "n. The quality of being penetrable; susceptibility of being penetrated  entered or pierced.

Penetrable: P e n e t r a b l e "a. Capable of being penetrated  entered or pierced. Used also figuratively.

Penetrail: P e n e t r a i l "n. Penetralia.

Penetralia: P e n e t r a l i a "n. pl. The recesses  or innermost parts of any thing or place especially of a temple or palace.

Penetralia: P e n e t r a l i a "n. pl. Hidden things or secrets; privacy; sanctuary; as  the sacred penetralia of the home.

Penetrance: P e n e t r a n c e "n. Alt. of Penetrancy

Penetrancy: P e n e t r a n c y "n. The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering or piercing; penetrating power of quality; as  the penetrancy of subtile effluvia.

Penetrant: P e n e t r a n t "a. Having power to enter or pierce; penetrating; sharp; subtile; as  penetrant cold.

Penetrate: P e n e t r a t e "v. t. To enter into; to make way into the interior of; to effect an entrance into; to pierce; as  light penetrates darkness.

Penetrate: P e n e t r a t e "v. t. To affect profoundly through the senses or feelings; to touch with feeling; to make sensible; to move deeply; as  to penetrate one's heart with pity.

Penetrate: P e n e t r a t e "v. t. To pierce into by the mind; to arrive at the inner contents or meaning of  as of a mysterious or difficult subject; to comprehend; to understand.

Penetrate: P e n e t r a t e "v. i. To pass; to make way; to pierce. Also used figuratively.

Penetrated: P e n e t r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Penetrate

Penetrating: P e n e t r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Penetrate

Penetrating: P e n e t r a t i n g "a. Having the power of entering  piercing or pervading; sharp; subtile; penetrative; as a penetrating odor.

Penetrating: P e n e t r a t i n g "a. Acute; discerning; sagacious; quick to discover; as  a penetrating mind.

Penetratingly: P e n e t r a t i n g l y "adv. In a penetrating manner.

Penetration: P e n e t r a t i o n "n. The act or process of penetrating  piercing or entering; also the act of mentally penetrating into or comprehending anything difficult.

Penetration: P e n e t r a t i o n "n. Acuteness; insight; sharp discoverment; sagacity; as  a person of singular penetration.

Penetrative: P e n e t r a t i v e "a. Tending to penetrate; of a penetrating quality; piercing; as  the penetrative sun.

Penetrative: P e n e t r a t i v e "a. Having the power to affect or impress the mind or heart; impressive; as  penetrative shame.

Penetrative: P e n e t r a t i v e "a. Acute; discerning; sagacious; as  penetrative wisdom.

Penetrativeness: P e n e t r a t i v e n e s s "n. The quality of being penetrative.

Penfish: P e n f i s h "n. A squid.

Penfold: P e n f o l d "n. See Pinfold.

Pengolin: P e n g o l i n "n. The pangolin.

Penguin: P e n g u i n "n. Any bird of the order Impennes  or Ptilopteri. They are covered with short thick feathers almost scalelike on the wings which are without true quills. They are unable to fly but use their wings to aid in diving in which they are very expert. See King penguin under Jackass.

Penguin: P e n g u i n "n. The egg-shaped fleshy fruit of a West Indian plant (Bromelia Pinguin) of the Pineapple family; also  the plant itself which has rigid pointed and spiny-toothed leaves and is used for hedges.

Penguinery: P e n g u i n e r y "n. A breeding place  or rookery of penguins.

Penholder: P e n h o l d e r "n. A handle for a pen.

Penhouse: P e n h o u s e "n. A penthouse.

Penible: P e n i b l e "a. Painstaking; assidous.

Penicil: P e n i c i l "n. A tent or pledget for wounds or ulcers.

Penicillate: P e n i c i l l a t e "a. Having the form of a pencil; furnished with a pencil of fine hairs; ending in a tuft of hairs like a camel's-hair brush  as the stigmas of some grasses.

Penicilliform: P e n i c i l l i f o r m "a. Penicillate.

Peninsula: P e n i n s u l a "n. A portion of land nearly surrounded by water  and connected with a larger body by a neck or isthmus.

Peninsular: P e n i n s u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to a peninsula; as  a peninsular form; peninsular people; the peninsular war.

Peninsulate: P e n i n s u l a t e "v. t. To form into a peninsula.

Peninsulated: P e n i n s u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Peninsulate

Peninsulating: P e n i n s u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peninsulate

Penis: P e n i s "n. The male member  or organ of generation.

Penitence: P e n i t e n c e "n. The quality or condition of being penitent; the disposition of a penitent; sorrow for sins or faults; repentance; contrition.

Penitencer: P e n i t e n c e r "n. A priest who heard confession and enjoined penance in extraordinary cases.

Penitency: P e n i t e n c y "n. Penitence.

Penitent: P e n i t e n t "a. Feeling pain or sorrow on account of sins or offenses; repentant; contrite; sincerely affected by a sense of guilt  and resolved on amendment of life.

Penitent: P e n i t e n t "a. Doing penance.

Penitent: P e n i t e n t "n. One who repents of sin; one sorrowful on account of his transgressions.

Penitent: P e n i t e n t "n. One under church censure  but admitted to penance; one undergoing penance.

Penitent: P e n i t e n t "n. One under the direction of a confessor.

Penitential: P e n i t e n t i a l "a. Of or pertaining to penitence  or to penance; expressing penitence; of the nature of penance; as the penitential book; penitential tears.

Penitential: P e n i t e n t i a l "n. A book formerly used by priests hearing confessions  containing rules for the imposition of penances; -- called also penitential book.

Penitentially: P e n i t e n t i a l l y "adv. In a penitential manner.

Penitentiaries: P e n i t e n t i a r i e s "pl. "of Penitentiary

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "a. Relating to penance  or to the rules and measures of penance.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "a. Expressive of penitence; as  a penitentiary letter.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "a. Used for punishment  discipline and reformation.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. One who prescribes the rules and measures of penance.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. One who does penance.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. A small building in a monastery where penitents confessed.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. That part of a church to which penitents were admitted.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. An office of the papal court which examines cases of conscience  confession absolution from vows etc. and delivers decisions dispensations etc. Its chief is a cardinal called the Grand Penitentiary appointed by the pope.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. An officer in some dioceses since A. D. 1215  vested with power from the bishop to absolve in cases reserved to him.

Penitentiary: P e n i t e n t i a r y "n. A house of correction  in which offenders are confined for punishment discipline and reformation and in which they are generally compelled to labor.

Penitentiaryship: P e n i t e n t i a r y s h i p "n. The office or condition of a penitentiary of the papal court.

Penitently: P e n i t e n t l y "adv. In a penitent manner.

Penk: P e n k "n. A minnow. See Pink  n. 4.

Penknife: P e n k n i f e "n. A small pocketknife; formerly  a knife used for making and mending quill pens.

Penknives: P e n k n i v e s "pl. "of Penknife

Penman: P e n m a n "n. One who uses the pen; a writer; esp.  one skilled in the use of the pen; a calligrapher; a writing master.

Penman: P e n m a n "n. An author; a composer.

Penmanship: P e n m a n s h i p "n. The use of the pen in writing; the art of writing; style or manner of writing; chirography; as  good or bad penmanship.

Penmen: P e n m e n "pl. "of Penman

Penna: P e n n a "n. A perfect  or normal feather.

Pennaceous: P e n n a c e o u s "a. Like or pertaining to a normal feather.

Pennach: P e n n a c h "n. A bunch of feathers; a plume.

Pennached: P e n n a c h e d "a. Variegated; striped.

Pennae: P e n n a e "pl. "of Penna

Pennage: P e n n a g e "n. Feathery covering; plumage.

Pennant: P e n n a n t "n. A small flag; a pennon. The narrow  / long pennant (called also whip or coach whip) is a long narrow piece of bunting carried at the masthead of a government vessel in commission. The board pennant is an oblong nearly square flag carried at the masthead of a commodore's vessel.

Pennant: P e n n a n t "n. A rope or strap to which a purchase is hooked.

Pennate: P e n n a t e "a. Alt. of Pennated

Pennated: P e n n a t e d "a. Winged; plume-shaped.

Pennated: P e n n a t e d "a. Same as Pinnate.

Pennatula: P e n n a t u l a "n. Any one of numerous species of Pennatula  Pteroides and allied genera of Alcyonaria having a featherlike form; a sea-pen. The zooids are situated along one edge of the side branches.

Pennatulacea: P e n n a t u l a c e a "n. pl. A division of alcyonoid corals  including the seapens and related kinds. They are able to move about by means of the hollow muscular peduncle which also serves to support them upright in the mud. See Pennatula and Illust. under Alcyonaria.

Pennatulae: P e n n a t u l a e "pl. "of Pennatula

Pennatulas: P e n n a t u l a s "pl. "of Pennatula

Penned: P e n n e d "imp. & p. p. of Pen
