Penned: P e n n e d "a. Written with a pen; composed.

Penner: P e n n e r "n. One who pens; a writer.

Penner: P e n n e r "n. A case for holding pens.

Pennies: P e n n i e s "pl. "of Penny

Penniform: P e n n i f o r m "a. Having the form of a feather or plume.

Pennigerous: P e n n i g e r o u s "a. Bearing feathers or quills.

Penniless: P e n n i l e s s "a. Destitute of money; impecunious; poor.

Penninerved: P e n n i n e r v e d "a. Pinnately veined or nerved.

Penning: P e n n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pen

Penning: P e n n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pen

Pennipotent: P e n n i p o t e n t "a. Strong of wing; strong on the wing.

Pennon: P e n n o n "n. A wing; a pinion.

Pennon: P e n n o n "n. A pennant; a flag or streamer.

Pennoncel: P e n n o n c e l "n. Alt. of Pennoncelle

Pennoncelle: P e n n o n c e l l e "n. See Pencel.

Penny: P e n n y "a. Denoting pound weight for one thousand; -- used in combination  with respect to nails; as tenpenny nails nails of which one thousand weight ten pounds.

Penny: P e n n y "n. An English coin  formerly of copper now of bronze the twelfth part of an English shilling in account value and equal to four farthings or about two cents; -- usually indicated by the abbreviation d. (the initial of denarius).

Penny: P e n n y "n. Any small sum or coin; a groat; a stiver.

Penny: P e n n y "n. Money  in general; as to turn an honest penny.

Penny: P e n n y "n. See Denarius.

Penny: P e n n y "a. Worth or costing one penny.

Penny-a-liner: P e n n y - a - l i n e r "n. One who furnishes matter to public journals at so much a line; a poor writer for hire; a hack writer.

Pennyroyal: P e n n y r o y a l "n. An aromatic herb (Mentha Pulegium) of Europe; also  a North American plant (Hedeoma pulegioides) resembling it in flavor.

Pennyweight: P e n n y w e i g h t "n. A troy weight containing twenty-four grains  or the twentieth part of an ounce; as a pennyweight of gold or of arsenic. It was anciently the weight of a silver penny whence the name.

Pennywort: P e n n y w o r t "n. A European trailing herb (Linaria Cymbalaria) with roundish  reniform leaves. It is often cultivated in hanging baskets.

Pennyworth: P e n n y w o r t h "n. A penny's worth; as much as may be bought for a penny.

Pennyworth: P e n n y w o r t h "n. Hence: The full value of one's penny expended; due return for money laid out; a good bargain; a bargain.

Pennyworth: P e n n y w o r t h "n. A small quantity; a trifle.

Penock: P e n o c k "n. See Pend.

Penological: P e n o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to penology.

Penologist: P e n o l o g i s t "n. One versed in  or a student of penology.

Penology: P e n o l o g y "n. The science or art of punishment.

Penrack: P e n r a c k "n. A rack for pens not in use.

Pens: P e n s "n. pl. of Penny.

Pensative: P e n s a t i v e "a. Pensive.

Pensel: P e n s e l "n. A pencel.

Pensible: P e n s i b l e "a. Held aloft.

Pensile: P e n s i l e "a. Hanging; suspended; pendent; pendulous.

Pensileness: P e n s i l e n e s s "n. State or quality of being pensile; pendulousness.

Pension: P e n s i o n "n. A payment; a tribute; something paid or given.

Pension: P e n s i o n "n. A stated allowance to a person in consideration of past services; payment made to one retired from service  on account of age disability or other cause; especially a regular stipend paid by a government to retired public officers disabled soldiers the families of soldiers killed in service or to meritorious authors or the like.

Pension: P e n s i o n "n. A certain sum of money paid to a clergyman in lieu of tithes.

Pension: P e n s i o n "n. A boarding house or boarding school in France  Belgium Switzerland etc.

Pension: P e n s i o n "v. t. To grant a pension to; to pay a regular stipend to; in consideration of service already performed; -- sometimes followed by off; as  to pension off a servant.

Pensionaries: P e n s i o n a r i e s "pl. "of Pensionary

Pensionary: P e n s i o n a r y "a. Maintained by a pension; receiving a pension; as  pensionary spies.

Pensionary: P e n s i o n a r y "a. Consisting of a pension; as  a pensionary provision for maintenance.

Pensionary: P e n s i o n a r y "n. One who receives a pension; a pensioner.

Pensionary: P e n s i o n a r y "n. One of the chief magistrates of towns in Holland.

Pensioned: P e n s i o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Pension

Pensioner: P e n s i o n e r "n. One in receipt of a pension; hence  figuratively a dependent.

Pensioner: P e n s i o n e r "n. One of an honorable band of gentlemen who attend the sovereign of England on state occasions  and receive an annual pension or allowance of  150 and two horses.

Pensioner: P e n s i o n e r "n. In the university of Cambridge  England one who pays for his living in commons; -- corresponding to commoner at Oxford.

Pensioning: P e n s i o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pension

Pensive: P e n s i v e "a. Thoughtful  sober or sad; employed in serious reflection; given to or favorable to earnest or melancholy musing.

Pensive: P e n s i v e "a. Expressing or suggesting thoughtfulness with sadness; as  pensive numbers.

Pensived: P e n s i v e d "a. Made pensive.

Pensively: P e n s i v e l y "adv. In a pensive manner.

Pensiveness: P e n s i v e n e s s "n. The state of being pensive; serious thoughtfulness; seriousness.

Penstock: P e n s t o c k "n. A close conduit or pipe for conducting water  as to a water wheel or for emptying a pond or for domestic uses.

Penstock: P e n s t o c k "n. The barrel of a wooden pump.

Pent: P e n t " of Pen

Pent: P e n t "v. t. Penned or shut up; confined; -- often with up.

Penta-: P e n t a - " A combining form denoting five; as  pentacapsular; pentagon.

Penta-: P e n t a - " Denoting the degree of five  either as regards quality property or composition; as pentasulphide; pentoxide etc. Also used adjectively.

Pentabasic: P e n t a b a s i c "a. Capable of uniting with five molecules of a monacid base; having five acid hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by a basic radical; -- said of certain acids.

Pentacapsular: P e n t a c a p s u l a r "a. Having five capsules.

Pentachenium: P e n t a c h e n i u m "n. A dry fruit composed of five carpels  which are covered by an epigynous calyx and separate at maturity.

Pentachloride: P e n t a c h l o r i d e "n. A chloride having five atoms of chlorine in each molecule.

Pentachord: P e n t a c h o r d "n. An ancient instrument of music with five strings.

Pentachord: P e n t a c h o r d "n. An order or system of five sounds.

Pentacid: P e n t a c i d "a. Capable of neutralizing  or combining with five molecules of a monobasic acid; having five hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by acid residues; -- said of certain complex bases.

Pentacle: P e n t a c l e "n. A figure composed of two equilateral triangles intersecting so as to form a six-pointed star  -- used in early ornamental art and also with superstitious import by the astrologers and mystics of the Middle Ages.

Pentacoccous: P e n t a c o c c o u s "a. Composed of five united carpels with one seed in each  as certain fruits.

Pentaconter: P e n t a c o n t e r "n. See Penteconter.

Pentacra: P e n t a c r a "pl. "of Pentacron

Pentacrinin: P e n t a c r i n i n "n. A red and purple pigment found in certain crinoids of the genus Pentacrinus.

Pentacrinite: P e n t a c r i n i t e "n. Any species of Pentacrinus.

Pentacrinoid: P e n t a c r i n o i d "n. An immature comatula when it is still attached by a stem  and thus resembles a Pentacrinus.

Pentacrinus: P e n t a c r i n u s "n. A genus of large  stalked crinoids of which several species occur in deep water among the West Indies and elsewhere.

Pentacron: P e n t a c r o n "n. A solid having five summits or angular points.

Pentacrons: P e n t a c r o n s "pl. "of Pentacron

Pentacrostic: P e n t a c r o s t i c "n. A set of verses so disposed that the name forming the subject of the acrostic occurs five times -- the whole set of verses being divided into five different parts from top to bottom.

Pentad: P e n t a d "n. Any element  atom or radical having a valence of five or which can be combined with substituted for or compared with five atoms of hydrogen or other monad; as nitrogen is a pentad in the ammonium compounds.

Pentad: P e n t a d "a. Having the valence of a pentad.

Pentadactyl: P e n t a d a c t y l "a. Alt. of Pentadactyle

Pentadactyle: P e n t a d a c t y l e "a. Having five digits to the hand or foot.

Pentadactyle: P e n t a d a c t y l e "a. Having five appendages resembling fingers or toes.

Pentadactyloid: P e n t a d a c t y l o i d "a. Having the form of  or a structure modified from a pentadactyl limb.

Pentadecane: P e n t a d e c a n e "n. A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series  (C15H32) found in petroleum tar oil etc. and obtained as a colorless liquid; -- so called from the fifteen carbon atoms in the molecule.

Pentadecatoic: P e n t a d e c a t o i c "a. Of  pertaining to or derived from pentadecane or designating an acid related to it.

Pentadecylic: P e n t a d e c y l i c "a. Same as Quindecylic.

Pentadelphous: P e n t a d e l p h o u s "a. Having the stamens arranged in five clusters  those of each cluster having their filaments more or less united as the flowers of the linden.

Pentafid: P e n t a f i d "a. Divided or cleft into five parts.

Pentaglot: P e n t a g l o t "n. A work in five different tongues.

Pentagon: P e n t a g o n "n. A plane figure having five angles  and consequently five sides; any figure having five angles.

Pentagonal: P e n t a g o n a l "a. Having five corners or angles.

Pentagonally: P e n t a g o n a l l y "adv. In the form of a pentagon; with five angles.

Pentagonous: P e n t a g o n o u s "a. Pentagonal.

Pentagram: P e n t a g r a m "n. A pentacle or a pentalpha.

Pentagraphic: P e n t a g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Pentagraphical

Pentagraphical: P e n t a g r a p h i c a l "a. Pantographic. See Pantograph.

Pentagynia: P e n t a g y n i a "n. pl. A Linnaean order of plants  having five styles or pistils.

Pentagynian: P e n t a g y n i a n "a. Alt. of Pentagynous

Pentagynous: P e n t a g y n o u s "a. Of or pertaining to plants of the order Pentagyna; having five styles.

Pentahedral: P e n t a h e d r a l "a. Having five sides; as  a pentahedral figure.

Pentahedrical: P e n t a h e d r i c a l "a. Pentahedral.

Pentahedron: P e n t a h e d r o n "n. A solid figure having five sides.

Pentahedrous: P e n t a h e d r o u s "a. Pentahedral.

Pentail: P e n t a i l "n. A peculiar insectivore (Ptilocercus Lowii) of Borneo; -- so called from its very long  quill-shaped tail which is scaly at the base and plumose at the tip.

Pentalpha: P e n t a l p h a "n. A five-pointed star  resembling five alphas joined at their bases; -- used as a symbol.

Pentamera: P e n t a m e r a "n. pl. An extensive division of Coleoptera  including those that normally have five-jointed tarsi. It embraces about half of all the known species of the Coleoptera.

Pentameran: P e n t a m e r a n "n. One of the Pentamera.

Pentamerous: P e n t a m e r o u s "a. Divided into  or consisting of five parts; also arranged in sets with five parts in each set as a flower with five sepals five petals five or twice five stamens and five pistils.

Pentamerous: P e n t a m e r o u s "a. Belonging to the Pentamera.

Pentamerus: P e n t a m e r u s "n. A genus of extinct Paleozoic brachiopods  often very abundant in the Upper Silurian.

Pentameter: P e n t a m e t e r "n. A verse of five feet.

Pentameter: P e n t a m e t e r "a. Having five metrical feet.

Pentamethylene: P e n t a m e t h y l e n e "n. A hypothetical hydrocarbon  C5H10 metameric with the amylenes and the nucleus of a large number of derivatives; -- so named because regarded as composed of five methylene residues. Cf. Trimethylene and Tetramethylene.

Pentandria: P e n t a n d r i a "n. pl. A Linnaean class of plants having five separate stamens.

Pentandrian: P e n t a n d r i a n "a. Alt. of Pentandrous

Pentandrous: P e n t a n d r o u s "a. Of or pertaining to the class Pentadria; having five stamens.

Pentane: P e n t a n e "n. Any one of the three metameric hydrocarbons  C5H12 of the methane or paraffin series. They are colorless volatile liquids two of which occur in petroleum. So called because of the five carbon atoms in the molecule.

Pentangle: P e n t a n g l e "n. A pentagon.

Pentangular: P e n t a n g u l a r "a. Having five corners or angles.

Pentapetalous: P e n t a p e t a l o u s "a. Having five petals  or flower leaves.

Pentaphyllous: P e n t a p h y l l o u s "a. Having five leaves or leaflets.

Pentapody: P e n t a p o d y "n. A measure or series consisting of five feet.

Pentaptote: P e n t a p t o t e "n. A noun having five cases.

Pentaptych: P e n t a p t y c h "n. A picture  or combination of pictures consisting of a centerpiece and double folding doors or wings as for an altarpiece.

Pentarchy: P e n t a r c h y "n. A government in the hands of five persons; five joint rulers.

Pentaspast: P e n t a s p a s t "n. A purchase with five pulleys.

Pentaspermous: P e n t a s p e r m o u s "a. Containing five seeds.

Pentastich: P e n t a s t i c h "n. A composition consisting of five verses.

Pentastichous: P e n t a s t i c h o u s "a. Having  or arranged in five vertical ranks as the leaves of an apple tree or a cherry tree.

Pentastomida: P e n t a s t o m i d a "n. pl. Same as Linguatulina.

Pentastyle: P e n t a s t y l e "a. Having five columns in front; -- said of a temple or portico in classical architecture.

Pentastyle: P e n t a s t y l e "n. A portico having five columns.

Pentateuch: P e n t a t e u c h "n. The first five books of the Old Testament  collectively; -- called also the Law of Moses Book of the Law of Moses etc.

Pentateuchal: P e n t a t e u c h a l "a. Of or pertaining to the Pentateuch.

Pentathionic: P e n t a t h i o n i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating an acid of sulphur obtained by leading hydrogen sulphide into a solution of sulphur dioxide; -- so called because it contains five atoms of sulphur.

Pentathlon: P e n t a t h l o n "n. A fivefold athletic performance peculiar to the great national games of the Greeks  including leaping foot racing wrestling throwing the discus and throwing the spear.

Pentatomic: P e n t a t o m i c "a. Having five atoms in the molecule.

Pentatomic: P e n t a t o m i c "a. Having five hydrogen atoms capable of substitution.

Pentavalent: P e n t a v a l e n t "a. Having a valence of five; -- said of certain atoms and radicals.

Penteconter: P e n t e c o n t e r "n. A Grecian vessel with fifty oars.

Pentecost: P e n t e c o s t "n. A solemn festival of the Jews; -- so called because celebrated on the fiftieth day (seven weeks) after the second day of the Passover (which fell on the sixteenth of the Jewish month Nisan); -- hence called  also the Feast of Weeks. At this festival an offering of the first fruits of the harvest was made. By the Jews it was generally regarded as commemorative of the gift of the law on the fiftieth day after the departure from Egypt.

Pentecost: P e n t e c o s t "n. A festival of the Roman Catholic and other churches in commemoration of the descent of the Holy Spirit on the apostles; which occurred on the day of Pentecost; -- called also Whitsunday.

Pentecostal: P e n t e c o s t a l "a. Of or pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide.

Pentecostals: P e n t e c o s t a l s "n. pl. Offerings formerly made to the parish priest  or to the mother church at Pentecost.

Pentecoster: P e n t e c o s t e r "n. An officer in the Spartan army commanding fifty men.

Pentecosties: P e n t e c o s t i e s "pl. "of Pentecosty

Pentecosty: P e n t e c o s t y "n. A troop of fifty soldiers in the Spartan army; -- called also pentecostys.

Pentelic: P e n t e l i c "a. Alt. of Pentelican

Pentelican: P e n t e l i c a n "a. Of or pertaining to Mount Pentelicus  near Athens famous for its fine white marble quarries; obtained from Mount Pentelicus; as the Pentelic marble of which the Parthenon is built.

Pentene: P e n t e n e "n. Same as Amylene.

Penthouse: P e n t h o u s e "n. A shed or roof sloping from the main wall or building  as over a door or window; a lean-to. Also figuratively.

Penthouse: P e n t h o u s e "a. Leaning; overhanging.

Pentice: P e n t i c e "n. A penthouse.

Pentile: P e n t i l e "n. See Pantile.

Pentine: P e n t i n e "n. An unsaturated hydrocarbon  C5H8 of the acetylene series. Same as Valerylene.

Pentoic: P e n t o i c "a. Pertaining to  or desingating an acid (called also valeric acid) derived from pentane.

Pentone: P e n t o n e "n. Same as Valylene.

Pentoxide: P e n t o x i d e "n. An oxide containing five atoms of oxygen in each molecule; as  phosphorus pentoxide P2O5.

Pentremite: P e n t r e m i t e "n. Any species of Pentremites.

Pentremites: P e n t r e m i t e s "n. A genus of crinoids belonging to the Blastoidea. They have five petal-like ambulacra.

Pentroof: P e n t r o o f "n. See Lean-to.

Pentrough: P e n t r o u g h "n. A penstock.

Pentyl: P e n t y l "n. The hypothetical radical  C5H11 of pentane and certain of its derivatives. Same as Amyl.

Pentylic: P e n t y l i c "a. Pertaining to  derived from or containing pentyl; as pentylic alcohol

Penuchle: P e n u c h l e "n. Alt. of Pinocle

Penult: P e n u l t "n. The last syllable but one of a word; the syllable preceding the final one.

Penultima: P e n u l t i m a "n. Same as Penult.

Penultimate: P e n u l t i m a t e "a. Last but one; as  the penultimate syllable the last syllable but one of a word.

Penultimate: P e n u l t i m a t e "n. The penult.

Penumbra: P e n u m b r a "n. An incomplete or partial shadow.

Penumbra: P e n u m b r a "n. The shadow cast  in an eclipse where the light is partly but not wholly cut off by the intervening body; the space of partial illumination between the umbra or perfect shadow on all sides and the full light.

Penumbra: P e n u m b r a "n. The part of a picture where the shade imperceptibly blends with the light.

Penumbrala: P e n u m b r a l a " Of or pertaining to a penumbra; resembling a penumbra; partially illuminated.

Penurious: P e n u r i o u s "a. Excessively sparing in the use of money; sordid; stingy; miserly.

Penurious: P e n u r i o u s "a. Not bountiful or liberal; scanty.

Penurious: P e n u r i o u s "a. Destitute of money; suffering extreme want.

Penury: P e n u r y "n. Absence of resources; want; privation; indigence; extreme poverty; destitution.

Penury: P e n u r y "n. Penuriousness; miserliness.

Penwiper: P e n w i p e r "n. A cloth  or other material for wiping off or cleaning ink from a pen.

Penwoman: P e n w o m a n "n. A female writer; an authoress.

Penwomen: P e n w o m e n "pl. "of Penwoman

Peon: P e o n "n. See Poon.

Peon: P e o n "n. A foot soldier; a policeman; also  an office attendant; a messenger.

Peon: P e o n "n. A day laborer; a servant; especially  in some of the Spanish American countries debtor held by his creditor in a form of qualified servitude to work out a debt.

Peon: P e o n "n. See 2d Pawn.

Peonage: P e o n a g e "n. The condition of a peon.

Peonies: P e o n i e s "pl. "of Peony

Peonism: P e o n i s m "n. Same as Peonage.

Peony: P e o n y "n. A plant  and its flower of the ranunculaceous genus Paeonia. Of the four or five species one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers often double in cultivation.

People: P e o p l e "n. The body of persons who compose a community  tribe nation or race; an aggregate of individuals forming a whole; a community; a nation.

People: P e o p l e "n. Persons  generally; an indefinite number of men and women; folks; population or part of population; as country people; -- sometimes used as an indefinite subject or verb like on in French and man in German; as people in adversity.

People: P e o p l e "n. The mass of comunity as distinguished from a special class; the commonalty; the populace; the vulgar; the common crowd; as  nobles and people.

People: P e o p l e "n. One's ancestors or family; kindred; relations; as  my people were English.

People: P e o p l e "n. One's subjects; fellow citizens; companions; followers.

People: P e o p l e "v. t. To stock with people or inhabitants; to fill as with people; to populate.

Peopled: P e o p l e d "imp. & p. p. of People

Peopled: P e o p l e d "a. Stocked with  or as with people; inhabited.

Peopleless: P e o p l e l e s s "a. Destitute of people.

Peopler: P e o p l e r "n. A settler; an inhabitant.

Peopling: P e o p l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of People

Peoplish: P e o p l i s h "a. Vulgar.

Peorias: P e o r i a s "n. pl. An Algonquin tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part of Illinois.

Pepastic: P e p a s t i c "a. & n. Same as Maturative.

Peperine: P e p e r i n e "n. Alt. of Peperino

Peperino: P e p e r i n o "n. A volcanic rock  formed by the cementing together of sand scoria cinders etc.

Peplis: P e p l i s "n. A genus of plants including water purslane.

Peplus: P e p l u s "n. An upper garment worn by Grecian and Roman women.

Peplus: P e p l u s "n. A kind of kerchief formerly worn by Englishwomen.

Pepo: P e p o "n. Any fleshy fruit with a firm rind  as a pumpkin melon or gourd. See Gourd.

Pepper: P e p p e r "n. A well-known  pungently aromatic condiment the dried berry either whole or powdered of the Piper nigrum.

Pepper: P e p p e r "n. The plant which yields pepper  an East Indian woody climber (Piper nigrum) with ovate leaves and apetalous flowers in spikes opposite the leaves. The berries are red when ripe. Also by extension any one of the several hundred species of the genus Piper widely dispersed throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of the earth.

Pepper: P e p p e r "n. Any plant of the genus Capsicum  and its fruit; red pepper; as the bell pepper.

Pepper: P e p p e r "v. t. To sprinkle or season with pepper.

Pepper: P e p p e r "v. t. Figuratively: To shower shot or other missiles  or blows upon; to pelt; to fill with shot or cover with bruises or wounds.

Pepper: P e p p e r "v. i. To fire numerous shots (at).

Pepper dulse: P e p p e r   d u l s e " A variety of edible seaweed (Laurencia pinnatifida) distinguished for its pungency.

Pepperbrand: P e p p e r b r a n d "n. See 1st Bunt.

Peppercorn: P e p p e r c o r n "n. A dried berry of the black pepper (Piper nigrum).

Peppercorn: P e p p e r c o r n "n. Anything insignificant; a particle.

Peppered: P e p p e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Pepper

Pepperer: P e p p e r e r "n. A grocer; -- formerly so called because he sold pepper.

Peppergrass: P e p p e r g r a s s "n. Any herb of the cruciferous genus Lepidium  especially the garden peppergrass or garden cress Lepidium sativum; -- called also pepperwort. All the species have a pungent flavor.

Peppergrass: P e p p e r g r a s s "n. The common pillwort of Europe (Pilularia globulifera). See Pillwort.

Pepperidge: P e p p e r i d g e "n. A North American tree (Nyssa multiflora) with very tough wood  handsome oval polished leaves and very acid berries -- the sour gum or common tupelo. See Tupelo.

Peppering: P e p p e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pepper

Peppering: P e p p e r i n g "a. Hot; pungent; peppery.

Peppermint: P e p p e r m i n t "n. An aromatic and pungent plant of the genus Mentha (M. piperita)  much used in medicine and confectionery.

Peppermint: P e p p e r m i n t "n. A volatile oil (oil of peppermint) distilled from the fresh herb; also  a well-known essence or spirit (essence of peppermint) obtained from it.

Peppermint: P e p p e r m i n t "n. A lozenge of sugar flavored with peppermint.

Pepperwort: P e p p e r w o r t "n. See Peppergrass.

Peppery: P e p p e r y "a. Of or pertaining to pepper; having the qualities of pepper; hot; pungent.

Peppery: P e p p e r y "a. Fig.: Hot-tempered; passionate; choleric.

Pepsin: P e p s i n "n. An unorganized proteolytic ferment or enzyme contained in the secretory glands of the stomach. In the gastric juice it is united with dilute hydrochloric acid (0.2 per cent  approximately) and the two together constitute the active portion of the digestive fluid. It is the active agent in the gastric juice of all animals.

Pepsinhydrochloric: P e p s i n h y d r o c h l o r i c "a. Same as Peptohydrochloric.

Pepsinogen: P e p s i n o g e n "n. The antecedent of the ferment pepsin. A substance contained in the form of granules in the peptic cells of the gastric glands. It is readily convertible into pepsin. Also called propepsin.

Peptic: P e p t i c "a. Relating to digestion; promoting digestion; digestive; as  peptic sauces.

Peptic: P e p t i c "a. Able to digest.

Peptic: P e p t i c "a. Pertaining to pepsin; resembling pepsin in its power of digesting or dissolving albuminous matter; containing or yielding pepsin  or a body of like properties; as the peptic glands.

Peptic: P e p t i c "n. An agent that promotes digestion.

Peptic: P e p t i c "n. The digestive organs.

Peptics: P e p t i c s "n. The science of digestion.

Peptogen: P e p t o g e n "n. A substance convertible into peptone.

Peptogenic: P e p t o g e n i c "a. Same as Peptogenous.

Peptogenous: P e p t o g e n o u s "a. Capable of yielding  or being converted into peptone.

Peptohydrochloric: P e p t o h y d r o c h l o r i c "a. Designating a hypothetical acid (called peptohydrochloric acid  pepsinhydrochloric acid and chloropeptic acid) which is supposed to be formed when pepsin and dilute (0.1-0.4 per cent) hydrochloric acid are mixed together.

Peptone: P e p t o n e "n. The soluble and diffusible substance or substances into which albuminous portions of the food are transformed by the action of the gastric and pancreatic juices. Peptones are also formed from albuminous matter by the action of boiling water and boiling dilute acids.

Peptone: P e p t o n e "n. Collectively  in a broader sense all the products resulting from the solution of albuminous matter in either gastric or pancreatic juice. In this case however intermediate products (albumose bodies) such as antialbumose hemialbumose etc. are mixed with the true peptones. Also termed albuminose.

Peptonize: P e p t o n i z e "v. t. To convert into peptone; to digest or dissolve by means of a proteolytic ferment; as  peptonized food.

Peptonoid: P e p t o n o i d "n. A substance related to peptone.

Peptonuria: P e p t o n u r i a "n. The presence of peptone  or a peptonelike body in the urine.

Peptotoxine: P e p t o t o x i n e "n. A toxic alkaloid found occasionally associated with the peptones formed from fibrin by pepsinhydrochloric acid.

Pequots: P e q u o t s "n. pl. A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited Eastern Connecticut.

Per: P e r "prep. Through; by means of; through the agency of; by; for; for each; as  per annum; per capita by heads or according to individuals; per curiam by the court; per se by itself of itself. Per is also sometimes used with English words.

Per-: P e r - " A prefix used to signify through  throughout by for or as an intensive as perhaps by hap or chance; perennial that lasts throughout the year; perforce through or by force; perfoliate perforate; perspicuous evident throughout or very evident; perplex literally to entangle very much.

Per-: P e r - " Originally  denoting that the element to the name of which it is prefixed in the respective compounds exercised its highest valence; now only that the element has a higher valence than in other similar compounds; thus barium peroxide is the highest oxide of barium; while nitrogen and manganese peroxides so-called are not the highest oxides of those elements.

Peract: P e r a c t "v. t. To go through with; to perform.

Peracute: P e r a c u t e "a. Very sharp; very violent; as  a peracute fever.

Peradventure: P e r a d v e n t u r e "adv. & conj. By chance; perhaps; it may be; if; supposing.

Peradventure: P e r a d v e n t u r e "n. Chance; hap; hence  doubt; question; as proved beyond peradventure.

Peraeopod: P e r a e o p o d "n. One of the thoracic legs of a crustacean. See Illust. of Crustacea.

Peragrate: P e r a g r a t e "v. t. To travel over or through.

Peragration: P e r a g r a t i o n "n. The act or state of passing through any space; as  the peragration of the moon in her monthly revolution.

Perambulate: P e r a m b u l a t e "v. t. To walk through or over; especially  to travel over for the purpose of surveying or examining; to inspect by traversing; specifically to inspect officially the boundaries of as of a town or parish by walking over the whole line.

Perambulate: P e r a m b u l a t e "v. i. To walk about; to ramble; to stroll; as  he perambulated in the park.

Perambulated: P e r a m b u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Perambulate

Perambulating: P e r a m b u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perambulate

Perambulation: P e r a m b u l a t i o n "n. The act of perambulating; traversing.

Perambulation: P e r a m b u l a t i o n "n. An annual survey of boundaries  as of town a parish a forest etc.

Perambulation: P e r a m b u l a t i o n "n. A district within which one is authorized to make a tour of inspection.

Perambulator: P e r a m b u l a t o r "n. One who perambulates.

Perambulator: P e r a m b u l a t o r "n. A surveyor's instrument for measuring distances. It consists of a wheel arranged to roll along over the ground  with an apparatus of clockwork and a dial plate upon which the distance traveled is shown by an index. See Odometer.

Perambulator: P e r a m b u l a t o r "n. A low carriage for a child  propelled by pushing.

Perameles: P e r a m e l e s "n. Any marsupial of the genus Perameles  which includes numerous species found in Australia. They somewhat resemble rabbits in size and form. See Illust. under Bandicoot.

Perbend: P e r b e n d "n. See Perpender.

Perbreak: P e r b r e a k "n. See Parbreak.

Perbromate: P e r b r o m a t e "n. A salt of perbromic acid.

Perbromic: P e r b r o m i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating the highest oxygen acid HBrO4 of bromine.

Perbromide: P e r b r o m i d e "n. A bromide having a higher proportion of bromine than any other bromide of the same substance or series.

Perca: P e r c a "n. A genus of fishes  including the fresh-water perch.

Percale: P e r c a l e "n. A fine cotton fabric  having a linen finish and often printed on one side -- used for women's and children's wear.

Percaline: P e r c a l i n e "n. A fine kind of French cotton goods  usually of one color.

Percarbide: P e r c a r b i d e "n. A compound containing a relatively large amount of carbon.

Percarburet: P e r c a r b u r e t "n. A percarbide.

Percarbureted: P e r c a r b u r e t e d "a. Combined with a relatively large amount of carbon.

Percase: P e r c a s e "adv. Perhaps; perchance.

Perce: P e r c e "v. t. To pierce.

Perceivable: P e r c e i v a b l e "a. Capable of being perceived; perceptible.

Perceivance: P e r c e i v a n c e "n. Power of perceiving.

Perceive: P e r c e i v e "v. t. To obtain knowledge of through the senses; to receive impressions from by means of the bodily organs; to take cognizance of the existence  character or identity of by means of the senses; to see hear or feel; as to perceive a distant ship; to perceive a discord.

Perceive: P e r c e i v e "v. t. To take intellectual cognizance of; to apprehend by the mind; to be convinced of by direct intuition; to note; to remark; to discern; to see; to understand.

Perceive: P e r c e i v e "v. t. To be affected of influented by.

Perceived: P e r c e i v e d "imp. & p. p. of Perceive

Perceiver: P e r c e i v e r "n. One who perceives (in any of the senses of the verb).

Perceiving: P e r c e i v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perceive

Percely: P e r c e l y "n. Parsley.

Percentage: P e r c e n t a g e "n. A certain rate per cent; the allowance  duty rate of interest discount or commission on a hundred.

Percept: P e r c e p t "n. That which is perceived.

Perceptibility: P e r c e p t i b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being perceptible; as  the perceptibility of light or color.

Perceptibility: P e r c e p t i b i l i t y "n. Perception.

Perceptible: P e r c e p t i b l e "a. Capable of being perceived; cognizable; discernible; perceivable.

Perception: P e r c e p t i o n "n. The act of perceiving; cognizance by the senses or intellect; apperhension by the bodily organs  or by the mind of what is presented to them; discernment; apperhension; cognition.

Perception: P e r c e p t i o n "n. The faculty of perceiving; the faculty  or peculiar part of man's constitution by which he has knowledge through the medium or instrumentality of the bodily organs; the act of apperhending material objects or qualities through the senses; -- distinguished from conception.

Perception: P e r c e p t i o n "n. The quality  state or capability of being affected by something external; sensation; sensibility.

Perception: P e r c e p t i o n "n. An idea; a notion.

Perceptive: P e r c e p t i v e "a. Of or pertaining to the act or power of perceiving; having the faculty or power of perceiving; used in perception.

Perceptivity: P e r c e p t i v i t y "n. The quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception.

Percesoces: P e r c e s o c e s "n. pl. An order of fishes including the gray mullets (Mugil)  the barracudas the silversides and other related fishes. So called from their relation both to perches and to pikes.

Perch: P e r c h "n. Any fresh-water fish of the genus Perca and of several other allied genera of the family Percidae  as the common American or yellow perch (Perca flavescens / Americana) and the European perch (P. fluviatilis).

Perch: P e r c h "n. Any one of numerous species of spiny-finned fishes belonging to the Percidae  Serranidae and related families and resembling more or less the true perches.

Perch: P e r c h "n. A pole; a long staff; a rod; esp.  a pole or other support for fowls to roost on or to rest on; a roost; figuratively any elevated resting place or seat.

Perch: P e r c h "n. A measure of length containing five and a half yards; a rod  or pole.

Perch: P e r c h "n. In land or square measure: A square rod; the 160th part of an acre.

Perch: P e r c h "n. In solid measure: A mass 16/ feet long  1 foot in height and 1/ feet in breadth or 24/ cubic feet (in local use from 22 to 25 cubic feet); -- used in measuring stonework.

Perch: P e r c h "n. A pole connecting the fore gear and hind gear of a spring carriage; a reach.

Perch: P e r c h "v. i. To alight or settle  as a bird; to sit or roost.

Perch: P e r c h "v. t. To place or to set on  or as on a perch.

Perch: P e r c h "v. t. To occupy as a perch.

Perchance: P e r c h a n c e "adv. By chance; perhaps; peradventure.

Perchant: P e r c h a n t "n. A bird tied by the foot  to serve as decoy to other birds by its fluttering.

Perched: P e r c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Perch

Percher: P e r c h e r "v. i. One who  or that which perches.

Percher: P e r c h e r "v. i. One of the Insessores.

Percher: P e r c h e r "v. i. A Paris candle anciently used in England; also  a large wax candle formerly set upon the altar.

Percheron: P e r c h e r o n "n. One of a breed of draught horses originating in Perche  an old district of France; -- called also Percheron-Norman.

Perching: P e r c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perch

Perchlorate: P e r c h l o r a t e "n. A salt of perchloric acid.

Perchloric: P e r c h l o r i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating the highest oxygen acid (HClO4) of chlorine; -- called also hyperchloric.

Perchloride: P e r c h l o r i d e "n. A chloride having a higher proportion of chlorine than any other chloride of the same substance or series.

Perchromic: P e r c h r o m i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating a certain one of the highly oxidized compounds of chromium which has a deep blue color and is produced by the action of hydrogen peroxide.

Perciform: P e r c i f o r m "a. Pertaining to the Perciformes.

Perciformes: P e r c i f o r m e s "n. pl. An extensive tribe or suborder of fishes  including the true perches (Percidae); the pondfishes (Centrarchidae); the sciaenoids (Sciaenidae); the sparoids (Sparidae); the serranoids (Serranidae) and some other related families.

Percipience: P e r c i p i e n c e "n. Alt. of Percipiency

Percipiency: P e r c i p i e n c y "n. The faculty  act or power of perceiving; perception.

Percipient: P e r c i p i e n t "a. Having the faculty of perception; perceiving; as  a percipient being.

Percipient: P e r c i p i e n t "n. One who  or that which is percipient.

Perclose: P e r c l o s e "n. Same as Parclose.

Perclose: P e r c l o s e "n. Conclusion; end.

Percoid: P e r c o i d "a. Belonging to  or resembling the perches or family Percidae.

Percoid: P e r c o i d "n. Any fish of the genus Perca  or allied genera of the family Percidae.

Percoidea: P e r c o i d e a "n. pl. Same as Perciformes.

Percolate: P e r c o l a t e "v. t. To cause to pass through fine interstices  as a liquor; to filter; to strain.

Percolate: P e r c o l a t e "v. i. To pass through fine interstices; to filter; as  water percolates through porous stone.

Percolated: P e r c o l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Percolate

Percolating: P e r c o l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Percolate

Percolation: P e r c o l a t i o n "n. The act or process of percolating  or filtering; filtration; straining. Specifically (Pharm.) the process of exhausting the virtues of a powdered drug by letting a liquid filter slowly through it.

Percolator: P e r c o l a t o r "n. One who  or that which filters.

Percomorphi: P e r c o m o r p h i "n. pl. A division of fishes including the perches and related kinds.

Perculaced: P e r c u l a c e d "a. Latticed. See Lattice  n. 2.

Percurrent: P e r c u r r e n t "a. Running through the entire length.

Percursory: P e r c u r s o r y "a. Running over slightly or in haste; cursory.

Percuss: P e r c u s s "v. t. To strike smartly; to strike upon or against; as  to percuss the chest in medical examination.

Percuss: P e r c u s s "v. i. To strike or tap in an examination by percussion. See Percussion  3.

Percussed: P e r c u s s e d "imp. & p. p. of Percuss

Percussing: P e r c u s s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Percuss

Percussion: P e r c u s s i o n "n. The act of percussing  or striking one body against another; forcible collision esp. such as gives a sound or report.

Percussion: P e r c u s s i o n "n. Hence: The effect of violent collision; vibratory shock; impression of sound on the ear.

Percussion: P e r c u s s i o n "n. The act of tapping or striking the surface of the body in order to learn the condition of the parts beneath by the sound emitted or the sensation imparted to the fingers. Percussion is said to be immediate if the blow is directly upon the body; if some interventing substance  as a pleximeter is used it is called mediate.

Percussive: P e r c u s s i v e "a. Striking against; percutient; as  percussive force.

Percutient: P e r c u t i e n t "a. Striking; having the power of striking.

Percutient: P e r c u t i e n t "n. That which strikes  or has power to strike.

Perdicine: P e r d i c i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the family Perdicidae  or partridges.

Perdie: P e r d i e "adv. See Parde.

Perdifoil: P e r d i f o i l "n. A deciduous plant; -- opposed to evergreen.

Perdition: P e r d i t i o n "n. Entire loss; utter destruction; ruin; esp.  the utter loss of the soul or of final happiness in a future state; future misery or eternal death.

Perdition: P e r d i t i o n "n. Loss of diminution.

Perditionable: P e r d i t i o n a b l e "a. Capable of being ruined; worthy of perdition.

Perdix: P e r d i x "n. A genus of birds including the common European partridge. Formerly the word was used in a much wider sense to include many allied genera.

Perdu: P e r d u "a. One placed on watch  or in ambush.

Perdu: P e r d u "a. A soldier sent on a forlorn hope.

Perdu: P e r d u "a. Alt. of Perdue

Perdue: P e r d u e "a. Lost to view; in concealment or ambush; close.

Perdue: P e r d u e "a. Accustomed to  or employed in desperate enterprises; hence reckless; hopeless.

Perduellion: P e r d u e l l i o n "n. Treason.

Perdulous: P e r d u l o u s "a. Lost; thrown away.

Perdurability: P e r d u r a b i l i t y "n. Durability; lastingness.

Perdurable: P e r d u r a b l e "n. Very durable; lasting; continuing long.

Perdurance: P e r d u r a n c e "n. Alt. of Perduration

Perduration: P e r d u r a t i o n "n. Long continuance.

Perdure: P e r d u r e "v. i. To last or endure for a long time; to be perdurable or lasting.

Perdy: P e r d y "adv. Truly. See Parde.

Pere: P e r e "n. A peer.

Peregal: P e r e g a l "a. Fully equal.

Peregrinate: P e r e g r i n a t e "v. i. To travel from place to place  or from one country to another; hence to sojourn in foreign countries.

Peregrinate: P e r e g r i n a t e "a. Having traveled; foreign.

Peregrination: P e r e g r i n a t i o n "n. A traveling from one country to another; a wandering; sojourn in foreign countries.

Peregrinator: P e r e g r i n a t o r "n. One who peregrinates; one who travels about.

Peregrine: P e r e g r i n e "a. Foreign; not native; extrinsic or from without; exotic.

Peregrine: P e r e g r i n e "n. The peregrine falcon.

Peregrinity: P e r e g r i n i t y "n. Foreignness; strangeness.

Peregrinity: P e r e g r i n i t y "n. Travel; wandering.

Perel: P e r e l "n. Apparel.

Perempt: P e r e m p t "v. t. To destroy; to defeat.

Peremption: P e r e m p t i o n "n. A quashing; a defeating.

Peremptorily: P e r e m p t o r i l y "adv. In a peremptory manner; absolutely; positively.

Peremptoriness: P e r e m p t o r i n e s s "n. The quality of being peremptory; positiveness.

Peremptory: P e r e m p t o r y "a. Precluding debate or expostulation; not admitting of question or appeal; positive; absolute; decisive; conclusive; final.

Peremptory: P e r e m p t o r y "a. Positive in opinion or judgment; decided; dictatorial; dogmatical.

Peremptory: P e r e m p t o r y "a. Firmly determined; unawed.

Perennial: P e r e n n i a l "a. ing or continuing through the year; as  perennial fountains.

Perennial: P e r e n n i a l "a. Continuing without cessation or intermission; perpetual; unceasing; never failing.

Perennial: P e r e n n i a l "a. Continuing more than two years; as  a perennial steam or root or plant.

Perennial: P e r e n n i a l "n. A perennial plant; a plant which lives or continues more than two years  whether it retains its leaves in winter or not.

Perennially: P e r e n n i a l l y "adv. In a perennial manner.

Perennibranchiata: P e r e n n i b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. Those Batrachia which retain their gills through life  as the menobranchus.

Perennibranchiate: P e r e n n i b r a n c h i a t e "a. Having branchae  or gills through life; -- said especially of certain Amphibia like the menobranchus. Opposed to caducibranchiate.

Perennibranchiate: P e r e n n i b r a n c h i a t e "a. Belonging to the Perennibranchiata.

Perennity: P e r e n n i t y "n. The quality of being perennial.

Pererration: P e r e r r a t i o n "n. A wandering  or rambling through various places.

Perfect: P e r f e c t "a. Brought to consummation or completeness; completed; not defective nor redundant; having all the properties or qualities requisite to its nature and kind; without flaw  fault or blemish; without error; mature; whole; pure; sound; right; correct.

Perfect: P e r f e c t "a. Well informed; certain; sure.

Perfect: P e r f e c t "a. Hermaphrodite; having both stamens and pistils; -- said of flower.

Perfect: P e r f e c t "n. The perfect tense  or a form in that tense.

Perfect: P e r f e c t "a. To make perfect; to finish or complete  so as to leave nothing wanting; to give to anything all that is requisite to its nature and kind.

Perfected: P e r f e c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Perfect

Perfecter: P e r f e c t e r "n. One who  or that which makes perfect.

Perfectibilian: P e r f e c t i b i l i a n "n. A perfectionist.

Perfectibilist: P e r f e c t i b i l i s t "n. A perfectionist. See also Illuminati  2.

Perfectibility: P e r f e c t i b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being perfectible.

Perfectible: P e r f e c t i b l e "a. Capable of becoming  or being made perfect.

Perfecting: P e r f e c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perfect

Perfection: P e r f e c t i o n "n. The quality or state of being perfect or complete  so that nothing requisite is wanting; entire development; consummate culture skill or moral excellence; the highest attainable state or degree of excellence; maturity; as perfection in an art in a science or in a system; perfection in form or degree; fruits in perfection.

Perfection: P e r f e c t i o n "n. A quality  endowment or acquirement completely excellent; an ideal faultlessness; especially the divine attribute of complete excellence.

Perfection: P e r f e c t i o n "v. t. To perfect.

Perfectional: P e r f e c t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to perfection; characterized by perfection.

Perfectionate: P e r f e c t i o n a t e "v. t. To perfect.

Perfectionism: P e r f e c t i o n i s m "n. The doctrine of the Perfectionists.

Perfectionist: P e r f e c t i o n i s t "n. One pretending to perfection; esp.  one pretending to moral perfection; one who believes that persons may and do attain to moral perfection and sinlessness in this life.

Perfectionment: P e r f e c t i o n m e n t "n. The act of bringing to perfection  or the state of having attained to perfection.

Perfective: P e r f e c t i v e "a. Tending or conducing to make perfect  or to bring to perfection; -- usually followed by of.

Perfectively: P e r f e c t i v e l y "adv. In a perfective manner.

Perfectly: P e r f e c t l y "adv. In a perfect manner or degree; in or to perfection; completely; wholly; throughly; faultlessly.

Perfectness: P e r f e c t n e s s "n. The quality or state of being perfect; perfection.

Perfervid: P e r f e r v i d "a. Very fervid; too fervid; glowing; ardent.

Perficient: P e r f i c i e n t "a. Making or doing throughly; efficient; effectual.

Perficient: P e r f i c i e n t "n. One who performs or perfects a work; especially  one who endows a charity.

Perfidies: P e r f i d i e s "pl. "of Perfidy

Perfidious: P e r f i d i o u s "a. Guilty of perfidy; violating good faith or vows; false to trust or confidence reposed; teacherous; faithless; as  a perfidious friend.

Perfidious: P e r f i d i o u s "a. Involving  or characterized by perfidy.

Perfidiously: P e r f i d i o u s l y "adv. In a perfidious manner.

Perfidiousness: P e r f i d i o u s n e s s "n. The quality of being perfidious; perfidy.

Perfidy: P e r f i d y "n. The act of violating faith or allegiance; violation of a promise or vow  or of trust reposed; faithlessness; treachery.

Perfit: P e r f i t "a. Perfect.

Perfix: P e r f i x "v. t. To fix surely; to appoint.

Perflable: P e r f l a b l e "a. Capable of being blown through.

Perflate: P e r f l a t e "v. t. To blow through.

Perflation: P e r f l a t i o n "n. The act of perflating.

Perfoliate: P e r f o l i a t e "a. Having the basal part produced around the stem; -- said of leaves which the stem apparently passes directory through.

Perfoliate: P e r f o l i a t e "a. Surrounded by a circle of hairs  or projections of any kind.

Perforata: P e r f o r a t a "n. pl. A division of corals including those that have a porous texture  as Porites and Madrepora; -- opposed to Aporosa.

Perforata: P e r f o r a t a "n. pl. A division of Foraminifera  including those having perforated shells.

Perforate: P e r f o r a t e "v. To bore through; to pierce through with a pointed instrument; to make a hole or holes through by boring or piercing; to pierce or penetrate the surface of.

Perforate: P e r f o r a t e "a. Alt. of Perforated

Perforated: P e r f o r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Perforate

Perforated: P e r f o r a t e d "a. Pierced with a hole or holes  or with pores; having transparent dots resembling holes.

Perforating: P e r f o r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perforate

Perforation: P e r f o r a t i o n "n. The act of perforating  or of boring or piercing through.

Perforation: P e r f o r a t i o n "n. A hole made by boring or piercing; an aperture.

Perforative: P e r f o r a t i v e "a. Having power to perforate or pierce.

Perforator: P e r f o r a t o r "n. One who  or that which perforates; esp. a cephalotome.

Perforce: P e r f o r c e "adv. By force; of necessary; at any rate.

Perforce: P e r f o r c e "v. t. To force; to compel.

Perform: P e r f o r m "v. t. To carry through; to bring to completion; to achieve; to accomplish; to execute; to do.

Perform: P e r f o r m "v. t. To discharge; to fulfill; to act up to; as  to perform a duty; to perform a promise or a vow.

Perform: P e r f o r m "v. t. To represent; to act; to play; as in drama.

Perform: P e r f o r m "v. i. To do  execute or accomplish something; to acquit one's self in any business; esp. to represent sometimes by action; to act a part; to play on a musical instrument; as the players perform poorly; the musician performs on the organ.

Performable: P e r f o r m a b l e "a. Admitting of being performed  done or executed; practicable.

Performance: P e r f o r m a n c e "n. The act of performing; the carrying into execution or action; execution; achievement; accomplishment; representation by action; as  the performance of an undertaking of a duty.

Performance: P e r f o r m a n c e "n. That which is performed or accomplished; a thing done or carried through; an achievement; a deed; an act; a feat; esp.  an action of an elaborate or public character.

Performed: P e r f o r m e d "imp. & p. p. of Perform

Performer: P e r f o r m e r "n. One who performs  accomplishes or fulfills; as a good promiser but a bad performer; especially one who shows skill and training in any art; as a performer of the drama; a performer on the harp.

Performing: P e r f o r m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perform

Perfricate: P e r f r i c a t e "v. t. To rub over.

Perfumatory: P e r f u m a t o r y "a. Emitting perfume; perfuming.

Perfume: P e r f u m e "v. t. To fill or impregnate with a perfume; to scent.

Perfume: P e r f u m e "v. The scent  odor or odoriferous particles emitted from a sweet-smelling substance; a pleasant odor; fragrance; aroma.

Perfume: P e r f u m e "v. A substance that emits an agreeable odor.

Perfumed: P e r f u m e d "imp. & p. p. of Perfume

Perfumer: P e r f u m e r "n. One who  oe that which perfumes.

Perfumer: P e r f u m e r "n. One whose trade is to make or sell perfumes.

Perfumery: P e r f u m e r y "n. Perfumes  in general.

Perfumery: P e r f u m e r y "n. The art of preparing perfumes.

Perfuming: P e r f u m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perfume

Perfunctorily: P e r f u n c t o r i l y "adv. In a perfunctory manner; formally; carelessly.

Perfunctoriness: P e r f u n c t o r i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being perfunctory.

Perfunctory: P e r f u n c t o r y "a. Done merely to get rid of a duty; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote; done in a careless and superficial manner; characterized by indifference; as  perfunctory admonitions.

Perfunctory: P e r f u n c t o r y "a. Hence: Mechanical; indifferent; listless; careless.

Perfuncturate: P e r f u n c t u r a t e "v. t. To perform in a perfunctory manner; to do negligently.

Perfuse: P e r f u s e "v. t. To suffuse; to fill full or to excess.
