Perfusion: P e r f u s i o n "n. The act of perfusing.

Perfusive: P e r f u s i v e "a. Of a nature to flow over  or to spread through.

Pergamenous: P e r g a m e n o u s "a. Alt. of Pergamentaceous

Pergamentaceous: P e r g a m e n t a c e o u s "a. Like parchment.

Perhaps: P e r h a p s "adv. By chance; peradventure; perchance; it may be.

Peri: P e r i "n. An imaginary being  male or female like an elf or fairy represented as a descendant of fallen angels excluded from paradise till penance is accomplished.

Peri-: P e r i - " A prefix used to signify around  by near over beyond or to give an intensive sense; as perimeter the measure around; perigee point near the earth; periergy work beyond what is needed; perispherical quite spherical.

Periagua: P e r i a g u a "n. See Pirogue.

Perianth: P e r i a n t h "n. The leaves of a flower generally  especially when the calyx and corolla are not readily distinguished.

Perianth: P e r i a n t h "n. A saclike involucre which incloses the young fruit in most hepatic mosses. See Illust. of Hepatica.

Perianthium: P e r i a n t h i u m "n. The perianth.

Periapt: P e r i a p t "n. A charm worn as a protection against disease or mischief; an amulet.

Periastral: P e r i a s t r a l "a. Among or around the stars.

Periastron: P e r i a s t r o n "n. That point  in the real or apparent orbit of one star revolving around another at which the former is nearest to the latter.

Periauger: P e r i a u g e r "n. See Pirogue.

Periblast: P e r i b l a s t "a. The protoplasmic matter which surrounds the entoblast  or cell nucleus and undergoes segmentation.

Periblem: P e r i b l e m "n. Nascent cortex  or immature cellular bark.

Peribolos: P e r i b o l o s "n. In ancient architecture  an inclosed court esp. one surrounding a temple.

Peribranchial: P e r i b r a n c h i a l "a. Surrounding the branchiae; as  a peribranchial cavity.

Peribranchial: P e r i b r a n c h i a l "a. Around the bronchi or bronchial tubes; as  the peribronchial lymphatics.

Pericambium: P e r i c a m b i u m "n. A layer of thin-walled young cells in a growing stem  in which layer certain new vessels originate.

Pericardiac: P e r i c a r d i a c "a. Alt. of Pericardial

Pericardial: P e r i c a r d i a l "a. Of or pertaining to pericardium; situated around the heart.

Pericardian: P e r i c a r d i a n "a. Pericardiac.

Pericardic: P e r i c a r d i c "a. Pericardiac.

Pericarditus: P e r i c a r d i t u s "n. Inflammation of the pericardium.

Pericardium: P e r i c a r d i u m "n. The double baglike fold of serous membrane which incloses the heart.

Pericarp: P e r i c a r p "n. The ripened ovary; the walls of the fruit. See Illusts. of Capsule  Drupe and Legume.

Pericarpial: P e r i c a r p i a l "a. Alt. of Pericarpic

Pericarpic: P e r i c a r p i c "a. Of or pertaining to a pericarp.

Pericellular: P e r i c e l l u l a r "a. Surrounding a cell; as  the pericellular lymph spaces surrounding ganglion cells.

Perichaeth: P e r i c h a e t h "n. The leafy involucre surrounding the fruit stalk of mosses; perichaetium; perichete.

Perichaetia: P e r i c h a e t i a "pl. "of Perichaetium

Perichaetial: P e r i c h a e t i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the perichaeth.

Perichaetium: P e r i c h a e t i u m "n. Same as Perichaeth.

Perichaetous: P e r i c h a e t o u s "a. Surrounded by setae; -- said of certain earthworms (genus Perichaetus).

Perichete: P e r i c h e t e "n. Same as Perichaeth.

Perichondrial: P e r i c h o n d r i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the perichondrium; situated around cartilage.

Perichondritis: P e r i c h o n d r i t i s "n. Inflammation of the perichondrium.

Perichondrium: P e r i c h o n d r i u m "n. The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests cartilage  except where covering articular surfaces.

Perichordal: P e r i c h o r d a l "a. Around the notochord; as  a perichordal column. See Epichordal.

Periclase: P e r i c l a s e "n. Alt. of Periclasite

Periclasite: P e r i c l a s i t e "n. A grayish or dark green mineral  consisting essentially of magnesia (magnesium oxide) occurring in granular forms or in isometric crystals.

Periclinia: P e r i c l i n i a "pl. "of Periclinium

Periclinium: P e r i c l i n i u m "n. The involucre which surrounds the common receptacle in composite flowers.

Periclitate: P e r i c l i t a t e "v. t. To endanger.

Periclitation: P e r i c l i t a t i o n "n. Trial; experiment.

Periclitation: P e r i c l i t a t i o n "n. The state of being in peril.

Pericope: P e r i c o p e "n. A selection or extract from a book; especially (Theol.)  a selection from the Bible appointed to be read in the churches or used as a text for a sermon.

Pericranial: P e r i c r a n i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the pericranium.

Pericranium: P e r i c r a n i u m "n. The periosteum which covers the cranium externally; the region around the cranium.

Pericula: P e r i c u l a "pl. "of Periculum

Periculous: P e r i c u l o u s "a. Dangerous; full of peril.

Periculum: P e r i c u l u m "n. Danger; risk.

Periculum: P e r i c u l u m "n. In a narrower  judicial sense: Accident or casus as distinguished from dolus and culpa and hence relieving one from the duty of performing an obligation.

Periderm: P e r i d e r m "n. The outer layer of bark.

Periderm: P e r i d e r m "n. The hard outer covering of hydroids and other marine animals; the perisarc.

Peridia: P e r i d i a "pl. "of Peridium

Peridiastole: P e r i d i a s t o l e "n. The almost inappreciable time which elapses between the systole and the diastole of the heart.

Peridium: P e r i d i u m "n. The envelope or coat of certain fungi  such as the puffballs and earthstars.

Peridot: P e r i d o t "n. Chrysolite.

Peridotite: P e r i d o t i t e "n. An eruptive rock characterized by the presence of chrysolite (peridot). It also usually contains pyroxene  enstatite chromite etc. It is often altered to serpentine.

Peridrome: P e r i d r o m e "n. The space between the columns and the wall of the cella  in a Greek or a Roman temple.

Periecians: P e r i e c i a n s "n. pl. See Perioecians.

Perienteron: P e r i e n t e r o n "n. The primitive perivisceral cavity.

Periergy: P e r i e r g y "n. Excessive care or diligence.

Periergy: P e r i e r g y "n. A bombastic or labored style.

Periganglionic: P e r i g a n g l i o n i c "a. Surrounding a ganglion; as  the periganglionic glands of the frog.

Perigastric: P e r i g a s t r i c "a. Surrounding the stomach; -- applied to the body cavity of Bryozoa and various other Invertebrata.

Perigean: P e r i g e a n "a. Pertaining to the perigee.

Perigee: P e r i g e e "n. Alt. of Perigeum

Perigenesis: P e r i g e n e s i s "n. A theory which explains inheritance by the transmission of the type of growth force possessed by one generation to another.

Perigenetic: P e r i g e n e t i c "a. Of or pertaining to perigenesis.

Perigeum: P e r i g e u m "n. That point in the orbit of the moon which is nearest to the earth; -- opposed to apogee. It is sometimes  but rarely used of the nearest points of other orbits as of a comet a planet etc. Called also epigee epigeum.

Perigone: P e r i g o n e "n. Any organ inclosing the essential organs of a flower; a perianth.

Perigone: P e r i g o n e "n. In mosses  the involucral bracts of a male flower.

Perigone: P e r i g o n e "n. A sac which surrounds the generative bodies in the gonophore of a hydroid.

Perigonia: P e r i g o n i a "pl. "of Perigonium

Perigonium: P e r i g o n i u m "n. Same as Perigone.

Perigord pie: P e r i g o r d   p i e " A pie made of truffles  much esteemed by epicures.

Perigraph: P e r i g r a p h "n. A careless or inaccurate delineation of anything.

Perigynia: P e r i g y n i a "pl. "of Perigynium

Perigynium: P e r i g y n i u m "n. Some unusual appendage about the pistil  as the bottle-shaped body in the sedges and the bristles or scales in some other genera of the Sedge family or Cyperaceae.

Perigynous: P e r i g y n o u s "a. Having the ovary free  but the petals and stamens borne on the calyx; -- said of flower such as that of the cherry or peach.

Perihelia: P e r i h e l i a "pl. "of Perihelium

Perihelion: P e r i h e l i o n "n. Alt. of Perihelium

Perihelium: P e r i h e l i u m "n. That point of the orbit of a planet or comet which is nearest to the sun; -- opposed to aphelion.

Peril: P e r i l "n. Danger; risk; hazard; jeopardy; exposure of person or property to injury  loss or destruction.

Peril: P e r i l "v. t. To expose to danger; to hazard; to risk; as  to peril one's life.

Peril: P e r i l "v. i. To be in danger.

Periled: P e r i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Peril

Periling: P e r i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peril

Perilla: P e r i l l a "n. A genus of labiate herbs  of which one species (Perilla ocimoides or P. Nankinensis) is often cultivated for its purple or variegated foliage.

Perilled: P e r i l l e d " of Peril

Perilling: P e r i l l i n g " of Peril

Perilous: P e r i l o u s "a. Full of  attended with or involving peril; dangerous; hazardous; as a perilous undertaking.

Perilous: P e r i l o u s "a. Daring; reckless; dangerous.

Perilymph: P e r i l y m p h "n. The fluid which surrounds the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear  and separates it from the walls of the chambers in which the labyrinth lies.

Perilymphangial: P e r i l y m p h a n g i a l "a. Around  or at the side of a lymphatic vessel.

Perilymphatic: P e r i l y m p h a t i c "a. Pertaining to  or containing perilymph.

Perilymphatic: P e r i l y m p h a t i c "a. Perilymphangial.

Perimeter: P e r i m e t e r "n. The outer boundary of a body or figure  or the sum of all the sides.

Perimeter: P e r i m e t e r "n. An instrument for determining the extent and shape of the field of vision.

Perimetric: P e r i m e t r i c "a. Alt. of Perimetrical

Perimetrical: P e r i m e t r i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the perimeter  or to perimetry; as a perimetric chart of the eye.

Perimetry: P e r i m e t r y "n. The art of using the perimeter; measurement of the field of vision.

Perimorph: P e r i m o r p h "n. A crystal of one species inclosing one of another species. See Endomorph.

Perimysial: P e r i m y s i a l "a. Surrounding a muscle or muscles.

Perimysial: P e r i m y s i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the perimysium.

Perimysium: P e r i m y s i u m "n. The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle  and sends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers.

Perinaeum: P e r i n a e u m "n. See Perineum.

Perineal: P e r i n e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the perineum.

Perineoplasty: P e r i n e o p l a s t y "n. The act or process of restoring an injured perineum.

Perineorrhaphy: P e r i n e o r r h a p h y "n. The operation of sewing up a ruptured perineum.

Perinephritis: P e r i n e p h r i t i s "n. Inflammation of the cellular tissue around the kidney.

Perineum: P e r i n e u m "n. The region which is included within the outlet of the pelvis  and is traversed by the urinogenital canal and the rectum.

Perineurial: P e r i n e u r i a l "a. Surrounding nerves or nerve fibers; of or pertaining to the perineurium.

Perineurium: P e r i n e u r i u m "n. The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a bundle of nerve fibers. See Epineurium  and Neurilemma.

Perinuclear: P e r i n u c l e a r "a. Of or pertaining to a nucleus; situated around a nucleus; as  the perinuclear protoplasm.

Period: P e r i o d "n. A portion of time as limited and determined by some recurring phenomenon  as by the completion of a revolution of one of the heavenly bodies; a division of time as a series of years months or days in which something is completed and ready to recommence and go on in the same order; as the period of the sun or the earth or a comet.

Period: P e r i o d "n. A stated and recurring interval of time; more generally  an interval of time specified or left indefinite; a certain series of years months days or the like; a time; a cycle; an age; an epoch; as the period of the Roman republic.

Period: P e r i o d "n. One of the great divisions of geological time; as  the Tertiary period; the Glacial period. See the Chart of Geology.

Period: P e r i o d "n. The termination or completion of a revolution  cycle series of events single event or act; hence a limit; a bound; an end; a conclusion.

Period: P e r i o d "n. A complete sentence  from one full stop to another; esp. a well-proportioned harmonious sentence.

Period: P e r i o d "n. The punctuation point [.] that marks the end of a complete sentence  or of an abbreviated word.

Period: P e r i o d "n. One of several similar sets of figures or terms usually marked by points or commas placed at regular intervals  as in numeration in the extraction of roots and in circulating decimals.

Period: P e r i o d "n. The time of the exacerbation and remission of a disease  or of the paroxysm and intermission.

Period: P e r i o d "n. A complete musical sentence.

Period: P e r i o d "v. t. To put an end to.

Period: P e r i o d "v. i. To come to a period; to conclude. [Obs.] You may period upon this  that  etc.

Periodate: P e r i o d a t e "n. A salt of periodic acid.

Periodic: P e r i o d i c "a. Pertaining to  derived from or designating the highest oxygen acid (HIO/) of iodine.

Periodic: P e r i o d i c "a. Alt. of Periodical

Periodical: P e r i o d i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a period or periods  or to division by periods.

Periodical: P e r i o d i c a l "a. Performed in a period  or regular revolution; proceeding in a series of successive circuits; as the periodical motion of the planets round the sun.

Periodical: P e r i o d i c a l "a. Happening  by revolution at a stated time; returning regularly after a certain period of time; acting happening or appearing at fixed intervals; recurring; as periodical epidemics.

Periodical: P e r i o d i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a period; constituting a complete sentence.

Periodical: P e r i o d i c a l "n. A magazine or other publication which appears at stated or regular intervals.

Periodicalist: P e r i o d i c a l i s t "n. One who publishes  or writes for a periodical.

Periodically: P e r i o d i c a l l y "adv. In a periodical manner.

Periodicalness: P e r i o d i c a l n e s s "n. Periodicity.

Periodicities: P e r i o d i c i t i e s "pl. "of Periodicity

Periodicity: P e r i o d i c i t y "n. The quality or state of being periodical  or regularly recurrent; as the periodicity in the vital phenomena of plants.

Periodide: P e r i o d i d e "n. An iodide containing a higher proportion of iodine than any other iodide of the same substance or series.

Periodontal: P e r i o d o n t a l "a. Surrounding the teeth.

Periodoscope: P e r i o d o s c o p e "n. A table or other means for calculating the periodical functions of women.

Perioeci: P e r i o e c i "n. pl. Alt. of Perioecians

Perioecians: P e r i o e c i a n s "n. pl. Those who live on the same parallel of latitude but on opposite meridians  so that it is noon in one place when it is midnight in the other. Compare Antoeci.

Periople: P e r i o p l e "n. The external smooth horny layer of the hoof of the horse and allied animals.

Perioplic: P e r i o p l i c "a. Of or pertaining to the periople; connected with the periople.

Periosteal: P e r i o s t e a l "a. Situated around bone; of or pertaining to the periosteum.

Periosteum: P e r i o s t e u m "n. The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests all bones except at the articular surfaces.

Periostitis: P e r i o s t i t i s "n. Inflammation of the periosteum.

Periostraca: P e r i o s t r a c a "pl. "of Periostracum

Periostracum: P e r i o s t r a c u m "n. A chitinous membrane covering the exterior of many shells; -- called also epidermis.

Periotic: P e r i o t i c "a. Surrounding  or pertaining to the region surrounding the internal ear; as the periotic capsule.

Periotic: P e r i o t i c "n. A periotic bone.

Peripatecian: P e r i p a t e c i a n "n. A peripatetic.

Peripatetic: P e r i p a t e t i c "a. Walking about; itinerant.

Peripatetic: P e r i p a t e t i c "a. Of or pertaining to the philosophy taught by Aristotle (who gave his instructions while walking in the Lyceum at Athens)  or to his followers.

Peripatetic: P e r i p a t e t i c "n. One who walks about; a pedestrian; an itinerant.

Peripatetic: P e r i p a t e t i c "n. A disciple of Aristotle; an Aristotelian.

Peripatetical: P e r i p a t e t i c a l "a. Peripatetic.

Peripateticism: P e r i p a t e t i c i s m "n. The doctrines or philosophical system of the peripatetics. See Peripatetic  n. 2.

Peripatus: P e r i p a t u s "n. A genus of lowly organized arthropods  found in South Africa Australia and tropical America. It constitutes the order Malacopoda.

Peripetalous: P e r i p e t a l o u s "a. Surrounding  or situated about the petals.

Peripheral: P e r i p h e r a l "a. Of or pertaining to a periphery; constituting a periphery; peripheric.

Peripheral: P e r i p h e r a l "a. External; away from the center; as  the peripheral portion of the nervous system.

Peripheric: P e r i p h e r i c "a. Alt. of Peripherical

Peripherical: P e r i p h e r i c a l "a. See Peripheral.

Peripheries: P e r i p h e r i e s "pl. "of Periphery

Periphery: P e r i p h e r y "n. The outside or superficial portions of a body; the surface.

Periphery: P e r i p h e r y "n. The circumference of a circle  ellipse or other figure.

Periphrase: P e r i p h r a s e "n. The use of more words than are necessary to express the idea; a roundabout  or indirect way of speaking; circumlocution.

Periphrase: P e r i p h r a s e "v. t. To express by periphrase or circumlocution.

Periphrase: P e r i p h r a s e "v. i. To use circumlocution.

Periphrased: P e r i p h r a s e d "imp. & p. p. of Periphrase

Periphrases: P e r i p h r a s e s "pl. "of Periphrasis

Periphrasing: P e r i p h r a s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Periphrase

Periphrasis: P e r i p h r a s i s "n. See Periphrase.

Periphrastic: P e r i p h r a s t i c "a. Alt. of Periphrastical

Periphrastical: P e r i p h r a s t i c a l "a. Expressing  or expressed in more words than are necessary; characterized by periphrase; circumlocutory.

Periphrastically: P e r i p h r a s t i c a l l y "adv. With circumlocution.

Periplast: P e r i p l a s t "n. Same as Periblast.

Peripneumonia: P e r i p n e u m o n i a "n. Alt. of Peripneumony

Peripneumonic: P e r i p n e u m o n i c "a. Of or pertaining to peripneumonia.

Peripneumony: P e r i p n e u m o n y "n. Pneumonia.

Periproct: P e r i p r o c t "n. The region surrounding the anus  particularly of echinoderms.

Periproctitis: P e r i p r o c t i t i s "n. Inflammation of the tissues about the rectum.

Peripteral: P e r i p t e r a l "a. Having columns on all sides; -- said of an edifice. See Apteral.

Peripterous: P e r i p t e r o u s "a. Peripteral.

Peripterous: P e r i p t e r o u s "a. Feathered all around.

Peris: P e r i s "pl. "of Peri

Perisarc: P e r i s a r c "n. The outer  hardened integument which covers most hydroids.

Periscian: P e r i s c i a n "a. Having the shadow moving all around.

Periscians: P e r i s c i a n s "n. pl. Alt. of Periscii

Periscii: P e r i s c i i "n. pl. Those who live within a polar circle  whose shadows during some summer days will move entirely round falling toward every point of the compass.

Periscope: P e r i s c o p e "n. A general or comprehensive view.

Periscope: P e r i s c o p e "n. an optical instrument of tubular shape containing an arrangement of lenses and mirrors (or prisms)  allowing a person to observe a field of view otherwise obstructed as beyond an obstructing object or (as in submarines) above the surface of the water.

Periscopic: P e r i s c o p i c "a. Viewing all around  or on all sides.

Periscopic: P e r i s c o p i c "a. of or relating to a periscope{2}.

Perish: P e r i s h "v. i. To be destroyed; to pass away; to become nothing; to be lost; to die; hence  to wither; to waste away.

Perish: P e r i s h "v. t. To cause perish.

Perishability: P e r i s h a b i l i t y "n. Perishableness.

Perishable: P e r i s h a b l e "a. Liable to perish; subject to decay  destruction or death; as perishable goods; our perishable bodies.

Perishableness: P e r i s h a b l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being perishable; liability to decay or destruction.

Perishably: P e r i s h a b l y "adv. In a perishable degree or manner.

Perished: P e r i s h e d "imp. & p. p. of Perish

Perishing: P e r i s h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perish

Perishment: P e r i s h m e n t "n. The act of perishing.

Perisoma: P e r i s o m a "n. Same as Perisome.

Perisomata: P e r i s o m a t a "pl. "of Perisoma

Perisome: P e r i s o m e "n. The entire covering of an invertebrate animal  as echinoderm or coelenterate; the integument.

Perisperm: P e r i s p e r m "n. The albumen of a seed  especially that portion which is formed outside of the embryo sac.

Perispheric: P e r i s p h e r i c "a. Alt. of Perispherical

Perispherical: P e r i s p h e r i c a l "a. Exactly spherical; globular.

Perispomena: P e r i s p o m e n a "pl. "of Perispomenon

Perispomenon: P e r i s p o m e n o n "n. A word which has the circumflex accent on the last syllable.

Perispore: P e r i s p o r e "n. The outer covering of a spore.

Perissad: P e r i s s a d "a. Odd; not even; -- said of elementary substances and of radicals whose valence is not divisible by two without a remainder. Contrasted with artiad.

Perisse: P e r i s s e "v. i. To perish.

Perissodactyl: P e r i s s o d a c t y l "n. One of the Perissodactyla.

Perissodactyla: P e r i s s o d a c t y l a "n. pl. A division of ungulate mammals  including those that have an odd number of toes as the horse tapir and rhinoceros; -- opposed to Artiodactyla.

Perissological: P e r i s s o l o g i c a l "a. Redundant or excessive in words.

Perissology: P e r i s s o l o g y "n. Superfluity of words.

Peristalsis: P e r i s t a l s i s "n. Peristaltic contraction or action.

Peristaltic: P e r i s t a l t i c "a. Applied to the peculiar wormlike wave motion of the intestines and other similar structures  produced by the successive contraction of the muscular fibers of their walls forcing their contents onwards; as peristaltic movement.

Peristeria: P e r i s t e r i a "n. A genus of orchidaceous plants. See Dove plant.

Peristerion: P e r i s t e r i o n "n. The herb vervain (Verbena officinalis).

Peristerite: P e r i s t e r i t e "n. A variety of albite  whitish and slightly iridescent like a pigeon's neck.

Peristeromorphous: P e r i s t e r o m o r p h o u s "a. Like or pertaining to the pigeons or Columbae.

Peristeropodous: P e r i s t e r o p o d o u s "a. Having pigeonlike feet; -- said of those gallinaceous birds that rest on all four toes  as the curassows and megapods.

Peristole: P e r i s t o l e "n. Peristaltic action  especially of the intestines.

Peristoma: P e r i s t o m a "n. Same as Peristome.

Peristomata: P e r i s t o m a t a "pl. "of Peristoma

Peristome: P e r i s t o m e "n. The fringe of teeth around the orifice of the capsule of mosses. It consists of 4 8 16 32 or 64 teeth and may be either single or double.

Peristome: P e r i s t o m e "n. The lip  or edge of the aperture of a spiral shell.

Peristome: P e r i s t o m e "n. The membrane surrounding the mouth of an invertebrate animal.

Peristomial: P e r i s t o m i a l "a. Of or pertaining to a peristome.

Peristomium: P e r i s t o m i u m "n. Same as Peristome.

Peristrephic: P e r i s t r e p h i c "a. Turning around; rotatory; revolving; as  a peristrephic painting (of a panorama).

Peristyle: P e r i s t y l e "n. A range of columns with their entablature  etc.; specifically a complete system of columns whether on all sides of a court or surrounding a building such as the cella of a temple. Used in the former sense it gives name to the larger and inner court of a Roman dwelling the peristyle. See Colonnade.

Perisystole: P e r i s y s t o l e "n. The interval between the diastole and systole of the heart. It is perceptible only in the dying.

Perite: P e r i t e "a. Skilled.

Perithecium: P e r i t h e c i u m "n. An organ in certain fungi and lichens  surrounding and enveloping the masses of fructification.

Peritomous: P e r i t o m o u s "a. Cleaving in more directions than one  parallel to the axis.

Peritonaeum: P e r i t o n a e u m "n. Same as Peritoneum.

Peritoneal: P e r i t o n e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the peritoneum.

Peritoneum: P e r i t o n e u m "n. The smooth serous membrane which lines the cavity of the abdomen  or the whole body cavity when there is no diaphragm and turning back surrounds the viscera forming a closed or nearly closed sac.

Peritonitis: P e r i t o n i t i s "n. Inflammation of the peritoneum.

Peritracheal: P e r i t r a c h e a l "a. Surrounding the tracheae.

Peritreme: P e r i t r e m e "n. That part of the integument of an insect which surrounds the spiracles.

Peritreme: P e r i t r e m e "n. The edge of the aperture of a univalve shell.

Peritricha: P e r i t r i c h a "n. pl. A division of ciliated Infusoria having a circle of cilia around the oral disk and sometimes another around the body. It includes the vorticellas. See Vorticella.

Peritrochium: P e r i t r o c h i u m "n. The wheel which  together with the axle forms the axis in peritrochio which see under Axis.

Peritropal: P e r i t r o p a l "a. Rotatory; circuitous.

Peritropal: P e r i t r o p a l "a. Having the axis of the seed perpendicular to the axis of the pericarp to which it is attached.

Peritropous: P e r i t r o p o u s "a. Peritropal.

Perityphlitis: P e r i t y p h l i t i s "n. Inflammation of the connective tissue about the caecum.

Periuterine: P e r i u t e r i n e "a. Surrounding the uterus.

Perivascular: P e r i v a s c u l a r "a. Around the blood vessels; as  perivascular lymphatics.

Perivertebral: P e r i v e r t e b r a l "a. Surrounding the vertebrae.

Perivisceral: P e r i v i s c e r a l "a. Around the viscera; as  the perivisceral cavity.

Perivitelline: P e r i v i t e l l i n e "a. Situated around the vitellus  or between the vitellus and zona pellucida of an ovum.

Periwig: P e r i w i g "n. A headdress of false hair  usually covering the whole head and representing the natural hair; a wig.

Periwig: P e r i w i g "v. t. To dress with a periwig  or with false hair.

Periwinkle: P e r i w i n k l e "n. Any small marine gastropod shell of the genus Littorina. The common European species (Littorina littorea)  in Europe extensively used as food has recently become naturalized abundantly on the American coast. See Littorina.

Periwinkle: P e r i w i n k l e "n. A trailing herb of the genus Vinca.

Perjenet: P e r j e n e t "n. A kind of pear.

Perjure: P e r j u r e "v. t. To cause to violate an oath or a vow; to cause to make oath knowingly to what is untrue; to make guilty of perjury; to forswear; to corrupt; -- often used reflexively; as  he perjured himself.

Perjure: P e r j u r e "v. t. To make a false oath to; to deceive by oaths and protestations.

Perjure: P e r j u r e "n. A perjured person.

Perjured: P e r j u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Perjure

Perjured: P e r j u r e d "a. Guilty of perjury; having sworn falsely; forsworn.

Perjurer: P e r j u r e r "n. One who is guilty of perjury; one who perjures or forswears  in any sense.

Perjuries: P e r j u r i e s "pl. "of Perjury

Perjuring: P e r j u r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perjure

Perjurious: P e r j u r i o u s "a. Alt. of Perjurous

Perjurous: P e r j u r o u s "a. Guilty of perjury; containing perjury.

Perjury: P e r j u r y "v. False swearing.

Perjury: P e r j u r y "v. At common law  a willfully false statement in a fact material to the issue made by a witness under oath in a competent judicial proceeding. By statute the penalties of perjury are imposed on the making of willfully false affirmations.

Perk: P e r k "v. t. To make trim or smart; to straighten up; to erect; to make a jaunty or saucy display of; as  to perk the ears; to perk up one's head.

Perk: P e r k "v. i. To exalt one's self; to bear one's self loftily.

Perk: P e r k "a. Smart; trim; spruce; jaunty; vain.

Perk: P e r k "v. i. To peer; to look inquisitively.

Perked: P e r k e d "imp. & p. p. of Perk

Perkin: P e r k i n "n. A kind of weak perry.

Perking: P e r k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perk

Perkinism: P e r k i n i s m "n. A remedial treatment  by drawing the pointed extremities of two rods each of a different metal over the affected part; tractoration -- first employed by Dr. Elisha Perkins of Norwich Conn. See Metallotherapy.

Perky: P e r k y "a. Perk; pert; jaunty; trim.

Perlaceous: P e r l a c e o u s "a. Pearly; resembling pearl.

Perlid: P e r l i d "n. Any insect of the genus Perla  or family Perlidae. See Stone fly under Stone.

Perlite: P e r l i t e "n. Same as Pearlite.

Perlitic: P e r l i t i c "a. Relating to or resembling perlite  or pearlstone; as the perlitic structure of certain rocks. See Pearlite.

Perlous: P e r l o u s "a. Perilous.

Perlustration: P e r l u s t r a t i o n "n. The act of viewing all over.

Permanable: P e r m a n a b l e "a. Permanent; durable.

Permanence: P e r m a n e n c e "n. Alt. of Permanency

Permanency: P e r m a n e n c y "n. The quality or state of being permanent; continuance in the same state or place; duration; fixedness; as  the permanence of institutions; the permanence of nature.

Permanent: P e r m a n e n t "a. Continuing in the same state  or without any change that destroys form or character; remaining unaltered or unremoved; abiding; durable; fixed; stable; lasting; as a permanent impression.

Permanently: P e r m a n e n t l y "adv. In a permanent manner.

Permanganate: P e r m a n g a n a t e "n. A salt of permanganic acid.

Permanganic: P e r m a n g a n i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating one of the higher acids of manganese HMnO4 which forms salts called permanganates.

Permansion: P e r m a n s i o n "n. Continuance.

Permeability: P e r m e a b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being permeable.

Permeable: P e r m e a b l e "a. Capable of being permeated  or passed through; yielding passage; passable; penetrable; -- used especially of substances which allow the passage of fluids; as wood is permeable to oil; glass is permeable to light.

Permeably: P e r m e a b l y "adv. In a permeable manner.

Permeant: P e r m e a n t "a. Passing through; permeating.

Permeate: P e r m e a t e "v. t. To pass through the pores or interstices of; to penetrate and pass through without causing rupture or displacement; -- applied especially to fluids which pass through substances of loose texture; as  water permeates sand.

Permeate: P e r m e a t e "v. t. To enter and spread through; to pervade.

Permeated: P e r m e a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Permeate

Permeating: P e r m e a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Permeate

Permeation: P e r m e a t i o n "n. The act of permeating  passing through or spreading throughout the pores or interstices of any substance.

Permian: P e r m i a n "a. Belonging or relating to the period  and also to the formation next following the Carboniferous and regarded as closing the Carboniferous age and Paleozoic era.

Permian: P e r m i a n "n. The Permian period. See Chart of Geology.

Permians: P e r m i a n s "n. pl. A tribe belonging to the Finnic race  and inhabiting a portion of Russia.

Permiscible: P e r m i s c i b l e "a. Capable of being mixed.

Permiss: P e r m i s s "n. A permitted choice; a rhetorical figure in which a thing is committed to the decision of one's opponent.

Permissibility: P e r m i s s i b i l i t y "n. The quality of being permissible; permissibleness; allowableness.

Permissible: P e r m i s s i b l e "a. That may be permitted; allowable; admissible.

Permission: P e r m i s s i o n "n. The act of permitting or allowing; formal consent; authorization; leave; license or liberty granted.

Permissive: P e r m i s s i v e "a. Permitting; granting leave or liberty.

Permissive: P e r m i s s i v e "a. Permitted; tolerated; suffered.

Permissively: P e r m i s s i v e l y "adv. In a permissive manner.

Permistion: P e r m i s t i o n "n. The act of mixing; the state of being mingled; mixture.

Permit: P e r m i t "v. t. To consent to; to allow or suffer to be done; to tolerate; to put up with.

Permit: P e r m i t "v. t. To grant (one) express license or liberty to do an act; to authorize; to give leave; -- followed by an infinitive.

Permit: P e r m i t "v. t. To give over; to resign; to leave; to commit.

Permit: P e r m i t "v. i. To grant permission; to allow.

Permit: P e r m i t "n. Warrant; license; leave; permission; specifically  a written license or permission given to a person or persons having authority; as a permit to land goods subject to duty.

Permittance: P e r m i t t a n c e "n. The act of permitting; allowance; permission; leave.

Permitted: P e r m i t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Permit

Permittee: P e r m i t t e e "n. One to whom a permission or permit is given.

Permitter: P e r m i t t e r "n. One who permits.

Permitting: P e r m i t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Permit

Permix: P e r m i x "v. t. To mix; to mingle.

Permixtion: P e r m i x t i o n "n. See Permission.

Permutable: P e r m u t a b l e "a. Capable of being permuted; exchangeable.

Permutation: P e r m u t a t i o n "n. The act of permuting; exchange of the thing for another; mutual transference; interchange.

Permutation: P e r m u t a t i o n "n. The arrangement of any determinate number of things  as units objects letters etc. in all possible orders one after the other; -- called also alternation. Cf. Combination n. 4.

Permutation: P e r m u t a t i o n "n. Any one of such possible arrangements.

Permutation: P e r m u t a t i o n "n. Barter; exchange.

Permute: P e r m u t e "v. t. To interchange; to transfer reciprocally.

Permute: P e r m u t e "v. t. To exchange; to barter; to traffic.

Permuter: P e r m u t e r "n. One who permutes.

Pern: P e r n "v. t. To take profit of; to make profitable.

Pern: P e r n "n. The honey buzzard.

Pernancy: P e r n a n c y "n. A taking or reception  as the receiving of rents or tithes in kind the receiving of profits.

Pernel: P e r n e l "n. See Pimpernel.

Pernicion: P e r n i c i o n "n. Destruction; perdition.

Pernicious: P e r n i c i o u s "a. Quick; swift (to burn).

Pernicious: P e r n i c i o u s "a. Having the quality of injuring or killing; destructive; very mischievous; baleful; malicious; wicked.

Pernicity: P e r n i c i t y "n. Swiftness; celerity.

Pernio: P e r n i o "n. A chilblain.

Pernoctalian: P e r n o c t a l i a n "n. One who watches or keeps awake all night.

Pernoctation: P e r n o c t a t i o n "n. The act or state of passing the whole night; a remaining all night.

Pernor: P e r n o r "v. One who receives the profits  as of an estate.

Pernot furnace: P e r n o t   f u r n a c e " A reverberatory furnace with a circular revolving hearth  -- used in making steel.

Pernyi moth: P e r n y i   m o t h " A silk-producing moth (Attacus Pernyi) which feeds upon the oak. It has been introduced into Europe and America from China.

Perofskite: P e r o f s k i t e "n. A titanate of lime occurring in octahedral or cubic crystals.

Perogue: P e r o g u e "n. See Pirogue.

Peronate: P e r o n a t e "a. A term applied to the stipes or stalks of certain fungi which are covered with a woolly substance which at length becomes powdery.

Peroneal: P e r o n e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the fibula; in the region of the fibula.

Perorate: P e r o r a t e "v. i. To make a peroration; to harangue.

Peroration: P e r o r a t i o n "n. The concluding part of an oration; especially  a final summing up and enforcement of an argument.

Peroxidation: P e r o x i d a t i o n "n. Act  process or result of peroxidizing; oxidation to a peroxide.

Peroxide: P e r o x i d e "n. An oxide containing more oxygen than some other oxide of the same element. Formerly peroxides were regarded as the highest oxides. Cf. Per-  2.

Peroxidize: P e r o x i d i z e "v. t. To oxidize to the utmost degree  so as to form a peroxide.

Peroxidized: P e r o x i d i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Peroxidize

Perpend: P e r p e n d "v. t. To weight carefully in the mind.

Perpend: P e r p e n d "v. i. To attend; to be attentive.

Perpend stone: P e r p e n d   s t o n e " See Perpender.

Perpender: P e r p e n d e r "n. A large stone reaching through a wall so as to appear on both sides of it  and acting as a binder; -- called also perbend perpend stone and perpent stone.

Perpendicle: P e r p e n d i c l e "n. Something hanging straight down; a plumb line.

Perpendicular: P e r p e n d i c u l a r "a. Exactly upright or vertical; pointing to the zenith; at right angles to the plane of the horizon; extending in a right line from any point toward the center of the earth.

Perpendicular: P e r p e n d i c u l a r "a. At right angles to a given line or surface; as  the line ad is perpendicular to the line bc.

Perpendicular: P e r p e n d i c u l a r "n. A line at right angles to the plane of the horizon; a vertical line or direction.

Perpendicular: P e r p e n d i c u l a r "n. A line or plane falling at right angles on another line or surface  or making equal angles with it on each side.

Perpendicularity: P e r p e n d i c u l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being perpendicular.

Perpendicularly: P e r p e n d i c u l a r l y "adv. In a perpendicular manner; vertically.

Perpension: P e r p e n s i o n "n. Careful consideration; pondering.

Perpensity: P e r p e n s i t y "n. Perpension.

Perpent stone: P e r p e n t   s t o n e " See Perpender.

Perpession: P e r p e s s i o n "n. Suffering; endurance.

Perpetrable: P e r p e t r a b l e "a. Capable of being perpetrated.

Perpetrate: P e r p e t r a t e "v. t. To do or perform; to carry through; to execute  commonly in a bad sense; to commit (as a crime an offense); to be guilty of; as to perpetrate a foul deed.

Perpetrated: P e r p e t r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Perpetrate

Perpetrating: P e r p e t r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perpetrate

Perpetration: P e r p e t r a t i o n "n. The act of perpetrating; a doing; -- commonly used of doing something wrong  as a crime.

Perpetration: P e r p e t r a t i o n "n. The thing perpetrated; an evil action.

Perpetrator: P e r p e t r a t o r "n. One who perpetrates; esp.  one who commits an offense or crime.

Perpetuable: P e r p e t u a b l e "a. Capable of being perpetuated or continued.

Perpetual: P e r p e t u a l "a. Neverceasing; continuing forever or for an unlimited time; unfailing; everlasting; continuous.

Perpetually: P e r p e t u a l l y "adv. In a perpetual manner; constantly; continually.

Perpetualty: P e r p e t u a l t y "n. The state or condition of being perpetual.

Perpetuance: P e r p e t u a n c e "n. Perpetuity.

Perpetuate: P e r p e t u a t e "v. t. To make perpetual; to cause to endure  or to be continued indefinitely; to preserve from extinction or oblivion; to eternize.

Perpetuate: P e r p e t u a t e "a. Made perpetual; perpetuated.

Perpetuated: P e r p e t u a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Perpetuate

Perpetuating: P e r p e t u a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Perpetuate

Perpetuation: P e r p e t u a t i o n "n. The act of making perpetual  or of preserving from extinction through an endless existence or for an indefinite period of time; continuance.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. The quality or state of being perpetual; as  the perpetuity of laws.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. Something that is perpetual.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. Endless time.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. The number of years in which the simple interest of any sum becomes equal to the principal.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. The number of years' purchase to be given for an annuity to continue forever.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. A perpetual annuity.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. Duration without limitations as to time.

Perpetuity: P e r p e t u i t y "n. The quality or condition of an estate by which it becomes inalienable  either perpetually or for a very long period; also the estate itself so modified or perpetuated.

Perplex: P e r p l e x "a. To involve; to entangle; to make intricate or complicated  and difficult to be unraveled or understood; as to perplex one with doubts.

Perplex: P e r p l e x "a. To embarrass; to puzzle; to distract; to bewilder; to confuse; to trouble with ambiguity  suspense or anxiety.

Perplex: P e r p l e x "a. To plague; to vex; to tormen.

Perplex: P e r p l e x "a. Intricate; difficult.

Perplexed: P e r p l e x e d "imp. & p. p. of Perplex

Perplexed: P e r p l e x e d "a. Entangled  involved or confused; hence embarrassd; puzzled; doubtful; anxious.

Perplexing: P e r p l e x i n g "a. Embarrassing; puzzling; troublesome.

Perplexities: P e r p l e x i t i e s "pl. "of Perplexity

Perplexity: P e r p l e x i t y "n. The quality or state of being perplexed or puzzled; complication; intricacy; entanglement; distraction of mind through doubt or difficulty; embarrassment; bewilderment; doubt.

Perplexiveness: P e r p l e x i v e n e s s "n. The quality of being perplexing; tendency to perplex.

Perplexly: P e r p l e x l y "adv. Perplexedly.

Perpotation: P e r p o t a t i o n "n. The act of drinking excessively; a drinking bout.

Perquisite: P e r q u i s i t e "n. Something gained from a place or employment over and above the ordinary salary or fixed wages for services rendered; especially  a fee allowed by law to an officer for a specific service.

Perquisite: P e r q u i s i t e "n. Things gotten by a man's own industry  or purchased with his own money as opposed to things which come to him by descent.

Perquisited: P e r q u i s i t e d "a. Supplied with perquisites.

Perquisition: P e r q u i s i t i o n "n. A thorough inquiry of search.

Perradial: P e r r a d i a l "a. Situated around the radii  or radial tubes of a radiate.

Perrie: P e r r i e "n. Precious stones; jewels.

Perrier: P e r r i e r "n. A short mortar used formerly for throwing stone shot.

Perroquet: P e r r o q u e t "n. See Paroquet  Parakeet.

Perruque: P e r r u q u e "n. See Peruke.

Perruquier: P e r r u q u i e r "n. A marker of perukes or wigs.

Perry: P e r r y "n. A fermented liquor made from pears; pear cider.

Perry: P e r r y "n. A suddent squall. See Pirry.

Pers: P e r s "a. Light blue; grayish blue; -- a term applied to different shades at different periods.

Pers: P e r s "n. A cloth of sky-blue color.

Persalt: P e r s a l t "n. A term formerly given to the salts supposed to be formed respectively by neutralizing acids with certain peroxides.

Persant: P e r s a n t "a. Piercing.

Perscrutation: P e r s c r u t a t i o n "n. A thorough searching; a minute inquiry or scrutiny.

Persecot: P e r s e c o t "n. See Persicot.

Persecute: P e r s e c u t e "v. t. To pursue in a manner to injure  grieve or afflict; to beset with cruelty or malignity; to harass; especially to afflict harass punish or put to death for adherence to a particular religious creed or mode of worship.

Persecute: P e r s e c u t e "v. t. To harass with importunity; to pursue with persistent solicitations; to annoy.

Persecuted: P e r s e c u t e d "imp. & p. p. of Persecute

Persecuting: P e r s e c u t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Persecute

Persecution: P e r s e c u t i o n "n. The act or practice of persecuting; especially  the infliction of loss pain or death for adherence to a particular creed or mode of worship.

Persecution: P e r s e c u t i o n "n. The state or condition of being persecuted.

Persecution: P e r s e c u t i o n "n. A carrying on; prosecution.

Persecutor: P e r s e c u t o r "n. One who persecutes  or harasses.

Persecutrix: P e r s e c u t r i x "n. A woman who persecutes.

Perseid: P e r s e i d "n. One of a group of shooting stars which appear yearly about the 10th of August  and cross the heavens in paths apparently radiating from the constellation Perseus. They are beleived to be fragments once connected with a comet visible in 1862.

Perseus: P e r s e u s "n. A Grecian legendary hero  son of Jupiter and Danae who slew the Gorgon Medusa.

Perseus: P e r s e u s "n. A consellation of the northern hemisphere  near Taurus and Cassiopea. It contains a star cluster visible to the naked eye as a nebula.

Persever: P e r s e v e r "v. i. To persevere.

Perseverance: P e r s e v e r a n c e "n. The act of persevering; persistence in anything undertaken; continued pursuit or prosecution of any business  or enterprise begun.

Perseverance: P e r s e v e r a n c e "n. Discrimination.

Perseverance: P e r s e v e r a n c e "n. Continuance in a state of grace until it is succeeded by a state of glory; sometimes called final perseverance  and the perseverance of the saints. See Calvinism.

Perseverant: P e r s e v e r a n t "a. Persevering.

Persevere: P e r s e v e r e "v. i. To persist in any business or enterprise undertaken; to pursue steadily any project or course begun; to maintain a purpose in spite of counter influences  opposition or discouragement; not to give or abandon what is undertaken.

Persevered: P e r s e v e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Persevere

Persevering: P e r s e v e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Persevere

Persevering: P e r s e v e r i n g "a. Characterized by perseverance; persistent.

Persian: P e r s i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Persia  to the Persians or to their language.

Persian: P e r s i a n "n. A native or inhabitant of Persia.

Persian: P e r s i a n "n. The language spoken in Persia.

Persian: P e r s i a n "n. A thin silk fabric  used formerly for linings.

Persian: P e r s i a n "n. See Persian columns  under Persian a.

Persic: P e r s i c "a. Of or relating to Persia.

Persic: P e r s i c "n. The Persian language.

Persicaria: P e r s i c a r i a "n. See Lady's thumb.

Persicot: P e r s i c o t "n. A cordial made of the kernels of apricots  nectarines etc. with refined spirit.

Persiflage: P e r s i f l a g e "n. Frivolous or bantering talk; a frivolous manner of treating any subject  whether serious or otherwise; light raillery.

Persifleur: P e r s i f l e u r "n. One who indulges in persiflage; a banterer; a quiz.

Persimmon: P e r s i m m o n "n. An American tree (Diospyros Virginiana) and its fruit  found from New York southward. The fruit is like a plum in appearance but is very harsh and astringent until it has been exposed to frost when it becomes palatable and nutritious.

Persis: P e r s i s "n. A kind of coloring matter obtained from lichens.

Persism: P e r s i s m "n. A Persian idiom.

Persist: P e r s i s t "v. i. To stand firm; to be fixed and unmoved; to stay; to continue steadfastly; especially  to continue fixed in a course of conduct against opposing motives; to persevere; -- sometimes conveying an unfavorable notion as of doggedness or obstinacy.

Persisted: P e r s i s t e d "imp. & p. p. of Persist

Persistence: P e r s i s t e n c e "n. Alt. of Persistency

Persistency: P e r s i s t e n c y "n. The quality or state of being persistent; staying or continuing quality; hence  in an unfavorable sense doggedness; obstinacy.

Persistency: P e r s i s t e n c y "n. The continuance of an effect after the cause which first gave rise to it is removed

Persistency: P e r s i s t e n c y "n. The persistence of motion.

Persistency: P e r s i s t e n c y "n. Visual persistence  or persistence of the visual impression; auditory persistence etc.

Persistent: P e r s i s t e n t "a. Inclined to persist; having staying qualities; tenacious of position or purpose.

Persistent: P e r s i s t e n t "a. Remaining beyond the period when parts of the same kind sometimes fall off or are absorbed; permanent; as  persistent teeth or gills; a persistent calyx; -- opposed to deciduous and caducous.

Persistently: P e r s i s t e n t l y "adv. In a persistent manner.

Persisting: P e r s i s t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Persist

Persisting: P e r s i s t i n g "a. Inclined to persist; tenacious of purpose; persistent.

Persistive: P e r s i s t i v e "a. See Persistent.

Persolve: P e r s o l v e "v. t. To pay wholly  or fully.

Person: P e r s o n "n. A character or part  as in a play; a specific kind or manifestation of individual character whether in real life or in literary or dramatic representation; an assumed character.

Person: P e r s o n "n. The bodily form of a human being; body; outward appearance; as  of comely person.

Person: P e r s o n "n. A living  self-conscious being as distinct from an animal or a thing; a moral agent; a human being; a man woman or child.

Person: P e r s o n "n. A human being spoken of indefinitely; one; a man; as  any person present.

Person: P e r s o n "n. A parson; the parish priest.

Person: P e r s o n "n. Among Trinitarians  one of the three subdivisions of the Godhead (the Father the Son and the Holy Ghost); an hypostasis.

Person: P e r s o n "n. One of three relations or conditions (that of speaking  that of being spoken to and that of being spoken of) pertaining to a noun or a pronoun and thence also to the verb of which it may be the subject.

Person: P e r s o n "n. A shoot or bud of a plant; a polyp or zooid of the compound Hydrozoa Anthozoa  etc.; also an individual in the narrowest sense among the higher animals.

Person: P e r s o n "v. t. To represent as a person; to personify; to impersonate.

Persona: P e r s o n a "n. Same as Person  n. 8.

Personable: P e r s o n a b l e "a. Having a well-formed body  or person; graceful; comely; of good appearance; presentable; as a personable man or woman.

Personable: P e r s o n a b l e "a. Enabled to maintain pleas in court.

Personable: P e r s o n a b l e "a. Having capacity to take anything granted.

Personae: P e r s o n a e "pl. "of Persona

Personage: P e r s o n a g e "n. Form  appearance or belongings of a person; the external appearance stature figure air and the like of a person.

Personage: P e r s o n a g e "n. Character assumed or represented.

Personage: P e r s o n a g e "n. A notable or distinguished person; a conspicious or peculiar character; as  an illustrious personage; a comely personage of stature tall.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Pertaining to human beings as distinct from things.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a particular person; relating to  or affecting an individual or each of many individuals; peculiar or proper to private concerns; not public or general; as personal comfort; personal desire.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Pertaining to the external or bodily appearance; corporeal; as  personal charms.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Done in person; without the intervention of another.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Relating to an individual  his character conduct motives or private affairs in an invidious and offensive manner; as personal reflections or remarks.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "a. Denoting person; as  a personal pronoun.

Personal: P e r s o n a l "n. A movable; a chattel.

Personalism: P e r s o n a l i s m "n. The quality or state of being personal; personality.

Personalities: P e r s o n a l i t i e s "pl. "of Personality

Personality: P e r s o n a l i t y "n. That which constitutes distinction of person; individuality.

Personality: P e r s o n a l i t y "n. Something said or written which refers to the person  conduct etc. of some individual especially something of a disparaging or offensive nature; personal remarks; as indulgence in personalities.

Personality: P e r s o n a l i t y "n. That quality of a law which concerns the condition  state and capacity of persons.

Personalize: P e r s o n a l i z e "v. t. To make personal.

Personalized: P e r s o n a l i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Personalize

Personalizing: P e r s o n a l i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Personalize

Personally: P e r s o n a l l y "adv. In a personal manner; by bodily presence; in person; not by representative or substitute; as  to deliver a letter personally.

Personally: P e r s o n a l l y "adv. With respect to an individual; as regards the person; individually; particularly.

Personally: P e r s o n a l l y "adv. With respect to one's individuality; as regards one's self; as  personally I have no feeling in the matter.

Personalty: P e r s o n a l t y "n. The state of being a person; personality.

Personalty: P e r s o n a l t y "n. Personal property  as distinguished from realty or real property.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "v. t. To celebrate loudly; to extol; to praise.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "v. t. To assume the character of; to represent by a fictitious appearance; to act the part of; hence  to counterfeit; to feign; as he tried to personate his brother; a personated devotion.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "v. t. To set forth in an unreal character; to disguise; to mask.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "v. t. To personify; to typify; to describe.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "v. i. To play or assume a character.

Personate: P e r s o n a t e "a. Having the throat of a bilabiate corolla nearly closed by a projection of the base of the lower lip; masked  as in the flower of the snapdragon.

Personated: P e r s o n a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Personate

Personating: P e r s o n a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Personate

Personation: P e r s o n a t i o n "n. The act of personating  or conterfeiting the person or character of another.

Personator: P e r s o n a t o r "n. One who personates.

Personeity: P e r s o n e i t y "n. Personality.

Personification: P e r s o n i f i c a t i o n "n. The act of personifying; impersonation; embodiment.

Personification: P e r s o n i f i c a t i o n "n. A figure of speech in which an inanimate object or abstract idea is represented as animated  or endowed with personality; prosopop/ia; as the floods clap their hands.

Personified: P e r s o n i f i e d "imp. & p. p. of Personify

Personifier: P e r s o n i f i e r "n. One who personifies.

Personify: P e r s o n i f y "v. t. To regard  treat or represent as a person; to represent as a rational being.

Personify: P e r s o n i f y "v. t. To be the embodiment or personification of; to impersonate; as  he personifies the law.

Personifying: P e r s o n i f y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Personify

Personize: P e r s o n i z e "v. t. To personify.

Personnel: P e r s o n n e l "n. The body of persons employed in some public service  as the army navy etc.; -- distinguished from materiel.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "n. Of or pertaining to the science of vision; optical.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "n. Pertaining to the art  or in accordance with the laws of perspective.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "a. A glass through which objects are viewed.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "a. That which is seen through an opening; a view; a vista.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "a. The effect of distance upon the appearance of objects  by means of which the eye recognized them as being at a more or less measurable distance. Hence aerial perspective the assumed greater vagueness or uncertainty of outline in distant objects.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "a. The art and the science of so delineating objects that they shall seem to grow smaller as they recede from the eye; -- called also linear perspective.

Perspective: P e r s p e c t i v e "a. A drawing in linear perspective.

Perspectively: P e r s p e c t i v e l y "adv. Optically; as through a glass.

Perspectively: P e r s p e c t i v e l y "adv. According to the rules of perspective.

Perspectograph: P e r s p e c t o g r a p h "n. An instrument for obtaining  and transferring to a picture the points and outlines of objects so as to represent them in their proper geometrical relations as viewed from some one point.

Perspectography: P e r s p e c t o g r a p h y "n. The science or art of delineating objects according to the laws of perspective; the theory of perspective.

Perspicuity: P e r s p i c u i t y "n. Sagacity; perspicacity.

Perspicuous: P e r s p i c u o u s "a. Capable of being through; transparent; translucent; not opaque.

Perspicuous: P e r s p i c u o u s "a. Clear to the understanding; capable of being clearly understood; clear in thought or in expression; not obscure or ambiguous; as  a perspicuous writer; perspicuous statements.

Persulphide: P e r s u l p h i d e "n. A sulphide containing more sulphur than some other compound of the same elements; as  iron pyrites is a persulphide; -- formerly called persulphuret.

Persulphocyanate: P e r s u l p h o c y a n a t e "n. A salt of persulphocyanic acid.

Persulphocyanic: P e r s u l p h o c y a n i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating a yellow crystalline substance (called also perthiocyanic acid) analogous to sulphocyanic acid but containing more sulphur.

Persulphocyanogen: P e r s u l p h o c y a n o g e n "n. An orange-yellow substance  produced by the action of chlorine or boiling dilute nitric acid and sulphocyanate of potassium; -- called also pseudosulphocyanogen perthiocyanogen and formerly sulphocyanogen.

Petal: P e t a l "n. One of the leaves of the corolla  or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla and Illust. of Flower.

Petal: P e t a l "n. One of the expanded ambulacra which form a rosette on the black of certain Echini.

Petala: P e t a l a "pl. "of Petalum

Petaled: P e t a l e d "a. Having petals; as  a petaled flower; -- opposed to apetalous and much used in compounds; as one-petaled three-petaled etc.

Petaliferous: P e t a l i f e r o u s "a. Bearing petals.

Petaliform: P e t a l i f o r m "a. Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped.

Petaline: P e t a l i n e "a. Pertaining to a petal; attached to  or resembling a petal.

Petalism: P e t a l i s m "n. A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which they banished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerous influence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; but olive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.

Petalite: P e t a l i t e "n. A rare mineral  occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses usually white or nearly so in color. It is a silicate of aluminia and lithia.

Petalody: P e t a l o d y "n. The metamorphosis of various floral organs  usually stamens into petals.

Petaloid: P e t a l o i d "a. Petaline.

Petaloideous: P e t a l o i d e o u s "a. Having the whole or part of the perianth petaline.

Petalosticha: P e t a l o s t i c h a "n. pl. An order of Echini  including the irregular sea urchins as the spatangoids. See Spatangoid.

Petalous: P e t a l o u s "a. Having petals; petaled; -- opposed to apetalous.

Petalum: P e t a l u m "n. A petal.

Petar: P e t a r "n. See Petard.

Petard: P e t a r d "n. A case containing powder to be exploded  esp. a conical or cylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank to be exploded against and break down gates barricades drawbridges etc. It has been superseded.

Petardeer: P e t a r d e e r "n. Alt. of Petardier

Petardier: P e t a r d i e r "n. One who managed a petard.

Petasus: P e t a s u s "n. The winged cap of Mercury; also  a broad-brimmed low-crowned hat worn by Greeks and Romans.

Petaurist: P e t a u r i s t "n. Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus  Phalangista Acrobata and allied genera. See Flying mouse under Flying and Phalangister.

Petechiae: P e t e c h i a e "n. pl. Small crimson  purple or livid spots like flea-bites due to extravasation of blood which appear on the skin in malignant fevers etc.

Petechial: P e t e c h i a l "a. Characterized by  or pertaining to petechiae; spotted.

Peter: P e t e r "n. A common baptismal name for a man. The name of one of the apostles

Peter: P e t e r "v. i. To become exhausted; to run out; to fail; -- used generally with out; as  that mine has petered out.

Peterel: P e t e r e l "n. See Petrel.

Peterero: P e t e r e r o "n. See Pederero.

Petering: P e t e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Peter

Peterman: P e t e r m a n "n. A fisherman; -- so called after the apostle Peter.

Petermen: P e t e r m e n "pl. "of Peterman

Petersham: P e t e r s h a m "n. A rough  knotted woolen cloth used chiefly for men's overcoats; also a coat of that material.

Peterwort: P e t e r w o r t "n. See Saint Peter's-wort  under Saint.

Petiolar: P e t i o l a r "a. Alt. of Petiolary

Petiolary: P e t i o l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to petiole  or proceeding from it; as a petiolar tendril; growing or supported upon a petiole; as a petiolar gland; a petiolar bud.

Petiolate: P e t i o l a t e "a. Alt. of Petiolated

Petiolated: P e t i o l a t e d "a. Having a stalk or petiole; as  a petioleate leaf; the petiolated abdomen of certain Hymenoptera.

Petiole: P e t i o l e "n. A leafstalk; the footstalk of a leaf  connecting the blade with the stem. See Illust. of Leaf.

Petiole: P e t i o l e "n. A stalk or peduncle.

Petioled: P e t i o l e d "a. Petiolate.

Petiolulate: P e t i o l u l a t e "a. Supported by its own petiolule.

Petiolule: P e t i o l u l e "n. A small petiole  or the petiole of a leaflet.

Petit: P e t i t "a. Small; little; insignificant; mean; -- Same as Petty.

Petition: P e t i t i o n "n. A prayer; a supplication; an imploration; an entreaty; especially  a request of a solemn or formal kind; a prayer to the Supreme Being or to a person of superior power rank or authority; also a single clause in such a prayer.

Petition: P e t i t i o n "n. A formal written request addressed to an official person  or to an organized body having power to grant it; specifically (Law) a supplication to government in either of its branches for the granting of a particular grace or right; -- in distinction from a memorial which calls certain facts to mind; also the written document.

Petition: P e t i t i o n "v. t. To make a prayer or request to; to ask from; to solicit; to entreat; especially  to make a formal written supplication or application to as to any branch of the government; as to petition the court; to petition the governor.

Petition: P e t i t i o n "v. i. To make a petition or solicitation.

Petitionarily: P e t i t i o n a r i l y "adv. By way of begging the question; by an assumption.

Petitionary: P e t i t i o n a r y "a. Supplicatory; making a petition.

Petitionary: P e t i t i o n a r y "a. Containing a petition; of the nature of a petition; as  a petitionary epistle.

Petitioned: P e t i t i o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Petition

Petitionee: P e t i t i o n e e "n. A person cited to answer  or defend against a petition.

Petitioner: P e t i t i o n e r "n. One who presents a petition.

Petitioning: P e t i t i o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Petition

Petitioning: P e t i t i o n i n g "n. The act of presenting apetition; a supplication.

Petitor: P e t i t o r "n. One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant.

Petitory: P e t i t o r y "a. Petitioning; soliciting; supplicating.

Petong: P e t o n g "n. See Packfong.

Petralogy: P e t r a l o g y "n. See Petrology.

Petrary: P e t r a r y "n. An ancient war engine for hurling stones.

Petre: P e t r e "n. See Saltpeter.

Petrean: P e t r e a n "a. Of or pertaining to to rock.

Petrel: P e t r e l "n. Any one of numerous species of longwinged sea birds belonging to the family Procellaridae. The small petrels  or Mother Carey's chickens belong to Oceanites Oceanodroma Procellaria and several allied genera.

Petrescence: P e t r e s c e n c e "n. The process of changing into stone; petrification.

Petrescent: P e t r e s c e n t "a. Petrifying; converting into stone; as  petrescent water.

Petrifaction: P e t r i f a c t i o n "n. The process of petrifying  or changing into stone; conversion of any organic matter (animal or vegetable) into stone or a substance of stony hardness.

Petrifaction: P e t r i f a c t i o n "n. The state or condition of being petrified.

Petrifaction: P e t r i f a c t i o n "n. That which is petrified; popularly  a body incrusted with stony matter; an incrustation.

Petrifaction: P e t r i f a c t i o n "n. Fig.: Hardness; callousness; obduracy.

Petrifactive: P e t r i f a c t i v e "a. Having the quality of converting organic matter into stone; petrifying.

Petrifactive: P e t r i f a c t i v e "a. Pertaining to  or characterized by petrifaction.

Petrific: P e t r i f i c "a. Petrifying; petrifactive.

Petrificate: P e t r i f i c a t e "v. t. To petrify.

Petrification: P e t r i f i c a t i o n "n. See Petrifaction.

Petrification: P e t r i f i c a t i o n "n. Fig.: Obduracy; callousness.

Petrified: P e t r i f i e d "imp. & p. p. of Petrify

Petrify: P e t r i f y "v. t. To convert  as any animal or vegetable matter into stone or stony substance.

Petrify: P e t r i f y "v. t. To make callous or obdurate; to stupefy; to paralyze; to transform; as by petrifaction; as  to petrify the heart. Young.

Petrify: P e t r i f y "v. i. To become stone  or of a stony hardness as organic matter by calcareous deposits.

Petrify: P e t r i f y "v. i. Fig.: To become stony  callous or obdurate.

Petrifying: P e t r i f y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Petrify

Petrine: P e t r i n e "a. Of or pertaining to St.Peter; as  the Petrine Epistles.

Petro-: P e t r o - " A combining form from Gr. / a rock  / a stone; as petrology petroglyphic.

Petrogale: P e t r o g a l e "n. Any Australian kangaroo of the genus Petrogale  as the rock wallaby (P. penicillata).

Petroglyphic: P e t r o g l y p h i c "a. Of or pertaining to petroglyphy.

Petroglyphy: P e t r o g l y p h y "n. The art or operation of carving figures or inscriptions on rock or stone.

Petrographic: P e t r o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Petrographical

Petrographical: P e t r o g r a p h i c a l "a. Pertaining to petrography.

Petrography: P e t r o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing on stone.

Petrography: P e t r o g r a p h y "n. The scientific description of rocks; that department of science which investigates the constitution of rocks; petrology.

Petrohyoid: P e t r o h y o i d "a. Pertaining to petrous  oe periotic portion of the skull and the hyoid arch; as the petrohyoid muscles of the frog.

Petrol: P e t r o l "n. Petroleum.

Petrolatum: P e t r o l a t u m "n. A semisolid unctuous substance  neutral and without taste or odor derived from petroleum by distilling off the lighter portions and purifying the residue. It is a yellowish fatlike mass transparent in thin layers and somewhat fluorescent. It is used as a bland protective dressing and as a substitute for fatty materials in ointments.

Petroleum: P e t r o l e u m "n. Rock oil  mineral oil or natural oil a dark brown or greenish inflammable liquid which at certain points exists in the upper strata of the earth from whence it is pumped or forced by pressure of the gas attending it. It consists of a complex mixture of various hydrocarbons largely of the methane series but may vary much in appearance composition

Petroleur: P e t r o l e u r "n. f. Alt. of Petroleuse

Petroleuse: P e t r o l e u s e "n. f. One who makes use of petroleum for incendiary purposes.

Petroline: P e t r o l i n e "n. A paraffin obtained from petroleum from Rangoon in India  and practically identical with ordinary paraffin.

Petrologic: P e t r o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Petrological

Petrological: P e t r o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to petrology.

Petrologically: P e t r o l o g i c a l l y "adv. According to petrology.

Petrologist: P e t r o l o g i s t "n. One who is versed in petrology.

Petrology: P e t r o l o g y "n. The department of science which is concerned with the mineralogical and chemical composition of rocks  and with their classification: lithology.

Petrology: P e t r o l o g y "n. A treatise on petrology.

Petromastoid: P e t r o m a s t o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the petrous and mastoid parts of the temporal bone  periotic.

Petromyzont: P e t r o m y z o n t "n. A lamprey.

Petronel: P e t r o n e l "n. A sort of hand cannon  or portable firearm used in France in the 15th century.

Petrosal: P e t r o s a l "a. Hard; stony; petrous; as  the petrosal bone; petrosal part of the temporal bone.

Petrosal: P e t r o s a l "a. Of  pertaining to or in the region of the petrous or petrosal bone or the corresponding part of the temporal bone.

Petrosal: P e t r o s a l "n. A petrosal bone.

Petrosal: P e t r o s a l "n. The auditory capsule.

Petrosilex: P e t r o s i l e x "n. Felsite.

Petrosilicious: P e t r o s i l i c i o u s "a. Containing  or consisting of petrosilex.

Petrostearine: P e t r o s t e a r i n e "n. A solid unctuous material  of which candles are made.

Petrous: P e t r o u s "a. Like stone; hard; stony; rocky; as  the petrous part of the temporal bone.

Petrous: P e t r o u s "a. Same as Petrosal.

Petted: P e t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Pet

Pettichaps: P e t t i c h a p s "n. See Pettychaps.

Petticoat: P e t t i c o a t "n. A loose under-garment worn by women  and covering the body below the waist.

Pettifog: P e t t i f o g "v. i. To do a petty business as a lawyer; also  to do law business in a petty or tricky way.

Pettifog: P e t t i f o g "v. t. To advocate like a pettifogger; to argue trickily; as  to pettifog a claim.

Pettifogged: P e t t i f o g g e d "imp. & p. p. of Pettifog

Pettifogger: P e t t i f o g g e r "n. A lawyer who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and tricky; an inferior lawyer.

Pettifoggery: P e t t i f o g g e r y "n. The practice or arts of a pettifogger; disreputable tricks; quibbles.

Pettifogging: P e t t i f o g g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pettifog

Pettifogging: P e t t i f o g g i n g "a. Paltry; quibbling; mean.

Pettifogging: P e t t i f o g g i n g "n. Pettifoggery.

Pettifogulize: P e t t i f o g u l i z e "v. i. To act as a pettifogger; to use contemptible tricks.

Pettily: P e t t i l y "adv. In a petty manner; frivolously.

Pettiness: P e t t i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being petty or paltry; littleness; meanness.

Petting: P e t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pet

Pettish: P e t t i s h "a. Fretful; peevish; moody; capricious; inclined to ill temper.

Pettitoes: P e t t i t o e s "n. pl. The toes or feet of a pig  -- often used as food; sometimes in contempt the human feet.

Petto: P e t t o "n. The breast.

Petty: P e t t y "superl. Little; trifling; inconsiderable; also  inferior; subordinate; as a petty fault; a petty prince.

Pettychaps: P e t t y c h a p s "n. Any one of several species of small European singing birds of the subfamily Sylviinae  as the willow warbler the chiff-chaff and the golden warbler (Sylvia hortensis).

Pettywhin: P e t t y w h i n "n. The needle furze. See under Needle.

Petulance: P e t u l a n c e "n. Alt. of Petulancy

Petulancy: P e t u l a n c y "n. The quality or state of being petulant; temporary peevishness; pettishness; capricious ill humor.

Petulant: P e t u l a n t "a. Forward; pert; insolent; wanton.

Petulant: P e t u l a n t "a. Capriciously fretful; characterized by ill-natured freakishness; irritable.

Petulantly: P e t u l a n t l y "adv. In a petulant manner.

Petulcity: P e t u l c i t y "n. Wantonness; friskiness.

Petulcous: P e t u l c o u s "a. Wanton; frisky; lustful.

Petunia: P e t u n i a "n. A genus of solanaceous herbs with funnelform or salver-shaped corollas. Two species are common in cultivation  Petunia violacera with reddish purple flowers and P. nyctaginiflora with white flowers. There are also many hybrid forms with variegated corollas.

Petunse: P e t u n s e "n. Alt. of Petuntze

Petuntse: P e t u n t s e "n. Alt. of Petuntze

Petuntze: P e t u n t z e "n. Powdered fledspar  kaolin or quartz used in the manufacture of porcelain.

Petworth marble: P e t w o r t h   m a r b l e " A kind of shell marble occurring in the Wealden clay at Petworth  in Sussex England; -- called also Sussex marble.

Petzite: P e t z i t e "n. A telluride of silver and gold  related to hessite.

Peucedanin: P e u c e d a n i n "n. A tasteless white crystalline substance  extracted from the roots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum) masterwort (Imperatoria) and other related plants; -- called also imperatorin.

Peucil: P e u c i l "n. A liquid resembling camphene  obtained by treating turpentine hydrochloride with lime.

Pew: P e w "n. One of the compartments in a church which are separated by low partitions  and have long seats upon which several persons may sit; -- sometimes called slip. Pews were originally made square but are now usually long and narrow.

Pew: P e w "n. Any structure shaped like a church pew  as a stall formerly used by money lenders etc.; a box in theater; a pen; a sheepfold.

Pew: P e w "v. t. To furnish with pews.

Pewee: P e w e e "n. A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis phoebe  or S. fuscus). Called also pewit and phoebe.

Pewee: P e w e e "n. The woodcock.

Pewet: P e w e t "n. Same as Pewit.

Pewfellow: P e w f e l l o w "n. One who occupies the same pew with another.

Pewfellow: P e w f e l l o w "n. An intimate associate; a companion.

Pewit: P e w i t "n. The lapwing.

Pewit: P e w i t "n. The European black-headed  or laughing gull (Xema ridibundus). See under Laughing.

Pewit: P e w i t "n. The pewee.

Pewter: P e w t e r "n. A hard  tough but easily fusible alloy originally consisting of tin with a little lead but afterwards modified by the addition of copper antimony or bismuth.

Pewter: P e w t e r "n. Utensils or vessels made of pewter  as dishes porringers drinking vessels tankards pots.

Pewterer: P e w t e r e r "n. One whose occupation is to make utensils of pewter; a pewtersmith.

Pewtery: P e w t e r y "a. Belonging to  or resembling pewter; as a pewtery taste.

Pexity: P e x i t y "n. Nap of cloth.

Peyer's glands: P e y e r ' s   g l a n d s " Patches of lymphoid nodules  in the walls of the small intestiness; agminated glands; -- called also Peyer's patches. In typhoid fever they become the seat of ulcers which are regarded as the characteristic organic lesion of that disease.

Peytrel: P e y t r e l "n. The breastplate of a horse's armor or harness. [Spelt also peitrel.] See Poitrel.

Peziza: P e z i z a "n. A genus of fungi embracing a great number of species  some of which are remarkable for their regular cuplike form and deep colors.

Pezizoid: P e z i z o i d "a. Resembling a fungus of the genus Peziza; having a cuplike form.

Pfennig: P f e n n i g "n. A small copper coin of Germany. It is the hundredth part of a mark  or about a quarter of a cent in United States currency.

Pfennige: P f e n n i g e "pl. "of Pfennig

Pfennigs: P f e n n i g s "pl. "of Pfennig

Phacelli: P h a c e l l i "pl. "of Phacellus

Phacellus: P h a c e l l u s "n. One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavity of certain jellyfishes.

Phacochere: P h a c o c h e r e "n. The wart hog.

Phacoid: P h a c o i d "a. Resembling a lentil; lenticular.

Phacolite: P h a c o l i t e "n. A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa  in Bohemia.

Phacops: P h a c o p s "n. A genus of trilobites found in the Silurian and Devonian formations. Phacops bufo is one of the most common species.

Phaeacian: P h a e a c i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the Phaeacians  a fabulous seafaring people fond of the feast the lyre and the dance mentioned by Homer.

Phaenogam: P h a e n o g a m "n. Any plant of the class Phaenogamia.

Phaenogamia: P h a e n o g a m i a "n. pl. The class of flowering plants including all which have true flowers with distinct floral organs; phanerogamia.

Phaenogamian: P h a e n o g a m i a n "a. Alt. of Phaenogamic

Phaenogamic: P h a e n o g a m i c "a. Same as Phaenogamous.

Phaenogamous: P h a e n o g a m o u s "a. Having true flowers with with distinct floral organs; flowering.

Phaenomenon: P h a e n o m e n o n "n. See Phenomenon.

Phaeospore: P h a e o s p o r e "n. A brownish zoospore  characteristic of an order (Phaeosporeae) of dark green or olive-colored algae.

Phaethon: P h a e t h o n "n. The son of Helios (Phoebus)  that is the son of light or of the sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission to drive the chariot of the sun in doing which his want of skill would have set the world on fire had he not been struck with a thunderbolt by Jupiter and hurled headlong into the river Po.

Phaethon: P h a e t h o n "n. A genus of oceanic birds including the tropic birds.

Phaeton: P h a e t o n "n. A four-wheeled carriage (with or without a top)  open or having no side pieces in front of the seat. It is drawn by one or two horses.

Phaeton: P h a e t o n "n. See Phaethon.

Phaeton: P h a e t o n "n. A handsome American butterfly (Euphydryas  / Melitaea Phaeton). The upper side of the wings is black with orange-red spots and marginal crescents and several rows of cream-colored spots; -- called also Baltimore.

Phagedena: P h a g e d e n a "n. A canine appetite; bulimia.

Phagedena: P h a g e d e n a "n. Spreading  obstinate ulceration.

Phagedenic: P h a g e d e n i c "a. Alt. of PhagedenicAL

PhagedenicAL: P h a g e d e n i c A L "a. Of  like or pertaining to phagedena; used in the treatment of phagedena; as a phagedenic ulcer or medicine.

PhagedenicAL: P h a g e d e n i c A L "n. A phagedenic medicine.

Phagedenous: P h a g e d e n o u s "a. Phagedenic.

Phagocyte: P h a g o c y t e "n. A leucocyte which plays a part in retrogressive processes by taking up (eating)  in the form of fine granules the parts to be removed.

Phainopepla: P h a i n o p e p l a "n. A small crested passerine bird (Phainopepla nitens)  native of Mexico and the Southern United States. The adult male is of a uniform glossy blue-black; the female is brownish. Called also black flycatcher.

Phakoscope: P h a k o s c o p e "n. An instrument for studying the mechanism of accommodation.

Phalaena: P h a l a e n a "n. A linnaean genus which included the moths in general.

Phalaenid: P h a l a e n i d "n. Any moth of the family Phalaenidae  of which the cankerworms are examples; a geometrid.

Phalangal: P h a l a n g a l "a. Of or pertaining to the phalanges. See Phalanx  2.

Phalangeal: P h a l a n g e a l "a. Alt. of Phalangal
