The science of nature  or of natural objects; that branch of science which treats of the laws and properties of matter and the forces acting upon it; especially that department of natural science which treats of the causes (as gravitation heat light magnetism electricity etc.) that modify the general properties of bodies; natural philosophy.

Physiocrat: P h y s i o c r a t "n. One of the followers of Quesnay of France  who in the 18th century founded a system of political economy based upon the supremacy of natural order.

Physiogeny: P h y s i o g e n y "n. The germ history of the functions  or the history of the development of vital activities in the individual being one of the branches of ontogeny. See Morphogeny.

Physiognomer: P h y s i o g n o m e r "n. Physiognomist.

Physiognomic: P h y s i o g n o m i c "a. Alt. of Physiognomical

Physiognomical: P h y s i o g n o m i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to physiognomy; according with the principles of physiognomy.

Physiognomies: P h y s i o g n o m i e s "pl. "of Physiognomy

Physiognomist: P h y s i o g n o m i s t "n. Same as Physiognomy  1.

Physiognomist: P h y s i o g n o m i s t "n. One skilled in physiognomy.

Physiognomist: P h y s i o g n o m i s t "n. One who tells fortunes by physiognomy.

Physiognomize: P h y s i o g n o m i z e "v. t. To observe and study the physiognomy of.

Physiognommonic: P h y s i o g n o m m o n i c "a. Physiognomic.

Physiognomy: P h y s i o g n o m y "n. The art and science of discovering the predominant temper  and other characteristic qualities of the mind by the outward appearance especially by the features of the face.

Physiognomy: P h y s i o g n o m y "n. The face or countenance  with respect to the temper of the mind; particular configuration cast or expression of countenance as denoting character.

Physiognomy: P h y s i o g n o m y "n. The art telling fortunes by inspection of the features.

Physiognomy: P h y s i o g n o m y "n. The general appearance or aspect of a thing  without reference to its scientific characteristics; as the physiognomy of a plant or of a meteor.

Physiogony: P h y s i o g o n y "n. The birth of nature.

Physiographic: P h y s i o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Physiographical

Physiographical: P h y s i o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to physiography.

Physiography: P h y s i o g r a p h y "n. The science which treats of the earth's exterior physical features  climate life etc. and of the physical movements or changes on the earth's surface as the currents of the atmosphere and ocean the secular variations in heat moisture magnetism etc.; physical geography.

Physiolatry: P h y s i o l a t r y "n. The worship of the powers or agencies of nature; materialism in religion; nature worship.

Physiologer: P h y s i o l o g e r "n. A physiologist.

Physiologic: P h y s i o l o g i c "a. Physiological.

Physiological: P h y s i o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to physiology; relating to the science of the functions of living organism; as  physiological botany or chemistry.

Physiologically: P h y s i o l o g i c a l l y "adv. In a physiological manner.

Physiologies: P h y s i o l o g i e s "pl. "of Physiology

Physiologist: P h y s i o l o g i s t "n. One who is versed in the science of physiology; a student of the properties and functions of animal and vegetable organs and tissues.

Physiologize: P h y s i o l o g i z e "v. i. To speculate in physiology; to make physiological investigations.

Physiology: P h y s i o l o g y "n. The science which treats of the phenomena of living organisms; the study of the processes incidental to  and characteristic of life.

Physiology: P h y s i o l o g y "n. A treatise on physiology.

Physiophyly: P h y s i o p h y l y "n. The tribal history of the functions  or the history of the paleontological development of vital activities -- being a branch of phylogeny. See Morphophyly.

Physique: P h y s i q u e "n. The natural constitution  or physical structure of a person.

Physnomy: P h y s n o m y "n. Physiogmony.

Physoclist: P h y s o c l i s t "n. One of the Physoclisti.

Physoclisti: P h y s o c l i s t i "n. pl. An order of teleost in which the air bladder has no opening.

Physograde: P h y s o g r a d e "n. Any siphonophore which has an air sac for a float  as the Physalia.

Physophorae: P h y s o p h o r a e "n. pl. An order of Siphonophora  furnished with an air sac or float and a series of nectocalyces. See Illust. under Nectocalyx.

Physopod: P h y s o p o d "n. One of the Physopoda; a thrips.

Physopoda: P h y s o p o d a "n. pl. Same as Thysanoptera.

Physostigmine: P h y s o s t i g m i n e "n. An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean (the seed of Physostigma venenosum)  and extracted as a white tasteless substance amorphous or crystalline; -- formerly called eserine with which it was regarded as identical.

Physostomi: P h y s o s t o m i "n. pl. An order of fishes in which the air bladder is provided with a duct  and the ventral fins when present are abdominal. It includes the salmons herrings carps catfishes and others.

Physostomous: P h y s o s t o m o u s "a. Having a duct to the air bladder.

Physostomous: P h y s o s t o m o u s "a. Pertaining to the Physostomi.

Phytelephas: P h y t e l e p h a s "n. A genus of South American palm trees  the seeds of which furnish the substance called vegetable ivory.

Phytivorous: P h y t i v o r o u s "a. Feeding on plants or herbage; phytophagous; as  phytivorous animals.

Phyto-: P h y t o - " A combining form from Gr. fyto`n a plant; as  phytochemistry phytography.

Phytochemical: P h y t o c h e m i c a l "a. Relating to phytochemistry.

Phytochemistry: P h y t o c h e m i s t r y "n. Chemistry in its relation to vegetable bodies; vegetable chemistry.

Phytochimy: P h y t o c h i m y "n. Phytochemistry.

Phytogenesis: P h y t o g e n e s i s "n. Alt. of Phytogeny

Phytogeny: P h y t o g e n y "n. The doctrine of the generation of plants.

Phytogeographical: P h y t o g e o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to phytogeography.

Phytogeography: P h y t o g e o g r a p h y "n. The geographical distribution of plants.

Phytoglyphic: P h y t o g l y p h i c "a. Relating to phytoglyphy.

Phytoglyphy: P h y t o g l y p h y "n. See Nature printing  under Nature.

Phytographical: P h y t o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to phytography.

Phytography: P h y t o g r a p h y "n. The science of describing plants in a systematic manner; also  a description of plants.

Phytoid: P h y t o i d "a. Resembling a plant; plantlike.

Phytolacca: P h y t o l a c c a "n. A genus of herbaceous plants  some of them having berries which abound in intensely red juice; poke or pokeweed.

Phytolite: P h y t o l i t e "n. An old name for a fossil plant.

Phytolithologist: P h y t o l i t h o l o g i s t "n. One versed in phytolithology; a paleobotanist.

Phytolithology: P h y t o l i t h o l o g y "n. The branch of science which treats of fossil plants; -- usually called paleobotany  sometimes paleophytology.

Phytological: P h y t o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to phytology; botanical.

Phytologist: P h y t o l o g i s t "n. One skilled in phytology; a writer on plants; a botanist.

Phytology: P h y t o l o g y "n. The science of plants; a description of the kinds and properties of plants; botany.

Phytomer: P h y t o m e r "n. Alt. of Phytomeron

Phytomeron: P h y t o m e r o n "n. An organic element of a flowering plant; a phyton.

Phyton: P h y t o n "n. One of the parts which by their repetition make up a flowering plant  each being a single joint of a stem with its leaf or leaves; a phytomer.

Phytonomy: P h y t o n o m y "n. The science of the origin and growth of plants.

Phytons: P h y t o n s "pl. "of Phyton

Phytopathologist: P h y t o p a t h o l o g i s t "n. One skilled in diseases of plants.

Phytopathology: P h y t o p a t h o l o g y "n. The science of diseases to which plants are liable.

Phytophaga: P h y t o p h a g a "n. pl. A division of Hymenoptera; the sawflies.

Phytophagic: P h y t o p h a g i c "a. Phytophagous.

Phytophagous: P h y t o p h a g o u s "a. Feeding on plants; herbivorous; as  a phytophagous animal.

Phytophagy: P h y t o p h a g y "n. The eating of plants.

Phytophysiology: P h y t o p h y s i o l o g y "n. Vegetable physiology.

Phytotomist: P h y t o t o m i s t "n. One versed in phytotomy.

Phytotomy: P h y t o t o m y "n. The dissection of plants; vegetable anatomy.

Phytozoa: P h y t o z o a "pl. "of Phytozoon

Phytozoaria: P h y t o z o a r i a "n. pl. Same as Infusoria.

Phytozoon: P h y t o z o o n "n. A plantlike animal. The term is sometimes applied to zoophytes.

Phyz: P h y z "n. See Phiz.

Pi: P i "n. A mass of type confusedly mixed or unsorted.

Pi: P i "v. t. To put into a mixed and disordered condition  as type; to mix and disarrange the type of; as to pi a form.

Pia mater: P i a   m a t e r " The delicate and highly vascular membrane immediately investing the brain and spinal cord.

Piacaba: P i a c a b a "n. See Piassava.

Piacle: P i a c l e "n. A heinous offense which requires expiation.

Piacular: P i a c u l a r "a. Expiatory; atoning.

Piacular: P i a c u l a r "a. Requiring expiation; criminal; atrociously bad.

Piacularity: P i a c u l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being piacular; criminality; wickedness.

Piaculous: P i a c u l o u s "a. Same as Piacular.

Pial: P i a l "a. Pertaining to the pia mater.

Pian: P i a n "n. The yaws. See Yaws.

Pianet: P i a n e t "n. The magpie.

Pianet: P i a n e t "n. The lesser woodpecker.

Pianette: P i a n e t t e "n. A small piano; a pianino.

Pianino: P i a n i n o "n. A pianette  or small piano.

Pianissimo: P i a n i s s i m o "a. Very soft; -- a direction to execute a passage as softly as possible. (Abbrev. pp.)

Pianist: P i a n i s t "n. A performer  esp. a skilled performer on the piano.

Piano: P i a n o "a. & adv. Soft; -- a direction to the performer to execute a certain passage softly  and with diminished volume of tone. (Abbrev. p.)

Piano: P i a n o "a. Alt. of Pianoforte

Pianoforte: P i a n o f o r t e "a. A well-known musical instrument somewhat resembling the harpsichord  and consisting of a series of wires of graduated length thickness and tension struck by hammers moved by keys.

Pianograph: P i a n o g r a p h "n. A form of melodiograph applied to a piano.

Piapec: P i a p e c "n. A West African pie (Ptilostomus Senegalensis).

Piarist: P i a r i s t "n. One of a religious order who are the regular clerks of the Scuole Pie (religious schools)  an institute of secondary education founded at Rome in the last years of the 16th century.

Piassava: P i a s s a v a "n. A fibrous product of two Brazilian palm trees (Attalea funifera and Leopoldinia Piassaba)  -- used in making brooms and for other purposes. Called also piacaba and piasaba.

Piaster: P i a s t e r "n. A silver coin of Spain and various other countries. See Peso. The Spanish piaster (commonly called peso  or peso duro) is of about the value of the American dollar. The Italian piaster or scudo was worth from 80 to 100 cents. The Turkish and Egyptian piasters are now worth about four and a half cents.

Piastre: P i a s t r e "n. See Piaster.

Piation: P i a t i o n "n. The act of making atonement; expiation.

Piatti: P i a t t i "n. pl. Cymbals.

Piazza: P i a z z a "n. An open square in a European town  especially an Italian town; hence (Arch.) an arcaded and roofed gallery; a portico. In the United States the word is popularly applied to a veranda.

Piazzas: P i a z z a s "pl. "of Piazza

Pibcorn: P i b c o r n "n. A wind instrument or pipe  with a horn at each end -- used in Wales.

Pibroch: P i b r o c h "n. A Highland air  suited to the particular passion which the musician would either excite or assuage; generally applied to those airs that are played on the bagpipe before the Highlanders when they go out to battle.

Pic: P i c "n. A Turkish cloth measure  varying from 18 to 28 inches.

Pica: P i c a "n. The genus that includes the magpies.

Pica: P i c a "n. A vitiated appetite that craves what is unfit for food  as chalk ashes coal etc.; chthonophagia.

Pica: P i c a "n. A service-book. See Pie.

Pica: P i c a "n. A size of type next larger than small pica  and smaller than English.

Picador: P i c a d o r "n. A horseman armed with a lance  who in a bullfight receives the first attack of the bull and excites him by picking him without attempting to kill him.

Picamar: P i c a m a r "n. An oily liquid hydrocarbon extracted from the creosote of beechwood tar. It consists essentially of certain derivatives of pyrogallol.

Picapare: P i c a p a r e "n. The finfoot.

Picard: P i c a r d "n. One of a sect of Adamites in the fifteenth century; -- so called from one Picard of Flanders. See Adamite.

Picaresque: P i c a r e s q u e "a. Applied to that class of literature in which the principal personage is the Spanish picaro  meaning a rascal a knave a rogue an adventurer.

Picariae: P i c a r i a e "n. pl. An extensive division of birds which includes the woodpeckers  toucans trogons hornbills kingfishers motmots rollers and goatsuckers. By some writers it is made to include also the cuckoos swifts and humming birds.

Picarian: P i c a r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Picariae.

Picarian: P i c a r i a n "n. One of the Picariae.

Picaroon: P i c a r o o n "n. One who plunders; especially  a plunderer of wrecks; a pirate; a corsair; a marauder; a sharper.

Picayune: P i c a y u n e "n. A small coin of the value of six and a quarter cents. See Fippenny bit.

Picayunish: P i c a y u n i s h "a. Petty; paltry; mean; as  a picayunish business.

Piccadil: P i c c a d i l "n. Alt. of Piccadilly

Piccadilly: P i c c a d i l l y "n. A high  stiff collar for the neck; also a hem or band about the skirt of a garment -- worn by men in the 17th century.

Piccage: P i c c a g e "n. Money paid at fairs for leave to break ground for booths.

Piccalilli: P i c c a l i l l i "n. A pickle of various vegetables with pungent species  -- originally made in the East Indies.

Piccolo: P i c c o l o "n. A small  shrill flute the pitch of which is an octave higher than the ordinary flute; an octave flute.

Piccolo: P i c c o l o "n. A small upright piano.

Piccolo: P i c c o l o "n. An organ stop  with a high piercing tone.

Pice: P i c e "n. A small copper coin of the East Indies  worth less than a cent.

Picea: P i c e a "n. A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere  including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones which do not readily fall to pieces in this and other respects differing from the firs.

Picene: P i c e n e "n. A hydrocarbon (C/H/) extracted from the pitchy residue of coal tar and petroleum as a bluish fluorescent crystalline substance.

Piceous: P i c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to pitch; resembling pitch in color or quality; pitchy.

Pichey: P i c h e y "n. A Brazilian armadillo (Dasypus minutus); the little armadillo.

Pichiciago: P i c h i c i a g o "n. A small  burrowing South American edentate (Chlamyphorus truncatus) allied to the armadillos. The shell is attached only along the back.

Pichurim bean: P i c h u r i m   b e a n " The seed of a Brazilian lauraceous tree (Nectandra Puchury) of a taste and smell between those of nutmeg and of sassafras  -- sometimes used medicinally. Called also sassafras nut.

Pici: P i c i "n. pl. A division of birds including the woodpeckers and wrynecks.

Pici: P i c i "pl. "of Picus

Piciform: P i c i f o r m "a. Of or pertaining to Piciformes.

Piciformes: P i c i f o r m e s "n. pl. A group of birds including the woodpeckers  toucans barbets colies kingfishes hornbills and some other related groups.

Picine: P i c i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the woodpeckers (Pici)  or to the Piciformes.

Pick: P i c k "v. To throw; to pitch.

Pick: P i c k "v. To peck at  as a bird with its beak; to strike at with anything pointed; to act upon with a pointed instrument; to pierce; to prick as with a pin.

Pick: P i c k "v. To separate or open by means of a sharp point or points; as  to pick matted wool cotton oakum etc.

Pick: P i c k "v. To open (a lock) as by a wire.

Pick: P i c k "v. To pull apart or away  especially with the fingers; to pluck; to gather as fruit from a tree flowers from the stalk feathers from a fowl etc.

Pick: P i c k "v. To remove something from with a pointed instrument  with the fingers or with the teeth; as to pick the teeth; to pick a bone; to pick a goose; to pick a pocket.

Pick: P i c k "v. To choose; to select; to separate as choice or desirable; to cull; as  to pick one's company; to pick one's way; -- often with out.

Pick: P i c k "v. To take up; esp.  to gather from here and there; to collect; to bring together; as to pick rags; -- often with up; as to pick up a ball or stones; to pick up information.

Pick: P i c k "v. To trim.

Pick: P i c k "v. i. To eat slowly  sparingly or by morsels; to nibble.

Pick: P i c k "v. i. To do anything nicely or carefully  or by attending to small things; to select something with care.

Pick: P i c k "v. i. To steal; to pilfer.

Pick: P i c k "n. A sharp-pointed tool for picking; -- often used in composition; as  a toothpick; a picklock.

Pick: P i c k "n. A heavy iron tool  curved and sometimes pointed at both ends wielded by means of a wooden handle inserted in the middle -- used by quarrymen roadmakers etc.; also a pointed hammer used for dressing millstones.

Pick: P i c k "n. A pike or spike; the sharp point fixed in the center of a buckler.

Pick: P i c k "n. Choice; right of selection; as  to have one's pick.

Pick: P i c k "n. That which would be picked or chosen first; the best; as  the pick of the flock.

Pick: P i c k "n. A particle of ink or paper imbedded in the hollow of a letter  filling up its face and occasioning a spot on a printed sheet.

Pick: P i c k "n. That which is picked in  as with a pointed pencil to correct an unevenness in a picture.

Pick: P i c k "n. The blow which drives the shuttle  -- the rate of speed of a loom being reckoned as so many picks per minute; hence in describing the fineness of a fabric a weft thread; as so many picks to an inch.

Pick-fault: P i c k - f a u l t "n. One who seeks out faults.

Pickaback: P i c k a b a c k "adv. On the back or shoulders; as  to ride pickback.

Pickaninnies: P i c k a n i n n i e s "pl. "of Pickaninny

Pickaninny: P i c k a n i n n y "n. A small child; especially  a negro or mulatto infant.

Pickapack: P i c k a p a c k "adv. Pickaback.

Pickax: P i c k a x "n. Alt. of Pickaxe

Pickaxe: P i c k a x e "n. A pick with a point at one end  a transverse edge or blade at the other and a handle inserted at the middle; a hammer with a flattened end for driving wedges and a pointed end for piercing as it strikes.

Pickback: P i c k b a c k "adv. On the back.

Picke: P i c k e "n. A small piece of land inclosed with a hedge; a close.

Picked: P i c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Pick

Picked: P i c k e d "a. Pointed; sharp.

Picked: P i c k e d "a. Having a pike or spine on the back; -- said of certain fishes.

Picked: P i c k e d "a. Carefully selected; chosen; as  picked men.

Picked: P i c k e d "a. Fine; spruce; smart; precise; dianty.

Pickedness: P i c k e d n e s s "n. The state of being sharpened; pointedness.

Pickedness: P i c k e d n e s s "n. Fineness; spruceness; smartness.

Pickeer: P i c k e e r "v. i. To make a raid for booty; to maraud; also  to skirmish in advance of an army. See Picaroon.

Pickeered: P i c k e e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Pickeer

Pickeerer: P i c k e e r e r "n. One who pickeers.

Pickeering: P i c k e e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pickeer

Picker: P i c k e r "n. One who  or that which picks in any sense -- as one who uses a pick; one who gathers; a thief; a pick; a pickax; as a cotton picker.

Picker: P i c k e r "n. A machine for picking fibrous materials to pieces so as to loosen and separate the fiber.

Picker: P i c k e r "n. The piece in a loom which strikes the end of the shuttle  and impels it through the warp.

Picker: P i c k e r "n. A priming wire for cleaning the vent.

Pickerel: P i c k e r e l "n. A young or small pike.

Pickerel: P i c k e r e l "n. Any one of several species of freshwater fishes of the genus Esox  esp. the smaller species.

Pickerel: P i c k e r e l "n. The glasseye  or wall-eyed pike. See Wall-eye.

Pickering: P i c k e r i n g "n. The sauger of the St.Lawrence River.

Pickery: P i c k e r y "n. Petty theft.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. A stake sharpened or pointed  especially one used in fortification and encampments to mark bounds and angles; or one used for tethering horses.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. A pointed pale  used in marking fences.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. A detached body of troops serving to guard an army from surprise  and to oppose reconnoitering parties of the enemy; -- called also outlying picket.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. By extension  men appointed by a trades union or other labor organization to intercept outsiders and prevent them from working for employers with whom the organization is at variance.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. A military punishment  formerly resorted to in which the offender was forced to stand with one foot on a pointed stake.

Picket: P i c k e t "n. A game at cards. See Piquet.

Picket: P i c k e t "v. t. To fortify with pointed stakes.

Picket: P i c k e t "v. t. To inclose or fence with pickets or pales.

Picket: P i c k e t "v. t. To tether to  or as to a picket; as to picket a horse.

Picket: P i c k e t "v. t. To guard  as a camp or road by an outlying picket.

Picket: P i c k e t "v. t. To torture by compelling to stand with one foot on a pointed stake.

Picketed: P i c k e t e d "imp. & p. p. of Picket

Picketee: P i c k e t e e "n. See Picotee.

Picketing: P i c k e t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Picket

Picking: P i c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pick

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. The act of digging or breaking up  as with a pick.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. The act of choosing  plucking or gathering.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. That which is  or may be picked or gleaned.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. Pilfering; also  that which is pilfered.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. The pulverized shells of oysters used in making walks.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. Rough sorting of ore.

Picking: P i c k i n g "n. Overburned bricks.

Picking: P i c k i n g "a. Done or made as with a pointed tool; as  a picking sound.

Picking: P i c k i n g "a. Nice; careful.

Pickle: P i c k l e "n. See Picle.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. A solution of salt and water  in which fish meat etc. may be preserved or corned; brine.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. Vinegar  plain or spiced used for preserving vegetables fish eggs oysters etc.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. Any article of food which has been preserved in brine or in vinegar.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. A bath of dilute sulphuric or nitric acid  etc. to remove burnt sand scale rust etc. from the surface of castings or other articles of metal or to brighten them or improve their color.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. A troublesome child; as  a little pickle.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. To preserve or season in pickle; to treat with some kind of pickle; as  to pickle herrings or cucumbers.

Pickle: P i c k l e "v. t. To give an antique appearance to; -- said of copies or imitations of paintings by the old masters.

Pickle-herring: P i c k l e - h e r r i n g "n. A herring preserved in brine; a pickled herring.

Pickle-herring: P i c k l e - h e r r i n g "n. A merry-andrew; a buffoon.

Pickled: P i c k l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pickle

Pickled: P i c k l e d "a. Preserved in a pickle.

Pickler: P i c k l e r "n. One who makes pickles.

Pickling: P i c k l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pickle

Picklock: P i c k l o c k "n. An instrument for picking locks.

Picklock: P i c k l o c k "n. One who picks locks; a thief.

Pickmire: P i c k m i r e "n. The pewit  or black-headed gull.

Picknick: P i c k n i c k "n. See Picnic.

Pickpack: P i c k p a c k "adv. Pickaback.

Pickpennies: P i c k p e n n i e s "pl. "of Pickpenny

Pickpenny: P i c k p e n n y "n. A miser; also  a sharper.

Pickpocket: P i c k p o c k e t "n. One who steals purses or other articles from pockets.

Pickpurse: P i c k p u r s e "n. One who steals purses  or money from purses.

Picksy: P i c k s y "n. See Pixy.

Pickthank: P i c k t h a n k "n. One who strives to put another under obligation; an officious person; hence  a flatterer. Used also adjectively.

Picktooth: P i c k t o o t h "n. A toothpick.

Picnic: P i c n i c "v. Formerly  an entertainment at which each person contributed some dish to a common table; now an excursion or pleasure party in which the members partake of a collation or repast (usually in the open air and from food carried by themselves).

Picnic: P i c n i c "v. i. To go on a picnic  or pleasure excursion; to eat in public fashion.

Picnicked: P i c n i c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Picnic

Picnicker: P i c n i c k e r "n. One who takes part in a picnic.

Picnicking: P i c n i c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Picnic

Picoid: P i c o i d "a. Like or pertaining to the Pici.

Picoline: P i c o l i n e "n. Any one of three isometric bases (C6H7N) related to pyridine  and obtained from bone oil acrolein ammonia and coal-tar naphtha as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also methyl pyridine.

Picotee: P i c o t e e "n. Alt. of Picotine

Picotine: P i c o t i n e "n. A variety of carnation having petals of a light color variously dotted and spotted at the edges.

Picquet: P i c q u e t "n. See Piquet.

Picra: P i c r a "n. The powder of aloes with canella  formerly officinal employed as a cathartic.

Picrate: P i c r a t e "n. A salt of picric acid.

Picric: P i c r i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating a strong organic acid (called picric acid) intensely bitter.

Picrite: P i c r i t e "n. A dark green igneous rock  consisting largely of chrysolite with hornblende augite biotite etc.

Picrolite: P i c r o l i t e "n. A fibrous variety of serpentine.

Picromel: P i c r o m e l "n. A colorless viscous substance having a bitter-sweet taste.

Picrotoxin: P i c r o t o x i n "n. A bitter white crystalline substance found in the cocculus indicus. It is a peculiar poisonous neurotic and intoxicant  and consists of a mixture of several neutral substances.

Picryl: P i c r y l "n. The hypothetical radical of picric acid  analogous to phenyl.

Pictish: P i c t i s h "a. Of or pertaining to Picts; resembling the Picts.

Pictograph: P i c t o g r a p h "n. A picture or hieroglyph representing and expressing an idea.

Pictorial: P i c t o r i a l "a. Of or pertaining to pictures; illustrated by pictures; forming pictures; representing with the clearness of a picture; as  a pictorial dictionary; a pictorial imagination.

Pictoric: P i c t o r i c "a. Alt. of Pictorical

Pictorical: P i c t o r i c a l "a. Pictorial.

Picts: P i c t s "n. pl. A race of people of uncertain origin  who inhabited Scotland in early times.

Pictura: P i c t u r a "n. Pattern of coloration.

Picturable: P i c t u r a b l e "a. Capable of being pictured  or represented by a picture.

Pictural: P i c t u r a l "a. Pictorial.

Pictural: P i c t u r a l "n. A picture.

Picture: P i c t u r e "n. The art of painting; representation by painting.

Picture: P i c t u r e "n. A representation of anything (as a person  a landscape a building) upon canvas paper or other surface produced by means of painting drawing engraving photography etc.; a representation in colors. By extension a figure; a model.

Picture: P i c t u r e "n. An image or resemblance; a representation  either to the eye or to the mind; that which by its likeness brings vividly to mind some other thing; as a child is the picture of his father; the man is the picture of grief.

Picture: P i c t u r e "v. t. To draw or paint a resemblance of; to delineate; to represent; to form or present an ideal likeness of; to bring before the mind.

Pictured: P i c t u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Picture

Pictured: P i c t u r e d "a. Furnished with pictures; represented by a picture or pictures; as  a pictured scene.

Picturer: P i c t u r e r "n. One who makes pictures; a painter.

Picturesque: P i c t u r e s q u e "a. Forming  or fitted to form a good or pleasing picture; representing with the clearness or ideal beauty appropriate to a picture; expressing that peculiar kind of beauty which is agreeable in a picture natural or artificial; graphic; vivid; as a picturesque scene or attitude; picturesque language.

Picturesquish: P i c t u r e s q u i s h "a. Somewhat picturesque.

Picturing: P i c t u r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Picture

Picturize: P i c t u r i z e "v. t. To picture.

Picturize: P i c t u r i z e "v. t. To adorn with pictures.

Picturized: P i c t u r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Picturize

Picturizing: P i c t u r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Picturize

Picul: P i c u l "n. A commercial weight varying in different countries and for different commodities. In Borneo it is 135/ lbs.; in China and Sumatra  133/ lbs.; in Japan 133/ lbs.; but sometimes 130 lbs. etc. Called also by the Chinese tan.

Piculet: P i c u l e t "n. Any species of very small woodpeckers of the genus Picumnus and allied genera. Their tail feathers are not stiff and sharp at the tips  as in ordinary woodpeckers.

Picus: P i c u s "n. A genus of woodpeckers  including some of the common American and European species.

Piddle: P i d d l e "v. i. To deal in trifles; to concern one's self with trivial matters rather than with those that are important.

Piddle: P i d d l e "v. i. To be squeamishly nice about one's food.

Piddle: P i d d l e "v. i. To urinate; -- child's word.

Piddled: P i d d l e d "imp. & p. p. of Piddle

Piddler: P i d d l e r "n. One who piddles.

Piddling: P i d d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Piddle

Piddling: P i d d l i n g "a. Trifling; trivial; frivolous; paltry; -- applied to persons and things.

Piddock: P i d d o c k "n. Any species of Pholas; a pholad. See Pholas.

Pie: P i e "n. An article of food consisting of paste baked with something in it or under it; as  chicken pie; venison pie; mince pie; apple pie; pumpkin pie.

Pie: P i e "n. See Camp  n. 5.

Pie: P i e "n. A magpie.

Pie: P i e "n. Any other species of the genus Pica  and of several allied genera.

Pie: P i e "n. The service book.

Pie: P i e "n. Type confusedly mixed. See Pi.

Pie: P i e "v. t. See Pi.

Piebald: P i e b a l d "a. Having spots and patches of black and white  or other colors; mottled; pied.

Piebald: P i e b a l d "a. Fig.: Mixed.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A fragment or part of anything separated from the whole  in any manner as by cutting splitting breaking or tearing; a part; a portion; as a piece of sugar; to break in pieces.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A definite portion or quantity  as of goods or work; as a piece of broadcloth; a piece of wall paper.

Piece: P i e c e "n. Any one thing conceived of as apart from other things of the same kind; an individual article; a distinct single effort of a series; a definite performance

Piece: P i e c e "n. A literary or artistic composition; as  a piece of poetry music or statuary.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A musket  gun or cannon; as a battery of six pieces; a following piece.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A coin; as  a sixpenny piece; -- formerly applied specifically to an English gold coin worth 22 shillings.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A fact; an item; as  a piece of news; a piece of knowledge.

Piece: P i e c e "n. An individual; -- applied to a person as being of a certain nature or quality; often  but not always used slightingly or in contempt.

Piece: P i e c e "n. One of the superior men  distinguished from a pawn.

Piece: P i e c e "n. A castle; a fortified building.

Piece: P i e c e "v. t. To make  enlarge or repair by the addition of a piece or pieces; to patch; as to piece a garment; -- often with out.

Piece: P i e c e "v. t. To unite; to join; to combine.

Piece: P i e c e "v. i. To unite by a coalescence of parts; to fit together; to join.

Pieced: P i e c e d "imp. & p. p. of Piece

Pieceless: P i e c e l e s s "a. Not made of pieces; whole; entire.

Piecely: P i e c e l y "adv. In pieces; piecemeal.

Piecemeal: P i e c e m e a l "adv. In pieces; in parts or fragments.

Piecemeal: P i e c e m e a l "adv. Piece by piece; by little and little in succession.

Piecemeal: P i e c e m e a l "a. Made up of parts or pieces; single; separate.

Piecemeal: P i e c e m e a l "n. A fragment; a scrap.

Piecemealed: P i e c e m e a l e d "a. Divided into pieces.

Piecener: P i e c e n e r "n. One who supplies rolls of wool to the slubbing machine in woolen mills.

Piecener: P i e c e n e r "n. Same as Piecer  2.

Piecer: P i e c e r "n. One who pieces; a patcher.

Piecer: P i e c e r "n. A child employed in spinning mill to tie together broken threads.

Piecework: P i e c e w o r k "n. Work done by the piece or job; work paid for at a rate based on the amount of work done  rather than on the time employed.

Piecing: P i e c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Piece

Pied: P i e d "imp. & p. p. of Pi

Pied: P i e d " imp. & p. p. of Pi  or Pie v.

Pied: P i e d "a. Variegated with spots of different colors; party-colored; spotted; piebald.

Piedmont: P i e d m o n t "a. Noting the region of foothills near the base of a mountain chain.

Piedmontite: P i e d m o n t i t e "n. A manganesian kind of epidote  from Piedmont. See Epidote.

Piedness: P i e d n e s s "n. The state of being pied.

Piedouche: P i e d o u c h e "n. A pedestal of small size  used to support small objects as busts vases and the like.

Piedstall: P i e d s t a l l "n. See Pedestal.

Pieing: P i e i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pi

Pieman: P i e m a n "n. A man who makes or sells pies.

Piemen: P i e m e n "pl. "of Pieman

Piend: P i e n d "n. See Peen.

Pieno: P i e n o "a. Full; having all the instruments.

Pieplant: P i e p l a n t "n. A plant (Rheum Rhaponticum) the leafstalks of which are acid  and are used in making pies; the garden rhubarb.

Piepoudre: P i e p o u d r e "n. Alt. of Piepowder

Piepowder: P i e p o w d e r "n. An ancient court of record in England  formerly incident to every fair and market of which the steward of him who owned or had the toll was the judge.

Pier: P i e r "n. Any detached mass of masonry  whether insulated or supporting one side of an arch or lintel as of a bridge; the piece of wall between two openings.

Pier: P i e r "n. Any additional or auxiliary mass of masonry used to stiffen a wall. See Buttress.

Pier: P i e r "n. A projecting wharf or landing place.

Pierage: P i e r a g e "n. Same as Wharfage.

Pierce: P i e r c e "v. t. To thrust into  penetrate or transfix with a pointed instrument.

Pierce: P i e r c e "v. t. To penetrate; to enter; to force a way into or through; to pass into or through; as  to pierce the enemy's line; a shot pierced the ship.

Pierce: P i e r c e "v. t. Fig.: To penetrate; to affect deeply; as  to pierce a mystery.

Pierce: P i e r c e "v. i. To enter; to penetrate; to make a way into or through something  as a pointed instrument does; -- used literally and figuratively.

Pierceable: P i e r c e a b l e "a. That may be pierced.

Pierced: P i e r c e d "imp. & p. p. of Pierce

Pierced: P i e r c e d "a. Penetrated; entered; perforated.

Piercel: P i e r c e l "n. A kind of gimlet for making vents in casks; -- called also piercer.

Piercer: P i e r c e r "n. One who  or that which pierces or perforates

Piercer: P i e r c e r "n. An instrument used in forming eyelets; a stiletto.

Piercer: P i e r c e r "n. A piercel.

Piercer: P i e r c e r "n. The ovipositor  or sting of an insect.

Piercer: P i e r c e r "n. An insect provided with an ovipositor.

Piercing: P i e r c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pierce

Piercing: P i e r c i n g "a. Forcibly entering  or adapted to enter at or by a point; perforating; penetrating; keen; -- used also figuratively; as a piercing instrument or thrust.

Pierian: P i e r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Pierides or Muses.

Pierid: P i e r i d "n. Any butterfly of the genus Pieris and related genera. See Cabbage butterfly  under Cabbage.

Pierides: P i e r i d e s "n. pl. The Muses.

Piet: P i e t "n. The dipper  or water ouzel.

Piet: P i e t "n. The magpie.

Pieta: P i e t a "n. A representation of the dead Christ  attended by the Virgin Mary or by holy women and angels.

Pietism: P i e t i s m "n. The principle or practice of the Pietists.

Pietism: P i e t i s m "n. Strict devotion; also  affectation of devotion.

Pietist: P i e t i s t "n. One of a class of religious reformers in Germany in the 17th century who sought to revive declining piety in the Protestant churches; -- often applied as a term of reproach to those who make a display of religious feeling. Also used adjectively.

Pietistic: P i e t i s t i c "a. Alt. of Pietistical

Pietistical: P i e t i s t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the Pietists; hence  in contempt affectedly or demonstratively religious.

Pietra dura: P i e t r a   d u r a " Hard and fine stones in general  such as are used for inlay and the like as distinguished from the softer stones used in building; thus a Florentine mosaic is a familiar instance of work in pietra dura though the ground may be soft marble.

Piety: P i e t y "n. Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being  and love of his character; loving obedience to the will of God and earnest devotion to his service.

Piety: P i e t y "n. Duty; dutifulness; filial reverence and devotion; affectionate reverence and service shown toward parents  relatives benefactors country etc.

Piewipe: P i e w i p e "n. The lapwing  or pewit.

Piezometer: P i e z o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the compressibility of liquids.

Piezometer: P i e z o m e t e r "n. A gauge connected with a water main to show the pressure at that point.

Piffara: P i f f a r a "n. A fife; also  a rude kind of oboe or a bagpipe with an inflated skin for reservoir.

Piffero: P i f f e r o "n. Alt. of Piffara

Pig: P i g "n. A piggin.

Pig: P i g "n. The young of swine  male or female; also any swine; a hog.

Pig: P i g "n. Any wild species of the genus Sus and related genera.

Pig: P i g "n. An oblong mass of cast iron  lead or other metal. See Mine pig under Mine.

Pig: P i g "n. One who is hoggish; a greedy person.

Pig: P i g "v. t. & i. To bring forth (pigs); to bring forth in the manner of pigs; to farrow.

Pig: P i g "v. t. & i. To huddle or lie together like pigs  in one bed.

Pig-eyed: P i g - e y e d "a. Having small  deep-set eyes.

Pig-headed: P i g - h e a d e d "a. Having a head like a pig; hence  figuratively: stupidity obstinate; perverse; stubborn.

Pig-jawed: P i g - j a w e d "a. Having the upper jaw projecting beyond the lower  with the upper incisors in advance of the lower; -- said of dogs.

Pig-sticking: P i g - s t i c k i n g "n. Boar hunting; -- so called by Anglo-Indians.

Pigeon: P i g e o n "n. Any bird of the order Columbae  of which numerous species occur in nearly all parts of the world.

Pigeon: P i g e o n "n. An unsuspected victim of sharpers; a gull.

Pigeon: P i g e o n "v. t. To pluck; to fleece; to swindle by tricks in gambling.

Pigeon-breasted: P i g e o n - b r e a s t e d "a. Having a breast like a pigeon  -- the sternum being so prominent as to constitute a deformity; chicken-breasted.

Pigeon-hearted: P i g e o n - h e a r t e d "a. Timid; easily frightened; chicken-hearted.

Pigeon-livered: P i g e o n - l i v e r e d "a. Pigeon-hearted.

Pigeonfoot: P i g e o n f o o t "n. The dove's-foot geranium (Geranium molle).

Pigeonhole: P i g e o n h o l e "n. A small compartment in a desk or case for the keeping of letters  documents etc.; -- so called from the resemblance of a row of them to the compartments in a dovecote.

Pigeonhole: P i g e o n h o l e "v. t. To place in the pigeonhole of a case or cabinet; hence  to put away; to lay aside indefinitely; as to pigeonhole a letter or a report.

Pigeonry: P i g e o n r y "n. A place for pigeons; a dovecote.

Pigeontoed: P i g e o n t o e d "a. Having the toes turned in.

Pigfish: P i g f i s h "n. Any one of several species of salt-water grunts; -- called also hogfish.

Pigfish: P i g f i s h "n. A sculpin. The name is also applied locally to several other fishes.

Pigfoot: P i g f o o t "n. A marine fish (Scorpaena porcus)  native of Europe. It is reddish brown mottled with dark brown and black.

Pigg: P i g g "n. A piggin. See 1st Pig.

Pigged: P i g g e d "imp. & p. p. of Pig

Piggeries: P i g g e r i e s "pl. "of Piggery

Piggery: P i g g e r y "n. A place where swine are kept.

Piggin: P i g g i n "n. A small wooden pail or tub with an upright stave for a handle  -- often used as a dipper.

Pigging: P i g g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pig

Piggish: P i g g i s h "a. Relating to  or like a pig; greedy.

Pight: P i g h t "imp. & p. p. Pitched; fixed; determined.

Pightel: P i g h t e l "n. A small inclosure.

Pigmean: P i g m e a n "a. See Pygmean.

Pigment: P i g m e n t "n. Any material from which a dye  a paint or the like may be prepared; particularly the refined and purified coloring matter ready for mixing with an appropriate vehicle.

Pigment: P i g m e n t "n. Any one of the colored substances found in animal and vegetable tissues and fluids  as bilirubin urobilin chlorophyll etc.

Pigment: P i g m e n t "n. Wine flavored with species and honey.

Pigmental: P i g m e n t a l "a. Alt. of Pigmentary

Pigmentary: P i g m e n t a r y "a. Of or pertaining to pigments; furnished with pigments.

Pigmentation: P i g m e n t a t i o n "n. A deposition  esp. an excessive deposition of coloring matter; as pigmentation of the liver.

Pigmented: P i g m e n t e d "a. Colored; specifically (Biol.)  filled or imbued with pigment; as pigmented epithelial cells; pigmented granules.

Pigmentous: P i g m e n t o u s "a. Pigmental.

Pigmy: P i g m y "n. See Pygmy.

Pignerate: P i g n e r a t e "v. t. To pledge or pawn.

Pignerate: P i g n e r a t e "v. t. to receive in pawn  as a pawnbroker does.

Pignora: P i g n o r a "pl. "of Pignus

Pignoration: P i g n o r a t i o n "n. The act of pledging or pawning.

Pignoration: P i g n o r a t i o n "n. The taking of cattle doing damage  by way of pledge till satisfaction is made.

Pignorative: P i g n o r a t i v e "a. Pledging  pawning.

Pignus: P i g n u s "n. A pledge or pawn.

Pignut: P i g n u t "n. See Groundnut (d).

Pignut: P i g n u t "n. The bitter-flavored nut of a species of hickory (Carya glabra  / porcina); also the tree itself.

Pigpecker: P i g p e c k e r "n. The European garden warbler (Sylvia  / Currica hortensis); -- called also beccafico and greater pettychaps.

Pigpen: P i g p e n "n. A pen  or sty for pigs.

Pigskin: P i g s k i n "n. The skin of a pig  -- used chiefly for making saddles; hence a colloquial or slang term for a saddle.

Pigsney: P i g s n e y "n. A word of endearment for a girl or woman.

Pigsties: P i g s t i e s "pl. "of Pigsty

Pigsty: P i g s t y "n. A pigpen.

Pigtail: P i g t a i l "n. The tail of a pig.

Pigtail: P i g t a i l "n. A cue  or queue.

Pigtail: P i g t a i l "n. A kind of twisted chewing tobacco.

Pigtailed: P i g t a i l e d "a. Having a tail like a pig's; as  the pigtailed baboon.

Pigweed: P i g w e e d "n. A name of several annual weeds. See Goosefoot  and Lamb's-quarters.

Pigwidgeon: P i g w i d g e o n "n. A cant word for anything petty or small. It is used by Drayton as the name of a fairy.

Pika: P i k a "n. Any one of several species of rodents of the genus Lagomys  resembling small tailless rabbits. They inhabit the high mountains of Asia and America. Called also calling hare and crying hare. See Chief hare.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A foot soldier's weapon  consisting of a long wooden shaft or staff with a pointed steel head. It is now superseded by the bayonet.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A pointed head or spike; esp.  one in the center of a shield or target.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A hayfork.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A pick.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A pointed or peaked hill.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A large haycock.

Pike: P i k e "n. & v. A turnpike; a toll bar.

Pike: P i k e "sing. & pl. A large fresh-water fish (Esox lucius)  found in Europe and America highly valued as a food fish; -- called also pickerel gedd luce and jack.

Pike-devant: P i k e - d e v a n t "n. A pointed beard.

Piked: P i k e d "a. Furnished with a pike; ending in a point; peaked; pointed.

Pikelet: P i k e l e t "n. Alt. of Pikelin

Pikelin: P i k e l i n "n. A light  thin cake or muffin.

Pikeman: P i k e m a n "pl. "of Pikeman

Pikeman: P i k e m a n "n. A soldier armed with a pike.

Pikeman: P i k e m a n "n. A miner who works with a pick.

Pikeman: P i k e m a n "n. A keeper of a turnpike gate.

Pikestaff: P i k e s t a f f "n. The staff  or shaft of a pike.

Pikestaff: P i k e s t a f f "n. A staff with a spike in the lower end  to guard against slipping.

Piketail: P i k e t a i l "n. See Pintail  1.

Pikrolite: P i k r o l i t e "n. See Picrolite.

Pilage: P i l a g e "n. See Pelage.

Pilaster: P i l a s t e r "n. An upright architectural member right-angled in plan  constructionally a pier (See Pier 1 (b)) but architecturally corresponding to a column having capital shaft and base to agree with those of the columns of the same order. In most cases the projection from the wall is one third of its width or less.

Pilastered: P i l a s t e r e d "a. Furnished with pilasters.

Pilau: P i l a u "n. See Pillau.

Pilch: P i l c h "n. A gown or case of skin  or one trimmed or lined with fur.

Pilchard: P i l c h a r d "n. A small European food fish (Clupea pilchardus) resembling the herring  but thicker and rounder. It is sometimes taken in great numbers on the coast of England.

Pilcher: P i l c h e r "n. A scabbard  as of a sword.

Pilcher: P i l c h e r "n. The pilchard.

Pilcrow: P i l c r o w "n. a paragraph mark  /.

Pildia: P i l d i a "pl. "of Pilidium

Pile: P i l e "n. A hair; hence  the fiber of wool cotton and the like; also the nap when thick or heavy as of carpeting and velvet.

Pile: P i l e "n. A covering of hair or fur.

Pile: P i l e "n. The head of an arrow or spear.

Pile: P i l e "n. A large stake  or piece of timber pointed and driven into the earth as at the bottom of a river or in a harbor where the ground is soft for the support of a building a pier or other superstructure or to form a cofferdam etc.

Pile: P i l e "n. One of the ordinaries or subordinaries having the form of a wedge  usually placed palewise with the broadest end uppermost.

Pile: P i l e "v. t. To drive piles into; to fill with piles; to strengthen with piles.

Pile: P i l e "n. A mass of things heaped together; a heap; as  a pile of stones; a pile of wood.

Pile: P i l e "n. A mass formed in layers; as  a pile of shot.

Pile: P i l e "n. A funeral pile; a pyre.

Pile: P i l e "n. A large building  or mass of buildings.

Pile: P i l e "n. Same as Fagot  n. 2.

Pile: P i l e "n. A vertical series of alternate disks of two dissimilar metals  as copper and zinc laid up with disks of cloth or paper moistened with acid water between them for producing a current of electricity; -- commonly called Volta's pile voltaic pile or galvanic pile.

Pile: P i l e "n. The reverse of a coin. See Reverse.

Pile: P i l e "v. t. To lay or throw into a pile or heap; to heap up; to collect into a mass; to accumulate; to amass; -- often with up; as  to pile up wood.

Pile: P i l e "v. t. To cover with heaps; or in great abundance; to fill or overfill; to load.

Pile-worn: P i l e - w o r n "a. Having the pile worn off; threadbare.

Pileate: P i l e a t e "a. Alt. of Pileated

Pileated: P i l e a t e d "a. Having the form of a cap for the head.

Pileated: P i l e a t e d "a. Having a crest covering the pileus  or whole top of the head.

Piled: P i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pile

Piled: P i l e d "a. Having a pile or point; pointed.

Piled: P i l e d "a. Having a pile or nap.

Piled: P i l e d "a. Formed from a pile or fagot; as  piled iron.

Pilei: P i l e i "pl. "of Pileus

Pileiform: P i l e i f o r m "a. Having the form of a pileus or cap; pileate.

Pilement: P i l e m e n t "n. An accumulation; a heap.

Pilenta: P i l e n t a "pl. "of Pilentum

Pilentum: P i l e n t u m "n. An easy chariot or carriage  used by Roman ladies and in which the vessels etc. for sacred rites were carried.

Pileorhiza: P i l e o r h i z a "n. A cap of cells which covers the growing extremity of a root; a rootcap.

Pileous: P i l e o u s "a. Consisting of  or covered with hair; hairy; pilose.

Piler: P i l e r "n. One who places things in a pile.

Piles: P i l e s "n. pl. The small  troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus and lower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids. See Hemorrhoids. [The singular pile is sometimes used.]

Pileus: P i l e u s "n. A kind of skull cap of felt.

Pileus: P i l e u s "n. The expanded upper portion of many of the fungi. See Mushroom.

Pileus: P i l e u s "n. The top of the head of a bird  from the bill to the nape.

Pileworm: P i l e w o r m "n. The teredo.

Pilewort: P i l e w o r t "n. A plant (Ranunculus Ficaria of Linnaeus) whose tuberous roots have been used in poultices as a specific for the piles.

Pilfer: P i l f e r "v. i. To steal in small quantities  or articles of small value; to practice petty theft.

Pilfer: P i l f e r "v. t. To take by petty theft; to filch; to steal little by little.

Pilfered: P i l f e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Pilfer

Pilferer: P i l f e r e r "n. One who pilfers; a petty thief.

Pilfering: P i l f e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pilfer

Pilfering: P i l f e r i n g "a. Thieving in a small way.

Pilfering: P i l f e r i n g "n. Petty theft.

Pilfery: P i l f e r y "n. Petty theft.

Pilgarlic: P i l g a r l i c "n. One who has lost his hair by disease; a sneaking fellow  or one who is hardly used.

Pilgrim: P i l g r i m "n. A wayfarer; a wanderer; a traveler; a stranger.

Pilgrim: P i l g r i m "n. One who travels far  or in strange lands to visit some holy place or shrine as a devotee; as a pilgrim to Loretto; Canterbury pilgrims. See Palmer.

Pilgrim: P i l g r i m "a. Of or pertaining to a pilgrim  or pilgrims; making pilgrimages.

Pilgrim: P i l g r i m "v. i. To journey; to wander; to ramble.

Pilgrimage: P i l g r i m a g e "n. The journey of a pilgrim; a long journey; especially  a journey to a shrine or other sacred place. Fig. the journey of human life.

Pilgrimage: P i l g r i m a g e "n. A tedious and wearisome time.

Pilgrimize: P i l g r i m i z e "v. i. To wander as a pilgrim; to go on a pilgrimage.

Pilidium: P i l i d i u m "n. The free-swimming  hat-shaped larva of certain nemertean worms. It has no resemblance to its parent and the young worm develops in its interior.

Pilifera: P i l i f e r a "n. pl. Same as Mammalia.

Piliferous: P i l i f e r o u s "a. Bearing a single slender bristle  or hair.

Piliferous: P i l i f e r o u s "a. Beset with hairs.

Piliform: P i l i f o r m "a. Resembling hairs or down.

Piligerous: P i l i g e r o u s "a. Bearing hair; covered with hair or down; piliferous.

Piling: P i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pile

Piling: P i l i n g "n. The act of heaping up.

Piling: P i l i n g "n. The process of building up  heating and working fagots or piles to form bars etc.

Piling: P i l i n g "n. A series of piles; piles considered collectively; as  the piling of a bridge.

Pill: P i l l "n. The peel or skin.

Pill: P i l l "v. i. To be peeled; to peel off in flakes.

Pill: P i l l "v. t. To deprive of hair; to make bald.

Pill: P i l l "v. t. & i. To rob; to plunder; to pillage; to peel. See Peel  to plunder.

Pill: P i l l "n. A medicine in the form of a little ball  or small round mass to be swallowed whole.

Pill: P i l l "n. Figuratively  something offensive or nauseous which must be accepted or endured.

Pill-willet: P i l l - w i l l e t "n. The willet.

Pillage: P i l l a g e "n. The act of pillaging; robbery.

Pillage: P i l l a g e "n. That which is taken from another or others by open force  particularly and chiefly from enemies in war; plunder; spoil; booty.

Pillage: P i l l a g e "v. i. To strip of money or goods by open violence; to plunder; to spoil; to lay waste; as  to pillage the camp of an enemy.

Pillage: P i l l a g e "v. i. To take spoil; to plunder; to ravage.

Pillaged: P i l l a g e d "imp. & p. p. of Pillage

Pillager: P i l l a g e r "n. One who pillages.

Pillar: P i l l a r "n. The general and popular term for a firm  upright insulated support for a superstructure; a pier column or post; also a column or shaft not supporting a superstructure as one erected for a monument or an ornament.

Pillar: P i l l a r "n. Figuratively  that which resembles such a pillar in appearance character or office; a supporter or mainstay; as the Pillars of Hercules; a pillar of the state.

Pillar: P i l l a r "n. A portable ornamental column  formerly carried before a cardinal as emblematic of his support to the church.

Pillar: P i l l a r "n. The center of the volta  ring or manege ground around which a horse turns.

Pillar: P i l l a r "a. Having a support in the form of a pillar  instead of legs; as a pillar drill.

Pillar-block: P i l l a r - b l o c k "n. See under Pillow.

Pillau: P i l l a u "n. An Oriental dish consisting of rice boiled with mutton  fat or butter.

Pilled: P i l l e d "a. Stripped of hair; scant of hair; bald.

Pilloried: P i l l o r i e d "imp. & p. p. of Pillory

Pillorize: P i l l o r i z e "v. t. To set in  or punish with the pillory; to pillory.

Pillory: P i l l o r y "n. A frame of adjustable boards erected on a post  and having holes through which the head and hands of an offender were thrust so as to be exposed in front of it.

Pillory: P i l l o r y "v. t. To set in  or punish with the pillory.

Pillory: P i l l o r y "v. t. Figuratively  to expose to public scorn.

Pillow: P i l l o w "n. Anything used to support the head of a person when reposing; especially  a sack or case filled with feathers down hair or other soft material.

Pillow: P i l l o w "n. A piece of metal or wood  forming a support to equalize pressure; a brass; a pillow block.

Pillow: P i l l o w "n. A block under the inner end of a bowsprit.

Pillow: P i l l o w "n. A kind of plain  coarse fustian.

Pillow: P i l l o w "v. t. To rest or lay upon  or as upon a pillow; to support; as to pillow the head.

Pillowcase: P i l l o w c a s e "n. A removable case or covering for a pillow  usually of white linen or cotton cloth.

Pillowed: P i l l o w e d "imp. & p. p. of Pillow

Pillowed: P i l l o w e d "a. Provided with a pillow or pillows; having the head resting on  or as on a pillow.

Pillowing: P i l l o w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pillow

Pillowy: P i l l o w y "a. Like a pillow.

Pillworm: P i l l w o r m "n. Any myriapod of the genus Iulus and allied genera which rolls up spirally; a galleyworm. See Illust. under Myriapod.

Pillwort: P i l l w o r t "n. Any plant of the genus Pilularia; minute aquatic cryptograms  with small pill-shaped fruit; -- sometimes called peppergrass.

Pilocarpine: P i l o c a r p i n e "n. An alkaloid extracted from jaborandi (Pilocarpus pennatifolius) as a white amorphous or crystalline substance which has a peculiar effect on the vasomotor system.

Pilorhizae: P i l o r h i z a e "pl. "of Pileorhiza

Pilose: P i l o s e "a. Hairy; full of  or made of hair.

Pilose: P i l o s e "a. Clothed thickly with pile or soft down.

Pilose: P i l o s e "a. Covered with long  slender hairs; resembling long hairs; hairy; as pilose pubescence.

Pilosity: P i l o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being pilose; hairiness.

Pilot: P i l o t "n. One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.

Pilot: P i l o t "n. Specifically  a person duly qualified and licensed by authority to conduct vessels into and out of a port or in certain waters for a fixed rate of fees.

Pilot: P i l o t "n. Figuratively: A guide; a director of another through a difficult or unknown course.

Pilot: P i l o t "n. An instrument for detecting the compass error.

Pilot: P i l o t "n. The cowcatcher of a locomotive.

Pilot: P i l o t "v. t. To direct the course of  as of a ship where navigation is dangerous.

Pilot: P i l o t "v. t. Figuratively: To guide  as through dangers or difficulties.

Pilwe: P i l w e "n. A pillow.

Pily: P i l y "a. Like pile or wool.

Pimaric: P i m a r i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating an acid found in galipot and isomeric with abietic acid.

Pimelic: P i m e l i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating a substance obtained from certain fatty substances and subsequently shown to be a mixture of suberic and adipic acids.

Pimelic: P i m e l i c "a. Designating the acid proper (C5H10(CO2/H)2) which is obtained from camphoric acid.

Pimelite: P i m e l i t e "n. An apple-green mineral having a greasy feel. It is a hydrous silicate of nickel  magnesia aluminia and iron.

Piment: P i m e n t "n. Wine flavored with spice or honey. See Pigment  3.

Pimenta: P i m e n t a "n. Same as Pimento.

Pimento: P i m e n t o "n. Allspice; -- applied both to the tree and its fruit. See Allspice.

Pimlico: P i m l i c o "n. The friar bird.

Pimp: P i m p "n. One who provides gratification for the lust of others; a procurer; a pander.

Pimp: P i m p "v. i. To procure women for the gratification of others' lusts; to pander.

Pimped: P i m p e d "imp. & p. p. of Pimp

Pimpernel: P i m p e r n e l "n. A plant of the genus Anagallis  of which one species (A. arvensis) has small flowers usually scarlet but sometimes purple blue or white which speedily close at the approach of bad weather.

Pimpillo: P i m p i l l o "n. A West Indian name for the prickly pear (Opuntia); -- called also pimploes.

Pimpinel: P i m p i n e l "n. The burnet saxifrage. See under Saxifrage.

Pimple: P i m p l e "n. Fig.: A swelling or protuberance like a pimple.

Pimpled: P i m p l e d "a. Having pimples.

Pimply: P i m p l y "a. Pimpled.

Pimpship: P i m p s h i p "n. The office  occupation or persom of a pimp.

Pin: P i n "v. t. To peen.

Pin: P i n "v. t. To inclose; to confine; to pen; to pound.

Pin: P i n "n. A piece of wood  metal etc. generally cylindrical used for fastening separate articles together or as a support by which one article may be suspended from another; a peg; a bolt.

Pin: P i n "n. Especially  a small pointed and headed piece of brass or other wire (commonly tinned) largely used for fastening clothes attaching papers etc.

Pin: P i n "n. Hence  a thing of small value; a trifle.

Pin: P i n "n. That which resembles a pin in its form or use

Pin: P i n "n. A peg in musical instruments  for increasing or relaxing the tension of the strings.

Pin: P i n "n. A linchpin.

Pin: P i n "n. A rolling-pin.

Pin: P i n "n. A clothespin.

Pin: P i n "n. A short shaft  sometimes forming a bolt a part of which serves as a journal.

Pin: P i n "n. The tenon of a dovetail joint.

Pin: P i n "n. One of a row of pegs in the side of an ancient drinking cup to mark how much each man should drink.

Pin: P i n "n. The bull's eye  or center of a target; hence the center.

Pin: P i n "n. Mood; humor.

Pin: P i n "n. Caligo. See Caligo.

Pin: P i n "n. An ornament  as a brooch or badge fastened to the clothing by a pin; as a Masonic pin.

Pin: P i n "n. The leg; as  to knock one off his pins.

Pin: P i n "n. To fasten with  or as with a pin; to join; as to pin a garment; to pin boards together.

Pin-eyed: P i n - e y e d "a. Having the stigma visible at the throad of a gamopetalous corolla  while the stamens are concealed in the tube; -- said of dimorphous flowers. The opposite of thrum-eyed.

Pin-tailed: P i n - t a i l e d "a. Having a tapered tail  with the middle feathers longest; -- said of birds.

Pinaces: P i n a c e s "pl. "of Pinax

Pinacoid: P i n a c o i d "n. A plane parallel to two of the crystalline axes.

Pinacolin: P i n a c o l i n "n. A colorless oily liquid related to the ketones  and obtained by the decomposition of pinacone; hence by extension any one of the series of which pinacolin proper is the type.

Pinacone: P i n a c o n e "n. A white crystalline substance related to the glycols  and made from acetone; hence by extension any one of a series of substances of which pinacone proper is the type.

Pinacotheca: P i n a c o t h e c a "n. A picture gallery.

Pinafore: P i n a f o r e "n. An apron for a child to protect the front part of dress; a tier.

Pinakothek: P i n a k o t h e k "n. Pinacotheca.

Pinaster: P i n a s t e r "n. A species of pine (Pinus Pinaster) growing in Southern Europe.

Pinax: P i n a x "n. A tablet; a register; hence  a list or scheme inscribed on a tablet.

Pince-nez: P i n c e - n e z "n. Eyeglasses kept on the nose by a spring.

Pincers: P i n c e r s "n. pl. See Pinchers.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. t. To press hard or squeeze between the ends of the fingers  between teeth or claws or between the jaws of an instrument; to squeeze or compress as between any two hard bodies.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. t. o seize; to grip; to bite; -- said of animals.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. t. To plait.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. t. Figuratively: To cramp; to straiten; to oppress; to starve; to distress; as  to be pinched for money.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. t. To move  as a railroad car by prying the wheels with a pinch. See Pinch n. 4.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. i. To act with pressing force; to compress; to squeeze; as  the shoe pinches.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. i. To take hold; to grip  as a dog does.

Pinch: P i n c h "v. i. To spare; to be niggardly; to be covetous.

Pinch: P i n c h "n. A close compression  as with the ends of the fingers or with an instrument; a nip.

Pinch: P i n c h "n. As much as may be taken between the finger and thumb; any very small quantity; as  a pinch of snuff.

Pinch: P i n c h "n. Pian; pang.

Pinch: P i n c h "n. A lever having a projection at one end  acting as a fulcrum -- used chiefly to roll heavy wheels etc. Called also pinch bar.

Pinchbeck: P i n c h b e c k "n. An alloy of copper and zinc  resembling gold; a yellow metal composed of about three ounces of zinc to a pound of copper. It is much used as an imitation of gold in the manufacture of cheap jewelry.

Pinchbeck: P i n c h b e c k "a. Made of pinchbeck; sham; cheap; spurious; unreal.

Pinchcock: P i n c h c o c k "n. A clamp on a flexible pipe to regulate the flow of a fluid through the pipe.

Pinched: P i n c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Pinch

Pinchem: P i n c h e m "n. The European blue titmouse.

Pincher: P i n c h e r "n. One who  or that which pinches.

Pinchers: P i n c h e r s "n. pl. An instrument having two handles and two grasping jaws working on a pivot; -- used for griping things to be held fast  drawing nails etc.

Pinchfist: P i n c h f i s t "n. A closefisted person; a miser.

Pinching: P i n c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pinch

Pinchingly: P i n c h i n g l y "adv. In a pinching way.

Pinchpenny: P i n c h p e n n y "n. A miserly person.

Pincoffin: P i n c o f f i n "n. A commercial preparation of garancin  yielding fine violet tints.

Pincpinc: P i n c p i n c "n. An African wren warbler. (Drymoica textrix).

Pincushion: P i n c u s h i o n "n. A small cushion  in which pins may be stuck for use.

Pindal: P i n d a l "n. Alt. of Pindar

Pindar: P i n d a r "n. The peanut (Arachis hypogaea); -- so called in the West Indies.

Pindaric: P i n d a r i c "a. Of or pertaining to Pindar  the Greek lyric poet; after the style and manner of Pindar; as Pindaric odes.

Pindaric: P i n d a r i c "n. A Pindaric ode.

Pindarical: P i n d a r i c a l "a. Pindaric.
