Polyscope: P o l y s c o p e "n. A glass which makes a single object appear as many; a multiplying glass.

Polyscope: P o l y s c o p e "n. An apparatus for affording a view of the different cavities of the body.

Polysepalous: P o l y s e p a l o u s "a. Having the sepals separate from each other.

Polysilicic: P o l y s i l i c i c "a. Of or pertaining to compounds formed by the condensation of two or more molecules of silicic acid.

Polyspast: P o l y s p a s t "n. A machine consisting of many pulleys; specifically  an apparatus formerly used for reducing luxations.

Polyspermous: P o l y s p e r m o u s "a. Containing many seeds; as  a polyspermous capsule or berry.

Polyspermy: P o l y s p e r m y "n. Fullness of sperm  or seed; the passage of more than one spermatozoon into the vitellus in the impregnation of the ovum.

Polysporous: P o l y s p o r o u s "a. Containing many spores.

Polystomata: P o l y s t o m a t a "n. pl. A division of trematode worms having more two suckers. Called also Polystomea and Polystoma.

Polystome: P o l y s t o m e "a. Having many mouths.

Polystome: P o l y s t o m e "n. An animal having many mouths; -- applied to Protozoa.

Polystyle: P o l y s t y l e "a. Having many columns; -- said of a building  especially of an interior part or court; as a polystyle hall.

Polystyle: P o l y s t y l e "n. A polystyle hall or edifice.

Polysulphide: P o l y s u l p h i d e "n. A sulphide having more than one atom of sulphur in the molecule; -- contrasted with monosulphide.

Polysulphuret: P o l y s u l p h u r e t "n. A polysulphide.

Polysyllabic: P o l y s y l l a b i c "a. Alt. of Polysyllabical

Polysyllabical: P o l y s y l l a b i c a l "a. Pertaining to a polysyllable; containing  or characterized by polysyllables; consisting of more than three syllables.

Polysyllabicism: P o l y s y l l a b i c i s m "n. Polysyllabism.

Polysyllabicity: P o l y s y l l a b i c i t y "n. Polysyllabism.

Polysyllabism: P o l y s y l l a b i s m "n. The quality or state of being polysyllabic.

Polysyllable: P o l y s y l l a b l e "n. A word of many syllables  or consisting of more syllables than three; -- words of less than four syllables being called monosyllables dissyllables and trisyllables.

Polysyndetic: P o l y s y n d e t i c "a. Characterized by polysyndeton  or the multiplication of conjunctions.

Polysyndeton: P o l y s y n d e t o n "n. A figure by which the conjunction is often repeated  as in the sentence We have ships and men and money and stores. Opposed to asyndeton.

Polysynthesis: P o l y s y n t h e s i s "n. The act or process of combining many separate elements into a whole.

Polysynthesis: P o l y s y n t h e s i s "n. The formation of a word by the combination of several simple words  as in the aboriginal languages of America; agglutination.

Polysynthetic: P o l y s y n t h e t i c "a. Characterized by polysynthesis; agglutinative.

Polytechnic: P o l y t e c h n i c "a. Comprehending  or relating to many arts and sciences; -- applied particularly to schools in which many branches of art and science are taught with especial reference to their practical application; also to exhibitions of machinery and industrial products.

Polytechnical: P o l y t e c h n i c a l "a. Polytechnic.

Polytechnics: P o l y t e c h n i c s "n. The science of the mechanic arts.

Polythalamia: P o l y t h a l a m i a "n. pl. A division of Foraminifera including those having a manychambered shell.

Polythalamous: P o l y t h a l a m o u s "a. Many-chambered; -- applied to shells of Foraminifera and cephalopods. See Illust. of Nautilus.

Polytheism: P o l y t h e i s m "n. The doctrine of  or belief in a plurality of gods.

Polytheist: P o l y t h e i s t "n. One who believes in  or maintains the doctrine of a plurality of gods.

Polytheistic: P o l y t h e i s t i c "a. Alt. of Polytheistical

Polytheistical: P o l y t h e i s t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to polytheism; characterized by polytheism; professing or advocating polytheism; as  polytheistic worship; a polytheistic author or nation.

Polytheize: P o l y t h e i z e "v. i. To adhere to  advocate or inculcate the doctrine of polytheism.

Polythelism: P o l y t h e l i s m "n. The condition of having more than two teats  or nipples.

Polytocous: P o l y t o c o u s "a. Bearing fruit repeatedly  as most perennial plants; polycarpic.

Polytocous: P o l y t o c o u s "a. Producing many or young.

Polytomous: P o l y t o m o u s "a. Subdivided into many distinct subordinate parts  which however not being jointed to the petiole are not true leaflets; -- said of leaves.

Polytomy: P o l y t o m y "n. A division into many members.

Polytungstate: P o l y t u n g s t a t e "n. A salt of polytungstic acid.

Polytungstic: P o l y t u n g s t i c "a. Containing several tungsten atoms or radicals; as  polytungstic acid.

Polytype: P o l y t y p e "n. A cast  or facsimile copy of an engraved block matter in type etc. (see citation); as a polytype in relief.

Polytype: P o l y t y p e "a. Of or pertaining to polytypes; obtained by polytyping; as  a polytype plate.

Polytype: P o l y t y p e "v. t. To produce a polytype of; as  to polytype an engraving.

Polytyped: P o l y t y p e d "imp. & p. p. of Polytype

Polytyping: P o l y t y p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Polytype

Polyvalent: P o l y v a l e n t "a. Multivalent.

Polyve: P o l y v e "n. A pulley.

Polyzoa: P o l y z o a "n. pl. Same as Bryozoa. See Illust. under Bryozoa  and Phylactolaemata.

Polyzoa: P o l y z o a "pl. "of Polyzoon

Polyzoan: P o l y z o a n "n. Any species of Polyzoa; one of the Polyzoa.

Polyzoan: P o l y z o a n "n. A polyzoon.

Polyzoaria: P o l y z o a r i a "pl. "of Polyzoarium

Polyzoarium: P o l y z o a r i u m "n. Same as Polyzoary.

Polyzoary: P o l y z o a r y "n. The compound organism of a polyzoan.

Polyzonal: P o l y z o n a l "a. Consisting of many zones or rings.

Polyzoon: P o l y z o o n "n. One of the individual zooids forming the compound organism of a polyzoan.

Pomace: P o m a c e "n. The substance of apples  or of similar fruit crushed by grinding.

Pomacentroid: P o m a c e n t r o i d "a. Pertaining to the Pomacentridae  a family of bright-colored tropical fishes having spiny opercula; -- often called coral fishes.

Pomaceous: P o m a c e o u s "a. Like an apple or pear; producing pomes.

Pomaceous: P o m a c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to a suborder (Pomeae) of rosaceous plants  which includes the true thorn trees the quinces service berries medlars and loquats as well as the apples pears crabs etc.

Pomaceous: P o m a c e o u s "a. Like pomace.

Pomade: P o m a d e "n. Cider.

Pomade: P o m a d e "n. Perfumed ointment; esp.  a fragrant unguent for the hair; pomatum; -- originally made from apples.

Pomander: P o m a n d e r "n. A perfume to be carried with one  often in the form of a ball.

Pomander: P o m a n d e r "n. A box to contain such perfume  formerly carried by ladies as at the end of a chain; -- more properly pomander box.

Pomarine: P o m a r i n e "a. Having the nostril covered with a scale.

Pomatum: P o m a t u m "n. A perfumed unguent or composition  chiefly used in dressing the hair; pomade.

Pomatum: P o m a t u m "v. t. To dress with pomatum.

Pome: P o m e "n. A fruit composed of several cartilaginous or bony carpels inclosed in an adherent fleshy mass  which is partly receptacle and partly calyx as an apple quince or pear.

Pome: P o m e "n. A ball of silver or other metal  which is filled with hot water and used by the priest in cold weather to warm his hands during the service.

Pome: P o m e "n. To grow to a head  or form a head in growing.

Pomegranate: P o m e g r a n a t e "n. The fruit of the tree Punica Granatum; also  the tree itself (see Balaustine) which is native in the Orient but is successfully cultivated in many warm countries and as a house plant in colder climates. The fruit is as large as an orange and has a hard rind containing many rather large seeds each one separately covered with crimson acid pulp.

Pomegranate: P o m e g r a n a t e "n. A carved or embroidered ornament resembling a pomegranate.

Pomel: P o m e l "n. A pommel.

Pomelo: P o m e l o "n. A variety of shaddock  called also grape fruit.

Pomely: P o m e l y "a. Dappled.

Pomeranian: P o m e r a n i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Pomerania  a province of Prussia on the Baltic Sea.

Pomeranian: P o m e r a n i a n "n. A native or inhabitant of Pomerania.

Pomewater: P o m e w a t e r "n. A kind of sweet  juicy apple.

Pomey: P o m e y "n. A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel  -- always of a green color.

Pomeys: P o m e y s "pl. "of Pomey

Pomfret: P o m f r e t "n. One of two or more species of marine food fishes of the genus Stromateus (S. niger  S. argenteus) native of Southern Europe and Asia.

Pomfret: P o m f r e t "n. A marine food fish of Bermuda (Brama Raji).

Pomiferous: P o m i f e r o u s "a. Bearing pomes  or applelike fruits.

Pomiferous: P o m i f e r o u s "a. Bearing fruits  or excrescences more or less resembling an apple.

Pommage: P o m m a g e "n. See Pomage.

Pomme: P o m m e "a. Having the ends terminating in rounded protuberances or single balls; -- said of a cross.

Pomme blanche: P o m m e   b l a n c h e " The prairie turnip. See under Prairie.

Pommel: P o m m e l "n. A knob or ball; an object resembling a ball in form

Pommel: P o m m e l "n. The knob on the hilt of a sword.

Pommel: P o m m e l "n. The knob or protuberant part of a saddlebow.

Pommel: P o m m e l "n. The top (of the head).

Pommel: P o m m e l "n. A knob forming the finial of a turret or pavilion.

Pommel: P o m m e l "v. t. To beat soundly  as with the pommel of a sword or with something knoblike; hence to beat with the fists.

Pommeled: P o m m e l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pommel

Pommeling: P o m m e l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pommel

Pommelion: P o m m e l i o n "n. The cascabel  or hindmost knob of a cannon.

Pommelled: P o m m e l l e d " of Pommel

Pommelling: P o m m e l l i n g " of Pommel

Pommette: P o m m e t t e "a. Having two balls or protuberances at each end; -- said of a cross.

Pomological: P o m o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to pomology.

Pomologist: P o m o l o g i s t "n. One versed in pomology; one who culticvates fruit trees.

Pomology: P o m o l o g y "n. The science of fruits; a treatise on fruits; the cultivation of fruits and fruit trees.

Pomona: P o m o n a "n. The goddess of fruits and fruit trees.

Pomp: P o m p "n. A procession distinguished by ostentation and splendor; a pageant.

Pomp: P o m p "n. Show of magnificence; parade; display; power.

Pomp: P o m p "v. i. To make a pompons display; to conduct.

Pompadour: P o m p a d o u r "n. A crimson or pink color; also  a style of dress cut low and square in the neck; also a mode of dressing the hair by drawing it straight back from the forehead over a roll; -- so called after the Marchioness de Pompadour of France. Also much used adjectively.

Pompano: P o m p a n o "n. Any one of several species of marine fishes of the genus Trachynotus  of which four species are found on the Atlantic coast of the United States; -- called also palometa.

Pompano: P o m p a n o "n. A California harvest fish (Stromateus simillimus)  highly valued as a food fish.

Pompatic: P o m p a t i c "a. Pompous.

Pompelmous: P o m p e l m o u s "n. A shaddock  esp. one of large size.

Pompelmouses: P o m p e l m o u s e s "pl. "of Pompelmous

Pompet: P o m p e t "n. The ball formerly used to ink the type.

Pompholyx: P o m p h o l y x "n. Impure zinc oxide.

Pompholyx: P o m p h o l y x "n. A skin disease in which there is an eruption of bullae  without inflammation or fever.

Pompillion: P o m p i l l i o n "n. An ointment or pomatum made of black poplar buds.

Pompion: P o m p i o n "n. See Pumpion.

Pompire: P o m p i r e "n. A pearmain.

Pompoleon: P o m p o l e o n "n. See Pompelmous.

Pompon: P o m p o n "n. Any trifling ornament for a woman's dress or bonnet.

Pompon: P o m p o n "n. A tuft or ball of wool  or the like sometimes worn by soldiers on the front of the hat instead of a feather.

Pomposities: P o m p o s i t i e s "pl. "of Pomposity

Pomposity: P o m p o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being pompous; pompousness.

Pomposo: P o m p o s o "a. & adv. Grand and dignified; in grand style.

Pompous: P o m p o u s "a. Displaying pomp; stately; showy with grandeur; magnificent; as  a pompous procession.

Pompous: P o m p o u s "a. Ostentatious; pretentious; boastful; vainlorious; as  pompous manners; a pompous style.

Pomptine: P o m p t i n e "a. See Pontine.

Pomwater: P o m w a t e r "n. Same as Pomewater.

Poncho: P o n c h o "n. A kind of cloak worn by the Spanish Americans  having the form of a blanket with a slit in the middle for the head to pass through. A kind of poncho made of rubber or painted cloth is used by the mounted troops in the United States service.

Poncho: P o n c h o "n. A trade name for camlets  or stout worsteds.

Ponchos: P o n c h o s "pl. "of Poncho

Pond: P o n d "n. A body of water  naturally or artificially confined and usually of less extent than a lake.

Pond: P o n d "v. t. To make into a pond; to collect  as water in a pond by damming.

Pond: P o n d "v. t. To ponder.

Ponder: P o n d e r "v. t. To weigh.

Ponder: P o n d e r "v. t. To weigh in the mind; to view with deliberation; to examine carefully; to consider attentively.

Ponder: P o n d e r "v. i. To think; to deliberate; to muse; -- usually followed by on or over.

Ponderability: P o n d e r a b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being ponderable.

Ponderable: P o n d e r a b l e "a. Capable of being weighed; having appreciable weight.

Ponderal: P o n d e r a l "a. Estimated or ascertained by weight; -- distinguished from numeral; as  a ponderal drachma.

Ponderance: P o n d e r a n c e "n. Weight; gravity.

Ponderary: P o n d e r a r y "a. Of or pertaining to weight; as  a ponderary system.

Ponderate: P o n d e r a t e "v. t. To consider; to ponder.

Ponderate: P o n d e r a t e "v. i. To have weight or influence.

Ponderation: P o n d e r a t i o n "n. The act of weighing.

Pondered: P o n d e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Ponder

Ponderer: P o n d e r e r "n. One who ponders.

Pondering: P o n d e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Ponder

Pondering: P o n d e r i n g "a. Deliberating.

Ponderosities: P o n d e r o s i t i e s "pl. "of Ponderosity

Ponderosity: P o n d e r o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being ponderous; weight; gravity; heaviness  ponderousness; as the ponderosity of gold.

Ponderous: P o n d e r o u s "a. Very heavy; weighty; as  a ponderous shield; a ponderous load; the ponderous elephant.

Ponderous: P o n d e r o u s "a. Important; momentous; forcible.

Ponderous: P o n d e r o u s "a. Heavy; dull; wanting; lightless or spirit; as  a ponderous style; a ponderous joke.

Ponderously: P o n d e r o u s l y "adv. In a ponderous manner.

Ponderousness: P o n d e r o u s n e s s "n. The quality or state of being ponderous; ponderosity.

Pondfish: P o n d f i s h "n. Any one of numerous species of American fresh-water fishes belonging to the family Centrarchidae; -- called also pond perch  and sunfish.

Pondweed: P o n d w e e d "n. Any aquatic plant of the genus Potamogeton  of which many species are found in ponds or slow-moving rivers.

Pone: P o n e "n. A kind of johnnycake.

Ponent: P o n e n t "a. Western; occidental.

Pongee: P o n g e e "n. A fabric of undyed silk from India and China.

Ponghee: P o n g h e e "n. A Buddhist priest of the higher orders in Burmah.

Pongo: P o n g o "n. Any large ape; especially  the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.

Poniard: P o n i a r d "n. A kind of dagger  -- usually a slender one with a triangular or square blade.

Poniard: P o n i a r d "v. t. To pierce with a poniard; to stab.

Poniarded: P o n i a r d e d "imp. & p. p. of Poniard

Poniarding: P o n i a r d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Poniard

Ponibility: P o n i b i l i t y "n. The capability of being placed or located.

Ponies: P o n i e s "pl. "of Pony

Pons: P o n s "n. A bridge; -- applied to several parts which connect others  but especially to the pons Varolii a prominent band of nervous tissue situated on the ventral side of the medulla oblongata and connected at each side with the hemispheres of the cerebellum; the mesocephalon. See Brain.

Pontage: P o n t a g e "n. A duty or tax paid for repairing bridges.

Pontee: P o n t e e "n. An iron rod used by glass makers for manipulating the hot glass; -- called also  puntil puntel punty and ponty. See Fascet.

Pontes: P o n t e s "pl. "of Pons

Pontic: P o n t i c "a. Of or pertaining to the Pontus  Euxine or Black Sea.

Pontifex: P o n t i f e x "n. A high priest; a pontiff.

Pontiff: P o n t i f f "n. A high priest.

Pontiff: P o n t i f f "n. One of the sacred college  in ancient Rome which had the supreme jurisdiction over all matters of religion at the head of which was the Pontifex Maximus.

Pontiff: P o n t i f f "n. The chief priest.

Pontiff: P o n t i f f "n. The pope.

Pontific: P o n t i f i c "a. Relating to  or consisting of pontiffs or priests.

Pontific: P o n t i f i c "a. Of or pertaining to the pope; papal.

Pontifical: P o n t i f i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pontiff  or high priest; as pontifical authority; hence belonging to the pope; papal.

Pontifical: P o n t i f i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the building of bridges.

Pontifical: P o n t i f i c a l "n. A book containing the offices  or formulas used by a pontiff.

Pontifical: P o n t i f i c a l "n. The dress and ornaments of a pontiff.

Pontificality: P o n t i f i c a l i t y "n. The state and government of the pope; the papacy.

Pontifically: P o n t i f i c a l l y "adv. In a pontifical manner.

Pontificate: P o n t i f i c a t e "n. The state or dignity of a high priest; specifically  the office of the pope.

Pontificate: P o n t i f i c a t e "n. The term of office of a pontiff.

Pontificate: P o n t i f i c a t e "v. i. To perform the duty of a pontiff.

Pontifice: P o n t i f i c e "n. Bridgework; structure or edifice of a bridge.

Pontifices: P o n t i f i c e s "pl. "of Pontifex

Pontificial: P o n t i f i c i a l "a. Papal; pontifical.

Pontifician: P o n t i f i c i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the pontiff or pope.

Pontifician: P o n t i f i c i a n "n. One who adheres to the pope or papacy; a papist.

Pontil: P o n t i l "n. Same as Pontee.

Pontile: P o n t i l e "a. Of or pertaining to the pons Varolii. See Pons.

Pontine: P o n t i n e "a. Of or pertaining to an extensive marshy district between Rome and Naples.

Pontlevis: P o n t l e v i s "n. The action of a horse in rearing repeatedly and dangerously.

Ponton: P o n t o n "n. See Pontoon.

Pontoon: P o n t o o n "n. A wooden flat-bottomed boat  a metallic cylinder or a frame covered with canvas India rubber etc. forming a portable float used in building bridges quickly for the passage of troops.

Pontoon: P o n t o o n "n. A low  flat vessel resembling a barge furnished with cranes capstans and other machinery used in careening ships raising weights drawing piles etc. chiefly in the Mediterranean; a lighter.

Pontooning: P o n t o o n i n g "n. The act  art or process of constructing pontoon bridges.

Ponty: P o n t y "n. See Pontee.

Ponvolant: P o n v o l a n t "n. A kind of light bridge  used in sieges for surprising a post or outwork which has but a narrow moat; a flying bridge.

Pony: P o n y "n. A small horse.

Pony: P o n y "n. Twenty-five pounds sterling.

Pony: P o n y "n. A translation or a key used to avoid study in getting lessons; a crib.

Pony: P o n y "n. A small glass of beer.

Pood: P o o d "n. A Russian weight  equal to forty Russian pounds or about thirty-six English pounds avoirdupois.

Poodle: P o o d l e "n. A breed of dogs having curly hair  and often showing remarkable intelligence in the performance of tricks.

Pooh: P o o h "interj. Pshaw! pish! nonsense! -- an expression of scorn  dislike or contempt.

Pooh-pooh: P o o h - p o o h "v. t. To make light of; to treat with derision or contempt  as if by saying pooh! pooh!

Pookoo: P o o k o o "n. A red African antelope (Kobus Vardoni) allied to the water buck.

Pool: P o o l "n. A small and rather deep collection of (usually) fresh water  as one supplied by a spring or occurring in the course of a stream; a reservoir for water; as the pools of Solomon.

Pool: P o o l "n. A small body of standing or stagnant water; a puddle.

Pool: P o o l "n. The stake played for in certain games of cards  billiards etc.; an aggregated stake to which each player has contributed a snare; also the receptacle for the stakes.

Pool: P o o l "n. A game at billiards  in which each of the players stakes a certain sum the winner taking the whole; also in public billiard rooms a game in which the loser pays the entrance fee for all who engage in the game; a game of skill in pocketing the balls on a pool table.

Pool: P o o l "n. In rifle shooting  a contest in which each competitor pays a certain sum for every shot he makes the net proceeds being divided among the winners.

Pool: P o o l "n. Any gambling or commercial venture in which several persons join.

Pool: P o o l "n. A combination of persons contributing money to be used for the purpose of increasing or depressing the market price of stocks  grain or other commodities; also the aggregate of the sums so contributed; as the pool took all the wheat offered below the limit; he put $10 000 into the pool.

Pool: P o o l "n. A mutual arrangement between competing lines  by which the receipts of all are aggregated and then distributed pro rata according to agreement.

Pool: P o o l "n. An aggregation of properties or rights  belonging to different people in a community in a common fund to be charged with common liabilities.

Pool: P o o l "v. t. To put together; to contribute to a common fund  on the basis of a mutual division of profits or losses; to make a common interest of; as the companies pooled their traffic.

Pool: P o o l "v. i. To combine or contribute with others  as for a commercial speculative or gambling transaction.

Pooled: P o o l e d "imp. & p. p. of Pool

Pooler: P o o l e r "n. A stick for stirring a tan vat.

Pooling: P o o l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pool

Pooling: P o o l i n g "n. The act of uniting  or an agreement to unite an aggregation of properties belonging to different persons with a view to common liabilities or profits.

Poon: P o o n "n. A name for several East Indian  or their wood used for the masts and spars of vessels as Calophyllum angustifolium C. inophullum and Sterculia foetida; -- called also peon.

Poonac: P o o n a c "n. A kind of oil cake prepared from the cocoanut. See Oil cake  under Cake.

Poonga oil: P o o n g a   o i l " A kind of oil used in India for lamps  and for boiling with dammar for pitching vessels. It is pressed from the seeds of a leguminous tree (Pongamia glabra).

Poop: P o o p "n. See 2d Poppy.

Poop: P o o p "v. i. To make a noise; to pop; also  to break wind.

Poop: P o o p "n. A deck raised above the after part of a vessel; the hindmost or after part of a vessel's hull; also  a cabin covered by such a deck. See Poop deck under Deck. See also Roundhouse.

Poop: P o o p "v. t. To break over the poop or stern  as a wave.

Poop: P o o p "v. t. To strike in the stern  as by collision.

Pooped: P o o p e d "imp. & p. p. of Poop

Pooped: P o o p e d "p. p. & a. Having a poop; furnished with a poop.

Pooped: P o o p e d "p. p. & a. Struck on the poop.

Pooping: P o o p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Poop

Pooping: P o o p i n g "n. The act or shock of striking a vessel's stern by a following wave or vessel.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Destitute of property; wanting in material riches or goods; needy; indigent.

Poor: P o o r "superl. So completely destitute of property as to be entitled to maintenance from the public.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Destitute of such qualities as are desirable  or might naturally be expected

Poor: P o o r "superl. Wanting in fat  plumpness or fleshiness; lean; emaciated; meager; as a poor horse ox dog etc.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Wanting in strength or vigor; feeble; dejected; as  poor health; poor spirits.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Of little value or worth; not good; inferior; shabby; mean; as  poor clothes; poor lodgings.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Destitute of fertility; exhausted; barren; sterile; -- said of land; as  poor soil.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Destitute of beauty  fitness or merit; as a poor discourse; a poor picture.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Without prosperous conditions or good results; unfavorable; unfortunate; unconformable; as  a poor business; the sick man had a poor night.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Inadequate; insufficient; insignificant; as  a poor excuse.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Worthy of pity or sympathy; -- used also sometimes as a term of endearment  or as an expression of modesty and sometimes as a word of contempt.

Poor: P o o r "superl. Free from self-assertion; not proud or arrogant; meek.

Poor: P o o r "n. A small European codfish (Gadus minutus); -- called also power cod.

Poor-john: P o o r - j o h n "n. A small European fish  similar to the cod but of inferior quality.

Poor-spirited: P o o r - s p i r i t e d "a. Of a mean spirit; cowardly; base.

Poor-will: P o o r - w i l l "n. A bird of the Western United States (Phalaenoptilus Nutalli) allied to the whip-poor-will.

Poor-willie: P o o r - w i l l i e "n. The bar-tailed godwit.

Poorbox: P o o r b o x "n. A receptacle in which money given for the poor is placed.

Poorhouse: P o o r h o u s e "n. A dwelling for a number of paupers maintained at public expense; an almshouse; a workhouse.

Poorliness: P o o r l i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being poorly; ill health.

Poorly: P o o r l y "adv. In a poor manner or condition; without plenty  or sufficiency or suitable provision for comfort; as to live poorly.

Poorly: P o o r l y "adv. With little or no success; indifferently; with little profit or advantage; as  to do poorly in business.

Poorly: P o o r l y "adv. Meanly; without spirit.

Poorly: P o o r l y "adv. Without skill or merit; as  he performs poorly.

Poorly: P o o r l y "a. Somewhat ill; indisposed; not in health.

Poorness: P o o r n e s s "n. The quality or state of being poor (in any of the senses of the adjective).

Pop: P o p "n. A small  sharp quick explosive sound or report; as to go off with a pop.

Pop: P o p "n. An unintoxicating beverage which expels the cork with a pop from the bottle containing it; as  ginger pop; lemon pop etc.

Pop: P o p "n. The European redwing.

Pop: P o p "v. i. To make a pop  or sharp quick sound; as the muskets popped away on all sides.

Pop: P o p "v. i. To enter  or issue forth with a quick sudden movement; to move from place to place suddenly; to dart; -- with in out upon off etc.

Pop: P o p "v. i. To burst open with a pop  when heated over a fire; as this corn pops well.

Pop: P o p "v. t. To thrust or push suddenly; to offer suddenly; to bring suddenly and unexpectedly to notice; as  to pop one's head in at the door.

Pop: P o p "v. t. To cause to pop; to cause to burst open by heat  as grains of Indian corn; as to pop corn or chestnuts.

Pop: P o p "adv. Like a pop; suddenly; unexpectedly.

Pope: P o p e "n. Any ecclesiastic  esp. a bishop.

Pope: P o p e "n. The bishop of Rome  the head of the Roman Catholic Church. See Note under Cardinal.

Pope: P o p e "n. A parish priest  or a chaplain of the Greek Church.

Pope: P o p e "n. A fish; the ruff.

Popedom: P o p e d o m "n. The place  office or dignity of the pope; papal dignity.

Popedom: P o p e d o m "n. The jurisdiction of the pope.

Popeling: P o p e l i n g "n. A petty or deputy pope.

Popeling: P o p e l i n g "n. An adherent of the pope.

Popelote: P o p e l o t e "n. A word variously explained as a little puppet  a little doll  or a young butterfly. Cf. Popet.

Popery: P o p e r y "n. The religion of the Roman Catholic Church  comprehending doctrines and practices; -- generally used in an opprobrious sense.

Popet: P o p e t "n. A puppet.

Popgun: P o p g u n "n. A child's gun; a tube and rammer for shooting pellets  with a popping noise by compression of air.

Popinjay: P o p i n j a y "n. The green woodpecker.

Popinjay: P o p i n j a y "n. A parrot.

Popinjay: P o p i n j a y "n. A target in the form of a parrot.

Popinjay: P o p i n j a y "n. A trifling  chattering fop or coxcomb.

Popish: P o p i s h "a. Of or pertaining to the pope; taught or ordained by the pope; hence  of or pertaining to the Roman Catholic Church; -- often used opprobriously.

Poplar: P o p l a r "n. Any tree of the genus Populus; also  the timber which is soft and capable of many uses.

Poplar: P o p l a r "n. The timber of the tulip tree; -- called also white poplar.

Poplexy: P o p l e x y "n. Apoplexy.

Poplin: P o p l i n "n. A fabric of many varieties  usually made of silk and worsted -- used especially for women's dresses.

Popliteal: P o p l i t e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the ham; in the region of the ham  or behind the knee joint; as the popliteal space.

Poplitic: P o p l i t i c "a. Popliteal.

Popped: P o p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Pop

Popper: P o p p e r "n. A utensil for popping corn  usually a wire basket with a long handle.

Popper: P o p p e r "n. A dagger.

Poppet: P o p p e t "n. See Puppet.

Poppet: P o p p e t "n. One of certain upright timbers on the bilge ways  used to support a vessel in launching.

Poppet: P o p p e t "n. An upright support or guide fastened at the bottom only.

Poppied: P o p p i e d "a. Mingled or interspersed with poppies.

Poppied: P o p p i e d "a. Affected with poppy juice; hence  figuratively drugged; drowsy; listless; inactive.

Poppies: P o p p i e s "pl. "of Poppy

Popping: P o p p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pop

Popping: P o p p i n g " a. & n. from Pop.

Popple: P o p p l e "v. i. To move quickly up and down; to bob up and down  as a cork on rough water; also to bubble.

Popple: P o p p l e "n. The poplar.

Popple: P o p p l e "n. Tares.

Poppy: P o p p y "n. Any plant or species of the genus Papaver  herbs with showy polypetalous flowers and a milky juice. From one species (Papaver somniferum) opium is obtained though all the species contain it to some extent; also a flower of the plant. See Illust. of Capsule.

Poppy: P o p p y "n. Alt. of Poppyhead

Poppyhead: P o p p y h e a d "n. A raised ornament frequently having the form of a final. It is generally used on the tops of the upright ends or elbows which terminate seats  etc. in Gothic churches.

Populace: P o p u l a c e "n. The common people; the vulgar; the multitude  -- comprehending all persons not distinguished by rank office education or profession.

Populacy: P o p u l a c y "n. Populace.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the common people  or to the whole body of the people as distinguished from a select portion; as the popular voice; popular elections.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Suitable to common people; easy to be comprehended; not abstruse; familiar; plain.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Adapted to the means of the common people; possessed or obtainable by the many; hence  cheap; common; ordinary; inferior; as popular prices; popular amusements.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Beloved or approved by the people; pleasing to people in general  or to many people; as a popular preacher; a popular law; a popular administration.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Devoted to the common people; studious of the favor of the populace.

Popular: P o p u l a r "a. Prevailing among the people; epidemic; as  a popular disease.

Populares: P o p u l a r e s "n. pl. The people or the people's party  in ancient Rome as opposed to the optimates.

Popularities: P o p u l a r i t i e s "pl. "of Popularity

Popularity: P o p u l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being popular; especially  the state of being esteemed by or of being in favor with the people at large; good will or favor proceeding from the people; as the popularity of a law statesman or a book.

Popularity: P o p u l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being adapted or pleasing to common  poor or vulgar people; hence cheapness; inferiority; vulgarity.

Popularity: P o p u l a r i t y "n. Something which obtains  or is intended to obtain the favor of the vulgar; claptrap.

Popularity: P o p u l a r i t y "n. The act of courting the favor of the people.

Popularity: P o p u l a r i t y "n. Public sentiment; general passion.

Popularization: P o p u l a r i z a t i o n "n. The act of making popular  or of introducing among the people.

Popularize: P o p u l a r i z e "v. t. To make popular; to make suitable or acceptable to the common people; to make generally known; as  to popularize philosophy.

Popularized: P o p u l a r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Popularize

Popularizer: P o p u l a r i z e r "n. One who popularizes.

Popularizing: P o p u l a r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Popularize

Popularly: P o p u l a r l y "adv. In a popular manner; so as to be generally favored or accepted by the people; commonly; currently; as  the story was popularity reported.

Popularness: P o p u l a r n e s s "n. The quality or state of being popular; popularity.

Populate: P o p u l a t e "a. Populous.

Populate: P o p u l a t e "v. t. To furnish with inhabitants  either by natural increase or by immigration or colonization; to cause to be inhabited; to people.

Populate: P o p u l a t e "v. i. To propagate.

Populated: P o p u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Populate

Populating: P o p u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Populate

Population: P o p u l a t i o n "n. The act or process of populating; multiplication of inhabitants.

Population: P o p u l a t i o n "n. The whole number of people  or inhabitants in a country or portion of a country; as a population of ten millions.

Populator: P o p u l a t o r "n. One who populates.

Populicide: P o p u l i c i d e "n. Slaughter of the people.

Populin: P o p u l i n "n. A glycoside  related to salicin found in the bark of certain species of the poplar (Populus) and extracted as a sweet white crystalline substance.

Populosity: P o p u l o s i t y "n. Populousness.

Populous: P o p u l o u s "a. Abounding in people; full of inhabitants; containing many inhabitants in proportion to the extent of the country.

Populous: P o p u l o u s "a. Popular; famous.

Populous: P o p u l o u s "a. Common; vulgar.

Populous: P o p u l o u s "a. Numerous; in large number.

Poraille: P o r a i l l e "n. Poor people; the poor.

Porbeagle: P o r b e a g l e "n. A species of shark (Lamna cornubica)  about eight feet long having a pointed nose and a crescent-shaped tail; -- called also mackerel shark.

Porcate: P o r c a t e "a. Having grooves or furrows broader than the intervening ridges; furrowed.

Porcelain: P o r c e l a i n "n. Purslain.

Porcelain: P o r c e l a i n "n. A fine translucent or semitransculent kind of earthenware  made first in China and Japan but now also in Europe and America; -- called also China or China ware.

Porcelainized: P o r c e l a i n i z e d "a. Baked like potter's lay; -- applied to clay shales that have been converted by heat into a substance resembling porcelain.

Porcelaneous: P o r c e l a n e o u s "a. Alt. of Porcellaneous

Porcelanite: P o r c e l a n i t e "n. A semivitrified clay or shale  somewhat resembling jasper; -- called also porcelain jasper.

Porcelanous: P o r c e l a n o u s "a. Alt. of Porcellanous

Porcellaneous: P o r c e l l a n e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to porcelain; resembling porcelain; as  porcelaneous shells.

Porcellaneous: P o r c e l l a n e o u s "a. Having a smooth  compact shell without pores; -- said of certain Foraminifera.

Porcellanous: P o r c e l l a n o u s "a. Porcelaneous.

Porch: P o r c h "n. A covered and inclosed entrance to a building  whether taken from the interior and forming a sort of vestibule within the main wall or projecting without and with a separate roof. Sometimes the porch is large enough to serve as a covered walk. See also Carriage porch under Carriage and Loggia.

Porch: P o r c h "n. A portico; a covered walk.

Porcine: P o r c i n e "a. Of or pertaining to swine; characteristic of the hog.

Porcupine: P o r c u p i n e "n. Any Old Word rodent of the genus Hystrix  having the back covered with long sharp erectile spines or quills sometimes a foot long. The common species of Europe and Asia (Hystrix cristata) is the best known.

Porcupine: P o r c u p i n e "n. Any species of Erethizon and related genera  native of America. They are related to the true porcupines but have shorter spines and are arboreal in their habits. The Canada porcupine (Erethizon dorsatus) is a well known species.

Pore: P o r e "v. One of the minute orifices in an animal or vegetable membrane  for transpiration absorption etc.

Pore: P o r e "v. A minute opening or passageway; an interstice between the constituent particles or molecules of a body; as  the pores of stones.

Pore: P o r e "v. i. To look or gaze steadily in reading or studying; to fix the attention; to be absorbed; -- often with on or upon  and now usually with over.

Poreblind: P o r e b l i n d "a. Nearsighted; shortsighted; purblind.

Pored: P o r e d "imp. & p. p. of Pore

Porer: P o r e r "n. One who pores.

Porgies: P o r g i e s "pl. "of Porgy

Porgy: P o r g y "n. The scup.

Porgy: P o r g y "n. The sailor's choice  or pinfish.

Porgy: P o r g y "n. The margate fish.

Porgy: P o r g y "n. The spadefish.

Porgy: P o r g y "n. Any one of several species of embiotocoids  or surf fishes of the Pacific coast. The name is also given locally to several other fishes as the bur fish.

Porifera: P o r i f e r a "n. pl. A grand division of the Invertebrata  including the sponges; -- called also Spongiae Spongida and Spongiozoa. The principal divisions are Calcispongiae Keratosa or Fibrospongiae and Silicea.

Poriferan: P o r i f e r a n "n. One of the Polifera.

Poriferata: P o r i f e r a t a "n. pl. The Polifera.

Poriform: P o r i f o r m "a. Resembling a pore  or small puncture.

Porime: P o r i m e "n. A theorem or proposition so easy of demonstration as to be almost self-evident.

Poriness: P o r i n e s s "n. Porosity.

Poring: P o r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pore

Porism: P o r i s m "n. A proposition affirming the possibility of finding such conditions as will render a certain determinate problem indeterminate or capable of innumerable solutions.

Porism: P o r i s m "n. A corollary.

Porismatic: P o r i s m a t i c "a. Alt. of Porismatical

Porismatical: P o r i s m a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a porism; poristic.

Poristic: P o r i s t i c "a. Alt. of Poristical

Poristical: P o r i s t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a porism; of the nature of a porism.

Porite: P o r i t e "n. Any coral of the genus Porites  or family Poritidae.

Porites: P o r i t e s "n. An important genus of reef-building corals having small twelve-rayed calicles  and a very porous coral. Some species are branched others grow in large massive or globular forms.

Pork: P o r k "n. The flesh of swine  fresh or salted used for food.

Porker: P o r k e r "n. A hog.

Porket: P o r k e t "n. A young hog; a pig.

Porkling: P o r k l i n g "n. A pig; a porket.

Porkwood: P o r k w o o d "n. The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree (Pisonia obtusata) of Florida and the West Indies. Also called pigeon wood  beefwood and corkwood.

Pornerastic: P o r n e r a s t i c "a. Lascivious; licentious.

Pornographic: P o r n o g r a p h i c "a. Of or pertaining to pornography; lascivious; licentious; as  pornographic writing.

Pornography: P o r n o g r a p h y "n. Licentious painting or literature; especially  the painting anciently employed to decorate the walls of rooms devoted to bacchanalian orgies.

Pornography: P o r n o g r a p h y "n. A treatise on prostitutes  or prostitution.

Porosity: P o r o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being porous; -- opposed to density.

Porotic: P o r o t i c "n. A medicine supposed to promote the formation of callus.

Porous: P o r o u s "n. Full of pores; having interstices in the skin or in the substance of the body; having spiracles or passages for fluids; permeable by liquids; as  a porous skin; porous wood.

Porously: P o r o u s l y "adv. In a porous manner.

Porousness: P o r o u s n e s s "n. The quality of being porous.

Porousness: P o r o u s n e s s "n. The open parts; the interstices of anything.

Porpentine: P o r p e n t i n e "n. Porcupine.

Porpesse: P o r p e s s e "n. A porpoise.

Porphyraceous: P o r p h y r a c e o u s "a. Porphyritic.

Porphyre: P o r p h y r e "n. Porphyry.

Porphyries: P o r p h y r i e s "pl. "of Porphyry

Porphyrite: P o r p h y r i t e "n. A rock with a porphyritic structure; as  augite porphyrite.

Porphyritic: P o r p h y r i t i c "a. Relating to  or resembling porphyry that is characterized by the presence of distinct crystals as of feldspar quartz or augite in a relatively fine-grained base often aphanitic or cryptocrystalline.

Porphyrization: P o r p h y r i z a t i o n "n. The act of porphyrizing  or the state of being porphyrized.

Porphyrize: P o r p h y r i z e "v. t. To cause to resemble porphyry; to make spotted in composition  like porphyry.

Porphyrogenitism: P o r p h y r o g e n i t i s m "n. The principle of succession in royal families  especially among the Eastern Roman emperors by which a younger son if born after the accession of his father to the throne was preferred to an elder son who was not so born.

Porphyry: P o r p h y r y "n. A term used somewhat loosely to designate a rock consisting of a fine-grained base (usually feldspathic) through which crystals  as of feldspar or quartz are disseminated. There are red purple and green varieties which are highly esteemed as marbles.

Porpita: P o r p i t a "n. A genus of bright-colored Siphonophora found floating in the warmer parts of the ocean. The individuals are round and disk-shaped  with a large zooid in the center of the under side surrounded by smaller nutritive and reproductive zooids and by slender dactylozooids near the margin. The disk contains a central float or pneumatocyst.

Porpoise: P o r p o i s e "n. Any small cetacean of the genus Phocaena  especially P. communis or P. phocaena of Europe and the closely allied American species (P. Americana). The color is dusky or blackish above paler beneath. They are closely allied to the dolphins but have a shorter snout. Called also harbor porpoise herring hag puffing pig and snuffer.

Porpoise: P o r p o i s e "n. A true dolphin (Delphinus); -- often so called by sailors.

Porporino: P o r p o r i n o "n. A composition of quicksilver  tin and sulphur forming a yellow powder sometimes used by mediaeval artists for the sake of economy instead of gold.

Porpus: P o r p u s "n. A porpoise.

Porraceous: P o r r a c e o u s "a. Resembling the leek in color; greenish.

Porrect: P o r r e c t "a. Extended horizontally; stretched out.

Porrection: P o r r e c t i o n "n. The act of stretching forth.

Porret: P o r r e t "n. A scallion; a leek or small onion.

Porridge: P o r r i d g e "n. A food made by boiling some leguminous or farinaceous substance  or the meal of it in water or in milk making of broth or thin pudding; as barley porridge milk porridge bean porridge etc.

Porringer: P o r r i n g e r "n. A porridge dish; esp.  a bowl or cup from which children eat or are fed; as a silver porringer.

Port: P o r t "n. A dark red or purple astringent wine made in Portugal. It contains a large percentage of alcohol.

Port: P o r t "v. A place where ships may ride secure from storms; a sheltered inlet  bay or cove; a harbor; a haven. Used also figuratively.

Port: P o r t "v. In law and commercial usage  a harbor where vessels are admitted to discharge and receive cargoes from whence they depart and where they finish their voyages.

Port: P o r t "n. A passageway; an opening or entrance to an inclosed place; a gate; a door; a portal.

Port: P o r t "n. An opening in the side of a vessel; an embrasure through which cannon may be discharged; a porthole; also  the shutters which close such an opening.

Port: P o r t "n. A passageway in a machine  through which a fluid as steam water etc. may pass as from a valve to the interior of the cylinder of a steam engine; an opening in a valve seat or valve face.

Port: P o r t "v. t. To carry; to bear; to transport.

Port: P o r t "v. t. To throw  as a musket diagonally across the body with the lock in front the right hand grasping the small of the stock and the barrel sloping upward and crossing the point of the left shoulder; as to port arms.

Port: P o r t "n. The manner in which a person bears himself; deportment; carriage; bearing; demeanor; hence  manner or style of living; as a proud port.

Port: P o r t "n. The larboard or left side of a ship (looking from the stern toward the bow); as  a vessel heels to port. See Note under Larboard. Also used adjectively.

Port: P o r t "v. t. To turn or put to the left or larboard side of a ship; -- said of the helm  and used chiefly in the imperative as a command; as port your helm.

Port-royalist: P o r t - r o y a l i s t "n. One of the dwellers in the Cistercian convent of Port Royal des Champs  near Paris when it was the home of the Jansenists in the 17th century among them being Arnauld Pascal and other famous scholars. Cf. Jansenist.

Porta: P o r t a "n. The part of the liver or other organ where its vessels and nerves enter; the hilus.

Porta: P o r t a "n. The foramen of Monro.

Portability: P o r t a b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being portable; fitness to be carried.

Portable: P o r t a b l e "a. Capable of being borne or carried; easily transported; conveyed without difficulty; as  a portable bed desk engine.

Portable: P o r t a b l e "a. Possible to be endured; supportable.

Portableness: P o r t a b l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being portable; portability.

Portace: P o r t a c e "n. See Portass.

Portae: P o r t a e "pl. "of Porta

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. A sailor's wages when in port.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. The amount of a sailor's wages for a voyage.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. A porthole.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. The act of carrying or transporting.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. The price of carriage; porterage.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. Capacity for carrying; tonnage.

Portage: P o r t a g e "n. A carry between navigable waters. See 3d Carry.

Portage: P o r t a g e "v. t. & i. To carry (goods  boats etc.) overland between navigable waters.

Portage group: P o r t a g e   g r o u p " A subdivision of the Chemung period in American geology. See Chart of Geology.

Portague: P o r t a g u e "n. A Portuguese gold coin formerly current  and variously estimated to be worth from three and one half to four and one half pounds sterling.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. A door or gate; hence  a way of entrance or exit especially one that is grand and imposing.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. The lesser gate  where there are two of different dimensions.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. Formerly  a small square corner in a room separated from the rest of the apartment by wainscoting forming a short passage to another apartment.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. By analogy with the French portail  used by recent writers for the whole architectural composition which surrounds and includes the doorways and porches of a church.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. The space  at one end between opposite trusses when these are terminated by inclined braces.

Portal: P o r t a l "n. A prayer book or breviary; a portass.

Portal: P o r t a l "a. Of or pertaining to a porta  especially the porta of the liver; as the portal vein which enters the liver at the porta and divides into capillaries after the manner of an artery.

Portamento: P o r t a m e n t o "n. In singing  or in the use of the bow a gradual carrying or lifting of the voice or sound very smoothly from one note to another; a gliding from tone to tone.

Portance: P o r t a n c e "n. See Port  carriage demeanor.

Portass: P o r t a s s "n. A breviary; a prayer book.

Portate: P o r t a t e "a. Borne not erect  but diagonally athwart an escutcheon; as a cross portate.

Portative: P o r t a t i v e "a. Portable.

Portative: P o r t a t i v e "a. Capable of holding up or carrying; as  the portative force of a magnet of atmospheric pressure or of capillarity.

Portcluse: P o r t c l u s e "n. A portcullis.

Portcrayon: P o r t c r a y o n "n. A metallic handle with a clasp for holding a crayon.

Portcullis: P o r t c u l l i s "n. A grating of iron or of timbers pointed with iron  hung over the gateway of a fortress to be let down to prevent the entrance of an enemy.

Portcullis: P o r t c u l l i s "n. An English coin of the reign of Elizabeth  struck for the use of the East India Company; -- so called from its bearing the figure of a portcullis on the reverse.

Portcullis: P o r t c u l l i s "v. t. To obstruct with  or as with a portcullis; to shut; to bar.

Portcullised: P o r t c u l l i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Portcullis

Portcullising: P o r t c u l l i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Portcullis

Porte: P o r t e "n. The Ottoman court; the government of the Turkish empire  officially called the Sublime Porte from the gate (port) of the sultan's palace at which justice was administered.

Porte-cochere: P o r t e - c o c h e r e "n. A large doorway allowing vehicles to drive into or through a building. It is common to have the entrance door open upon the passage of the porte-cochere. Also  a porch over a driveway before an entrance door.

Ported: P o r t e d "imp. & p. p. of Port

Ported: P o r t e d "a. Having gates.

Portegue: P o r t e g u e "n. See Portague.

Portemonnaie: P o r t e m o n n a i e "n. A small pocketbook or wallet for carrying money.

Portend: P o r t e n d "v. t. To indicate (events  misfortunes etc.) as in future; to foreshow; to foretoken; to bode; -- now used esp. of unpropitious signs.

Portend: P o r t e n d "v. t. To stretch out before.

Portended: P o r t e n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Portend

Portending: P o r t e n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Portend

Portension: P o r t e n s i o n "n. The act of foreshowing; foreboding.

Portent: P o r t e n t "n. That which portends  or foretoken; esp. that which portends evil; a sign of coming calamity; an omen; a sign.

Portentive: P o r t e n t i v e "a. Presaging; foreshadowing.

Portentous: P o r t e n t o u s "a. Of the nature of a portent; containing portents; foreshadowing  esp. foreshadowing ill; ominous.

Portentous: P o r t e n t o u s "a. Hence: Monstrous; prodigious; wonderful; dreadful; as  a beast of portentous size.

Porter: P o r t e r "n. A man who has charge of a door or gate; a doorkeeper; one who waits at the door to receive messages.

Porter: P o r t e r "n. A carrier; one who carries or conveys burdens  luggage etc.; for hire.

Porter: P o r t e r "n. A bar of iron or steel at the end of which a forging is made; esp.  a long large bar to the end of which a heavy forging is attached and by means of which the forging is lifted and handled in hammering and heating; -- called also porter bar.

Porter: P o r t e r "n. A malt liquor  of a dark color and moderately bitter taste possessing tonic and intoxicating qualities.

Porterage: P o r t e r a g e "n. The work of a porter; the occupation of a carrier or of a doorkeeper.

Porterage: P o r t e r a g e "n. Money charged or paid for the carriage of burdens or parcels by a porter.

Porteress: P o r t e r e s s "n. See Portress.

Porterhouse: P o r t e r h o u s e "n. A house where porter is sold.

Portesse: P o r t e s s e "n. See Porteass.

Portfire: P o r t f i r e "n. A case of strong paper filled with a composition of niter  sulphur and mealed powder -- used principally to ignite the priming in proving guns and as an incendiary material in shells.

Portfolio: P o r t f o l i o "n. A portable case for holding loose papers  prints drawings etc.

Portfolio: P o r t f o l i o "n. Hence: The office and functions of a minister of state or member of the cabinet; as  to receive the portfolio of war; to resign the portfolio.

Portglave: P o r t g l a v e "n. A sword bearer.

Portgrave: P o r t g r a v e " In old English law  the chief magistrate of a port or maritime town.; a portreeve.

Portgreve: P o r t g r e v e " Alt. of Portgrave

Porthole: P o r t h o l e "n. An embrasure in a ship's side. See 3d Port.

Porthook: P o r t h o o k "n. One of the iron hooks to which the port hinges are attached.

Porthors: P o r t h o r s "n. See Portass.

Portico: P o r t i c o "n. A colonnade or covered ambulatory  especially in classical styles of architecture; usually a colonnade at the entrance of a building.

Porticoed: P o r t i c o e d "a. Furnished with a portico.

Porticoes: P o r t i c o e s "pl. "of Portico

Porticos: P o r t i c o s "pl. "of Portico

Portiere: P o r t i e r e "n. A curtain hanging across a doorway.

Portigue: P o r t i g u e "n. See Portague.

Porting: P o r t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Port

Portingal: P o r t i n g a l "a. Of or pertaining to Portugal; Portuguese.

Portingal: P o r t i n g a l "n. A Portuguese.

Portion: P o r t i o n "n. That which is divided off or separated  as a part from a whole; a separated part of anything.

Portion: P o r t i o n "n. A part considered by itself  though not actually cut off or separated from the whole.

Portion: P o r t i o n "n. A part assigned; allotment; share; fate.

Portion: P o r t i o n "n. The part of an estate given to a child or heir  or descending to him by law and distributed to him in the settlement of the estate; an inheritance.

Portion: P o r t i o n "n. A wife's fortune; a dowry.

Portion: P o r t i o n "v. t. To separate or divide into portions or shares; to parcel; to distribute.

Portion: P o r t i o n "v. t. To endow with a portion or inheritance.

Portioned: P o r t i o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Portion

Portioner: P o r t i o n e r "n. One who portions.

Portioner: P o r t i o n e r "n. See Portionist  2.

Portioning: P o r t i o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Portion

Portionist: P o r t i o n i s t "n. A scholar at Merton College  Oxford who has a certain academical allowance or portion; -- corrupted into postmaster.

Portionist: P o r t i o n i s t "n. One of the incumbents of a benefice which has two or more rectors or vicars.

Portionless: P o r t i o n l e s s "a. Having no portion.

Portise: P o r t i s e "n. See Portass.

Portland cement: P o r t l a n d   c e m e n t " A cement having the color of the Portland stone of England  made by calcining an artificial mixture of carbonate of lime and clay or sometimes certain natural limestones or chalky clays. It contains a large proportion of clay and hardens under water.

Portland stone: P o r t l a n d   s t o n e " A yellowish-white calcareous freestone from the Isle of Portland in England  much used in building.

Portland vase: P o r t l a n d   v a s e " A celebrated cinerary urn or vase found in the tomb of the Emperor Alexander Severus. It is owned by the Duke of Portland  and kept in the British Museum.

Portlast: P o r t l a s t "n. The portoise. See Portoise.

Portliness: P o r t l i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being portly; dignity of mien or of personal appearance; stateliness.

Portliness: P o r t l i n e s s "n. Bulkiness; corpulence.

Portly: P o r t l y "a. Having a dignified port or mien; of a noble appearance; imposing.

Portly: P o r t l y "a. Bulky; corpulent.

Portman: P o r t m a n "n. An inhabitant or burgess of a port  esp. of one of the Cinque Ports.

Portmanteau: P o r t m a n t e a u "n. A bag or case  usually of leather for carrying wearing apparel etc. on journeys.

Portmanteaus: P o r t m a n t e a u s "pl. "of Portmanteau

Portmantle: P o r t m a n t l e "n. A portmanteau.

Portmen: P o r t m e n "pl. "of Portman

Portmote: P o r t m o t e "n. In old English law  a court or mote held in a port town.

Portoir: P o r t o i r "n. One who  or that which bears; hence one who or that which produces.

Portoise: P o r t o i s e "n. The gunwale of a ship.

Portos: P o r t o s "n. See Portass.

Portpane: P o r t p a n e "n. A cloth for carrying bread  so as not to touch it with the hands.

Portrait: P o r t r a i t "n. The likeness of a person  painted drawn or engraved; commonly a representation of the human face painted from real life.

Portrait: P o r t r a i t "n. Hence  any graphic or vivid delineation or description of a person; as a portrait in words.

Portrait: P o r t r a i t "v. t. To portray; to draw.

Portraitist: P o r t r a i t i s t "n. A portrait painter.

Portraiture: P o r t r a i t u r e "n. A portrait; a likeness; a painted resemblance; hence  that which is copied from some example or model.

Portraiture: P o r t r a i t u r e "n. Pictures  collectively; painting.

Portraiture: P o r t r a i t u r e "n. The art or practice of making portraits.

Portraiture: P o r t r a i t u r e "v. t. To represent by a portrait  or as by a portrait; to portray.

Portray: P o r t r a y "v. t. To paint or draw the likeness of; as  to portray a king on horseback.

Portray: P o r t r a y "v. t. Hence  figuratively to describe in words.

Portray: P o r t r a y "v. t. To adorn with pictures.

Portrayal: P o r t r a y a l "n. The act or process of portraying; description; delineation.

portrayed: p o r t r a y e d "imp. & p. p. of Portray

Portrayer: P o r t r a y e r "n. One who portrays.

Portraying: P o r t r a y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Portray

Portreeve: P o r t r e e v e "n. A port warden.

Portress: P o r t r e s s "n. A female porter.

Portsale: P o r t s a l e "n. Public or open sale; auction.

Portuary: P o r t u a r y "n. A breviary.

Portuguese: P o r t u g u e s e "a. Of or pertaining to Portugal  or its inhabitants.

Portuguese: P o r t u g u e s e "n. sing. & pl. A native or inhabitant of Portugal; people of Portugal.

Portulaca: P o r t u l a c a "n. A genus of polypetalous plants; also  any plant of the genus.

Portulacaceous: P o r t u l a c a c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Portulacaceae)  of which Portulaca is the type and which includes also the spring beauty (Claytonia) and other genera.

Porwigle: P o r w i g l e "n. See Polliwig.

Pory: P o r y "a. Porous; as  pory stone. [R.] Dryden.

Pose: P o s e "a. Standing still  with all the feet on the ground; -- said of the attitude of a lion horse or other beast.

Pose: P o s e "n. A cold in the head; catarrh.

Pose: P o s e "v. t. The attitude or position of a person; the position of the body or of any member of the body; especially  a position formally assumed for the sake of effect; an artificial position; as the pose of an actor; the pose of an artist's model or of a statue.

Pose: P o s e "v. t. To place in an attitude or fixed position  for the sake of effect; to arrange the posture and drapery of (a person) in a studied manner; as to pose a model for a picture; to pose a sitter for a portrait.

Pose: P o s e "v. i. To assume and maintain a studied attitude  with studied arrangement of drapery; to strike an attitude; to attitudinize; figuratively to assume or affect a certain character; as she poses as a prude.

Pose: P o s e "v. t. To interrogate; to question.

Pose: P o s e "v. t. To question with a view to puzzling; to embarrass by questioning or scrutiny; to bring to a stand.

Posed: P o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Pose

Posed: P o s e d "a. Firm; determined; fixed.

Poser: P o s e r "n. One who  or that which puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or fact.

Posied: P o s i e d "a. Inscribed with a posy.

Posies: P o s i e s "pl. "of Posy

Posing: P o s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pose

Posingly: P o s i n g l y "adv. So as to pose or puzzle.

Posit: P o s i t "v. t. To dispose or set firmly or fixedly; to place or dispose in relation to other objects.

Posit: P o s i t "v. t. To assume as real or conceded; as  to posit a principle.

Posited: P o s i t e d "imp. & p. p. of Posit

Positing: P o s i t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Posit

Position: P o s i t i o n "n. The state of being posited  or placed; the manner in which anything is placed; attitude; condition; as a firm an inclined or an upright position.

Position: P o s i t i o n "n. The spot where a person or thing is placed or takes a place; site; place; station; situation; as  the position of man in creation; the fleet changed its position.

Position: P o s i t i o n "n. Hence: The ground which any one takes in an argument or controversy; the point of view from which any one proceeds to a discussion; also  a principle laid down as the basis of reasoning; a proposition; a thesis; as to define one's position; to appear in a false position.

Position: P o s i t i o n "n. Relative place or standing; social or official rank; as  a person of position; hence office; post; as to lose one's position.

Position: P o s i t i o n "n. A method of solving a problem by one or two suppositions; -- called also the rule of trial and error.

Position: P o s i t i o n "v. t. To indicate the position of; to place.

Positional: P o s i t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to position.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Having a real position  existence or energy; existing in fact; real; actual; -- opposed to negative.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Derived from an object by itself; not dependent on changing circumstances or relations; absolute; -- opposed to relative; as  the idea of beauty is not positive but depends on the different tastes individuals.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Definitely laid down; explicitly stated; clearly expressed; -- opposed to implied; as  a positive declaration or promise.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Hence: Not admitting of any doubt  condition qualification or discretion; not dependent on circumstances or probabilities; not speculative; compelling assent or obedience; peremptory; indisputable; decisive; as positive instructions; positive truth; positive proof.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Prescribed by express enactment or institution; settled by arbitrary appointment; said of laws.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Fully assured; confident; certain; sometimes  overconfident; dogmatic; overbearing; -- said of persons.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Having the power of direct action or influence; as  a positive voice in legislation.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Corresponding with the original in respect to the position of lights and shades  instead of having the lights and shades reversed; as a positive picture.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Electro-positive.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "a. Hence  basic; metallic; not acid; -- opposed to negative and said of metals bases and basic radicals.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "n. That which is capable of being affirmed; reality.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "n. That which settles by absolute appointment.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "n. The positive degree or form.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "n. A picture in which the lights and shades correspond in position with those of the original  instead of being reversed as in a negative.

Positive: P o s i t i v e "n. The positive plate of a voltaic or electrolytic cell.

Positively: P o s i t i v e l y "adv. In a positive manner; absolutely; really; expressly; with certainty; indubitably; peremptorily; dogmatically; -- opposed to negatively.

Positiveness: P o s i t i v e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being positive; reality; actualness; certainty; confidence; peremptoriness; dogmatism. See Positive  a.

Positivism: P o s i t i v i s m "n. A system of philosophy originated by M. Auguste Comte  which deals only with positives. It excludes from philosophy everything but the natural phenomena or properties of knowable things together with their invariable relations of coexistence and succession as occurring in time and space. Such relations are denominated laws which are to be discovered by observation experiment and comparison. This philosophy holds all inquiry into causes both efficient and final to be useless and unprofitable.

Positivist: P o s i t i v i s t "n. A believer in positivism.

Positivist: P o s i t i v i s t "a. Relating to positivism.

Positivity: P o s i t i v i t y "n. Positiveness.

Positure: P o s i t u r e "n. See Posture.

Posnet: P o s n e t "n. A little basin; a porringer; a skillet.

Posologic: P o s o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Posological

Posological: P o s o l o g i c a l "a. Pertaining to posology.

Posology: P o s o l o g y "n. The science or doctrine of doses; dosology.

Pospolite: P o s p o l i t e "n. A kind of militia in Poland  consisting of the gentry which in case of invasion was summoned to the defense of the country.

Poss: P o s s "v. t. To push; to dash; to throw.

Posse: P o s s e "n. See Posse comitatus.

Posse comitatus: P o s s e   c o m i t a t u s " The power of the county  or the citizens who may be summoned by the sheriff to assist the authorities in suppressing a riot or executing any legal precept which is forcibly opposed.

Posse comitatus: P o s s e   c o m i t a t u s " A collection of people; a throng; a rabble.

Possess: P o s s e s s "v. t. To occupy in person; to hold or actually have in one's own keeping; to have and to hold.

Possess: P o s s e s s "v. t. To have the legal title to; to have a just right to; to be master of; to own; to have; as  to possess property an estate a book.

Possess: P o s s e s s "v. t. To obtain occupation or possession of; to accomplish; to gain; to seize.

Possess: P o s s e s s "v. t. To enter into and influence; to control the will of; to fill; to affect; -- said especially of evil spirits  passions etc.

Possess: P o s s e s s "v. t. To put in possession; to make the owner or holder of property  power knowledge etc.; to acquaint; to inform; -- followed by of or with before the thing possessed and now commonly used reflexively.

Possessed: P o s s e s s e d "imp. & p. p. of Possess

Possessing: P o s s e s s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Possess

Possession: P o s s e s s i o n "n. The act or state of possessing  or holding as one's own.

Possession: P o s s e s s i o n "n. The having  holding or detention of property in one's power or command; actual seizin or occupancy; ownership whether rightful or wrongful.

Possession: P o s s e s s i o n "n. The thing possessed; that which any one occupies  owns or controls; in the plural property in the aggregate; wealth; dominion; as foreign possessions.

Possession: P o s s e s s i o n "n. The state of being possessed or controlled  as by an evil spirit or violent passions; madness; frenzy; as demoniacal possession.

Possession: P o s s e s s i o n "v. t. To invest with property.

Possessionary: P o s s e s s i o n a r y "a. Of or pertaining to possession; arising from possession.

Possessioner: P o s s e s s i o n e r "n. A possessor; a property holder.

Possessioner: P o s s e s s i o n e r "n. An invidious name for a member of any religious community endowed with property in lands  buildings etc. as contrasted with mendicant friars.

Possessival: P o s s e s s i v a l "a. Of or pertaining to the possessive case; as  a possessival termination.

Possessive: P o s s e s s i v e "a. Of or pertaining to possession; having or indicating possession.

Possessive: P o s s e s s i v e "n. The possessive case.

Possessive: P o s s e s s i v e "n. A possessive pronoun  or a word in the possessive case.

Possessively: P o s s e s s i v e l y "adv. In a possessive manner.

Possessor: P o s s e s s o r "n. One who possesses; one who occupies  holds owns or controls; one who has actual participation or enjoyment generally of that which is desirable; a proprietor.

Possessory: P o s s e s s o r y "a. Of or pertaining to possession  either as a fact or a right; of the nature of possession; as a possessory interest; a possessory lord.

Posset: P o s s e t "n. A beverage composed of hot milk curdled by some strong infusion  as by wine etc. -- much in favor formerly.

Posset: P o s s e t "v. t. To curdle; to turn  as milk; to coagulate; as to posset the blood.

Posset: P o s s e t "v. t. To treat with possets; to pamper.

Posseted: P o s s e t e d "imp. & p. p. of Posset

Posseting: P o s s e t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Posset

Possibilities: P o s s i b i l i t i e s "pl. "of Possibility

Possibility: P o s s i b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being possible; the power of happening  being or existing.

Possibility: P o s s i b i l i t y "n. That which is possible; a contingency; a thing or event that may not happen; a contingent interest  as in real or personal estate.

Possible: P o s s i b l e "a. Capable of existing or occurring  or of being conceived or thought of; able to happen; capable of being done; not contrary to the nature of things; -- sometimes used to express extreme improbability; barely able to be or to come to pass; as possibly he is honest as it is possible that Judas meant no wrong.

Possibly: P o s s i b l y "adv. In a possible manner; by possible means; especially  by extreme remote or improbable intervention change or exercise of power; by a chance; perhaps; as possibly he may recover.

Possum: P o s s u m "n. An opossum.

Post: P o s t "a. Hired to do what is wrong; suborned.

Post: P o s t "n. A piece of timber  metal or other solid substance fixed or to be fixed firmly in an upright position especially when intended as a stay or support to something else; a pillar; as a hitching post; a fence post; the posts of a house.

Post: P o s t "n. The doorpost of a victualer's shop or inn  on which were chalked the scores of customers; hence a score; a debt.

Post: P o s t "n. The place at which anything is stopped  placed or fixed; a station.

Post: P o s t "n. A station  or one of a series of stations established for the refreshment and accommodation of travelers on some recognized route; as a stage or railway post.

Post: P o s t "n. A military station; the place at which a soldier or a body of troops is stationed; also  the troops at such a station.

Post: P o s t "n. The piece of ground to which a sentinel's walk is limited.

Post: P o s t "n. A messenger who goes from station; an express; especially  one who is employed by the government to carry letters and parcels regularly from one place to another; a letter carrier; a postman.

Post: P o s t "n. An established conveyance for letters from one place or station to another; especially  the governmental system in any country for carrying and distributing letters and parcels; the post office; the mail; hence the carriage by which the mail is transported.

Post: P o s t "n. Haste or speed  like that of a messenger or mail carrier.

Post: P o s t "n. One who has charge of a station  especially of a postal station.

Post: P o s t "n. A station  office or position of service trust or emolument; as the post of duty; the post of danger.

Post: P o s t "n. A size of printing and writing paper. See the Table under Paper.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To attach to a post  a wall or other usual place of affixing public notices; to placard; as to post a notice; to post playbills.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To hold up to public blame or reproach; to advertise opprobriously; to denounce by public proclamation; as  to post one for cowardice.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To enter (a name) on a list  as for service promotion or the like.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To assign to a station; to set; to place; as  to post a sentinel.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To carry  as an account from the journal to the ledger; as to post an account; to transfer as accounts to the ledger.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To place in the care of the post; to mail; as  to post a letter.

Post: P o s t "v. t. To inform; to give the news to; to make (one) acquainted with the details of a subject; -- often with up.

Post: P o s t "v. i. To travel with post horses; figuratively  to travel in haste.

Post: P o s t "v. i. To rise and sink in the saddle  in accordance with the motion of the horse esp. in trotting.

Post: P o s t "adv. With post horses; hence  in haste; as to travel post.

Post note: P o s t   n o t e " A note issued by a bank  payable at some future specified time as distinguished from a note payable on demand.

Post office: P o s t   o f f i c e "n. See under 4th Post.

Post-: P o s t - " A prefix signifying behind  back after; as postcommissure postdot postscript.

Post-abdomen: P o s t - a b d o m e n "n. That part of a crustacean behind the cephalothorax; -- more commonly called abdomen.

Post-captain: P o s t - c a p t a i n "n. A captain of a war vessel whose name appeared  or was posted  in the seniority list of the British navy as distinguished from a commander whose name was not so posted. The term was also used in the United States navy; but no such commission as post-captain was ever recognized in either service and the term has fallen into disuse.

Post-disseizin: P o s t - d i s s e i z i n "n. A subsequent disseizin committed by one of lands which the disseizee had before recovered of the same disseizor; a writ founded on such subsequent disseizin  now abolished.

Post-disseizor: P o s t - d i s s e i z o r "n. A person who disseizes another of lands which the disseizee had before recovered of the same disseizor.

Post-fine: P o s t - f i n e "n. A duty paid to the king by the cognizee in a fine of lands  when the same was fully passed; -- called also the king's silver.

Post-mortem: P o s t - m o r t e m "a. After death; as  post-mortem rigidity.

Post-obit: P o s t - o b i t " Alt. of Post-obit bond

Post-obit bond: P o s t - o b i t   b o n d " A bond in which the obligor  in consideration of having received a certain sum of money binds himself to pay a larger sum on unusual interest on the death of some specified individual from whom he has expectations.

Post-temporal: P o s t - t e m p o r a l "a. Situated back of the temporal bone or the temporal region of the skull; -- applied especially to a bone which usually connects the supraclavicle with the skull in the pectoral arch of fishes.

Post-temporal: P o s t - t e m p o r a l "n. A post-temporal bone.

Post-tragus: P o s t - t r a g u s "n. A ridge within and behind the tragus in the ear of some animals.

Post-tympanic: P o s t - t y m p a n i c "a. Situated behind the tympanum  or in the skull behind the auditory meatus.

Postable: P o s t a b l e "a. Capable of being carried by  or as by post.

Postact: P o s t a c t "n. An act done afterward.

Postage: P o s t a g e "n. The price established by law to be paid for the conveyance of a letter or other mailable matter by a public post.

Postal: P o s t a l "a. Belonging to the post office or mail service; as  postal arrangements; postal authorities.

Postanal: P o s t a n a l "a. Situated behind  or posterior to the anus.

Postaxial: P o s t a x i a l "a. Situated behind any transverse axis in the body of an animal; caudal; posterior; especially  behind or on the caudal or posterior (that is ulnar or fibular) side of the axis of a vertebrate limb.

Postboy: P o s t b o y "n. One who rides post horses; a position; a courier.

Postboy: P o s t b o y "n. A boy who carries letters from the post.

Postcava: P o s t c a v a "n. The inferior vena cava.

Postcavae: P o s t c a v a e "pl. "of Postcava

Postclavicle: P o s t c l a v i c l e "n. A bone in the pectoral girdle of many fishes projecting backward from the clavicle.

Postcomminion: P o s t c o m m i n i o n "n. The concluding portion of the communion service.

Postcomminion: P o s t c o m m i n i o n "n. A prayer or prayers which the priest says at Mass  after the ablutions.

Postcommissure: P o s t c o m m i s s u r e "n. A transverse commisure in the posterior part of the roof of the third ventricle of the brain; the posterior cerebral commisure.

Postcornu: P o s t c o r n u "n. The posterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain.

Postcornua: P o s t c o r n u a "pl. "of Postcornu

Postdate: P o s t d a t e "v. t. To date after the real time; as  to postdate a contract that is to date it later than the time when it was in fact made.

Postdate: P o s t d a t e "v. t. To affix a date to after the event.

Postdate: P o s t d a t e "a. Made or done after the date assigned.

Postdate: P o s t d a t e "n. A date put to a bill of exchange or other paper  later than that when it was actually made.

Postdated: P o s t d a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Postdate

Postdating: P o s t d a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postdate

Postdiluvial: P o s t d i l u v i a l "a. Alt. of Postdiluvian

Postdiluvian: P o s t d i l u v i a n "a. Being or happening after the flood in Noah's days.

Postdiluvian: P o s t d i l u v i a n "n. One who lived after the flood.

Postea: P o s t e a "n. The return of the judge before whom a cause was tried  after a verdict of what was done in the cause which is indorsed on the nisi prius record.

Posted: P o s t e d "imp. & p. p. of Post

Postel: P o s t e l "n. Apostle.

Postencephalon: P o s t e n c e p h a l o n "n. The metencephalon.

Postentry: P o s t e n t r y "n. A second or subsequent  at the customhouse of goods which had been omitted by mistake.

Postentry: P o s t e n t r y "n. An additional or subsequent entry.

Poster: P o s t e r "n. A large bill or placard intended to be posted in public places.

Poster: P o s t e r "n. One who posts bills; a billposter.

Poster: P o s t e r "n. One who posts  or travels expeditiously; a courier.

Poster: P o s t e r "n. A post horse.

Posterior: P o s t e r i o r "a. Later in time; hence  later in the order of proceeding or moving; coming after; -- opposed to prior.

Posterior: P o s t e r i o r "a. Situated behind; hinder; -- opposed to anterior.

Posterior: P o s t e r i o r "a. At or toward the caudal extremity; caudal; -- in human anatomy often used for dorsal.

Posterior: P o s t e r i o r "a. On the side next the axis of inflorescence; -- said of an axillary flower.

Posteriority: P o s t e r i o r i t y "n. The state of being later or subsequent; as  posteriority of time or of an event; -- opposed to priority.

Posteriorly: P o s t e r i o r l y "adv. Subsequently in time; also  behind in position.
