Posteriors: P o s t e r i o r s "n. pl. The hinder parts  as of an animal's body.

Posterity: P o s t e r i t y "n. The race that proceeds from a progenitor; offspring to the furthest generation; the aggregate number of persons who are descended from an ancestor of a generation; descendants; -- contrasted with ancestry; as  the posterity of Abraham.

Posterity: P o s t e r i t y "n. Succeeding generations; future times.

Postern: P o s t e r n "n. Originally  a back door or gate; a private entrance; hence any small door or gate.

Postern: P o s t e r n "n. A subterraneous passage communicating between the parade and the main ditch  or between the ditches and the interior of the outworks.

Postern: P o s t e r n "a. Back; being behind; private.

Postero: P o s t e r o " - (/). A combining form meaning posterior  back; as postero-inferior situated back and below; postero-lateral situated back and at the side.

Postexist: P o s t e x i s t "v. i. To exist after; to live subsequently.

Postexistence: P o s t e x i s t e n c e "n. Subsequent existence.

Postexistent: P o s t e x i s t e n t "a. Existing or living after.

Postfact: P o s t f a c t "a. Relating to a fact that occurs after another.

Postfact: P o s t f a c t "n. A fact that occurs after another.

Postfactum: P o s t f a c t u m "n. Same as Postfact.

Postfix: P o s t f i x "n. A letter  syllable or word added to the end of another word; a suffix.

Postfix: P o s t f i x "v. t. To annex; specifically (Gram.)  to add or annex as a letter syllable or word to the end of another or principal word; to suffix.

Postfixes: P o s t f i x e s "pl. "of Postfix

Postfrontal: P o s t f r o n t a l "a. Situated behind the frontal bone or the frontal region of the skull; -- applied especially to a bone back of and below the frontal in many animals.

Postfrontal: P o s t f r o n t a l "n. A postfrontal bone.

Postfurca: P o s t f u r c a "n. One of the internal thoracic processes of the sternum of an insect.

Postfurcae: P o s t f u r c a e "pl. "of Postfurca

Postgeniture: P o s t g e n i t u r e "n. The condition of being born after another in the same family; -- distinguished from primogeniture.

Postglenoid: P o s t g l e n o i d "a. Situated behind the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone.

Posthaste: P o s t h a s t e "n. Haste or speed in traveling  like that of a post or courier.

Posthaste: P o s t h a s t e "adv. With speed or expedition; as  he traveled posthaste; to send posthaste.

Posthetomy: P o s t h e t o m y "n. Circumcision.

Posthouse: P o s t h o u s e "n. A house established for the convenience of the post  where relays of horses can be obtained.

Posthouse: P o s t h o u s e "n. A house for distributing the malls; a post office.

Posthume: P o s t h u m e "a. Alt. of Posthumed

Posthumed: P o s t h u m e d "a. Posthumous.

Posthumous: P o s t h u m o u s "a. Born after the death of the father  or taken from the dead body of the mother; as a posthumous son or daughter.

Posthumous: P o s t h u m o u s "a. Published after the death of the author; as  posthumous works; a posthumous edition.

Posthumous: P o s t h u m o u s "a. Being or continuing after one's death; as  a posthumous reputation.

Posthumously: P o s t h u m o u s l y "adv. In a posthumous manner; after one's decease.

Postic: P o s t i c "a. Backward.

Postil: P o s t i l "n. Originally  an explanatory note in the margin of the Bible so called because written after the text; hence a marginal note; a comment.

Postil: P o s t i l "n. A short homily or commentary on a passage of Scripture; as  the first postils were composed by order of Charlemagne.

Postil: P o s t i l "v. t. To write marginal or explanatory notes on; to gloss.

Postil: P o s t i l "v. i. To write postils  or marginal notes; to comment; to postillate.

Postiled: P o s t i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Postil

Postiler: P o s t i l e r "n. One who writers marginal notes; one who illustrates the text of a book by notes in the margin.

Postiling: P o s t i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postil

Postilion: P o s t i l i o n "n. One who rides and guides the first pair of horses of a coach or post chaise; also  one who rides one of the horses when one pair only is used.

Postillate: P o s t i l l a t e "v. t. To explain by marginal notes; to postil.

Postillate: P o s t i l l a t e "v. i. To write postils; to comment.

Postillate: P o s t i l l a t e "v. i. To preach by expounding Scripture verse by verse  in regular order.

Postillation: P o s t i l l a t i o n "n. The act of postillating; exposition of Scripture in preaching.

Postillator: P o s t i l l a t o r "n. One who postillates; one who expounds the Scriptures verse by verse.

Postilled: P o s t i l l e d " of Postil

Postilling: P o s t i l l i n g " of Postil

Posting: P o s t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Post

Posting: P o s t i n g "n. The act of traveling post.

Posting: P o s t i n g "n. The act of transferring an account  as from the journal to the ledger.

Postliminiar: P o s t l i m i n i a r "a. Contrived  done or existing subsequently.

Postliminiary: P o s t l i m i n i a r y "a. Pertaining to  or involving the right of postliminium.

Postliminium: P o s t l i m i n i u m "n. Alt. of Postliminy

Postliminy: P o s t l i m i n y "n. The return to his own country  and his former privileges of a person who had gone to sojourn in a foreign country or had been banished or taken by an enemy.

Postliminy: P o s t l i m i n y "n. The right by virtue of which persons and things taken by an enemy in war are restored to their former state when coming again under the power of the nation to which they belonged.

Postlude: P o s t l u d e "n. A voluntary at the end of a service.

Postman: P o s t m a n "n. A post or courier; a letter carrier.

Postman: P o s t m a n "n. One of the two most experienced barristers in the Court of Exchequer  who have precedence in motions; -- so called from the place where he sits. The other of the two is called the tubman.

Postmark: P o s t m a r k "n. The mark  or stamp of a post office on a letter giving the place and date of mailing or of arrival.

Postmark: P o s t m a r k "v. t. To mark with a post-office stamp; as  to postmark a letter or parcel.

Postmarked: P o s t m a r k e d "imp. & p. p. of Postmark

Postmarking: P o s t m a r k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postmark

Postmaster: P o s t m a s t e r "n. One who has charge of a station for the accommodation of travelers; one who supplies post horses.

Postmaster: P o s t m a s t e r "n. One who has charge of a post office  and the distribution and forwarding of mails.

Postmaster-general: P o s t m a s t e r - g e n e r a l "n. The chief officer of the post-office department of a government. In the United States the postmaster-general is a member of the cabinet.

Postmasters-general: P o s t m a s t e r s - g e n e r a l "pl. "of Postmaster-general

Postmastership: P o s t m a s t e r s h i p "n. The office of postmaster.

Postmen: P o s t m e n "pl. "of Postman

Postmeridian: P o s t m e r i d i a n "a. Coming after the sun has passed the meridian; being in  or belonging to the afternoon. (Abbrev. P. M.)

Postmeridian: P o s t m e r i d i a n "a. Fig.  belonging to the after portion of life; late.

Postnares: P o s t n a r e s "n. pl. The posterior nares. See Nares.

Postnatal: P o s t n a t a l "a. After birth; subsequent to birth; as  postnatal infanticide; postnatal diseases.

Postnate: P o s t n a t e "a. Subsequent.

Postnuptial: P o s t n u p t i a l "a. Being or happening after marriage; as  a postnuptial settlement on a wife.

Postoblongata: P o s t o b l o n g a t a "n. The posterior part of the medulla oblongata.

Postocular: P o s t o c u l a r "a. & n. Same as Postorbital.

Postoral: P o s t o r a l "a. Situated behind  or posterior to the mouth.

Postorbital: P o s t o r b i t a l "a. Situated behind the orbit; as  the postorbital scales of some fishes and reptiles.

Postorbital: P o s t o r b i t a l "n. A postorbital bone or scale.

Postpaid: P o s t p a i d "a. Having the postage prepaid  as a letter.

Postpalatine: P o s t p a l a t i n e "a. Situated behind the palate  or behind the palatine bones.

Postpliocene: P o s t p l i o c e n e "a. Of or pertaining to the period immediately following the Pliocene; Pleistocene. Also used as a noun. See Quaternary.

Postpone: P o s t p o n e "v. t. To defer to a future or later time; to put off; also  to cause to be deferred or put off; to delay; to adjourn; as to postpone the consideration of a bill to the following day or indefinitely.

Postpone: P o s t p o n e "v. t. To place after  behind or below something in respect to precedence preference value or importance.

Postponed: P o s t p o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Postpone

Postponement: P o s t p o n e m e n t "n. The act of postponing; a deferring  or putting off to a future time; a temporary delay.

Postponence: P o s t p o n e n c e "n. The act of postponing  in sense 2.

Postponer: P o s t p o n e r "n. One who postpones.

Postponing: P o s t p o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postpone

Postpose: P o s t p o s e "v. t. To postpone.

Postposed: P o s t p o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Postpose

Postposing: P o s t p o s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postpose

Postposit: P o s t p o s i t "v. t. To postpone.

Postposition: P o s t p o s i t i o n "n. The act of placing after  or the state of being placed after.

Postposition: P o s t p o s i t i o n "n. A word or particle placed after  or at the end of another word; -- distinguished from preposition.

Postpositional: P o s t p o s i t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to postposition.

Postpositive: P o s t p o s i t i v e "a. Placed after another word; as  a postpositive conjunction; a postpositive letter.

Postprandial: P o s t p r a n d i a l "a. Happening  or done after dinner; after-dinner; as postprandial speeches.

Postremogeniture: P o s t r e m o g e n i t u r e "n. The right of the youngest born.

Postremote: P o s t r e m o t e "a. More remote in subsequent time or order.

Postrider: P o s t r i d e r "n. One who rides over a post road to carry the mails.

Postscapula: P o s t s c a p u l a "n. The part of the scapula behind or below the spine  or mesoscapula.

Postscapular: P o s t s c a p u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the postscapula; infraspinous.

Postscenium: P o s t s c e n i u m "n. The part of a theater behind the scenes; the back part of the stage of a theater.

Postscribe: P o s t s c r i b e "v. t. To make a postscript.

Postscript: P o s t s c r i p t "n. A paragraph added to a letter after it is concluded and signed by the writer; an addition made to a book or composition after the main body of the work has been finished  containing something omitted or something new occurring to the writer.

Postscripted: P o s t s c r i p t e d "a. Having a postscript; added in a postscript.

Postscutellum: P o s t s c u t e l l u m "n. The hindermost dorsal piece of a thoracic somite of an insect; the plate behind the scutellum.

Postsphenoid: P o s t s p h e n o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the posterior part of the sphenoid bone.

Posttertiary: P o s t t e r t i a r y "a. Following  or more recent than the Tertiary; Quaternary.

Postticous: P o s t t i c o u s "a. Posterior.

Postticous: P o s t t i c o u s "a. Situated on the outer side of a filament; -- said of an extrorse anther.

Posttiller: P o s t t i l l e r "n. See Postiler.

Postulant: P o s t u l a n t "n. One who makes a request or demand; hence  a candidate.

Postulata: P o s t u l a t a "pl. "of Postulatum

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "n. Something demanded or asserted; especially  a position or supposition assumed without proof or one which is considered as self-evident; a truth to which assent may be demanded or challenged without argument or evidence.

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "n. The enunciation of a self-evident problem  in distinction from an axiom which is the enunciation of a self-evident theorem.

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "a. Postulated.

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "v. t. To beg  or assume without proof; as to postulate conclusions.

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "v. t. To take without express consent; to assume.

Postulate: P o s t u l a t e "v. t. To invite earnestly; to solicit.

Postulated: P o s t u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Postulate

Postulated: P o s t u l a t e d "a. Assumed without proof; as  a postulated inference.

Postulating: P o s t u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Postulate

Postulation: P o s t u l a t i o n "n. The act of postulating  or that which is postulated; assumption; solicitation; suit; cause.

Postulatory: P o s t u l a t o r y "a. Of the nature of a postulate.

Postulatum: P o s t u l a t u m "n. A postulate.

Postumous: P o s t u m o u s "a. See Posthumous.

Postural: P o s t u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to posture.

Posture: P o s t u r e "n. The position of the body; the situation or disposition of the several parts of the body with respect to each other  or for a particular purpose; especially (Fine Arts) the position of a figure with regard to the several principal members by which action is expressed; attitude.

Posture: P o s t u r e "n. Place; position; situation.

Posture: P o s t u r e "n. State or condition  whether of external circumstances or of internal feeling and will; disposition; mood; as a posture of defense; the posture of affairs.

Posture: P o s t u r e "v. t. To place in a particular position or attitude; to dispose the parts of  with reference to a particular purpose; as to posture one's self; to posture a model.

Posture: P o s t u r e "v. i. To assume a particular posture or attitude; to contort the body into artificial attitudes  as an acrobat or contortionist; also to pose.

Posture: P o s t u r e "v. i. Fig.: To assume a character; as  to posture as a saint.

Postured: P o s t u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Posture

Posturer: P o s t u r e r "n. One who postures.

Posturing: P o s t u r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Posture

Postzygapophyses: P o s t z y g a p o p h y s e s "pl. "of Postzygapophysis

Postzygapophysis: P o s t z y g a p o p h y s i s "n. A posterior zygapophysis.

Posy: P o s y "n. A brief poetical sentiment; hence  any brief sentiment motto or legend; especially one inscribed on a ring.

Posy: P o s y "n. A flower; a bouquet; a nosegay.

Pot: P o t "n. A metallic or earthen vessel  appropriated to any of a great variety of uses as for boiling meat or vegetables for holding liquids for plants etc.; as a quart pot; a flower pot; a bean pot.

Pot: P o t "n. An earthen or pewter cup for liquors; a mug.

Pot: P o t "n. The quantity contained in a pot; a potful; as  a pot of ale.

Pot: P o t "n. A metal or earthenware extension of a flue above the top of a chimney; a chimney pot.

Pot: P o t "n. A crucible; as  a graphite pot; a melting pot.

Pot: P o t "n. A wicker vessel for catching fish  eels etc.

Pot: P o t "n. A perforated cask for draining sugar.

Pot: P o t "n. A size of paper. See Pott.

Pot: P o t "v. t. To place or inclose in pots

Pot: P o t "v. t. To preserve seasoned in pots.

Pot: P o t "v. t. To set out or cover in pots; as  potted plants or bulbs.

Pot: P o t "v. t. To drain; as  to pot sugar by taking it from the cooler and placing it in hogsheads etc. having perforated heads through which the molasses drains off.

Pot: P o t "v. t. To pocket.

Pot: P o t "v. i. To tipple; to drink.

Pot-bellied: P o t - b e l l i e d "a. Having a protuberant belly  like the bottom of a pot.

Pot-belly: P o t - b e l l y "n. A protuberant belly.

Pot-sure: P o t - s u r e "a. Made confident by drink.

Pot-valiant: P o t - v a l i a n t "a. Having the courage given by drink.

Pot-walloper: P o t - w a l l o p e r "n. A voter in certain boroughs of England  where before the passage of the reform bill of 1832 the qualification for suffrage was to have boiled (walloped) his own pot in the parish for six months.

Pot-walloper: P o t - w a l l o p e r "n. One who cleans pots; a scullion.

Potable: P o t a b l e "a. Fit to be drunk; drinkable.

Potable: P o t a b l e "n. A potable liquid; a beverage.

Potableness: P o t a b l e n e s s "n. The quality of being drinkable.

Potage: P o t a g e "n. See Pottage.

Potager: P o t a g e r "n. A porringer.

Potagro: P o t a g r o "n. See Potargo.

Potale: P o t a l e "n. The refuse from a grain distillery  used to fatten swine.

Potamian: P o t a m i a n "n. A river tortoise; one of a group of tortoises (Potamites  or Trionychoidea) having a soft shell webbed feet and a sharp beak. See Trionyx.

Potamography: P o t a m o g r a p h y "n. An account or description of rivers; potamology.

Potamology: P o t a m o l o g y "n. A scientific account or discussion of rivers; a treatise on rivers; potamography.

Potamospongiae: P o t a m o s p o n g i a e "n. pl. The fresh-water sponges. See Spongilla.

Potance: P o t a n c e "n. The stud in which the bearing for the lower pivot of the verge is made.

Potargo: P o t a r g o "n. A kind of sauce or pickle.

Potash: P o t a s h "n. The hydroxide of potassium hydrate  a hard white brittle substance KOH having strong caustic and alkaline properties; -- hence called also caustic potash.

Potash: P o t a s h "n. The impure potassium carbonate obtained by leaching wood ashes  either as a strong solution (lye) or as a white crystalline (pearlash).

Potashes: P o t a s h e s "n. pl. Potash.

Potassa: P o t a s s a "n. Potassium oxide.

Potassa: P o t a s s a "n. Potassium hydroxide  commonly called caustic potash.

Potassamide: P o t a s s a m i d e "n. A yellowish brown substance obtained by heating potassium in ammonia.

Potassium: P o t a s s i u m "n. An Alkali element  occurring abundantly but always combined as in the chloride sulphate carbonate or silicate in the minerals sylvite kainite orthoclase muscovite etc. Atomic weight 39.0. Symbol K (Kalium).

Potassoxyl: P o t a s s o x y l "n. The radical KO  derived from and supposed to exist in potassium hydroxide and other compounds.

Potation: P o t a t i o n "n. The act of drinking.

Potation: P o t a t i o n "n. A draught.

Potation: P o t a t i o n "n. Drink; beverage.

Potato: P o t a t o "n. A plant (Solanum tuberosum) of the Nightshade family  and its esculent farinaceous tuber of which there are numerous varieties used for food. It is native of South America but a form of the species is found native as far north as New Mexico.

Potato: P o t a t o "n. The sweet potato (see below).

Potatoes: P o t a t o e s "pl. "of Potato

Potator: P o t a t o r "n. A drinker.

Potatory: P o t a t o r y "a. Of or pertaining to drinking.

Potboiler: P o t b o i l e r "n. A term applied derisively to any literary or artistic work  and esp. a painting done simply for money and the means of living.

Potboy: P o t b o y "n. A boy who carries pots of ale  beer etc.; a menial in a public house.

Potch: P o t c h "v. i. To thrust; to push.

Potch: P o t c h "v. t. See Poach  to cook.

Potcher: P o t c h e r "n. One who  or that which potches.

Potecary: P o t e c a r y "n. An apothecary.

Poteen: P o t e e n "n. Whisky; especially  whisky illicitly distilled by the Irish peasantry.

Potelot: P o t e l o t "n. Molybdenum sulphide.

Potence: P o t e n c e "n. Potency; capacity.

Potency: P o t e n c y "n. The quality or state of being potent; physical or moral power; inherent strength; energy; ability to effect a purpose; capability; efficacy; influence.

Potent: P o t e n t "a. Producing great physical effects; forcible; powerful' efficacious; as  a potent medicine.

Potent: P o t e n t "a. Having great authority  control or dominion; puissant; mighty; influential; as a potent prince.

Potent: P o t e n t "a. Powerful  in an intellectual or moral sense; having great influence; as potent interest; a potent argument.

Potent: P o t e n t "n. A prince; a potentate.

Potent: P o t e n t "n. A staff or crutch.

Potent: P o t e n t "n. One of the furs; a surface composed of patches which are supposed to represent crutch heads; they are always alternately argent and azure  unless otherwise specially mentioned.

Potentacy: P o t e n t a c y "n. Sovereignty.

Potentate: P o t e n t a t e "a. One who is potent; one who possesses great power or sway; a prince  sovereign or monarch.

Potential: P o t e n t i a l "a. Being potent; endowed with energy adequate to a result; efficacious; influential.

Potential: P o t e n t i a l "a. Existing in possibility  not in actuality.

Potential: P o t e n t i a l "n. Anything that may be possible; a possibility; potentially.

Potential: P o t e n t i a l "n. In the theory of gravitation  or of other forces acting in space a function of the rectangular coordinates which determine the position of a point such that its differential coefficients with respect to the coordinates are equal to the components of the force at the point considered; -- also called potential function or force function. It is called also Newtonian potential when the force is directed to a fixed center and is inversely as the square of the distance from the center.

Potential: P o t e n t i a l "n. The energy of an electrical charge measured by its power to do work; hence  the degree of electrification as referred to some standard as that of the earth; electro-motive force.

Potentiality: P o t e n t i a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being potential; possibility  not actuality; inherent capability or disposition not actually exhibited.

Potentially: P o t e n t i a l l y "adv. With power; potently.

Potentially: P o t e n t i a l l y "adv. In a potential manner; possibly  not positively.

Potentiate: P o t e n t i a t e "v. t. To render active or potent.

Potentiated: P o t e n t i a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Potentiate

Potentiating: P o t e n t i a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Potentiate

Potentiometer: P o t e n t i o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring or comparing electrial potentials or electro-motive forces.

Potentize: P o t e n t i z e "v. t. To render the latent power of (anything) available.

Potentized: P o t e n t i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Potentize

Potentizing: P o t e n t i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Potentize

Potently: P o t e n t l y "adv. With great force or energy; powerfully; efficaciously.

Potentness: P o t e n t n e s s "n. The quality or state of being potent; powerfulness; potency; efficacy.

Potestate: P o t e s t a t e "n. A chief ruler; a potentate. [Obs.] Wyclif.

Potestative: P o t e s t a t i v e "a. Authoritative.

Potgun: P o t g u n "n. A pot-shaped cannon; a mortar.

Potgun: P o t g u n "n. A popgun.

Pothecary: P o t h e c a r y "n. An apothecary.

Potheen: P o t h e e n "n. See Poteen.

Pother: P o t h e r "n. Bustle; confusion; tumult; flutter; bother.

Pother: P o t h e r "v. i. To make a bustle or stir; to be fussy.

Pother: P o t h e r "v. t. To harass and perplex; to worry.

Pothered: P o t h e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Pother

Pothering: P o t h e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pother

Pothole: P o t h o l e "n. A circular hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by the grinding action of stones or gravel whirled round by the water in what was at first a natural depression of the rock.

Pothook: P o t h o o k "n. An S-shaped hook on which pots and kettles are hung over an open fire.

Pothook: P o t h o o k "n. A written character curved like a pothook; (pl.) a scrawled writing.

Pothouse: P o t h o u s e "n. An alehouse.

Potichomania: P o t i c h o m a n i a "n. Alt. of Potichomanie

Potichomanie: P o t i c h o m a n i e "n. The art or process of coating the inside of glass vessels with engravings or paintings  so as to give them the appearance of painted ware.

Potion: P o t i o n "n. A draught; a dose; usually  a draught or dose of a liquid medicine.

Potion: P o t i o n "v. t. To drug.

Potlid: P o t l i d "n. The lid or cover of a pot.

Potluck: P o t l u c k "n. Whatever may chance to be in the pot  or may be provided for a meal.

Potman: P o t m a n "n. A pot companion.

Potman: P o t m a n "n. A servant in a public house; a potboy.

Potmen: P o t m e n "pl. "of Potman

Potoo: P o t o o "n. A large South American goatsucker (Nyctibius grandis).

Potoroo: P o t o r o o "n. Any small kangaroo belonging to Hypsiprymnus  Bettongia and allied genera native of Australia and Tasmania. Called also kangaroo rat.

Potpie: P o t p i e "n. A meat pie which is boiled instead of being baked.

Potpourri: P o t p o u r r i "n. A medley or mixture.

Potpourri: P o t p o u r r i "n. A literary production composed of parts brought together without order or bond of connection.

Potsdam group: P o t s d a m   g r o u p " A subdivision of the Primordial or Cambrian period in American geology; -- so named from the sandstone of Potsdam  New York. See Chart of Geology.

Pott's disease: P o t t ' s   d i s e a s e " Caries of the vertebrae  frequently resulting in curvature of the spine and paralysis of the lower extremities; -- so named from Percival Pott an English surgeon.

Pounce: P o u n c e "n. A fine powder  as of sandarac or cuttlefish bone -- formerly used to prevent ink from spreading on manuscript.

Pounce: P o u n c e "n. Charcoal dust  or some other colored powder for making patterns through perforated designs -- used by embroiderers lace makers etc.

Pounce: P o u n c e "v. t. To sprinkle or rub with pounce; as  to pounce paper or a pattern.

Pounce: P o u n c e "v. t. The claw or talon of a bird of prey.

Pounce: P o u n c e "v. t. To strike or seize with the talons; to pierce  as with the talons.

Pounce: P o u n c e "v. i. To fall suddenly and seize with the claws; -- with on or upon; as  a hawk pounces upon a chicken. Also used figuratively.

Pound: P o u n d "v. t. To strike repeatedly with some heavy instrument; to beat.

Pound: P o u n d "v. i. To strike heavy blows; to beat.

Pound: P o u n d "v. i. To make a jarring noise  as in running; as the engine pounds.

Pound: P o u n d "n. An inclosure  maintained by public authority in which cattle or other animals are confined when taken in trespassing or when going at large in violation of law; a pinfold.

Pound: P o u n d "n. A level stretch in a canal between locks.

Pound: P o u n d "n. A kind of net  having a large inclosure with a narrow entrance into which fish are directed by wings spreading outward.

Pound: P o u n d "v. t. To confine in  or as in a pound; to impound.

Pound: P o u n d "pl. "of Pound

Pound: P o u n d "n. A certain specified weight; especially  a legal standard consisting of an established number of ounces.

Pound: P o u n d "n. A British denomination of money of account  equivalent to twenty shillings sterling and equal in value to about $4.86. There is no coin known by this name but the gold sovereign is of the same value.

Pound-breach: P o u n d - b r e a c h "n. The breaking of a public pound for releasing impounded animals.

Pound/keeper: P o u n d / k e e p e r "n. The keeper of a pound.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "n. A sum deducted from a pound  or a certain sum paid for each pound; a commission.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "n. A subsidy of twelve pence in the pound  formerly granted to the crown on all goods exported or imported and if by aliens more.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "n. The sum allowed to a sheriff or other officer upon the amount realized by an execution; -- estimated in England  and formerly in the United States at so much of the pound.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "v. t. To collect  as poundage; to assess or rate by poundage.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "n. Confinement of cattle  or other animals in a public pound.

Poundage: P o u n d a g e "n. A charge paid for the release of impounded cattle.

Poundal: P o u n d a l "n. A unit of force based upon the pound  foot and second being the force which acting on a pound avoirdupois for one second causes it to acquire by the of that time a velocity of one foot per second. It is about equal to the weight of half an ounce and is 13 825 dynes.

Poundcake: P o u n d c a k e "n. A kind of rich  sweet cake; -- so called from the ingredients being used by pounds or in equal quantities.

Pounder: P o u n d e r "n. An instrument used for pounding; a pestle.

Pounder: P o u n d e r "n. A person or thing  so called with reference to a certain number of pounds in value weight capacity etc.; as a cannon carrying a twelve-pound ball is called a twelve pounder.

Pounding: P o u n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pound

Pounding: P o u n d i n g "n. A pounded or pulverized substance.

Pounds: P o u n d s "pl. "of Pound

Pour: P o u r "a. Poor.

Pour: P o u r "v. i. To pore.

Pour: P o u r "v. t. To send forth from  as in a stream; to discharge uninterruptedly.

Pour: P o u r "v. i. To flow  pass or issue in a stream or as a stream; to fall continuously and abundantly; as the rain pours; the people poured out of the theater.

Pour: P o u r "n. A stream  or something like a stream; a flood.

Powan: P o w a n "n. Alt. of Powen

Powder: P o w d e r "n. The fine particles to which any dry substance is reduced by pounding  grinding or triturating or into which it falls by decay; dust.

Powder: P o w d e r "n. An explosive mixture used in gunnery  blasting etc.; gunpowder. See Gunpowder.

Powder: P o w d e r "v. t. To reduce to fine particles; to pound  grind or rub into a powder; to comminute; to pulverize; to triturate.

Powder: P o w d e r "v. t. To sprinkle with powder  or as with powder; to be sprinkle; as to powder the hair.

Powder: P o w d e r "v. t. To sprinkle with salt; to corn  as meat.

Powder: P o w d e r "v. i. To be reduced to powder; to become like powder; as  some salts powder easily.

Powder: P o w d e r "v. i. To use powder on the hair or skin; as  she paints and powders.

Powder-posted: P o w d e r - p o s t e d "a. Affected with dry rot; reduced to dust by rot. See Dry rot  under Dry.

Powdered: P o w d e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Powder

Powdered: P o w d e r e d "a. Reduced to a powder; sprinkled with  or as with powder.

Powdered: P o w d e r e d "a. Sprinkled with salt; salted; corned.

Powdered: P o w d e r e d "a. Same as Seme.

Powderflask: P o w d e r f l a s k "n. A flask in which gunpowder is carried  having a charging tube at the end.

Powderhorn: P o w d e r h o r n "n. A horn in which gunpowder is carried.

Powdering: P o w d e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Powder

Powdering: P o w d e r i n g " a. & n. from Powder  v. t.

Powdermill: P o w d e r m i l l "n. A mill in which gunpowder is made.

Powdery: P o w d e r y "a. Easily crumbling to pieces; friable; loose; as  a powdery spar.

Powdery: P o w d e r y "a. Sprinkled or covered with powder; dusty; as  the powdery bloom on plums.

Powdery: P o w d e r y "a. Resembling powder; consisting of powder.

Powdike: P o w d i k e "n. A dike a marsh or fen.

Powdry: P o w d r y "a. See Powdery.

Powen: P o w e n "n. A small British lake whitefish (Coregonus clupeoides  or C. ferus); -- called also gwyniad and lake herring.

Power: P o w e r "n. Same as Poor  the fish.

Power: P o w e r "n. Ability to act  regarded as latent or inherent; the faculty of doing or performing something; capacity for action or performance; capability of producing an effect whether physical or moral: potency; might; as a man of great power; the power of capillary attraction; money gives power.

Power: P o w e r "n. Ability  regarded as put forth or exerted; strength force or energy in action; as the power of steam in moving an engine; the power of truth or of argument in producing conviction; the power of enthusiasm.

Power: P o w e r "n. Capacity of undergoing or suffering; fitness to be acted upon; susceptibility; -- called also passive power; as  great power of endurance.

Power: P o w e r "n. The exercise of a faculty; the employment of strength; the exercise of any kind of control; influence; dominion; sway; command; government.

Power: P o w e r "n. The agent exercising an ability to act; an individual invested with authority; an institution  or government which exercises control; as the great powers of Europe; hence often a superhuman agent; a spirit; a divinity.

Power: P o w e r "n. A military or naval force; an army or navy; a great host.

Power: P o w e r "n. A large quantity; a great number; as  a power o/ good things.

Power: P o w e r "n. The rate at which mechanical energy is exerted or mechanical work performed  as by an engine or other machine or an animal working continuously; as an engine of twenty horse power.

Power: P o w e r "n. A mechanical agent; that from which useful mechanical energy is derived; as  water power; steam power; hand power etc.

Power: P o w e r "n. Applied force; force producing motion or pressure; as  the power applied at one and of a lever to lift a weight at the other end.

Power: P o w e r "n. A machine acted upon by an animal  and serving as a motor to drive other machinery; as a dog power.

Power: P o w e r "n. The product arising from the multiplication of a number into itself; as  a square is the second power and a cube is third power of a number.

Power: P o w e r "n. Mental or moral ability to act; one of the faculties which are possessed by the mind or soul; as  the power of thinking reasoning judging willing fearing hoping etc.

Power: P o w e r "n. The degree to which a lens  mirror or any optical instrument magnifies; in the telescope and usually in the microscope the number of times it multiplies or augments the apparent diameter of an object; sometimes in microscopes the number of times it multiplies the apparent surface.

Power: P o w e r "n. An authority enabling a person to dispose of an interest vested either in himself or in another person; ownership by appointment.

Power: P o w e r "n. Hence  vested authority to act in a given case; as the business was referred to a committee with power.

Powerable: P o w e r a b l e "a. Capable of being effected or accomplished by the application of power; possible.

Powerable: P o w e r a b l e "a. Capable of exerting power; powerful.

Powerful: P o w e r f u l "a. Full of power; capable of producing great effects of any kind; potent; mighty; efficacious; intense; as  a powerful man or beast; a powerful engine; a powerful argument; a powerful light; a powerful vessel.

Powerful: P o w e r f u l "a. Large; capacious; -- said of veins of ore.

Powerless: P o w e r l e s s "a. Destitute of power  force or energy; weak; impotent; not able to produce any effect.

Powldron: P o w l d r o n "n. Same as Pauldron.

Powp: P o w p "v. i. See Poop  v. i.

Powpow: P o w p o w "n. A priest  or conjurer among the North American Indians.

Powpow: P o w p o w "n. Conjuration attended with great noise and confusion  and often with feasting dancing etc. performed by Indians for the cure of diseases to procure success in hunting or in war and for other purposes.

Powpow: P o w p o w "n. Hence: Any assembly characterized by noise and confusion; a noisy frolic or gathering.

Powter: P o w t e r "n. See Pouter.

Powwow: P o w w o w "v. i. To use conjuration  with noise and confusion for the cure of disease etc. as among the North American Indians.

Powwow: P o w w o w "v. i. Hence: To hold a noisy  disorderly meeting.

Pox: P o x "n. Strictly  a disease by pustules or eruptions of any kind but chiefly or wholly restricted to three or four diseases -- the smallpox the chicken pox and the vaccine and the venereal diseases.

Pox: P o x "v. t. To infect with the pox  or syphilis.

Poxed: P o x e d "imp. & p. p. of Pox

Poxing: P o x i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pox

Poy: P o y "n. A support; -- used in composition; as  teapoy.

Poy: P o y "n. A ropedancer's balancing pole.

Poy: P o y "n. A long boat hook by which barges are propelled against the stream.

Poy nette: P o y   n e t t e "n. A bodkin.

Poynado: P o y n a d o "n. A poniard.

Poynd: P o y n d "n. Alt. of Poynder

Poynder: P o y n d e r "n. See Poind  Poinder.

Poyntel: P o y n t e l "n. Paving or flooring made of small squares or lozenges set diagonally.

Poyou: P o y o u "n. A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called also sixbanded armadillo.

Poze: P o z e "v. t. See 5th Pose.

Pozzolana: P o z z o l a n a "n. Volcanic ashes from Pozzuoli  in Italy used in the manufacture of a kind of mortar which hardens under water.

Pozzuolana: P o z z u o l a n a "n. Alt. of Pozzolana

Praam: P r a a m "n. A flat-bottomed boat or lighter  -- used in Holland and the Baltic and sometimes armed in case of war.

Practic: P r a c t i c "a. Practical.

Practic: P r a c t i c "a. Artful; deceitful; skillful.

Practicability: P r a c t i c a b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being practicable; practicableness; feasibility.

Practicable: P r a c t i c a b l e "a. That may be practiced or performed; capable of being done or accomplished with available means or resources; feasible; as  a practicable method; a practicable aim; a practicable good.

Practicable: P r a c t i c a b l e "a. Capable of being used; passable; as  a practicable weapon; a practicable road.

Practical: P r a c t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to practice or action.

Practical: P r a c t i c a l "a. Capable of being turned to use or account; useful  in distinction from ideal or theoretical; as practical chemistry.

Practical: P r a c t i c a l "a. Evincing practice or skill; capable of applying knowledge to some useful end; as  a practical man; a practical mind.

Practical: P r a c t i c a l "a. Derived from practice; as  practical skill.

Practicality: P r a c t i c a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being practical; practicalness.

Practicalize: P r a c t i c a l i z e "v. t. To render practical.

Practically: P r a c t i c a l l y "adv. In a practical way; not theoretically; really; as  to look at things practically; practically worthless.

Practically: P r a c t i c a l l y "adv. By means of practice or use; by experience or experiment; as  practically wise or skillful; practically acquainted with a subject.

Practically: P r a c t i c a l l y "adv. In practice or use; as  a medicine practically safe; theoretically wrong but practically right.

Practically: P r a c t i c a l l y "adv. Almost.

Practicalness: P r a c t i c a l n e s s "n. Same as Practicality.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Frequently repeated or customary action; habitual performance; a succession of acts of a similar kind; usage; habit; custom; as  the practice of rising early; the practice of making regular entries of accounts; the practice of daily exercise.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Customary or constant use; state of being used.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Skill or dexterity acquired by use; expertness.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Actual performance; application of knowledge; -- opposed to theory.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Systematic exercise for instruction or discipline; as  the troops are called out for practice; she neglected practice in music.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Application of science to the wants of men; the exercise of any profession; professional business; as  the practice of medicine or law; a large or lucrative practice.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. Skillful or artful management; dexterity in contrivance or the use of means; art; stratagem; artifice; plot; -- usually in a bad sense.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. A easy and concise method of applying the rules of arithmetic to questions which occur in trade and business.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "n. The form  manner and order of conducting and carrying on suits and prosecutions through their various stages according to the principles of law and the rules laid down by the courts.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To do or perform frequently  customarily or habitually; to make a practice of; as to practice gaming.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To exercise  or follow as a profession trade art etc. as to practice law or medicine.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To exercise one's self in  for instruction or improvement or to acquire discipline or dexterity; as to practice gunnery; to practice music.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To put into practice; to carry out; to act upon; to commit; to execute; to do.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To make use of; to employ.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. t. To teach or accustom by practice; to train.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. i. To perform certain acts frequently or customarily  either for instruction profit or amusement; as to practice with the broadsword or with the rifle; to practice on the piano.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. i. To learn by practice; to form a habit.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. i. To try artifices or stratagems.

Practice: P r a c t i c e "v. i. To apply theoretical science or knowledge  esp. by way of experiment; to exercise or pursue an employment or profession esp. that of medicine or of law.

Practiced: P r a c t i c e d "imp. & p. p. of Practice

Practiced: P r a c t i c e d "a. Experienced; expert; skilled; as  a practiced marksman.

Practiced: P r a c t i c e d "a. Used habitually; learned by practice.

Practicer: P r a c t i c e r "n. One who practices  or puts in practice; one who customarily performs certain acts.

Practicer: P r a c t i c e r "n. One who exercises a profession; a practitioner.

Practicer: P r a c t i c e r "n. One who uses art or stratagem.

Practician: P r a c t i c i a n "n. One who is acquainted with  or skilled in anything by practice; a practitioner.

Practicing: P r a c t i c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Practice

Practick: P r a c t i c k "n. Practice.

Practisant: P r a c t i s a n t "n. An agent or confederate in treachery.

Practise: P r a c t i s e "v. t. & i. See Practice.

Practisour: P r a c t i s o u r "n. A practitioner.

Practitioner: P r a c t i t i o n e r "n. One who is engaged in the actual use or exercise of any art or profession  particularly that of law or medicine.

Practitioner: P r a c t i t i o n e r "n. One who does anything customarily or habitually.

Practitioner: P r a c t i t i o n e r "n. A sly or artful person.

Practive: P r a c t i v e "a. Doing; active.

Prad: P r a d "n. A horse.

Prae-: P r a e - " A prefix. See Pre-.

Praecava: P r a e c a v a "n. The superior vena cava.

Praecipe: P r a e c i p e "n. A writ commanding something to be done  or requiring a reason for neglecting it.

Praecipe: P r a e c i p e "n. A paper containing the particulars of a writ  lodged in the office out of which the writ is to be issued.

Praecoces: P r a e c o c e s "n. pl. A division of birds including those whose young are able to run about when first hatched.

Praecocial: P r a e c o c i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the Praecoces.

Praecognita: P r a e c o g n i t a "n. pl. This previously known  or which should be known in order to understand something else.

Praecommissure: P r a e c o m m i s s u r e "n. A transverse commissure in the anterior part of the third ventricle of the brain; the anterior cerebral commissure.

Praecoracoid: P r a e c o r a c o i d "n. See Precoracoid.

Praecordia: P r a e c o r d i a "n. The front part of the thoracic region; the epigastrium.

Praecordial: P r a e c o r d i a l "a. Same as Precordial.

Praecornu: P r a e c o r n u "n. The anterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain.

Praecornua: P r a e c o r n u a "pl. "of Praecornu

Praedial: P r a e d i a l "a. See Predial.

Praefloration: P r a e f l o r a t i o n "n. Same as Prefloration.

Praefoliation: P r a e f o l i a t i o n "n. Same as Prefoliation.

Praemaxilla: P r a e m a x i l l a "n. See Premaxilla.

Praemnire: P r a e m n i r e "v. t. The subject to the penalties of praemunire.

Praemolar: P r a e m o l a r "a. See Premolar.

Praemorse: P r a e m o r s e "a. Same as Premorse.

Praemunire: P r a e m u n i r e "n. The offense of introducing foreign authority into England  the penalties for which were originally intended to depress the civil power of the pope in the kingdom.

Praemunire: P r a e m u n i r e "n. The writ grounded on that offense.

Praemunire: P r a e m u n i r e "n. The penalty ascribed for the offense of praemunire.

Praemunitory: P r a e m u n i t o r y "a. See Premunitory.

Praenares: P r a e n a r e s "n. pl. The anterior nares. See Nares.

Praenasal: P r a e n a s a l "a. Same as Prenasal.

Praenomen: P r a e n o m e n "n. The first name of a person  by which individuals of the same family were distinguished answering to our Christian name as Caius Lucius Marcus etc.

Praenomina: P r a e n o m i n a "pl. "of Praenomen

Praenominical: P r a e n o m i n i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a praenomen.

Praeoperculum: P r a e o p e r c u l u m "n. Same as Preoperculum.

Praesternum: P r a e s t e r n u m "n. Same as Preoral  Prepubis Prescapula etc.

Praeter-: P r a e t e r - " A prefix. See Preter-.

Praeterist: P r a e t e r i s t "n. See Preterist.

Praetermit: P r a e t e r m i t "v. t. See Pretermit.

Praetexta: P r a e t e x t a "n. A white robe with a purple border  worn by a Roman boy before he was entitled to wear the toga virilis or until about the completion of his fourteenth year and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by magistrates and priests.

Praetextae: P r a e t e x t a e "pl. "of Praetexta

Praetextas: P r a e t e x t a s "pl. "of Praetexta

Praetor: P r a e t o r "n. See Pretor.

Praetores: P r a e t o r e s "n. pl. A division of butterflies including the satyrs.

Praetorian: P r a e t o r i a n "a. See Pretorian.

Praetorium: P r a e t o r i u m "n. See Pretorium.

Praezygapophysis: P r a e z y g a p o p h y s i s "n. Same as Prezygapophysis.

Pragmatic: P r a g m a t i c "a. Alt. of Pragmatical

Pragmatic: P r a g m a t i c "n. One skilled in affairs.

Pragmatic: P r a g m a t i c "n. A solemn public ordinance or decree.

Pragmatical: P r a g m a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to business or to affairs; of the nature of business; practical; material; businesslike in habit or manner.

Pragmatical: P r a g m a t i c a l "a. Busy; specifically  busy in an objectionable way; officious; fussy and positive; meddlesome.

Pragmatical: P r a g m a t i c a l "a. Philosophical; dealing with causes  reasons and effects rather than with details and circumstances; -- said of literature.

Pragmatically: P r a g m a t i c a l l y "adv. In a pragmatical manner.

Pragmaticalness: P r a g m a t i c a l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being pragmatical.

Pragmatism: P r a g m a t i s m "n. The quality or state of being pragmatic; in literature  the pragmatic or philosophical method.

Pragmatist: P r a g m a t i s t "n. One who is pragmatic.

Pragmatize: P r a g m a t i z e "v. t. To consider  represent or embody (something unreal) as fact; to materialize.

Prairial: P r a i r i a l "n. The ninth month of the French Republican calendar  which dated from September 22 1792. It began May 20 and ended June 18. See Vendemiaire.

Prairie: P r a i r i e "n. An extensive tract of level or rolling land  destitute of trees covered with coarse grass and usually characterized by a deep fertile soil. They abound throughout the Mississippi valley between the Alleghanies and the Rocky mountains.

Prairie: P r a i r i e "n. A meadow or tract of grass; especially  a so called natural meadow.

Praisable: P r a i s a b l e "a. Fit to be praised; praise-worthy; laudable; commendable.

Praisably: P r a i s a b l y "adv. In a praisable manner.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. To commend; to applaud; to express approbation of; to laud; -- applied to a person or his acts.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. To extol in words or song; to magnify; to glorify on account of perfections or excellent works; to do honor to; to display the excellence of; -- applied especially to the Divine Being.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. To value; to appraise.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. Commendation for worth; approval expressed; honor rendered because of excellence or worth; laudation; approbation.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. Especially  the joyful tribute of gratitude or homage rendered to the Divine Being; the act of glorifying or extolling the Creator; worship particularly worship by song distinction from prayer and other acts of worship; as a service of praise.

Praise: P r a i s e "v. The object  ground or reason of praise.

Praise-meeting: P r a i s e - m e e t i n g "n. A religious service mainly in song.

Praised: P r a i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Praise

Praiseer: P r a i s e e r "n. One who praises.

Praiseer: P r a i s e e r "n. An appraiser; a valuator.

Praiseful: P r a i s e f u l "a. Praiseworthy.

Praiseful: P r a i s e f u l "a. Praiseworthy.

Praiseless: P r a i s e l e s s "a. Without praise or approbation.

Praisement: P r a i s e m e n t "n. Appraisement.

Praiseworthily: P r a i s e w o r t h i l y "adv. In a praiseworthy manner.

Praiseworthiness: P r a i s e w o r t h i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being praiseworthy.

Praiseworthy: P r a i s e w o r t h y "a. Worthy of praise or applause; commendable; as  praiseworthy action; he was praiseworthy.

Praising: P r a i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Praise

Prakrit: P r a k r i t "n. Any one of the popular dialects descended from  or akin to Sanskrit; -- in distinction from the Sanskrit which was used as a literary and learned language when no longer spoken by the people. Pali is one of the Prakrit dialects.

Prakritic: P r a k r i t i c "a. Pertaining to Prakrit.

Pram: P r a m "n. Alt. of Prame

Prame: P r a m e "n. See Praam.

Prance: P r a n c e "v. i. To spring or bound  as a horse in high mettle.

Prance: P r a n c e "v. i. To ride on a prancing horse; to ride in an ostentatious manner.

Prance: P r a n c e "v. i. To walk or strut about in a pompous  showy manner or with warlike parade.

Pranced: P r a n c e d "imp. & p. p. of Prance

Prancer: P r a n c e r "n. A horse which prances.

Prancing: P r a n c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prance

Prandial: P r a n d i a l "a. Of or pertaining to a repast  especially to dinner.

Prangos: P r a n g o s "n. A genus of umbelliferous plants  one species of which (P. pabularia) found in Thibet Cashmere Afghanistan etc. has been used as fodder for cattle. It has decompound leaves with very long narrow divisions and a highly fragrant smell resembling that of new clover hay.

Prank: P r a n k "v. t. To adorn in a showy manner; to dress or equip ostentatiously; -- often followed by up; as  to prank up the body. See Prink.

Prank: P r a n k "v. i. To make ostentatious show.

Prank: P r a n k "n. A gay or sportive action; a ludicrous  merry or mischievous trick; a caper; a frolic.

Prank: P r a n k "a. Full of gambols or tricks.

Pranked: P r a n k e d "imp. & p. p. of Prank

Pranker: P r a n k e r "n. One who dresses showily; a prinker.

Pranking: P r a n k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prank

Prankish: P r a n k i s h "a. Full of pranks; frolicsome.

Prase: P r a s e "n. A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.

Praseo-: P r a s e o - " A combining form signifying green; as  praseocobalt a green variety of cobalt.

Praseodymium: P r a s e o d y m i u m "n. An elementary substance  one of the constituents of didymium; -- so called from the green color of its salts. Symbol Ps. Atomic weight 143.6.

Praseolite: P r a s e o l i t e "n. A variety of altered iolite of a green color and greasy luster.

Prasinous: P r a s i n o u s "a. Grass-green; clear  lively green without any mixture.

Prasoid: P r a s o i d "a. Resembling prase.

Prate: P r a t e "v. i. To talk much and to little purpose; to be loquacious; to speak foolishly; to babble.

Prate: P r a t e "v. t. To utter foolishly; to speak without reason or purpose; to chatter  or babble.

Prate: P r a t e "n. Talk to little purpose; trifling talk; unmeaning loquacity.

Prated: P r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Prate

Prateful: P r a t e f u l "a. Talkative.

Prater: P r a t e r "n. One who prates.

Pratic: P r a t i c "n. See Pratique.

Pratincole: P r a t i n c o l e "n. Any bird of the Old World genus Glareola  or family Glareolidae allied to the plovers. They have long pointed wings and a forked tail.

Prating: P r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prate

Pratingly: P r a t i n g l y "adv. With idle talk; with loquacity.

Pratique: P r a t i q u e "n. Primarily  liberty of converse; intercourse; hence a certificate given after compliance with quarantine regulations permitting a ship to land passengers and crew; -- a term used particularly in the south of Europe.

Pratique: P r a t i q u e "n. Practice; habits.

Prattle: P r a t t l e "v. i. To talk much and idly; to prate; hence  to talk lightly and artlessly like a child; to utter child's talk.

Prattle: P r a t t l e "v. t. To utter as prattle; to babble; as  to prattle treason.

Prattle: P r a t t l e "n. Trifling or childish tattle; empty talk; loquacity on trivial subjects; prate; babble.

Prattled: P r a t t l e d "imp. & p. p. of Prattle

Prattlement: P r a t t l e m e n t "n. Prattle.

Prattler: P r a t t l e r "n. One who prattles.

Prattling: P r a t t l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prattle

Pravity: P r a v i t y "n. Deterioration; degeneracy; corruption; especially  moral crookedness; moral perversion; perverseness; depravity; as the pravity of human nature.

Prawn: P r a w n "n. Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and long antennae. They mostly belong to the genera Pandalus  Palaemon Palaemonetes and Peneus and are much used as food. The common English prawn is Palaemon serratus.

Praxinoscope: P r a x i n o s c o p e "n. An instrument  similar to the phenakistoscope for presenting to view or projecting upon a screen images the natural motions of real objects.

Praxis: P r a x i s "n. Use; practice; especially  exercise or discipline for a specific purpose or object.

Praxis: P r a x i s "n. An example or form of exercise  or a collection of such examples for practice.

Pray: P r a y "n. & v. See Pry.

Pray: P r a y "v. i. To make request with earnestness or zeal  as for something desired; to make entreaty or supplication; to offer prayer to a deity or divine being as a religious act; specifically to address the Supreme Being with adoration confession supplication and thanksgiving.

Pray: P r a y "v. t. To address earnest request to; to supplicate; to entreat; to implore; to beseech.

Pray: P r a y "v. t. To ask earnestly for; to seek to obtain by supplication; to entreat for.

Pray: P r a y "v. t. To effect or accomplish by praying; as  to pray a soul out of purgatory.

Prayed: P r a y e d "imp. & p. p. of Pray

Prayer: P r a y e r "n. One who prays; a supplicant.

Prayer: P r a y e r "v. i. The act of praying  or of asking a favor; earnest request or entreaty; hence a petition or memorial addressed to a court or a legislative body.

Prayer: P r a y e r "v. i. The act of addressing supplication to a divinity  especially to the true God; the offering of adoration confession supplication and thanksgiving to the Supreme Being; as public prayer; secret prayer.

Prayer: P r a y e r "v. i. The form of words used in praying; a formula of supplication; an expressed petition; especially  a supplication addressed to God; as a written or extemporaneous prayer; to repeat one's prayers.

Prayerful: P r a y e r f u l "a. Given to prayer; praying much or often; devotional.

Prayerless: P r a y e r l e s s "a. Not using prayer; habitually neglecting prayer to God; without prayer.

Praying: P r a y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Pray

Praying: P r a y i n g " a. & n. from Pray  v.

Prayingly: P r a y i n g l y "adv. With supplication to God.

Pre-: P r e - " A prefix denoting priority (of time  place or rank); as precede to go before; precursor a forerunner; prefix to fix or place before; preeminent eminent before or above others. Pre- is sometimes used intensively as in prepotent very potent.

Preaccusation: P r e a c c u s a t i o n "n. Previous accusation.

Preace: P r e a c e "v. & n. Press.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. i. To proclaim or publish tidings; specifically  to proclaim the gospel; to discourse publicly on a religious subject or from a text of Scripture; to deliver a sermon.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. i. To give serious advice on morals or religion; to discourse in the manner of a preacher.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. t. To proclaim by public discourse; to utter in a sermon or a formal religious harangue.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. t. To inculcate in public discourse; to urge with earnestness by public teaching.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. t. To deliver or pronounce; as  to preach a sermon.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. t. To teach or instruct by preaching; to inform by preaching.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. t. To advise or recommend earnestly.

Preach: P r e a c h "v. A religious discourse.

Preached: P r e a c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Preach

Preacher: P r e a c h e r "n. One who preaches; one who discourses publicly on religious subjects.

Preacher: P r e a c h e r "n. One who inculcates anything with earnestness.

Preachership: P r e a c h e r s h i p "n. The office of a preacher.

Preachify: P r e a c h i f y "v. i. To discourse in the manner of a preacher.

Preaching: P r e a c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Preach

Preaching: P r e a c h i n g "n. The act of delivering a religious discourse; the art of sermonizing; also  a sermon; a public religious discourse; serious earnest advice.

Preachman: P r e a c h m a n "n. A preacher; -- so called in contempt.

Preachmen: P r e a c h m e n "pl. "of Preachman

Preachment: P r e a c h m e n t "n. A religious harangue; a sermon; -- used derogatively.

Preacquaint: P r e a c q u a i n t "v. t. To acquaint previously or beforehand.

Preacquaintance: P r e a c q u a i n t a n c e "n. Previous acquaintance or knowledge.

Preact: P r e a c t "v. t. To act beforehand; to perform previously.

Preaction: P r e a c t i o n "n. Previous action.

Preadamic: P r e a d a m i c "a. Prior to Adam.

Preadamite: P r e a d a m i t e "n. An inhabitant of the earth before Adam.

Preadamite: P r e a d a m i t e "n. One who holds that men existed before Adam.

Preadamitic: P r e a d a m i t i c "a. Existing or occurring before Adam; preadamic; as  preadamitic periods.

Preadjustment: P r e a d j u s t m e n t "n. Previous adjustment.

Preadministration: P r e a d m i n i s t r a t i o n "n. Previous administration.

Preadmonish: P r e a d m o n i s h "v. t. To admonish previously.

Preadmonition: P r e a d m o n i t i o n "n. Previous warning or admonition; forewarning.

Preadvertise: P r e a d v e r t i s e "v. t. To advertise beforehand; to preannounce publicly.

Preamble: P r e a m b l e "n. A introductory portion; an introduction or preface  as to a book document etc.; specifically the introductory part of a statute which states the reasons and intent of the law.

Preamble: P r e a m b l e "v. t. & i. To make a preamble to; to preface; to serve as a preamble.

Preambulary: P r e a m b u l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to a preamble; introductory; contained or provided for in a preamble.

Preambulate: P r e a m b u l a t e "v. i. To walk before.

Preambulation: P r e a m b u l a t i o n "n. A walking or going before; precedence.

Preambulation: P r e a m b u l a t i o n "n. A preamble.

Preambulatory: P r e a m b u l a t o r y "a. Preceding; going before; introductory.

Preambulous: P r e a m b u l o u s "n. See Perambulatory.

Preannounce: P r e a n n o u n c e "v. t. To announce beforehand.

Preantenultimate: P r e a n t e n u l t i m a t e "a. Being or indicating the fourth syllable from the end of a word  or that before the antepenult.

Preaortic: P r e a o r t i c "a. In front  or on the ventral side of the aorta.

Preappoint: P r e a p p o i n t "v. t. To appoint previously  or beforehand.

Preappointment: P r e a p p o i n t m e n t "n. Previous appointment.

Preapprehension: P r e a p p r e h e n s i o n "n. An apprehension or opinion formed before examination or knowledge.

Prearm: P r e a r m "v. t. To forearm.

Prearrange: P r e a r r a n g e "v. t. To arrange beforehand.

Prease: P r e a s e "v. t. & i. To press; to crowd.

Prease: P r e a s e "n. A press; a crowd.

Preassurance: P r e a s s u r a n c e "n. Previous assurance.

Preataxic: P r e a t a x i c "a. Occurring before the symptom ataxia has developed; -- applied to the early symptoms of locomotor ataxia.

Preative: P r e a t i v e "a. Alt. of Preatory

Preatory: P r e a t o r y "a. Suppliant; beseeching.

Preaudience: P r e a u d i e n c e "n. Precedence of rank at the bar among lawyers.

Preaxial: P r e a x i a l "a. Situated in front of any transverse axis in the body of an animal; anterior; cephalic; esp.  in front or on the anterior or cephalic (that is radial or tibial) side of the axis of a limb.

Prebend: P r e b e n d "n. A payment or stipend; esp.  the stipend or maintenance granted to a prebendary out of the estate of a cathedral or collegiate church with which he is connected. See Note under Benefice.

Prebend: P r e b e n d "n. A prebendary.

Prebendal: P r e b e n d a l "a. Of or pertaining to a prebend; holding a prebend; as  a prebendal priest or stall.

Prebendary: P r e b e n d a r y "n. A clergyman attached to a collegiate or cathedral church who enjoys a prebend in consideration of his officiating at stated times in the church. See Note under Benefice  n. 3.

Prebendary: P r e b e n d a r y "n. A prebendaryship.

Prebendaryship: P r e b e n d a r y s h i p "n. The office of a prebendary.

Prebendate: P r e b e n d a t e "v. t. To invest with the office of prebendary; to present to a prebend.

Prebendship: P r e b e n d s h i p "n. A prebendaryship.

Prebronchial: P r e b r o n c h i a l "a. Situated in front of the bronchus; -- applied especially to an air sac on either side of the esophagus of birds.

Precalculate: P r e c a l c u l a t e "v. t. To calculate or determine beforehand; to prearrange.

Precant: P r e c a n t "n. One who prays.

Precarious: P r e c a r i o u s "a. Depending on the will or pleasure of another; held by courtesy; liable to be changed or lost at the pleasure of another; as  precarious privileges.

Precarious: P r e c a r i o u s "a. Held by a doubtful tenure; depending on unknown causes or events; exposed to constant risk; not to be depended on for certainty or stability; uncertain; as  a precarious state of health; precarious fortunes.

Precation: P r e c a t i o n "n. The act of praying; supplication; entreaty.

Precaution: P r e c a u t i o n "n. Previous caution or care; caution previously employed to prevent mischief or secure good; as  his life was saved by precaution.

Precaution: P r e c a u t i o n "n. A measure taken beforehand to ward off evil or secure good or success; a precautionary act; as  to take precautions against accident.

Precaution: P r e c a u t i o n "v. t. To warn or caution beforehand.

Precaution: P r e c a u t i o n "v. t. To take precaution against.

Precautional: P r e c a u t i o n a l "a. Precautionary.

Precautionary: P r e c a u t i o n a r y "a. Of or pertaining to precaution  or precautions; as precautionary signals.

Precautious: P r e c a u t i o u s "a. Taking or using precaution; precautionary.

Precedaneous: P r e c e d a n e o u s "a. Preceding; antecedent; previous.

Precede: P r e c e d e "v. t. To go before in order of time; to occur first with relation to anything.

Precede: P r e c e d e "v. t. To go before in place  rank or importance.

Precede: P r e c e d e "v. t. To cause to be preceded; to preface; to introduce; -- used with by or with before the instrumental object.

Preceded: P r e c e d e d "imp. & p. p. of Precede

Precedence: P r e c e d e n c e "n. Alt. of Precedency

Precedency: P r e c e d e n c y "n. The act or state of preceding or going before in order of time; priority; as  one event has precedence of another.

Precedency: P r e c e d e n c y "n. The act or state of going or being before in rank or dignity  or the place of honor; right to a more honorable place; superior rank; as barons have precedence of commoners.

Precedent: P r e c e d e n t "a. Going before; anterior; preceding; antecedent; as  precedent services.

Precedent: P r e c e d e n t "n. Something done or said that may serve as an example to authorize a subsequent act of the same kind; an authoritative example.

Precedent: P r e c e d e n t "n. A preceding circumstance or condition; an antecedent; hence  a prognostic; a token; a sign.

Precedent: P r e c e d e n t "n. A rough draught of a writing which precedes a finished copy.

Precedent: P r e c e d e n t "n. A judicial decision which serves as a rule for future determinations in similar or analogous cases; an authority to be followed in courts of justice; forms of proceeding to be followed in similar cases.

Precedented: P r e c e d e n t e d "a. Having a precedent; authorized or sanctioned by an example of a like kind.

Precedential: P r e c e d e n t i a l "a. Of the nature of a precedent; having force as an example for imitation; as  precedential transactions.

Precedently: P r e c e d e n t l y "adv. Beforehand; antecedently.

Preceding: P r e c e d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Precede

Preceding: P r e c e d i n g "a. Going before; -- opposed to following.

Preceding: P r e c e d i n g "a. In the direction toward which stars appear to move. See Following  2.

Precel: P r e c e l "v. t. & i. To surpass; to excel; to exceed.

Precellence: P r e c e l l e n c e "n. Alt. of Precellency

Precellency: P r e c e l l e n c y "n. Excellence; superiority.

Precellent: P r e c e l l e n t "a. Excellent; surpassing.

Precent: P r e c e n t "n. Any commandment  instruction or order intended as an authoritative rule of action; esp. a command respecting moral conduct; an injunction; a rule.

Precent: P r e c e n t "n. A command in writing; a species of writ or process.

Precentor: P r e c e n t o r "n. A leader of a choir; a directing singer.

Precentor: P r e c e n t o r "n. The leader of the choir in a cathedral; -- called also the chanter or master of the choir.

Precentor: P r e c e n t o r "n. The leader of the congregational singing in Scottish and other churches.

Precentorship: P r e c e n t o r s h i p "n. The office of a precentor.

Precept: P r e c e p t "v. t. To teach by precepts.

Preceptial: P r e c e p t i a l "a. Preceptive.

Preception: P r e c e p t i o n "n. A precept.

Preceptive: P r e c e p t i v e "a. Containing or giving precepts; of the nature of precepts; didactic; as  the preceptive parts of the Scriptures.

Preceptor: P r e c e p t o r "n. One who gives commands  or makes rules; specifically the master or principal of a school; a teacher; an instructor.

Preceptor: P r e c e p t o r "n. The head of a preceptory among the Knights Templars.

Preceptorial: P r e c e p t o r i a l "a. Of or pertaining to a preceptor.

Preceptories: P r e c e p t o r i e s "pl. "of Preceptory

Preceptory: P r e c e p t o r y "a. Preceptive.

Preceptory: P r e c e p t o r y "n. A religious house of the Knights Templars  subordinate to the temple or principal house of the order in London. See Commandery n. 2.

Preceptress: P r e c e p t r e s s "n. A woman who is the principal of a school; a female teacher.

Precession: P r e c e s s i o n "n. The act of going before  or forward.

Precessional: P r e c e s s i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to pression; as  the precessional movement of the equinoxes.

Precessor: P r e c e s s o r "n. A predecessor.

Precinct: P r e c i n c t "n. The limit or exterior line encompassing a place; a boundary; a confine; limit of jurisdiction or authority; -- often in the plural; as  the precincts of a state.

Precinct: P r e c i n c t "n. A district within certain boundaries; a minor territorial or jurisdictional division; as  an election precinct; a school precinct.

Precinct: P r e c i n c t "n. A parish or prescribed territory attached to a church  and taxed for its support.

Preciosity: P r e c i o s i t y "n. Preciousness; something precious.

Precious: P r e c i o u s "a. Of great price; costly; as  a precious stone.

Precious: P r e c i o u s "a. Of great value or worth; very valuable; highly esteemed; dear; beloved; as  precious recollections.

Precious: P r e c i o u s "a. Particular; fastidious; overnice.

Preciously: P r e c i o u s l y "adv. In a precious manner; expensively; extremely; dearly. Also used ironically.

Preciousness: P r e c i o u s n e s s "n. The quality or state of being precious; costliness; dearness.

Precipe: P r e c i p e "n. See Praecipe  and Precept.

Precipice: P r e c i p i c e "n. A sudden or headlong fall.

Precipice: P r e c i p i c e "n. A headlong steep; a very steep  perpendicular or overhanging place; an abrupt declivity; a cliff.

Precipient: P r e c i p i e n t "a. Commanding; directing.

Precipitability: P r e c i p i t a b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being precipitable.

Precipitable: P r e c i p i t a b l e "a. Capable of being precipitated  or cast to the bottom as a substance in solution. See Precipitate n. (Chem.)

Precipitance: P r e c i p i t a n c e "n. Alt. of Precipitancy

Precipitancy: P r e c i p i t a n c y "n. The quality or state of being precipitant  or precipitate; headlong hurry; excessive or rash haste in resolving forming an opinion or executing a purpose; precipitation; as the precipitancy of youth.

Precipitant: P r e c i p i t a n t "a. Falling or rushing headlong; rushing swiftly  violently or recklessly; moving precipitately.

Precipitant: P r e c i p i t a n t "a. Unexpectedly or foolishly brought on or hastened; rashly hurried; hasty; sudden; reckless.

Precipitant: P r e c i p i t a n t "n. Any force or reagent which causes the formation of a precipitate.

Precipitantly: P r e c i p i t a n t l y "adv. With rash or foolish haste; in headlong manner.

Precipitantness: P r e c i p i t a n t n e s s "n. The quality or state of being precipitant; precipitation.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "a. Overhasty; rash; as  the king was too precipitate in declaring war.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "a. Lacking due deliberation or care; hurried; said or done before the time; as  a precipitate measure.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "a. Falling  flowing or rushing with steep descent; headlong.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "a. Ending quickly in death; brief and fatal; as  a precipitate case of disease.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "n. An insoluble substance separated from a solution in a concrete state by the action of some reagent added to the solution  or of some force such as heat or cold. The precipitate may fall to the bottom (whence the name) may be diffused through the solution or may float at or near the surface.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. t. To throw headlong; to cast down from a precipice or height.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. t. To urge or press on with eager haste or violence; to cause to happen  or come to a crisis suddenly or too soon; as precipitate a journey or a conflict.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. t. To separate from a solution  or other medium in the form of a precipitate; as water precipitates camphor when in solution with alcohol.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. i. To dash or fall headlong.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. i. To hasten without preparation.

Precipitate: P r e c i p i t a t e "v. i. To separate from a solution as a precipitate. See Precipitate  n.

Precipitated: P r e c i p i t a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Precipitate

Precipitately: P r e c i p i t a t e l y "adv. In a precipitate manner; headlong; hastily; rashly.

Precipitating: P r e c i p i t a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Precipitate

Precipitation: P r e c i p i t a t i o n "n. The act of precipitating  or the state of being precipitated or thrown headlong.

Precipitation: P r e c i p i t a t i o n "n. A falling  flowing or rushing downward with violence and rapidity.

Precipitation: P r e c i p i t a t i o n "n. Great hurry; rash  tumultuous haste; impetuosity.

Precipitation: P r e c i p i t a t i o n "n. The act or process of precipitating from a solution.

Precipitator: P r e c i p i t a t o r "n. One who precipitates  or urges on with vehemence or rashness.

Precipitious: P r e c i p i t i o u s "a. Precipitous.

Precipitous: P r e c i p i t o u s "a. Steep  like a precipice; as a precipitous cliff or mountain.

Precipitous: P r e c i p i t o u s "a. Headlong; as  precipitous fall.

Precipitous: P r e c i p i t o u s "a. Hasty; rash; quick; sudden; precipitate; as  precipitous attempts.

Precis: P r e c i s "n. A concise or abridged statement or view; an abstract; a summary.

Precise: P r e c i s e "a. Having determinate limitations; exactly or sharply defined or stated; definite; exact; nice; not vague or equivocal; as  precise rules of morality.

Precise: P r e c i s e "a. Strictly adhering or conforming to rule; very nice or exact; punctilious in conduct or ceremony; formal; ceremonious.

Precisian: P r e c i s i a n "n. One who limits  or restrains.

Precisian: P r e c i s i a n "n. An overprecise person; one rigidly or ceremoniously exact in the observance of rules; a formalist; -- formerly applied to the English Puritans.

Precisianism: P r e c i s i a n i s m "n. The quality or state of being a precisian; the practice of a precisian.

Precisianist: P r e c i s i a n i s t "n. A precisian.

Precision: P r e c i s i o n "n. The quality or state of being precise; exact limitation; exactness; accuracy; strict conformity to a rule or a standard; definiteness.

Precisive: P r e c i s i v e "a. Cutting off; (Logic) exactly limiting by cutting off all that is not absolutely relative to the purpose; as  precisive censure; precisive abstraction.

Preclude: P r e c l u d e "v. To put a barrier before; hence  to shut out; to hinder; to stop; to impede.

Preclude: P r e c l u d e "v. To shut out by anticipative action; to prevent or hinder by necessary consequence or implication; to deter action of  access to employment of etc.; to render ineffectual; to obviate by anticipation.

Precluded: P r e c l u d e d "imp. & p. p. of Preclude

Precluding: P r e c l u d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Preclude

Preclusion: P r e c l u s i o n "n. The act of precluding  or the state of being precluded; a shutting out.

Preclusive: P r e c l u s i v e "a. Shutting out; precluding  or tending to preclude; hindering.

Precoce: P r e c o c e "a. Precocious.

Precoces: P r e c o c e s "n. pl. Same as Praecoces.

Precocious: P r e c o c i o u s "a. Ripe or mature before the proper or natural time; early or prematurely ripe or developed; as  precocious trees.

Precocious: P r e c o c i o u s "a. Developed more than is natural or usual at a given age; exceeding what is to be expected of one's years; too forward; -- used especially of mental forwardness; as  a precocious child; precocious talents.

Precociously: P r e c o c i o u s l y "adv. In a precocious manner.

Precociousness: P r e c o c i o u s n e s s "n. Alt. of Precocity

Precocity: P r e c o c i t y "n. The quality or state of being precocious; untimely ripeness; premature development  especially of the mental powers; forwardness.

Preconize: P r e c o n i z e "v. t. To approve by preconization.

Preconscious: P r e c o n s c i o u s "a. Of or pertaining to a state before consciousness.

Precontract: P r e c o n t r a c t "n. A contract preceding another

Precontract: P r e c o n t r a c t "n. a contract of marriage which  according to the ancient law rendered void a subsequent marriage solemnized in violation of it.
