Prognostication: P r o g n o s t i c a t i o n "n. The act of foreshowing or foretelling something future by present signs; prediction.

Prognostication: P r o g n o s t i c a t i o n "n. That which foreshows; a foretoken.

Prognosticator: P r o g n o s t i c a t o r "n. One who prognosticates; a foreknower or foreteller of a future course or event by present signs.

Program: P r o g r a m "n. Same as Programme.

Programma: P r o g r a m m a "n. Any law  which after it had passed the Athenian senate was fixed on a tablet for public inspection previously to its being proposed to the general assembly of the people.

Programma: P r o g r a m m a "n. An edict published for public information; an official bulletin; a public proclamation.

Programma: P r o g r a m m a "n. See Programme.

Programma: P r o g r a m m a "n. A preface.

Programmata: P r o g r a m m a t a "pl. "of Programma

Programme: P r o g r a m m e "n. That which is written or printed as a public notice or advertisement; a scheme; a prospectus; especially  a brief outline or explanation of the order to be pursued or the subjects embraced in any public exercise performance or entertainment; a preliminary sketch.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. A moving or going forward; a proceeding onward; an advance

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. In actual space  as the progress of a ship carriage etc.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. In the growth of an animal or plant; increase.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. In business of any kind; as  the progress of a negotiation; the progress of art.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. In knowledge; in proficiency; as  the progress of a child at school.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. Toward ideal completeness or perfection in respect of quality or condition; -- applied to individuals  communities or the race; as social moral religious or political progress.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "n. A journey of state; a circuit; especially  one made by a sovereign through parts of his own dominions.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "v. i. To make progress; to move forward in space; to continue onward in course; to proceed; to advance; to go on; as  railroads are progressing.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "v. i. To make improvement; to advance.

Progress: P r o g r e s s "v. t. To make progress in; to pass through.

Progressed: P r o g r e s s e d "imp. & p. p. of Progress

Progressing: P r o g r e s s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Progress

Progression: P r o g r e s s i o n "n. The act of moving forward; a proceeding in a course; motion onward.

Progression: P r o g r e s s i o n "n. Course; passage; lapse or process of time.

Progression: P r o g r e s s i o n "n. Regular or proportional advance in increase or decrease of numbers; continued proportion  arithmetical geometrical or harmonic.

Progression: P r o g r e s s i o n "n. A regular succession of tones or chords; the movement of the parts in harmony; the order of the modulations in a piece from key to key.

Progressional: P r o g r e s s i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to progression; tending to  or capable of progress.

Progressionist: P r o g r e s s i o n i s t "n. One who holds to a belief in the progression of society toward perfection.

Progressionist: P r o g r e s s i o n i s t "n. One who maintains the doctrine of progression in organic forms; -- opposed to uniformitarian.

Progressist: P r o g r e s s i s t "n. One who makes  or holds to progress; a progressionist.

Progressive: P r o g r e s s i v e "a. Moving forward; proceeding onward; advancing; evincing progress; increasing; as  progressive motion or course; -- opposed to retrograde.

Progressive: P r o g r e s s i v e "a. Improving; as  art is in a progressive state.

Progue: P r o g u e "v. i. To prog.

Progue: P r o g u e "n. A sharp point; a goad.

Progue: P r o g u e "v. t. "To prick; to goad.

Proheme: P r o h e m e "n. Proem.

Prohibit: P r o h i b i t "v. t. To forbid by authority; to interdict; as  God prohibited Adam from eating of the fruit of a certain tree; we prohibit a person from doing a thing and also the doing of the thing; as the law prohibits men from stealing or it prohibits stealing.

Prohibit: P r o h i b i t "v. t. To hinder; to debar; to prevent; to preclude.

Prohibited: P r o h i b i t e d "imp. & p. p. of Prohibit

Prohibiter: P r o h i b i t e r "n. One who prohibits or forbids; a forbidder; an interdicter.

Prohibiting: P r o h i b i t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prohibit

Prohibition: P r o h i b i t i o n "n. The act of prohibiting; a declaration or injunction forbidding some action; interdict.

Prohibition: P r o h i b i t i o n "n. Specifically  the forbidding by law of the sale of alcoholic liquors as beverages.

Prohibitionist: P r o h i b i t i o n i s t "n. One who favors prohibitory duties on foreign goods in commerce; a protectionist.

Prohibitionist: P r o h i b i t i o n i s t "n. One who favors the prohibition of the sale (or of the sale and manufacture) of alcoholic liquors as beverages.

Prohibitive: P r o h i b i t i v e "a. That prohibits; prohibitory; as  a tax whose effect is prohibitive.

Prohibitory: P r o h i b i t o r y "a. Tending to prohibit  forbid or exclude; implying prohibition; forbidding; as a prohibitory law; a prohibitory price.

Proin: P r o i n "v. t. To lop; to trim; to prune; to adorn.

Proin: P r o i n "v. i. To employed in pruning.

Proitor: P r o i t o r "n. A traitor.

Project: P r o j e c t "n. The place from which a thing projects  or starts forth.

Project: P r o j e c t "n. That which is projected or designed; something intended or devised; a scheme; a design; a plan.

Project: P r o j e c t "n. An idle scheme; an impracticable design; as  a man given to projects.

Project: P r o j e c t "v. t. To throw or cast forward; to shoot forth.

Project: P r o j e c t "v. t. To cast forward or revolve in the mind; to contrive; to devise; to scheme; as  to project a plan.

Project: P r o j e c t "v. t. To draw or exhibit  as the form of anything; to delineate; as to project a sphere a map an ellipse and the like; -- sometimes with on upon into etc.; as to project a line or point upon a plane. See Projection 4.

Project: P r o j e c t "v. i. To shoot forward; to extend beyond something else; to be prominent; to jut; as  the cornice projects; branches project from the tree.

Project: P r o j e c t "v. i. To form a project; to scheme.

Projected: P r o j e c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Project

Projectile: P r o j e c t i l e "a. Projecting or impelling forward; as  a projectile force.

Projectile: P r o j e c t i l e "a. Caused or imparted by impulse or projection; impelled forward; as  projectile motion.

Projectile: P r o j e c t i l e "n. A body projected  or impelled forward by force; especially a missile adapted to be shot from a firearm.

Projectile: P r o j e c t i l e "n. A part of mechanics which treats of the motion  range time of flight etc. of bodies thrown or driven through the air by an impelling force.

Projecting: P r o j e c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Project

Projection: P r o j e c t i o n "n. The act of throwing or shooting forward.

Projection: P r o j e c t i o n "n. A jutting out; also  a part jutting out as of a building; an extension beyond something else.

Projection: P r o j e c t i o n "n. The act of scheming or planning; also  that which is planned; contrivance; design; plan.

Projection: P r o j e c t i o n "n. The representation of something; delineation; plan; especially  the representation of any object on a perspective plane or such a delineation as would result were the chief points of the object thrown forward upon the plane each in the direction of a line drawn through it from a given point of sight or central point; as the projection of a sphere. The several kinds of projection differ according to the assumed point of sight and plane of projection in each.

Projection: P r o j e c t i o n "n. Any method of representing the surface of the earth upon a plane.

Projectment: P r o j e c t m e n t "n. Design; contrivance; projection.

Projector: P r o j e c t o r "n. One who projects a scheme or design; hence  one who forms fanciful or chimerical schemes.

Projecture: P r o j e c t u r e "n. A jutting out beyond a surface.

Projet: P r o j e t "n. A plan proposed; a draft of a proposed measure; a project.

Proke: P r o k e "v. i. To poke; to thrust.

Prolapse: P r o l a p s e "n. The falling down of a part through the orifice with which it is naturally connected  especially of the uterus or the rectum.

Prolapse: P r o l a p s e "v. i. To fall down or out; to protrude.

Prolapsion: P r o l a p s i o n "n. Prolapse.

Prolapsus: P r o l a p s u s "n. Prolapse.

Prolata: P r o l a t a "pl. "of Prolatum

Prolate: P r o l a t e "a. Stretched out; extended; especially  elongated in the direction of a line joining the poles; as a prolate spheroid; -- opposed to oblate.

Prolate: P r o l a t e "v. t. To utter; to pronounce.

Prolation: P r o l a t i o n "n. The act of prolating or pronouncing; utterance; pronunciation.

Prolation: P r o l a t i o n "n. The act of deferring; delay.

Prolation: P r o l a t i o n "n. A mediaeval method of determining of the proportionate duration of semibreves and minims.

Prolatum: P r o l a t u m "n. A prolate spheroid. See Ellipsoid of revolution  under Ellipsoid.

Proleg: P r o l e g "n. One of the fleshy legs found on the abdominal segments of the larvae of Lepidoptera  sawflies and some other insects. Those of Lepidoptera have a circle of hooks. Called also proped propleg and falseleg.

Prolegate: P r o l e g a t e "n. The deputy or substitute for a legate.

Prolegomena: P r o l e g o m e n a "pl. "of Prolegomenon

Prolegomenary: P r o l e g o m e n a r y "a. Of the nature of a prolegomenon; preliminary; introductory; prefatory.

Prolegomenon: P r o l e g o m e n o n "n. A preliminary remark or observation; an introductory discourse prefixed to a book or treatise.

Prolepsis: P r o l e p s i s "n. A figure by which objections are anticipated or prevented.

Prolepsis: P r o l e p s i s "n. A necessary truth or assumption; a first or assumed principle.

Prolepsis: P r o l e p s i s "n. An error in chronology  consisting in an event being dated before the actual time.

Prolepsis: P r o l e p s i s "n. The application of an adjective to a noun in anticipation  or to denote the result of the action of the verb; as to strike one dumb.

Proleptic: P r o l e p t i c "a. Alt. of Proleptical

Proleptical: P r o l e p t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to prolepsis; anticipative.

Proleptical: P r o l e p t i c a l "a. Previous; antecedent.

Proleptical: P r o l e p t i c a l "a. Anticipating the usual time; -- applied to a periodical disease whose paroxysms return at an earlier hour at every repetition.

Proleptically: P r o l e p t i c a l l y "adv. In a proleptical manner.

Proleptics: P r o l e p t i c s "n. The art and science of predicting in medicine.

Proletaire: P r o l e t a i r e "n. One of the common people; a low person; also  the common people as a class or estate in a country.

Proletaneous: P r o l e t a n e o u s "a. Having a numerous offspring.

Proletarian: P r o l e t a r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the proletaries; belonging to the commonalty; hence  mean; vile; vulgar.

Proletarian: P r o l e t a r i a n "n. A proletary.

Proletariat: P r o l e t a r i a t "n. The indigent class in the State; the body of proletarians.

Proletariate: P r o l e t a r i a t e "n. The lower classes; beggars.

Proletaries: P r o l e t a r i e s "pl. "of Proletary

Proletary: P r o l e t a r y "n. A citizen of the lowest class  who served the state not with property but only by having children; hence a common person.

Prolicide: P r o l i c i d e "n. The crime of destroying one's offspring  either in the womb or after birth.

Proliferate: P r o l i f e r a t e "v. t. To produce or form cells; especially  to produce cells rapidly.

Proliferate: P r o l i f e r a t e "v. t. To produce zooids by budding.

Proliferation: P r o l i f e r a t i o n "n. The continuous development of cells in tissue formation; cell formation.

Proliferation: P r o l i f e r a t i o n "n. The production of numerous zooids by budding  especially when buds arise from other buds in succession.

Proliferous: P r o l i f e r o u s "a. Bearing offspring; -- applied to a flower from within which another is produced  or to a branch or frond from which another rises or to a plant which is reproduced by buds or gemmae.

Proliferous: P r o l i f e r o u s "a. Producing young by budding.

Proliferous: P r o l i f e r o u s "a. Producing sexual zooids by budding; -- said of the blastostyle of a hydroid.

Proliferous: P r o l i f e r o u s "a. Producing a cluster of branchlets from a larger branch; -- said of corals.

Prolific: P r o l i f i c "a. Having the quality of generating; producing young or fruit; generative; fruitful; productive; -- applied to plants producing fruit  animals producing young etc.; -- usually with the implied idea of frequent or numerous production; as a prolific tree female and the like.

Prolific: P r o l i f i c "a. Serving to produce; fruitful of results; active; as  a prolific brain; a controversy prolific of evil.

Prolific: P r o l i f i c "a. Proliferous.

Prolificacy: P r o l i f i c a c y "n. Prolificness.

Prolifical: P r o l i f i c a l "a. Producing young or fruit abundantly; fruitful; prolific.

Prolificate: P r o l i f i c a t e "v. t. To make prolific; to fertilize; to impregnate.

Prolification: P r o l i f i c a t i o n "n. The generation of young.

Prolification: P r o l i f i c a t i o n "n. Reproduction by the growth of a plant  or part of a plant directly from an older one or by gemmae.

Prolificness: P r o l i f i c n e s s "n. The quality or state of being prolific; fruitfulness; prolificacy.

Prolix: P r o l i x "a. Extending to a great length; unnecessarily long; minute in narration or argument; excessively particular in detail; -- rarely used except with reference to discourse written or spoken; as  a prolix oration; a prolix poem; a prolix sermon.

Prolix: P r o l i x "a. Indulging in protracted discourse; tedious; wearisome; -- applied to a speaker or writer.

Prolixious: P r o l i x i o u s "a. Dilatory; tedious; superfluous.

Prolixity: P r o l i x i t y "n. The quality or state of being prolix; great length; minute detail; as  prolixity in discourses and writings.

Prolixly: P r o l i x l y "adv. In a prolix manner.

Prolixness: P r o l i x n e s s "n. Prolixity.

Proll: P r o l l "v. t. To search or prowl after; to rob; to plunder.

Proll: P r o l l "v. i. To prowl about; to rob.

Prolled: P r o l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Proll

Proller: P r o l l e r "n. Prowler; thief.

Prolocutor: P r o l o c u t o r "n. One who speaks for another.

Prolocutor: P r o l o c u t o r "n. The presiding officer of a convocation.

Prolog: P r o l o g "n. & v. Prologue.

Prologize: P r o l o g i z e "v. i. To deliver a Prologue.

Prologizer: P r o l o g i z e r "n. One who prologizes.

Prologue: P r o l o g u e "n. The preface or introduction to a discourse  poem or performance; as the prologue of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales; esp. a discourse or poem spoken before a dramatic performance

Prologue: P r o l o g u e "n. One who delivers a prologue.

Prologued: P r o l o g u e d "imp. & p. p. of Prologue

Prolong: P r o l o n g "a. To extend in space or length; as  to prolong a line.

Prolong: P r o l o n g "a. To lengthen in time; to extend the duration of; to draw out; to continue; as  to prolong one's days.

Prolong: P r o l o n g "a. To put off to a distant time; to postpone.

Prolongable: P r o l o n g a b l e "a. Capable of being prolonged; as  life is prolongable by care.

Prolongate: P r o l o n g a t e "v. t. To prolong; to extend in space or in time.

Prolongated: P r o l o n g a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Prolongate

Prolongating: P r o l o n g a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prolongate

Prolongation: P r o l o n g a t i o n "n. The act of lengthening in space or in time; extension; protraction.

Prolongation: P r o l o n g a t i o n "n. That which forms an additional length.

Prolonge: P r o l o n g e "n. A rope with a hook and a toggle  sometimes used to drag a gun carriage or to lash it to the limber and for various other purposes.

Prolonged: P r o l o n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Prolong

Prolonger: P r o l o n g e r "n. One who  or that which causes an extension in time or space.

Prolonging: P r o l o n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prolong

Prolongment: P r o l o n g m e n t "n. Prolongation.

Prolusion: P r o l u s i o n "n. A trial before the principal performance; a prelude; hence  an introductory essay or exercise.

Promanation: P r o m a n a t i o n "n. The act of flowing forth; emanation; efflux.

Promenade: P r o m e n a d e "n. A walk for pleasure  display or exercise.

Promenade: P r o m e n a d e "n. A place for walking; a public walk.

Promenade: P r o m e n a d e "v. i. To walk for pleasure  display or exercise.

Promenaded: P r o m e n a d e d "imp. & p. p. of Promenade

Promenader: P r o m e n a d e r "n. One who promenades.

Promenading: P r o m e n a d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Promenade

Promerit: P r o m e r i t "v. t. To oblige; to confer a favor on.

Promerit: P r o m e r i t "v. t. To deserve; to procure by merit.

Promerops: P r o m e r o p s "n. Any one of several species of very brilliant birds belonging to Promerops  Epimarchus and allied genera closely related to the paradise birds and mostly native of New Guinea. They have a long curved beak and a long graduated tail.

Promerphological: P r o m e r p h o l o g i c a l "a. Relating to promorphology; as  a promorphological conception.

Promethea: P r o m e t h e a "n. A large American bombycid moth (Callosamia promethea). Its larva feeds on the sassafras  wild cherry and other trees and suspends its cocoon from a branch by a silken band.

Promethean: P r o m e t h e a n "a. Of or pertaining to Prometheus. See Prometheus.

Promethean: P r o m e t h e a n "a. Having a life-giving quality; inspiring.

Promethean: P r o m e t h e a n "n. An apparatus for automatic ignition.

Promethean: P r o m e t h e a n "n. A kind of lucifer match.

Prometheus: P r o m e t h e u s "n. The son of Iapetus (one of the Titans) and Clymene  fabled by the poets to have surpassed all mankind in knowledge and to have formed men of clay to whom he gave life by means of fire stolen from heaven. Jupiter being angry at this sent Mercury to bind Prometheus to Mount Caucasus where a vulture preyed upon his liver.

Prominence: P r o m i n e n c e "n. Alt. of Prominency

Prominency: P r o m i n e n c y "n. The quality or state of being prominent; a standing out from something; conspicuousness.

Prominency: P r o m i n e n c y "n. That which is prominent; a protuberance.

Prominent: P r o m i n e n t "a. Standing out  or projecting beyond the line surface of something; jutting; protuberant; in high relief; as a prominent figure on a vase.

Prominent: P r o m i n e n t "a. Hence; Distinctly manifest; likely to attract attention from its size or position; conspicuous; as  a prominent feature of the face; a prominent building.

Prominent: P r o m i n e n t "a. Eminent; distinguished above others; as  a prominent character.

Prominently: P r o m i n e n t l y "adv. In a prominent manner.

Promiscuity: P r o m i s c u i t y "n. Promiscuousness; confusion.

Promiscuous: P r o m i s c u o u s "a. Consisting of individuals united in a body or mass without order; mingled; confused; undistinguished; as  a promiscuous crowd or mass.

Promiscuous: P r o m i s c u o u s "a. Distributed or applied without order or discrimination; not restricted to an individual; common; indiscriminate; as  promiscuous love or intercourse.

Promiscuously: P r o m i s c u o u s l y "adv. In a promiscuous manner.

Promiscuousness: P r o m i s c u o u s n e s s "n. The quality or state of being promiscuous.

Promise: P r o m i s e "a. In general  a declaration written or verbal made by one person to another which binds the person who makes it to do or to forbear to do a specified act; a declaration which gives to the person to whom it is made a right to expect or to claim the performance or forbearance of a specified act.

Promise: P r o m i s e "a. An engagement by one person to another  either in words or in writing but properly not under seal for the performance or nonperformance of some particular thing. The word promise is used to denote the mere engagement of a person without regard to the consideration for it or the corresponding duty of the party to whom it is made.

Promise: P r o m i s e "a. That which causes hope  expectation or assurance; especially that which affords expectation of future distinction; as a youth of great promise.

Promise: P r o m i s e "a. Bestowal  fulfillment or grant of what is promised.

Promise: P r o m i s e "v. t. To engage to do  give make or to refrain from doing giving or making or the like; to covenant; to engage; as to promise a visit; to promise a cessation of hostilities; to promise the payment of money.

Promise: P r o m i s e "v. t. To afford reason to expect; to cause hope or assurance of; as  the clouds promise rain.

Promise: P r o m i s e "v. t. To make declaration of or give assurance of  as some benefit to be conferred; to pledge or engage to bestow; as the proprietors promised large tracts of land; the city promised a reward.

Promise: P r o m i s e "v. i. To give assurance by a promise  or binding declaration.

Promise: P r o m i s e "v. i. To afford hopes or expectation; to give ground to expect good; rarely  to give reason to expect evil.

Promised: P r o m i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Promise

Promisee: P r o m i s e e "n. The person to whom a promise is made.

Promiser: P r o m i s e r "n. One who promises.

Promising: P r o m i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Promise

Promising: P r o m i s i n g "a. Making a promise or promises; affording hope or assurance; as  promising person; a promising day.

Promisor: P r o m i s o r "n. One who engages or undertakes; a promiser.

Promissive: P r o m i s s i v e "a. Making a promise; implying a promise; promising.

Promissorily: P r o m i s s o r i l y "adv. In a promissory manner.

Promissory: P r o m i s s o r y "a. Containing a promise or binding declaration of something to be done or forborne.

Promont: P r o m o n t "n. Promontory.

Promontories: P r o m o n t o r i e s "pl. "of Promontory

Promontory: P r o m o n t o r y "n. A high point of land or rock projecting into the sea beyond the line of coast; a headland; a high cape.

Promontory: P r o m o n t o r y "n. A projecting part. Especially: (a) The projecting angle of the ventral side of the sacrum where it joins the last lumbar vertebra. (b) A prominence on the inner wall of the tympanum of the ear.

Promorphologist: P r o m o r p h o l o g i s t "n. One versed in the science of promorphology.

Promorphology: P r o m o r p h o l o g y "n. Crystallography of organic forms; -- a division of morphology created by Haeckel. It is essentially stereometric  and relates to a mathematical conception of organic forms. See Tectology.

Promote: P r o m o t e "v. t. To contribute to the growth  enlargement or prosperity of (any process or thing that is in course); to forward; to further; to encourage; to advance; to excite; as to promote learning; to promote disorder; to promote a business venture.

Promote: P r o m o t e "v. t. To exalt in station  rank or honor; to elevate; to raise; to prefer; to advance; as to promote an officer.

Promote: P r o m o t e "v. i. To urge on or incite another  as to strife; also to inform against a person.

Promoted: P r o m o t e d "imp. & p. p. of Promote

Promoter: P r o m o t e r "n. One who  or that which forwards advances or promotes; an encourager; as a promoter of charity or philosophy.

Promoter: P r o m o t e r "n. Specifically  one who sets on foot and takes the preliminary steps in a scheme for the organization of a corporation a joint-stock company or the like.

Promoter: P r o m o t e r "n. One who excites; as  a promoter of sedition.

Promoter: P r o m o t e r "n. An informer; a makebate.

Promoting: P r o m o t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Promote

Promotive: P r o m o t i v e "a. Tending to advance  promote or encourage.

Promottion: P r o m o t t i o n "n. The act of promoting  advancing or encouraging; the act of exalting in rank or honor; also the condition of being advanced encouraged or exalted in honor; preferment.

Promove: P r o m o v e "v. t. To move forward; to advance; to promote.

Promover: P r o m o v e r "n. A promoter.

Prompt: P r o m p t "n. A limit of time given for payment of an account for produce purchased  this limit varying with different goods. See Prompt-note.

Prompt: P r o m p t "v. t. To assist or induce the action of; to move to action; to instigate; to incite.

Prompt: P r o m p t "v. t. To suggest; to dictate.

Prompt: P r o m p t "v. t. To remind  as an actor or an orator of words or topics forgotten.

Prompt-book: P r o m p t - b o o k "n. The book used by a prompter of a theater.

Prompt-note: P r o m p t - n o t e "n. A memorandum of a sale  and time when payment is due given to the purchaser at a sale of goods.

Prompted: P r o m p t e d "imp. & p. p. of Prompt

Prompter: P r o m p t e r "n. One who  or that which prompts; one who admonishes or incites to action.

Prompter: P r o m p t e r "n. One who reminds another  as an actor or an orator of the words to be spoken next; specifically one employed for this purpose in a theater.

Prompting: P r o m p t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Prompt

Promptitude: P r o m p t i t u d e "a. The quality of being prompt; quickness of decision and action when occasion demands; alacrity; as  promptitude in obedience.

Promptly: P r o m p t l y "adv. In a prompt manner.

Promptness: P r o m p t n e s s "n. Promptitude; readiness; quickness of decision or action.

Promptness: P r o m p t n e s s "n. Cheerful willingness; alacrity.

Promptuary: P r o m p t u a r y "a. Of or pertaining to preparation.

Promptuary: P r o m p t u a r y "a. That from which supplies are drawn; a storehouse; a magazine; a repository.

Prompture: P r o m p t u r e "a. Suggestion; incitement; prompting.

Promt: P r o m t "superl. Ready and quick to act as occasion demands; meeting requirements readily; not slow  dilatory or hesitating in decision or action; responding on the instant; immediate; as prompt in obedience or compliance; -- said of persons.

Promt: P r o m t "superl. Done or rendered quickly  readily or immediately; given without delay or hesitation; -- said of conduct; as prompt assistance.

Promt: P r o m t "superl. Easy; unobstructed.

Promulgate: P r o m u l g a t e "v. t. To make known by open declaration  as laws decrees or tidings; to publish; as to promulgate the secrets of a council.

Promulgated: P r o m u l g a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Promulgate

Promulgating: P r o m u l g a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Promulgate

Promulgation: P r o m u l g a t i o n "n. The act of promulgating; publication; open declaration; as  the promulgation of the gospel.

Promulgator: P r o m u l g a t o r "n. One who promulgates or publishes.

Promulge: P r o m u l g e "v. t. To promulgate; to publish or teach.

Promulged: P r o m u l g e d "imp. & p. p. of Promulge

Promulger: P r o m u l g e r "n. One who promulges or publishes what was before unknown.

Promuscis: P r o m u s c i s "n. The proboscis of hemipterous insects. See Illust. under Hemiptera.

Pronaos: P r o n a o s "n. The porch or vestibule of a temple.

Pronate: P r o n a t e "a. Somewhat prone; inclined; as  pronate trees.

Pronation: P r o n a t i o n "n. The act of turning the palm or palmar surface of the forefoot downward.

Pronation: P r o n a t i o n "n. That motion of the forearm whereby the palm or palmar  surface is turned downward.

Pronation: P r o n a t i o n "n. The position of the limb resulting from the act of pronation. Opposed to supination.

Pronator: P r o n a t o r "n. A muscle which produces pronation.

Prone: P r o n e "a. Bending forward; inclined; not erect.

Prone: P r o n e "a. Prostrate; flat; esp.  lying with the face down; -- opposed to supine.

Prone: P r o n e "a. Headlong; running downward or headlong.

Prone: P r o n e "a. Sloping  with reference to a line or surface; declivous; inclined; not level.

Prone: P r o n e "a. Inclined; propense; disposed; -- applied to the mind or affections  usually in an ill sense. Followed by to.

Pronely: P r o n e l y "adv. In a prone manner or position.

Proneness: P r o n e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being prone  or of bending downward; as the proneness of beasts is opposed to the erectness of man.

Proneness: P r o n e n e s s "n. The state of lying with the face down; -- opposed to supineness.

Proneness: P r o n e n e s s "n. Descent; declivity; as  the proneness of a hill.

Proneness: P r o n e n e s s "n. Inclination of mind  heart or temper; propension; disposition; as proneness to self-gratification.

Pronephric: P r o n e p h r i c "a. Of or pertaining to the pronephros.

Pronephron: P r o n e p h r o n "n. The head kidney. See under Head.

Pronephros: P r o n e p h r o s "n. Alt. of Pronephron

Prong: P r o n g "n. A sharp-pointed instrument.

Prong: P r o n g "n. The tine of a fork  or of a similar instrument; as a fork of two or three prongs.

Prong: P r o n g "n. A sharp projection  as of an antler.

Prong: P r o n g "n. The fang of a tooth.

Prong-hoe: P r o n g - h o e "n. A hoe with prongs to break the earth.

Prongbuck: P r o n g b u c k "n. The springbuck.

Prongbuck: P r o n g b u c k "n. The pronghorn.

Pronged: P r o n g e d "a. Having prongs or projections like the tines of a fork; as  a three-pronged fork.

Pronghorn: P r o n g h o r n "n. An American antelope (Antilocapra Americana)  native of the plain near the Rocky Mountains. The upper parts are mostly yellowish brown; the under parts the sides of the head and throat and the buttocks are white. The horny sheath of the horns is shed annually. Called also cabree cabut prongbuck and pronghorned antelope.

Pronity: P r o n i t y "n. Proneness; propensity.

Pronominal: P r o n o m i n a l "a. Belonging to  or partaking of the nature of a pronoun.

Pronominalize: P r o n o m i n a l i z e "v. t. To give the effect of a pronoun to; as  to pronominalize the substantives person people etc.

Pronominally: P r o n o m i n a l l y "adv. In a pronominal manner/ with the nature or office of a pronoun; as a pronoun.

Prononce: P r o n o n c e "a. Strongly marked; decided  as in manners etc.

Pronota: P r o n o t a "pl. "of Pronotum

Pronotary: P r o n o t a r y "n. See Prothonotary.

Pronotum: P r o n o t u m "n. The dorsal plate of the prothorax in insects. See Illust. of Coleoptera.

Pronoun: P r o n o u n "n. A word used instead of a noun or name  to avoid the repetition of it. The personal pronouns in English are I thou or you he she it we ye and they.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. t. To utter articulately; to speak out or distinctly; to utter  as words or syllables; to speak with the proper sound and accent as adults rarely learn to pronounce a foreign language correctly.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. t. To utter officially or solemnly; to deliver  as a decree or sentence; as to pronounce sentence of death.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. t. To speak or utter rhetorically; to deliver; to recite; as  to pronounce an oration.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. t. To declare or affirm; as  he pronounced the book to be a libel; he pronounced the act to be a fraud.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. i. To give a pronunciation; to articulate; as  to pronounce faultlessly.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "v. i. To make declaration; to utter on opinion; to speak with confidence.

Pronounce: P r o n o u n c e "n. Pronouncement; declaration; pronunciation.

Pronounceable: P r o n o u n c e a b l e "a. Capable of being pronounced.

Pronounced: P r o n o u n c e d "imp. & p. p. of Pronounce

Pronounced: P r o n o u n c e d "a. Strongly marked; unequivocal; decided. [A Gallicism]

Pronouncer: P r o n o u n c e r "n. One who pronounces  utters or declares; also a pronouncing book.

Pronouncing: P r o n o u n c i n g "a. Pertaining to  or indicating pronunciation; as a pronouncing dictionary.

Pronubial: P r o n u b i a l "a. Presiding over marriage.

Pronuclei: P r o n u c l e i "pl. "of Pronucleus

Pronucleus: P r o n u c l e u s "n. One of the two bodies or nuclei (called male and female pronuclei) which unite to form the first segmentation nucleus of an impregnated ovum.

Pronuncial: P r o n u n c i a l "a. Of or pertaining to pronunciation; pronunciative.

Pronunciamento: P r o n u n c i a m e n t o "n. A proclamation or manifesto; a formal announcement or declaration.

Pronunciamiento: P r o n u n c i a m i e n t o "n. See Pronunciamento.

Pronunciation: P r o n u n c i a t i o n "n. The act of uttering with articulation; the act of giving the proper sound and accent; utterance; as  the pronunciation of syllables of words; distinct or indistinct pronunciation.

Pronunciation: P r o n u n c i a t i o n "n. The mode of uttering words or sentences.

Pronunciation: P r o n u n c i a t i o n "n. The art of manner of uttering a discourse publicly with propriety and gracefulness; -- now called delivery.

Pronunciative: P r o n u n c i a t i v e "a. Of or pertaining to pronunciation.

Pronunciative: P r o n u n c i a t i v e "a. Uttering confidently; dogmatical.

Pronunciator: P r o n u n c i a t o r "n. One who pronounces; a pronouncer.

Pronunciatory: P r o n u n c i a t o r y "a. Of or pertaining to pronunciation; that pronounces.

Proocutorship: P r o o c u t o r s h i p "n. The office of a prolocutor.

Proof: P r o o f "n. Any effort  process or operation designed to establish or discover a fact or truth; an act of testing; a test; a trial.

Proof: P r o o f "n. That degree of evidence which convinces the mind of any truth or fact  and produces belief; a test by facts or arguments that induce or tend to induce certainty of the judgment; conclusive evidence; demonstration.

Proof: P r o o f "n. The quality or state of having been proved or tried; firmness or hardness that resists impression  or does not yield to force; impenetrability of physical bodies.

Proof: P r o o f "n. Firmness of mind; stability not to be shaken.

Proof: P r o o f "n. A trial impression  as from type taken for correction or examination; -- called also proof sheet.

Proof: P r o o f "n. A process for testing the accuracy of an operation performed. Cf. Prove  v. t. 5.

Proof: P r o o f "v. t. Armor of excellent or tried quality  and deemed impenetrable; properly armor of proof.

Proof: P r o o f "a. Used in proving or testing; as  a proof load or proof charge.

Proof: P r o o f "a. Firm or successful in resisting; as  proof against harm; waterproof; bombproof.

Proof: P r o o f "a. Being of a certain standard as to strength; -- said of alcoholic liquors.

Proof-arm: P r o o f - a r m "v. t. To arm with proof armor; to arm securely; as  to proof-arm herself.

Proof-proof: P r o o f - p r o o f "a. Proof against proofs; obstinate in the wrong.

Proofless: P r o o f l e s s "a. Wanting sufficient evidence to induce belief; not proved.

Proostraca: P r o o s t r a c a "pl. "of Proostracum

Proostracum: P r o o s t r a c u m "n. The anterior prolongation of the guard of the phragmocone of belemnites and allied fossil cephalopods  whether horny or calcareous. See Illust. of Phragmocone.

Prootic: P r o o t i c "a. In front of the auditory capsule; -- applied especially to a bone  or center of ossification in the periotic capsule.

Prootic: P r o o t i c "n. A prootic bone.

Prop: P r o p "n. A shell  used as a die. See Props.

Prop: P r o p "v. t. To support  or prevent from falling by placing something under or against; as to prop up a fence or an old building; (Fig.) to sustain; to maintain; as to prop a declining state.

Prop: P r o p "v. That which sustains an incumbent weight; that on which anything rests or leans for support; a support; a stay; as  a prop for a building.

Propaedeutic: P r o p a e d e u t i c "a. Alt. of Propaedeutical

Propaedeutics: P r o p a e d e u t i c s "n. The preliminary learning connected with any art or science; preparatory instruction.

Propagable: P r o p a g a b l e "a. Capable of being propagated  or of being continued or multiplied by natural generation or production.

Propagable: P r o p a g a b l e "a. Capable of being spread or extended by any means; -- said of tenets  doctrines or principles.

Propaganda: P r o p a g a n d a "n. A congregation of cardinals  established in 1622 charged with the management of missions.

Propaganda: P r o p a g a n d a "n. The college of the Propaganda  instituted by Urban VIII. (1623-1644) to educate priests for missions in all parts of the world.

Propaganda: P r o p a g a n d a "n. Hence  any organization or plan for spreading a particular doctrine or a system of principles.

Propagandism: P r o p a g a n d i s m "n. The art or practice of propagating tenets or principles; zeal in propagating one's opinions.

Propagandist: P r o p a g a n d i s t "n. A person who devotes himself to the spread of any system of principles.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. t. To cause to continue or multiply by generation  or successive production; -- applied to animals and plants; as to propagate a breed of horses or sheep; to propagate a species of fruit tree.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. t. To cause to spread to extend; to impel or continue forward in space; as  to propagate sound or light.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. t. To spread from person to person; to extend the knowledge of; to originate and spread; to carry from place to place; to disseminate; as  to propagate a story or report; to propagate the Christian religion.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. t. To multiply; to increase.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. t. To generate; to produce.

Propagate: P r o p a g a t e "v. i. To have young or issue; to be produced or multiplied by generation  or by new shoots or plants; as rabbits propagate rapidly.

Propagated: P r o p a g a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Propagate

Propagation: P r o p a g a t i o n "n. The spreading abroad  or extension of anything; diffusion; dissemination; as the propagation of sound; the propagation of the gospel.

Propagative: P r o p a g a t i v e "a. Producing by propagation  or by a process of growth.

Propagator: P r o p a g a t o r "n. One who propagates; one who continues or multiplies.

Propagulum: P r o p a g u l u m "n. A runner terminated by a germinating bud.

Propane: P r o p a n e "n. A heavy gaseous hydrocarbon  C3H8 of the paraffin series occurring naturally dissolved in crude petroleum and also made artificially; -- called also propyl hydride.

Propargyl: P r o p a r g y l "n. Same as Propinyl.

Proped: P r o p e d "n. Same as Proleg.

Propeller: P r o p e l l e r "n. One who  or that which propels.

Propeller: P r o p e l l e r "n. A contrivance for propelling a steam vessel  usually consisting of a screw placed in the stern under water and made to revolve by an engine; a propeller wheel.

Propeller: P r o p e l l e r "n. A steamboat thus propelled; a screw steamer.

Propensities: P r o p e n s i t i e s "pl. "of Propensity

Propensity: P r o p e n s i t y "n. The quality or state of being propense; natural inclination; disposition to do good or evil; bias; bent; tendency.

Propenyl: P r o p e n y l "n. A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical  C3H5 isomeric with allyl and glyceryl and regarded as the essential residue of glycerin. Cf. Allyl and Glyceryl.

Propepsin: P r o p e p s i n "n. See Persinogen.

Propeptone: P r o p e p t o n e "n. A product of gastric digestion intermediate between albumin and peptone  identical with hemialbumose.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Belonging to one; one's own; individual.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Belonging to the natural or essential constitution; peculiar; not common; particular; as  every animal has his proper instincts and appetites.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Befitting one's nature  qualities etc.; suitable in all respect; appropriate; right; fit; decent; as water is the proper element for fish; a proper dress.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Becoming in appearance; well formed; handsome.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Pertaining to one of a species  but not common to the whole; not appellative; -- opposed to common; as a proper name; Dublin is the proper name of a city.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Rightly so called; strictly considered; as  Greece proper; the garden proper.

Proper: P r o p e r "a. Represented in its natural color; -- said of any object used as a charge.

Proper: P r o p e r "adv. Properly; hence  to a great degree; very; as proper good.

Properly: P r o p e r l y "adv. Individually; after one's own manner.

Properness: P r o p e r n e s s "n. The quality of being proper.

Properness: P r o p e r n e s s "n. Tallness; comeliness.

Propertied: P r o p e r t i e d "a. Possessing property; holding real estate  or other investments of money.

Properties: P r o p e r t i e s "pl. "of Property

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. That which is proper to anything; a peculiar quality of a thing; that which is inherent in a subject  or naturally essential to it; an attribute; as sweetness is a property of sugar.

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. An acquired or artificial quality; that which is given by art  or bestowed by man; as the poem has the properties which constitute excellence.

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. The exclusive right of possessing  enjoying and disposing of a thing; ownership; title.

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. That to which a person has a legal title  whether in his possession or not; thing owned; an estate whether in lands goods or money; as a man of large property or small property.

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. All the adjuncts of a play except the scenery and the dresses of the actors; stage requisites.

Property: P r o p e r t y "a. Propriety; correctness.

Property: P r o p e r t y "v. t. To invest which properties  or qualities.

Property: P r o p e r t y "v. t. To make a property of; to appropriate.

Prophetic: P r o p h e t i c "a. Alt. of Prophetical

Prophetical: P r o p h e t i c a l "a. Containing  or pertaining to prophecy; foretelling events; as prophetic writings; prophetic dreams; -- used with of before the thing foretold.

Propheticality: P r o p h e t i c a l i t y "n. Propheticalness.

Propice: P r o p i c e "a. Fit; propitious.

Propidene: P r o p i d e n e "n. The unsymmetrical hypothetical hydrocarbon radical  CH3.CH2.CH analogous to ethylidene and regarded as the type of certain derivatives of propane; -- called also propylidene.

Propination: P r o p i n a t i o n "n. The act of pledging  or drinking first and then offering the cup to another.

Propine: P r o p i n e "v. t. To pledge; to offer as a toast or a health in the manner of drinking  that is by drinking first and passing the cup.

Propine: P r o p i n e "v. t. Hence  to give in token of friendship.

Propine: P r o p i n e "v. t. To give  or deliver; to subject.

Propine: P r o p i n e "n. A pledge.

Propine: P r o p i n e "n. A gift; esp.  drink money.

Propine: P r o p i n e "n. Same as Allylene.

Propinquity: P r o p i n q u i t y "n. Nearness in place; neighborhood; proximity.

Propinquity: P r o p i n q u i t y "n. Nearness in time.

Propinquity: P r o p i n q u i t y "n. Nearness of blood; kindred; affinity.

Propinyl: P r o p i n y l "n. A hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of propine and allied compounds.

Propiolate: P r o p i o l a t e "n. A salt of propiolic acid.

Propiolic: P r o p i o l i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating an organic acid (called also propargylic acid) of the acetylene or tetrolic series analogous to propionic acid and obtained as a white crystalline substance.

Propionate: P r o p i o n a t e "n. A salt of propionic acid.

Propione: P r o p i o n e "n. The ketone of propionic acid  obtained as a colorless fragrant liquid.

Propionic: P r o p i o n i c "a. Pertaining to  derived from or designating an organic acid which is produced in the distillation of wood in the fermentation of various organic substances as glycerin calcium lactate etc. and is obtained as a colorless liquid having a sharp pungent odor. Propionic acid is so called because it is the first or lowest member of the fatty acid series whose salts have a fatty feel.

Propionyl: P r o p i o n y l "n. The hypothetical radical C3H5O  regarded as the essential residue of propionic acid and certain related compounds.

Propithecus: P r o p i t h e c u s "n. A genus including the long-tailed  or diadem indris. See Indris.

Propitiable: P r o p i t i a b l e "a. Capable of being propitiated.

Propitiate: P r o p i t i a t e "v. t. To appease to render favorable; to make propitious; to conciliate.

Propitiate: P r o p i t i a t e "v. i. To make propitiation; to atone.

Propitiated: P r o p i t i a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Propitiate

Propitiating: P r o p i t i a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Propitiate

Propitiation: P r o p i t i a t i o n "n. The act of appeasing the wrath and conciliating the favor of an offended person; the act of making propitious.

Propitiation: P r o p i t i a t i o n "n. That which propitiates; atonement or atoning sacrifice; specifically  the influence or effects of the death of Christ in appeasing the divine justice and conciliating the divine favor.

Propitiator: P r o p i t i a t o r "n. One who propitiates or appeases.

Propitiatorily: P r o p i t i a t o r i l y "adv. By way of propitiation.

Propitiatory: P r o p i t i a t o r y "a. Having the power to make propitious; pertaining to  or employed in propitiation; expiatory; as a propitiatory sacrifice.

Propitiatory: P r o p i t i a t o r y "n. The mercy seat; -- so called because a symbol of the propitiated Jehovah.

Propitious: P r o p i t i o u s "a. Convenient; auspicious; favorable; kind; as  a propitious season; a propitious breeze.

Propitious: P r o p i t i o u s "a. Hence  kind; gracious; merciful; helpful; -- said of a person or a divinity.

Proplasm: P r o p l a s m "n. A mold; a matrix.

Proplastic: P r o p l a s t i c "a. Forming a mold.

Proplastics: P r o p l a s t i c s "n. The art of making molds for castings.

Propleg: P r o p l e g "n. Same as Proleg.

Propodia: P r o p o d i a "pl. "of Propodium

Propodial: P r o p o d i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the propodialia  or the parts of the limbs to which they belong.

Propodiale: P r o p o d i a l e "n. The bone of either the upper arm or the thing  the propodialia being the humerus and femur.

Propodialia: P r o p o d i a l i a "pl. "of Propodiale

Propodite: P r o p o d i t e "n. The sixth joint of a typical leg of a crustacean; usually  the penultimate joint.

Propodium: P r o p o d i u m "n. The anterior portion of the foot of a mollusk.

Propodium: P r o p o d i u m "n. The segment which forms the posterior part of the thorax of a hymenopterous insect.

Propolis: P r o p o l i s "n. Same as Bee glue  under Bee.

Propone: P r o p o n e "v. t. To propose; to bring forward.

Proponent: P r o p o n e n t "a. Making proposals; proposing.

Proponent: P r o p o n e n t "n. One who makes a proposal  or lays down a proposition.

Proponent: P r o p o n e n t "n. The propounder of a thing.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. The relation or adaptation of one portion to another  or to the whole as respect magnitude quantity or degree; comparative relation; ratio; as the proportion of the parts of a building or of the body.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. Harmonic relation between parts  or between different things of the same kind; symmetrical arrangement or adjustment; symmetry; as to be out of proportion.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. The portion one receives when a whole is distributed by a rule or principle; equal or proper share; lot.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. A part considered comparatively; a share.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. The equality or similarity of ratios  especially of geometrical ratios; or a relation among quantities such that the quotient of the first divided by the second is equal to that of the third divided by the fourth; -- called also geometrical proportion in distinction from arithmetical proportion or that in which the difference of the first and second is equal to the difference of the third and fourth.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "n. The rule of three  in arithmetic in which the three given terms together with the one sought are proportional.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "v. To adjust in a suitable proportion  as one thing or one part to another; as to proportion the size of a building to its height; to proportion our expenditures to our income.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "v. To form with symmetry or suitableness  as the parts of the body.

Proportion: P r o p o r t i o n "v. To divide into equal or just shares; to apportion.

Proportionable: P r o p o r t i o n a b l e "a. Capable of being proportioned  or made proportional; also proportional; proportionate.

Proportionably: P r o p o r t i o n a b l y "adv. Proportionally.

Proportional: P r o p o r t i o n a l "a. Having a due proportion  or comparative relation; being in suitable proportion or degree; as the parts of an edifice are proportional.

Proportional: P r o p o r t i o n a l "a. Relating to  or securing proportion.

Proportional: P r o p o r t i o n a l "a. Constituting a proportion; having the same  or a constant ratio; as proportional quantities; momentum is proportional to quantity of matter.

Proportional: P r o p o r t i o n a l "n. Any number or quantity in a proportion; as  a mean proportional.

Proportional: P r o p o r t i o n a l "n. The combining weight or equivalent of an element.

Proportionality: P r o p o r t i o n a l i t y "n. The state of being in proportion.

Proportionally: P r o p o r t i o n a l l y "adv. In proportion; in due degree; adapted relatively; as  all parts of the building are proportionally large.

Proportionate: P r o p o r t i o n a t e "a. Adjusted to something else according to a proportion; proportional.

Proportionate: P r o p o r t i o n a t e "v. To make proportional; to adjust according to a settled rate  or to due comparative relation; to proportion; as to proportionate punishment to crimes.

Proportionated: P r o p o r t i o n a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Proportionate

Proportionately: P r o p o r t i o n a t e l y "adv. In a proportionate manner; with due proportion; proportionally.

Proportionateness: P r o p o r t i o n a t e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being proportionate.

Proportionating: P r o p o r t i o n a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Proportionate

Proportioned: P r o p o r t i o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Proportion

Proportioning: P r o p o r t i o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Proportion

Proportionless: P r o p o r t i o n l e s s "a. Without proportion; unsymmetrical.

Proportionment: P r o p o r t i o n m e n t "n. The act or process of dividing out proportionally.

Proposal: P r o p o s a l "n. That which is proposed  or propounded for consideration or acceptance; a scheme or design; terms or conditions proposed; offer; as to make proposals for a treaty of peace; to offer proposals for erecting a building; to make proposals of marriage.

Proposal: P r o p o s a l "n. The offer by a party of what he has in view as to an intended business transaction  which with acceptance constitutes a contract.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. To set forth.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. To offer for consideration  discussion acceptance or adoption; as to propose terms of peace; to propose a question for discussion; to propose an alliance; to propose a person for office.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. To set before one's self or others as a purpose formed; hence  to purpose; to intend.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. i. To speak; to converse.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. i. To form or declare a purpose or intention; to lay a scheme; to design; as  man proposes but God disposes.

Propose: P r o p o s e "v. i. To offer one's self in marriage.

Propose: P r o p o s e "n. Talk; discourse.

Proposed: P r o p o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Propose

Proposer: P r o p o s e r "n. One who proposes or offers anything for consideration or adoption.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. The act of setting or placing before; the act of offering.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. That which is proposed; that which is offered  as for consideration acceptance or adoption; a proposal; as the enemy made propositions of peace; his proposition was not accepted.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. A statement of religious doctrine; an article of faith; creed; as  the propositions of Wyclif and Huss.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. A complete sentence  or part of a sentence consisting of a subject and predicate united by a copula; a thought expressed or propounded in language; a from of speech in which a predicate is affirmed or denied of a subject; as snow is white.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. A statement in terms of a truth to be demonstrated  or of an operation to be performed.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. That which is offered or affirmed as the subject of the discourse; anything stated or affirmed for discussion or illustration.

Proposition: P r o p o s i t i o n "n. The part of a poem in which the author states the subject or matter of it.

Propositional: P r o p o s i t i o n a l "a. Pertaining to  or in the nature of a proposition; considered as a proposition; as a propositional sense.

Proprietaries: P r o p r i e t a r i e s "pl. "of Proprietary

Proprietary: P r o p r i e t a r y "n. A body proprietors  taken collectively.

Proprietary: P r o p r i e t a r y "n. A monk who had reserved goods and effects to himself  notwithstanding his renunciation of all at the time of profession.

Propylaeum: P r o p y l a e u m "n. Any court or vestibule before a building or leading into any inclosure.

Propylene: P r o p y l e n e "n. A colorless gaseous hydrocarbon (C3H6) of the ethylene series  having a garlic odor. It occurs in coal gas and is produced artificially in various ways. Called also propene.

Proscript: P r o s c r i p t "n. One who is proscribed.

Proscription: P r o s c r i p t i o n "n. The act of proscribing; a dooming to death or exile; outlawry; specifically  among the ancient Romans the public offer of a reward for the head of a political enemy; as under the triumvirate many of the best Roman citizens fell by proscription.

Proscription: P r o s c r i p t i o n "n. The state of being proscribed; denunciation; interdiction; prohibition.

Prosdist: P r o s d i s t "n. One skilled in prosody.

Prose: P r o s e "n. The ordinary language of men in speaking or writing; language not cast in poetical measure or rhythm; -- contradistinguished from verse  or metrical composition.

Prose: P r o s e "n. Hence  language which evinces little imagination or animation; dull and commonplace discourse.

Prose: P r o s e "n. A hymn with no regular meter  sometimes introduced into the Mass. See Sequence.

Prose: P r o s e "a. Pertaining to  or composed of prose; not in verse; as prose composition.

Prose: P r o s e "a. Possessing or exhibiting unpoetical characteristics; plain; dull; prosaic; as  the prose duties of life.

Prose: P r o s e "v. t. To write in prose.

Prose: P r o s e "v. t. To write or repeat in a dull  tedious or prosy way.

Prose: P r o s e "v. i. To write prose.

Prosector: P r o s e c t o r "n. One who makes dissections for anatomical illustration; usually  the assistant of a professional anatomist.

Prosecutable: P r o s e c u t a b l e "a. Capable of being prosecuted; liable to prosecution.

Prosecute: P r o s e c u t e "v. t. To follow or pursue with a view to reach  execute or accomplish; to endeavor to obtain or complete; to carry on; to continue; as to prosecute a scheme hope or claim.

Prosecute: P r o s e c u t e "v. t. To seek to obtain by legal process; as  to prosecute a right or a claim in a court of law.

Prosecute: P r o s e c u t e "v. t. To pursue with the intention of punishing; to accuse of some crime or breach of law  or to pursue for redress or punishment before a legal tribunal; to proceed against judicially; as to prosecute a man for trespass or for a riot.

Prosecute: P r o s e c u t e "v. i. To follow after.

Prosecute: P r o s e c u t e "v. i. To institute and carry on a legal prosecution; as  to prosecute for public offenses.

Prosecution: P r o s e c u t i o n "n. The act or process of prosecuting  or of endeavoring to gain or accomplish something; pursuit by efforts of body or mind; as the prosecution of a scheme plan design or undertaking; the prosecution of war.

Prosecution: P r o s e c u t i o n "n. The institution and carrying on of a suit in a court of law or equity  to obtain some right or to redress and punish some wrong; the carrying on of a judicial proceeding in behalf of a complaining party as distinguished from defense.

Prosecution: P r o s e c u t i o n "n. The institution  or commencement and continuance of a criminal suit; the process of exhibiting formal charges against an offender before a legal tribunal and pursuing them to final judgment on behalf of the state or government as by indictment or information.

Prosecution: P r o s e c u t i o n "n. The party by whom criminal proceedings are instituted.

Prosenchyma: P r o s e n c h y m a "n. A general term applied to the tissues formed of elongated cells  especially those with pointed or oblique extremities as the principal cells of ordinary wood.

Prosiphon: P r o s i p h o n "n. A minute tube found in the protoconch of ammonites  and not connected with the true siphon.

Proslavery: P r o s l a v e r y "a. Favoring slavery.

Proslavery: P r o s l a v e r y "n. Advocacy of slavery.

Prosobranch: P r o s o b r a n c h "n. One of the Prosobranchiata.

Prosobranchiata: P r o s o b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. The highest division  or subclass of gastropod mollusks including those that have the gills situated anteriorly or forward of the heart and the sexes separate.

Prosocoele: P r o s o c o e l e "n. The entire cavity of the prosencephalon.

Prosocoelia: P r o s o c o e l i a "n. Same as Prosocoele.
